div3.p: de\ answering to me\n in the last sentence of bk. vii. The subject of h)gge/lqh is ta\ geno/mena (ibid.) Thucydides did not divide the books. The order e)s de\ . . . e)peidh\ . . . instead of e)peidh\ de\ e)s . . . brings out the opposition between the disaster peri\ *sikeli/an and its effect on the Athenians at home.

h)pi/stoui Plut. Nic. 30 has it that a stranger landed at Peiraeus and mentioned the matter in a barber's shop as a thing which he supposed to be known. The barber ran to the Archons, but met with no credit, being regarded as a logopoio/s. According to Athenaeus (ix. 72) the Athenians were in the theatre when they received the news, but sat the performance out, concealing their grief from the foreigners present.

kai\ toi=s pa/nu . . . diapefeugo/si is usually rendered ‘even the most respectable of the soldiers . . . though they had escaped.’ With this use of pa/nu are compared Xen. Mem. iii. 5, tw=| tou= pa/nu *perikle/ous ui(w=|; Luc. Philops. 5, para\ *eu)kra/tous h(/kw soi tou= pa/nu; inf. c. 89, § 2, e)/xontes h(gemo/nas tw=n pa/nu strathgw=n tw=n e)n th=| o)ligarxi/a| (q.v.) An indefinite adjective varying with the context is to be supplied (e.g. pistoi=s here). But Jowett, with good reason, objects that the present use is not sufficiently parallel with those quoted. He joins pa/nu diapefeugo/si, ‘the very soldiers who had escaped.’ With this we may cf. iii. 44, h)\n ga\r a)pofh/nw pa/nu a)dikou=ntas au)tou/s. The sense with the participle is ‘no matter how much they had escaped.’ We require not ‘the élite,’ but those who had ‘actually’ been engaged. Had tw=n stratiwtw=n followed diapefeugo/si this rendering would have been certain. Classen, accepting the usual rendering of oi( pa/nu, prefers the
rather strained construction ‘diapefeugo/si, attributive; a)gge/llousi, predicative; and kai\ before safw=s, epitatic.’
mh\ redundant after h)pi/stoun. Cf. i. 10, a)pistoi/h a)\n mh\ gene/sqai.
ou(/tw ge a)/gan ‘so utterly.’ Cf. i. 75, mh\ ou(/tws a)/gan e)pifqo/nws.

cumproqumhqei=si, i.e. who had encouraged the zeal of the people in the same direction. For the accus. cf. inf. c. 90, § 1, th\n o(mologi/an prou)qumou=nto; v. 17, prou)qumh/qh th\n cu/mbasin. The neuter pron. accus. v. 39, proqumoume/nwn ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s, and Xen. Cyr. vi. 1, 19, tau=ta sumproqumei=sqai, is easier. The present use partakes, on the one hand, of the accus. with verbs of emotion or feeling, e.g. qarrei=n, and, on the other, of the accus. with verbs of desiring or contriving, e.g. spouda/zw.

xrhsmolo/gois te kai\ ma/ntesi The ma/nteis were the publicly recognised seers (Cl.) ‘ma/ntis is the more general term, including divination of all kinds’ (Jowett). Cf. Paus. i. 34, 3, ma/ntew/n g' ou)dei\s xrhsmolo/gos h)=n, a)gaqoi\ de\ o)nei/rata e)chgh/sasqai kai\ diagnw=nai pth/seis o)rni/qwn kai\ spla/gxna i(erei/wn, i.e. xrhsmolo/goi collect and repeat oracles, ma/nteis may include xr. but are also diviners by dreams, auspices, etc. Haruspices, augures, harioli,vates, coniectores, are all stated by Cicero (N.D. i. 20, 55) to be concerned with mantikh/. Cf. ii. 8, polla\ me\n lo/gia e)le/gonto, polla\ de\ xrhsmolo/goi h)=|don; and ii. 21, xrhsmolo/goi h)=|don xrhsmou\s pantoi/ous. See the passage Ar. Eq. 961 sqq.

au)tou\s . . . e)ph/lpisan. e)pi\- gives a causative sense to certain neuter verbs, e.g. e)palhqeu/w, ‘verify,’ inf. 52, to
 tou= *)alkibia/dou lo/gon . . . e)phlh/qeusen o( *li/xas; iv. 85, th
 ai)ti/an e)palhqeu/ousa. So e)pilh/qw=‘make to forget.’ See Rutherford, New Phryn. p. 216. Arnold cft. Appian, Mithr. 68, peri\ th=s *)asi/as au)to
 e)pelpi/zontes.

e)lu/pei te the so-called trajective te, the subject of e)lu/pei not being the same as that of perieisth/kei. ‘The writer did not wish to say pa/nta de/ te’ (P-S). The writer scarcely possessed such consciousness: rather he was thinking of ‘both grieved and alarmed them,’ but substitutes a differently turned phrase for kate/plhsse.

stepo/menoi Several MSS. have sterou/menoi, a form also given in Xen. Anab. i. 9, 13, while steroi=to appears ibid. vii. 6, 16. The rule seems to be that ste/romai, steri/skomai form the
pres. and imperf., and stere/omai the rest. Yet e)sterou/mhn, Antiph. ii. 2, 9. The signification of ste/romai is frequently that of a perfect.
i)di/a| e(/kastos tw=n oi)kei/wn is to be supplied from o(plitw=n by a zeugma.

e)n tw=| koinw=| So vi. 6. In i. 80 and 141 without the article. The cases are different. Thus i. 80, ou)/te e)n koinw=| e)/xomen (xrh/mata) ou)/te e(toi/mws e)k tw=n i)di/wn fe/romen, and 141, ou)/te i)di/a| ou)/te e)n koinw=| xrh/mata/ e)stin au)toi=s, the meaning is ‘in (any) public stock,’ not ‘in the public treasury.’ Contrast vi. 6, skeyome/nous ei) u(pa/rxei (xrh/mata) e)n tw=| koinw=| kai\ e)n toi=s i(eroi=s.

u(phresi/as Cf. the concrete use of Lat. servitium, remigium, etc. Lucian and late writers have h( oi)ketei/a = oi( oi)ke/tai. Some understand the term as = ‘crew’ (rowers and sailors) as opposed to the e)piba/tai, or ‘marines’; but Dobree, Arnold (vi. 31), and Shilleto (i. 143) are much more probably right in rendering ‘petty officers.’ In i. 143 a point is made of the possession of kubernh/tas poli/tas kai\ th\n a)/llhn u(phresi/an plei/ous kai\ a)mei/nous h)\ pa=sa h( a)/llh *(ella/s. See also Lys. 162, 10; Isoc. Paneg. § 142, and context. The skill of the officers is of special importance. In vi. 31 the u(phresi/ai are opposed to the qrani=tai. A petty officer might well be called a u(phreth/s (cf. ‘mate’) of the captain.

pleu/sesqai MSS. give pleusei=sqai. The ‘Doric’ futures pleusou=mai, pneusou=mai, klausou=mai, r(eusei=tai, etc., are scarcely to be retained in Attic writers of the best period. feucou=mai, however, is warranted by the metre in Euripides, and even in Aristophanes, along with feu/comai: v. Rutherford, N. P. Art. xxiii.; G. Meyer, Gk. Gr. p. 473 (ed. 2). It is scarcely an accident that u appears in the diphthong of the root-syllable of each of the above verbs.
kai\ diplasi/ws i.e. by the accession of the Siceliot contingents.

w(s e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn. The ‘still they determined under any circumstances’ of Jowett is wrong. Rather ‘to hold out as far as circumstances (or resources) permitted.’ mh\ e)ndido/nai=a)nte/xein. Cf. vii. 76, e)pipariw\n w(s e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn e)qa/rsune; Xen. An. vi. 4, 9, e)/qayan e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn w(s e)du/nanto ka/llista.

kai\ nautiko/n answering to kai\ ta\ tw=n c. e)s a)sf. poei=sqai. Classen thinks e.g. stratia/n te w(s plei/sthn has fallen out before these words. Rather Thucyd. began with an undeveloped thought, e.g. paraskeua/zesqai kai\ nautiko\n kai\ toiau=ta
a(\ ta\ tw=n cumma/xwn e)s a)sfa/leian katasth/sei. There is no ‘trajection’ of kai\, but Thucydides inserted the participial clause parenthetically, and this diverted the construction. Otherwise kai\ nautiko/n might mean ‘even a navy,’ i.e. not merely preparing to defend themselves against blockade, but making ready for operations of their own.

e)s a)sfa/leian poei=sqai ‘to secure.’ Cf. e)s fulakh\n poei=sqai (iii. 3), e)s to\ summaxiko\n poiei=sqai, Hdt. ix. 106. a)sfali/zesqai is not a classical word, but e)s a)sf. poei=sqai stands to that verb as e)n o)rgh=| poei=sqai to o)rgi/zesqai.
tw=n kata\ th\n po/lin in festivals, processions, etc. ti= ‘here and there,’ ‘a certain economy in.’

e)s eu)te/leian Cf. c. 4, custello/menoi e)s eu)te/leian; c. 86, § 6, ei) de e)s eu)te/leia/n ti cunte/tmhtai. swfroni/sai has something of the sense redigere (in). The present instance is different from the purely adverbial use of e)s eu)te/leian=‘cheaply’ in Ar. Av. 805, ei)s eu)te/leian xhni\ suggegramme/nw|.

probouleu/sousi i.e. draw up probouleu/mata and submit them to the assembly. Cf. Aristot. Pol. iv. 11, 9,a)pxei=on, oi(=on e)n e)ni/ais politei/ais e)sti\n, ou(\s kalou=si probou/lous . . . kai\ peri\ tou/twn xrhmati/zein, peri\ w(=n ou(=toi probouleu/swsi. See Grote, vol. vii. ch. lxi. (note), who says ‘the Board was doubtless merged in the Oligarchy of the 400, like all the other magistracies of the state, and was not reconstituted after their deposition.’ This would mean that it lasted a year and a half. A pro/boulos is a character in the Lysistrata of Aristophanes. In Arist. Rhet. iii. 18, 6, *sofoklh=s (not the poet) e)rwtw/menos u(po\ *peisa/ndrou ei) e)/docen au)tw=| w(/sper kai\ toi=s a)/llois probou/lois, katasth=sai tou\s tetrakosi/ous, e)/fh. The same action of the pro/bouloi is stated in Lys. 126, 10 (Eratosth.) Thucyd. does not say that the committee consisted of ten (as is generally assumed), and the ten cuggrafh=s of c. 67, § 1, are quite a different body.
dh=mos ‘a democracy.’

kai\ w(s e)/docen au)toi=s, kai\ e)poi/oun tau=ta lit. ‘and when they had so decided, they also (or accordingly) proceeded to carry it out.’ o(/mws de\ . . . probouleu/sousi gives the policy they thought best; but acting upon a resolve does not necessarily follow. Cf. ii. 93, w(s de\ e)/docen au)toi=s, kai\ e)xw/roun eu)qu/s. So Hdt. viii. 64, w(s de/ sfi e)/doce, kai\ e)poi/eun tau=ta.

e)phrme/noi h)=san implying not merely excitement but elation and self-assertion; cf. vi. 11, pro\s ta\s tw=n e)nanti/wn tu/xas e)pai/resqai. The allies of neither side, those of the Laced., and the subjects of Athens all have reason to pluck up activity.
mhdete/rwn the sense is hypothetical, ei)/ tines mhdet. h)=san.

w(s . . . ei)/h From the sense of e)phrme/noi is to be supplied e.g. oi)o/menoi, or e)phr. h)=san w(/ste oi)/esqai . . . h)/n tis kai\ mh\, k.t.l. The kai\ is not ‘trajective’ as P-S would have it, but belongs to mh\-parakalh=|, on which it throws emphasis, ‘if any one did not call them.’ Cf. i. 140, h)\n a)/ra ti kai\ sfallw/meqa, ‘supposing we meet with a reverse’; iii. 46, etc.

e(/kastoi ‘each people (of them)’; put in this position in order to stand closely with sfa=s (cf. ad suum quisque tabernaculum). The usual order would be nomi/santes e)/kastoi . . . Trs. ‘each thought the Athenians would have come against them.’
ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a| either adverbial with katw/rqwsan intrans., or the direct accus. with the verb in a trans. sense.
ou(= . . . ei)=nai Goodwin, M. and T. § 755.

cumproqumhqe/ntes . . . a)palla/cesqai ‘with one mind filled with eagerness to get rid, etc.’ It is almost impossible with P-S to take a)palla/cesqai as depending on nomi/santes in the sense ‘thinking that, if they assisted them with more zeal than before, they would speedily, etc.’ cumproqumhqe/ntes answers to nomi/santes and takes the future infin. by a usage familiar to Thucydides and not unknown in other authors (v. Goodwin, M. and T. § 113). Cf. i. 27, e)deh/qhsan cumprope/myein; vi. 6, e)fie/menoi a)/rcein; vi. 57, e)bou/lonto protimwrh/sesqai. The MSS. vary in some cases, and some scholars would regularly substitute the aorist; but here (as Shilleto on i. 27 points out) a)palla/casqai is inadmissible, as the 1st aor. mid. means ‘to barter.’ A verb of intending and wishing easily passes into the construction of a verb of expecting or hoping.
au)tw=n after a)fi/stasqai.

o)rgw=ntes Vat. has o)rgw=ntas, but the attracted nom. is the Greek idiom. Cf ii. 65, o)rego/menoi tou= prw=tos e)/kastos gi/gnesqai; Aes. Ag. 1588, moi=ran hu(/ret' a)sfalh= to\ mh\ qanw\n patrw=|on ai(ma/cai pe/don. o)rga=n is mostly a poetical or late word. It occurs iv. 108, and in ii. 21 w)/rghto is a variant for w)/rmhto.
The meaning is not o)rgizo/menoi, but ‘judging by their excited feelings’ (Jowett). Cf. the use of o)rgai/ inf. c. 83, § 3.

mhd' u(polei/pein lo/gon au)toi=s Cf. Antiph. Tetr. B. b'. (661), ou)dei\s h(mi=n lo/gos u(pelei/peto mh\ fone/as ei)=nai; Isoc. Pan. 146, mhde/na lo/gon u(polei/pein toi=s ei)qisme/nois th\n tw=n *persw=n a)ndri/an e)painei=n. Commentators (Arn., Cl, P-S, etc.) give to lo/gon the sense ‘calculation,’ i.e. ‘left no room in their estimate’; but the word kri/nein and the expressions u(polei/pein pro/fasin, etc., make rather for the metaphorical turn, ‘they tried them in a prejudiced court and left them not even the plea that . . .’ The plea of the Athenians would be oi(=oi/ te e)so/meqa to/ g' e)pio\n qe/ros (‘at least for the next campaign’) perigene/sqai. The ge is retained when the plea is refused.
pa=si tou/tois causal. pollh=| duna/mei circumstantial.

kat' a)na)gkhn . . . prosgegenhme/nou ‘the(ir) fleet having now been, through force of circumstances, added to their forces’; i.e. the Syracusans and other anti-Athenian Siceliots had been compelled by the Athenian invasion to construct a fleet, and were now in a position to come and actively assist.

kindu/nwn toiou/twn . . . oi(=os kai\ o( . . ., lit. ‘rid of dangers of such a sort as the danger from the Athenians, for instance, would have surrounded them.’ We should say, ‘rid of such dangers as that into which the Athenians would have brought them,’ omitting the kai\. Cf. vii. 21, pro\s a)/ndras tolmhrou\s, oi(/ous kai\ *)aqhnai/ous.

a)phlla/xqai a)
 ‘would be rid of’ once for all. A tense with a)
 in infin. in orat. obliq. represents the same tense with a)
 in or. rect. in the indic. or optat. according to the expressed or implied protasis (Goodwin, M. and T. § 206). The protasis here is kalw=s teleuth/santos au)tou==ei) kalw=s teleuth/seie. The apodosis in orat. rect. would be a)phllagme/noi a)
 ei)=men, liberi simus.
e)kei/nous au)toi\ brought together for the antithesis.
eu)qu\s not with e)n tw=| xeimw=ni tou/tw| as Jowett renders, ‘at the beginning of . . .’ This would be eu)qu\s a)rxome/nou tou= x. t.
*)=agis me\n . . . *lakedaimo/nioi de\ . . . (§ 2).

ta\ tw=n cumma/xwn h)rgurolo/ghsen The accus. with the sense e)/pracen au)tou\s a)rgu/rion. Cf. ii. 69, o(/rws tau=ta (‘these regions’) a)rgurologw=si; iii. 19; and Aeschin. Ctes. 545,
tou\s *)/ellhnas h)rgurolo/ghse. The allies in question were probably the smaller Boeotian communities and the Opuntian Locrians (Cl.)

*mhliw=s called in iii. 96 to\n *mhliako\n ko/lpon. The proper relation of *mhlieu/s to *mhliako/s is that of Gallus to Gallicus. The local and general Greek name has a_ (*ma_lieu/s), and this form was preferred in later Attic (e.g. Arist. Pol. iv. 13) and in the common dialect.
*oi)tai/wn For their previous relations with Sparta see iii. 92. These relations account for the article th\n. The genit. is possessive with lei/as, not dependent on a)polabw/n.

th=s lei/as ‘pillageable property’ (Arn.) But the sense of ‘booty’ or ‘plunder’ passes into that of ‘cattle,’ because cattle were the chief and usual booty of marauders. Cf. avertere praedam; ii. 94, a)nqrw/pous kai\ lei/an labo/ntes; Soph. Aj. 54, lei/as a)/dasta bouko/lwn frourh/mata.
xrh/mata e)pra/cato i.e. as ransom for their cattle. a)polabw\n gives the method of exaction: ‘he got money from them by cutting off their cattle.’
e)pra/cato sc. au)tou\s or a)p' (e)c or par') au)tw=n (inf. cc. 5 and 37).
tou\s *fqiw/tas to distinguish them from the Achaeans of N. W. Peloponnese.

tou\s a)/llous Poppo understands these to be the Perrhaebi and Magnesians, referring to ii. 101, oi( pro\s no/ton oi)kou=ntes *qessaloi\ kai\ *ma/gnhtes kai\ oi( a)/lloi u(ph/kooi *qessalw=n, and iv. 78, *peraiboi\ u(ph/kooi o)/ntes *qessalw=n. But neither the Magnesians nor the Perrhaebians were tau/th|, i.e. about the Malian Gulf; and there were doubtless other u(ph/kooi than the two mentioned above. Thucydides here loosely designates any more or less unorganised peoples about the Gulf. In v. 51 *ai)nia=nas kai\ *do/loras kai\ *mhlia=s kai\ *qessalw=n tinas are joined against Heraclea Trachinia. Some of these peoples may be meant here.

tinas Classen makes this appositive to o(mh/rous, ‘to give certain persons as hostages.’ kate/qeto, katati/qesqai of depositing in a safe place. Cf. iii. 72, tou\s pre/sbeis w(s newteri/zontas cullabo/ntes kate/qento ei)s *ai)/ginan.
prosa/gein sc. the various peoples from whom he had taken hostages.

e)/s te The correspondence of the particles throughout the above long sentence is as follows— ta/ te . . . h)rgurolo/ghsen . . . kai\ trapo/menos{*oi)tai/wn te . . . e)pra/cato . . . {kai\ *)axaiou\s. . . .{o(mh/rous te . . . h)na/gkase dou=nai . . . {{e)/s te . . . prosa/gein. The words kai\ xrh/mata are an addition to o(mh/rous, and kai\ kate/qeto . . . *ko/rinqon is a kind of parenthesis.

th\n pro/stacin k.t.l. The articles th\n and th=s imply that a requisition was a matter of course, and that it as a matter of course involved the building of a certain number of ships. Lit. ‘the requisition which they issued for the building of ships was one for 100 ships,’ i.e. (as Jowett) ‘the whole number of ships the allies were to build was fixed at a hundred.’ Otherwise th=s nauphgi/as is a qualifying afterthought, i.e. ‘the building of them’ (not necessarily the manning).
e)poiou=nto note the tense. They were engaged (while Agis was acting as above) in settling upon and sending round the order. The allies of Sparta are enumerated in ii. 9.
kai\ e(autoi=s me\n i.e. ‘and (of these 100) . . .’
*boiwtoi=s . . . *fwkeu=si . . . *lokroi=s In ii. 9 these supply cavalry but not ships, while the Arcadians supply infantry.

div2.p:
th/n te nauphgi/an k.t.l. P-S would join pareskeua/zonto th/n te nauphgi/an kai\ o(/rws k.t.l. More probably Thucydides had no such construction in mind, and o(/pws merely follows and gives the motive of teixi/santes, that participle with kai\ having been determined by the preceding cu/la cumporisa/menoi. When he wrote te Thucydides had not determined the form of words which was to follow. He meant, e g., th/n te nauphgi/an kai\ ta)=lla a(\ e)/dei or th/n te naup. kai\ toiau=ta a(\ tai=s s. nausi\n a)sfa/leian pare/cei. ‘They began to prepare both the shipbuilding and . . .’ Before writing ‘and,’ he inserts the participial cu/la cumporisa/menoi, and then proceeds kai\ *s. teixi/santes in the same participial way, unconscious that grammatically he is making the fortifying of Sunium as much a matter of shipbuilding as the ‘getting together of timber.’ The particles at present may be thus arranged—
pareskeua/zonto th/n te nauphgi/an (cu/la cumporisa/menoi) (kai\ ta)=lla a(\ e)/dei) irregularly replaced by{kai\ *s. teixi/santes (o(/pws . . .) {kai\{e)klipo/ntes te . . . {{kai\ ta)=lla custello/menoi . . . {ma/lista de\ . . . *sou/nion the point at which the enemy might waylay the cornships on their way from the Euxine (Xen. Hell. i. 1, 36), or from Egypt viâ the Cyclades (inf. c. 35, § 2). Cf. vii. 28, h( tw=n e)pithdei/wn parakomidh\ e)k th=s *eu)boi/as peri\ *sou/nion kata\ qa/lassan polutelh\s e)gi/gneto.
tou= peri/plou with a)sfa/leia, ‘safety in sailing round it.’

div3.p: o)/ntwn . . . e)n kataskeuh=| These words are to be joined, the rest being translated ‘just as if they were beginning.’ Cf. c. 14, § 3, e)n teixismw=| te pa/ntes h)=san kai\ paraskeuh=| pole/mou, and ii. 80, to\ nautiko\n e)n paraskeuh=| h)=n.

kataskeuh\ differs from paraskeuh\ merely as ‘laying a groundwork’ from ‘getting ready.’ Answering to the use here we have ii. 78, toiau/th me\n h( *plataiw=n poliorki/a kateskeua/sqh; ii. 85, a)/llhn naumaxi/an belti/w kataskeua/zesqai.

a)posta/sews tw=n *)aqhnai/wn Elsewhere the genitive with this noun appears to be always subjective. Here it follows the verbal construction of a)fi/stasqai/ tinos (c. 2, § 2); v. 81, meta\ th\n tw=n *)argei/wn a)po/stasin e)k th=s cummaxi/as.
*sqenela/|dou see footnote. There is an ephor named *sqenela/|das in i. 85.
w(s e)s th\n *eu)/boian. w(s gives Agis' intention as represented to the Spartans. a)/rxontas is proleptic.

tw=n neodamw/dwn ‘the newly enfranchised’ (da=mos). This was the class between Helots and Perioeci, though with certain rights not possessed even by the latter. Cf. vii. 58, neodamw/deis tou\s a)/llous kai\ *ei(/lwtas . . . du/natai de\ to\ neodamw=des e)leu/qeron h)/dh ei)=nai, and v. 34.
tw=n *boiwtw=n as Aeolian cuggenei=s (iii. 2) of the Lesbians. Inf. c. 100, § 3, *)anaca/ndrou *qhbai/ou kata\ to\ cuggene\s h(goume/nou (sc. *mhqumnai/wn).

pareskeu/aze The inf. paraskeua/zein would have been
expected. For a similar combination cf. v. 14, cune/bh w(/ste pole/mou me
 mhde
 e)/ti a(/yasqai mhdete/rous, pro\s de\ th
 ei)rh/nhn ma=llon th
 gnw/mhn ei)=xon (P-S).

*)alkame/nh te . . . The clause with kai\ would naturally be e.g kai\ de/ka nau=s u(pisxnou/menos w(/sper kai\ oi( *boiwtoi/. But the antithesis ships) (Alcamenes is otherwise expressed. 15 a(rmosth\n. Harmosts were sent by Sparta not only to subject states, but also to confederate cities. In Xen. Anab. v. 5, 19, the word is used without reference to Lacedaemon in the general sense praefectus.
po/lews i.e. without formal public sanction (po/lis =populus).
cunagei/rein sc. stratia\n ei)/ tina e)bou/leto.
au)tou= An emphatic e)kei/nou might have been looked for: ‘they obeyed him more than . . .’ From position and antithesis, however, au)tou= gets an implication of the sense au)tou= mo/nou.
*xi=oi i.e. the oligarchical party in Chios acting without the knowledge of the democratic body. Cf. c. 9, § 3.
*)eruqrai=oi who had a geographical and dialectical affinity with the Chians; Herod. i. 142, *xi=oi me/n nun kai\ *)eruqrai=oi kata\ tw)uto\ diale/gontai.
*darei/w| Darius II. (Ochus or Nothus), illegitimate son of Artaxerxes I., reigned B.C. 424-405. Tissaphernes had quelled the rebellion of Pissuthnes in B.C. 414, and succeeded him in the satrapy.

tw=n ka/tw, neuter: ‘of lower Asia,’ i.e. the coastward ‘parts.’ Cf. Herod. i. 177, ta\ me/n nun ka/tw th=s *)asi/hs *(/arpagos a)na/stata e)poi/ee, ta\ de\ a)/nw au)th=s au)to\s *ku=ros. Herodotus makes h( a)/nw *)asi/h the part E. of the Halys. ta\ ka/tw here does not mean all W. of the Halys, the parts about the Hellespont being in the hands of Pharnabazus. See Arnold's note. From c. 108 it appears that Tissaphernes' satrapy included territories as far north as Antandrus and Atramyttium. Of Cyrus, who succeeded Tissaphernes, we read (Xen. Hell. i. 4, 3), *ku=ros, a)/rcwn pa/ntwn tw=n e)pi\ qala/tth| . . . e)pistolh\n e)/fepe toi=s ka/tw pa=si . . . e)n h(=| e)nh=n kai\ ta/de: *katape/mpw *ku=ron ka/ranon tw=n ei)s *kastwlo\n a)qroizome/nwn. For this use of ka/tw in Thuc. cf. i. 7; o(/soi o)/ntes ou) qala/ssioi ka/tw w)/|koun, i. 120; and a)/nw, ii. 83.

pepragme/nos, a)ph|thme/nos. Schol. ‘The king had
quite lately been demanding of him,’ Jowett. More probably the king had actually made him pay it. There is no need to call this a passive of the middle pra/ssesqai rather than of the act. pra/ssein. The pass. also in Plat. Leg. 921 C, diplou=n pratte/sqw.
tou\s . . . fo/rous, ou(\s . . . History is obscure as to the relations of these Hellenic states with the Persians on the one hand and the Athenians on the other. It is at least clear that the Persian king had a nominal claim to tribute from certain cities in Ionia, and that he looked to his subordinates to exact it. In Herod. vi. 42, the Ionian cities which had been reduced by the Persians after the Ionic revolt are said to be paying a tribute in the time of the writer.

e)pwfei/lhsen ‘he had fallen into arrears,’ not ‘still owed’ as Jowett renders. The aorist of a single occurrence antecedent to e)tu/gxane pepragme/nos. We should use the pluperfect (Goodwin, M. and T. § 58).

*)amo/rghn For his subsequent history v. c. 28. Concerning Pissuthnes cf. i. 115, *pissou/qnh| tw=| *(usta/spou, o(\s ei)=xe *sa/rdeis to/te (B.C. 440), and iii. 31. He had surrendered under a promise and been treacherously put to death. † to
 *pissou/qnou ui(o
 no/qon. No adequate defence is offered for this position of article and epithetic adjective. There seems no ground for taking ui(o
 no/qon as a compound noun= ‘bastard.’ The usual order is no/qos ui(o/s, cf. c. 28, § 3, *pissou/qnou no/qon ui(o/n and no/qon may either be a gloss or may have been an interlinear correction which was subsequently admitted into the text at the wrong place. Thus from *p*iCC*o*u*q*n*o*u*n*o*q*<*>u*i<*> (*pissou/qnou no/qon ui(o
) *n*o*q<*> may have fallen out, have been replaced between the lines, and copied by error after instead of before ui(o
. The present position of the adjective cannot be defended by quoting similar positions of a participle, e g. vii. 23, ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai, etc. That position of participle was recognised outside Thucydides, e.g. Dem. 269 (126), ai( u(po\ tou/tou blasfhmi/ai ei)rhme/nai. In Aeschin. De Fals. Leg. § 132 (301), ta\ tw=n paro/dwn tw=n ei)s *pu/las xwri/a ku/ria, a transposition should probably be made. On to
 e(autou= strato
 pezo
 of Vat. inf. c. 23, § 5, see critical note. As Pissuthnes has been mentioned before and Amorges not, the easiest correction seems to be tou= for to
.

a)poktenei=n the future, seems a necessary correction for the a)poktei/nein or a)poktei=nai of MSS. That a)poktei=nai should follow e)no/mize in a future sense, though poh/sein has preceded,
might perhaps be allowed to Thucydides, if we supposed him to have forgotten the precise verb with which he began, and if no infinitive had come in since poh/sein. But a)/cein so immediately precedes and proves his consciousness of e)no/mize, that the combination a)/cein h)\ a)poktei=nai seems out of the question. In iv. 28 h(\ a)/cein zw=ntas h)\ au)tou= a)poktenei=n is given without variant. On the question of the aorist in such sentences see Int. § 2 (iii.), and Goodwin, M. and T § 127. Some ‘exceeding bold’ scholars would regularly substitute the future. See Shilleto's doubts on ii. 3, e)no/misan . . . krath=sai (where all MSS. agree). In v. 22, ou)k e)/fasan de/casqai, there is no variant.

*farnaba/zw| tw=| *farna/kou. Cf. i. 129 (B.C. 476), *ce/rchs a)poste/llei *)arta/bazon to
 *farna/kou e)pi\ qa/lassan kai\ keleu/ei au)to
 th/n te *daskuli=tin satrapei/an paralabei=n k.t.l.; ii. 67 (B.C. 430), poreuqh=nai pe/ran tou= *(ellhspo/ntou w(s *farna/khn to
 *farnaba/zou. So v. 1 (B.C. 422) Pharnaces is in command of Atramyttium. From these passages it appears that the names had of late alternated (as with the Athenians), Pharnabazus—Pharnaces—Pharnabazus; and also that the satrapy was hereditary.
komi/seian ‘bring’ for him, not for themselves; hence active. o(/rws of course depends upon pe/myantos.
a(/per prou)qumei=to Cf. c. 1, § 1.

e)n th=| e(autou= a)pxh=| the *daskuli=tis satrapei/a of i. 129, Dascylium being the central point of the satrapy, which embraced Hellespontine Phrygia, Bithynia, and Paphlagonia. Cf. Xen. Hell. iv. 1, 15, e)pi\ *daskulei/ou e)poreu/eto e)/nqa kai\ ta\ basi/leia h)=n *farnaba/zw|.
dia\ tou\s fo/rous i.e. so as to be enabled to get in the tributes from the Grecian states, which the king expected of him as he did of Tissaphernes.
a)f' e(autou= i.e. make it ‘originate with’ him. Cf. vi. 61, a)p' e)kei/nou e)do/kei praxqh=nai.

tw=n e)n th=| *lakedai/moni. au)tw=n of Haase, Cl., etc., is not required. The meaning is ‘of the parties present in L.,’ not the Lacedaemonians themselves, for these begin the next sentence, oi( me/ntoi *laked.. . . . The words are not superfluous, as P-S would suppose; there are other parties than the two just named, e.g. Alcibiades.

o(/pws . . . pei/sousi See crit. note. The future is
regular with expressions of ‘striving.’ The subjunctive is ‘less frequent,’ Goodwin, M. and T. § 339.

*)alkibia/dhs, now aet. 37, and an open enemy of his country. See vi. 88, vii. 18. The mission of Gylippus and the occupation of Decelea had been suggested by him, and the success of these measures no doubt gave him great influence.
*)endi/w| mentioned v. 44 as among those Laced. who were e)pith/deioi toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.
patriko\s not=patrw=|os, but ‘by ancestral tradition.’ Cf. Ar. Av. 142, patriko\s fi/los; Dem. 530, e)/xqras patrikh=s.

o(/qen kai\ tou)/noma k.t.l. lit. ‘whence also their house got its name of a Laconian character (got a Laconian name) in accordance with the existing bond of friendship,’ i.e. ‘and that is why the name which their house adopted was taken from Laconia.’ au)tw=n, not au)tou=,=Alcibiades' family, the name not being confined to this Alc. but having been frequently used by his house. His paternal grandfather was named Alcibiades (Hdt. viii. 17), and he himself had a son of the same name (Isoc. 352 [28]).
e)/sxen ‘originally adopted.’ The words kata\ th\n ceni/an (omitted by Herwerden, P-S, etc.) are really redundant after o(/qen, or else o(/qen itself is needless.

*)/endios ga\r *)alkibia/dou e)kalei=to the proof that the name was Laconian. Lit. ‘for Endius was called *)alkibia/dou,’ i.e. he was spoken of in full as *)/endios *)alkibia/dou. There might be other persons called Endins, and *)alkibia/dou is the only kind of surname which Greek admitted. Cf. Wilson, Johnson, etc. The reading *)alkibia/dhs of most MSS. is a conjectural emendation which is wrong. For the use cf. Hdt. vi. 88, *niko/dromos *knoi/qou kaleo/menos. Arnold's statement that ‘Alcibiades was the surname to every Endius and Endius to every Alcibiades’ is too decided.
kata/skopon . . . ei), as if kataskeyo/menon ei).
pe/myantes . . . e)poh/santo The intervening words are adverbial extension.

peri/oikon The perioeci, though politically inferior to the *spartia=tai, served in the army and were often appointed to important posts (cf. inf. c. 22). Their position generally is that of Saxons to Normans.

seismou= genome/nou, a sign that heaven was unpropitious to an undertaking. Cf. v. 45 (end), seismou= de\ genome/nou
pri/n ti e)pikurwqh=nai, h( e)kklhsi/a a)neblh/qh; v. 50, ou)de\n e)pra/xqh, a)lla\ seismou= genome/nou dielu/qhsan e(/kastoi e)r' oi)/kou.
e)/pempon note the tense; it appears afterwards that he did not yet start.

eu)qu\s, not with e)peigome/nwn (which would mean ‘immediately that they pressed them’), but with the sentence. e)peigome/nwn, e)peigo/ntwn Schol. The middle in the sense of ‘getting’ the matter urged on. The active does not appear to be used with the infinitive in this way. e)pei/gesqai/ ti (iii. 2, etc.) is ‘to press a thing on in one's own interest’; so e)pei/gesqai (w(/ste) a\postei=lai au)tou\s ta\s nau=s. Cf. Hom. Od. xiii. 29— polla\ pro\s h)e/lion kefalh\n tre/pe pamfano/wnta, du=nai e)peigo/menos (‘eager that it should set’).
ta\s nau=s viz. the forty of c. 6, § 4.
pa/ntes ‘all the parties,’ viz. (i.) the Chians, Erythraeans, and Tissaphernes' envoy; (ii.) Calligeitus and Timagoras, the envoys of Pharnabazus.
*spartia/tas i.e. of the best stock.
u(perenegko/ntes With the feat and the double acc. (traicere naves Isthmum) cf. iv. 8, u(perenexqei=sai to\n *keukadi/wn i)sqmo/n. Inf. c. 8, § 3, diafe/rein to\n *)i. ta\s h(misei/as.
pa/sas emphatic. Lesbos is to be passed over.

tw=n cummaxikw=n ‘the total number of ships belonging to the allied contingents.’ Kruger compares Xen. Cyr. iii. 3, 12, e)di/dasken h)=| e(/kaston i)sxuro\n h)=n tw=n summaxikw=n. ta\ cummaxika\ are the collective cummaxiko\n (cf. to\ nautiko/n, to\ pezo/n, etc.) looked at in its several components. Classen accepts the reading cummaxi/dwn, understanding po/lewn. This ellipse requires support and there is plainly none in e.g. ii. 2, § 1. Why should not Thuc. rather have written ai( cu/mpasai cummaxi/des nh=es?

u(pe tou= *farnaba/zou k.t.l.. Construe ou)k e)koinou=nto u(pe tou= *f. to
 sto/lon, i.e. they refused to let Pharn. be represented in the matter. e)s th
 *xi/on may be taken with the sense of the sentence, but it is more Thucydidean to join it with the verbal noun sto/lon (=to
 e)s th

 kata\ th

e)koinou=nto This is the less supported reading; but e)koinwnou=nto would require the genitive. koinwnei=n tini/ tinos is the regular construction, though a contained accus. is found with the active in Eur. El. 1048, fo/non e)koinw/nhse/ moi. The middle does not occui, and though the passage of Euripides may give some dubious warrant for e)koinw/noun ti, it gives none for e)koinwnou=nto/ ti. MSS. vary again in c. 48, § 3, e)koinw/nhsan and e)koi/nwsan. For koinou=sqai with accus. cf. inf. c. 75, § 3, ta\ a)pobhso/mena cunekoinw/santo, and Eur. Ion 608, koinoume)/nh ta\s sumfora/s.

e)s th\n a)postolh\n sc. tw=n new=n, to be joined with e)di/dosan. e)f' e(autw=n, kaq' e(autou/s Schol. A phrase common in Herodotus. Cf. Xen. Anab. ii. 4, 10, u(forw=ntes tou/tous au)toi\ e)f' e(autw=n e)xw/roun. Thuc. i. 17; ii. 63, e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n au)to/nomoi; vi. 40, au)th\ e)f' au(th=s skopou=sa.

w(rmhme/nous, i.e. mentally, used of intention; cf. c. 23, § 1.
kai\ *)alkame/nh a)/rxonta sc. plei=n (e)/doce); a variation from the *)alkame/nh e)/xontas a)/rxonta which might have been looked for. dienoei=to, plei=n is grammatically the simplest word to add, though the construction of dianoei=sqai leads one to feel a virtual ellipse of pe/mpein.

*kle/arxos, who afterwards figures in the Anabasis of Xenophon (i. 1, 9, etc.), e.g. ii. 6, 1, ei(=s au)tw=n (sc. tw=n ta\s kefala\s a)potmhqe/ntwn) *kle/arxos o(mologoume/nws e)k pa/ntwn tw=n e)mpei/rws au)tou= e)xo/ntwn do/cas gene/sqai a)nh\r kai\ polemiko\s kai\ filopo/lemos e)sxa/tws. In Xen. Hell. i. 1, 36 (B.C. 410-409) he is sent as a(rmosth/s to Byzantium, and in B.C. 408 (Hell. i. 3, 15 sqq.) he crosses over to Pharnabazus to collect money, etc.
ta\s h(misei/as, really 21 out of 39 (§ 4).

o(/pws mh\ . . . ma=llon . . . h)\ We should say, ‘might be led to pay as much attention to the later ones as to these,’ or ‘more attention . . . than . . .’ These words explain ta\s h(misei/as, i.e the reason of the manœuvre of transporting only half at once. The Athenians would have their attention distracted and might allow the first half to reach Chios without much delay.
e)pidiaferome/nas ‘transported in addition.’
kai\ ga\r gives the reason of the Athenians knowing that only half the ships were yet launched.

tau/th| ‘Cenchreis’ (P - S). Rather ‘in this way,’ with epexegesis e)k tou= profanou=s. katafronh/santes . . . a)dunasi/an. katafronei=n is here constructed like katagignw/skein. In vi. 34 katafronei=n tou\s e)pio/ntas is different, since katafronei=n tina (‘despise’) is used as well as k. tinos. But that meaning would necessitate th\n tw=n *)aq. a)dunasi/an. Moreover, the impotence of Athens is only an assumption. In <*>. 83 katafronou=ntes ka)\n proaisqe/sqai= ‘full of the prond notion that they would see it in time.’ The construction here follows the sense (katagno/ntes) rather than the rule of the particular word. The sense is paralleled in in. 16, ai)sqo/menoi de\ au)tou\s dia\ kata/gnwsin a)sqenei/as sfw=n paraskeuazome/nous.
polu\ predic. with e)fai/neto, ‘was as yet showing itself in any large dimensions.’
w(s de\ . . . kai\ . . . Cf. c. 1 (end).
au)tw=n, the allied states.
ou) prou)qumh/qhsan ‘desired not to <*>.’ Cf. ou)/ fhmi, ou) bou/lomai, etc.

pri
 . . . dieorta/swsin Thucydides agrees with the tragedians in the use of the subjunct. without a)
, not only after pri
, me/xri (i. 137, me/xri plou=s ge/nhtai; iv. 16, me/xri ou(= e)pane/lqwsin), but also, if MSS. can be relied on, after ei (vi. 21, a)/llws te kai\ ei) custw=sin). It is an error to call these ‘omissions’ of a)/n. For pri
 with subj. see Goodwin, M. and T. § 648.
ta\ *)/isqmia cog. ace. These games were held in Corinthian territory, and under the presideney of Corinth. They were a triethri/s, and were held in spring or early summer.
au)toi=s dat. eth. ‘They found Agis quite ready to oblige them.’

mh\ lu/ein dh\ k.t.l. Jowett's ‘Agis was prepared to respect their scruples, and to take the responsibility of the expedition on himself’ seems to miss the point. Agis is ambitious; he has been checked already in his fancy for acting alone, and he is quite ready to let the Corinthians stay at home and to take all the control upon himself. This gives
more force to au)toi=s and e(toi=mos, more point to dh\, and suits the strong e(autou= i)/dion. e(toi=mos is a strong word, ‘zealous,’ v. Dem. De F. L. § 408. dh\ is ironical, scilicet, not utique (as P-S); cf. c. 48, § 5. lu/ein (not lu=sai), ‘should not think of . . .’ e(autou= i)/dion may be joined, but it is as well to take the words as separate predicates. Cf. Soph. Antig. 546, mhd' a(\ mh\ 'qiges poiou= seauth=s. Literally ‘they found Agis quite eager that, while they should not of course think of breaking the Isthmian truce, he should make the expedition a private one of his own.’

ta\s *)i. sponda/s during which states at war with each other were allowed to send contestants and qewroi/ to the common games, such visitors having a safe pass (a)sfa/leia kai\ a)/deia) to and from the celebration.

to\ pisto\n, in apposition to nau=s sfi/si cumpe/mpein rather than nau=s alone. See Jelf, § 580, and cf. the stock instance *(ele/nhn kta/nwmen, *menele/w| lu/rhn pikra/n. The article implies that the Athenians naturally required some proof. Construe ‘and when they denied it, they bade them, as the proper guarantee, send, etc.’
oi( polloi\, whose sympathies were with democracies like Athens. Cf. the case of Corcyra, iv. 46.
oi( d' o)li/goi kai\ cuneido/tes ‘while the oligarchical party, who were in the plot, . . .’

e)phgge/lqhsan ga/r. ai( spondai\ of some books was not read by the Scholiast, who notes ai( spondai\ dhlo/noti. The subject is apparently ta\ *)/isqmia, or rather ai( *)isqmia/des spondai/ implied in it. Cf. v. 49, le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw e)s *lakedai/mona ta\s sponda/s. For the plural verb cf. v. 75, *ka/rneia e)tu/gxanon o)/nta; i. 126, e)peidh\ e)ph=lqon *)olu/mpia. Mr. J. Riddell referred the notion to the plurality of the spectacles. The announcement was made by spondofo/roi, Aesch. De F. Leg. § 302, oi( spondofo/roi oi( ta\s musthriwti/das sponda\s e)pagge/llontes. Grote (c. lxi. note) supposes the parenthesis to imply that the invitation was in the circumstances unusual and noticeable. This does not sufficiently appear from the passage. An alternative construction is to understand oi( *)aqhnai=oi as the subject of e)phgge/lqhsan by an extension of the passive use, which use is certainly not very strict in Greek. Thus the notion e)pagge/llousin au)tou\s parei=nai may result in a passive e)pagge/llontai, ‘they have the summons conveyed to them.’ The position of the words makes rather for this rendering.
e)qew/roun i.e. sent qewroi/. Athens had proedri/a at these games (Plut. Thes. c. 25).

u(ph=gon, ‘began to draw off.’ The verb is either trans. or intrans (as here). Cf. (i.) ei)s dusxwri/an u(pa/gein tou\s polemi/ous (Xen. Cyr. i. 6, 37); (ii.) u(pomei/nantes e)pifero/menon kai\, o(/tan kairo\s h)=|, ko/smw| kai\ ta(cei u(pagago/ntes (Thuc. iv. 126; cf. v. 10).
pe/lagos ‘the open sea,’ so plei=n pela/gios frequently.
e)panexw/rhsan ‘withdrew to their station’ (e)pi. ‘home’). Not as P-S, ‘retired after they had done so.’ The addition of other ships proves that they returned to port.
sfw=n not au)tw=n, as if reflexive with e)no/mizon.

a)/llas prosplhrw/santes e(pta\ kai\ tria/konta is the MS. reading. Jowett's note is clearly put: ‘Not “having manned in addition to the twenty-one ships, thirty-seven others,” but the Athenians, after they had returned home, manned an increased fleet (pros-) making in all thirty-seven ships.’ He admits, however, that the expression is curious, and the sense seems too much to get out of the words. prosrlhrou=n is used quite naturally in vi. 104, pro\s tai=s sfete/rais de/ka *leukadi/as du/o prosplhrw/santes, and vii. 34, prosplhrw/santes e)/ti nau=s. The insertion of e)s is much more reasonable than the omission of kai\ tria/konta. The addition of thirty-seven ships is out of the question. Comparing c. 15 and c. 20, we find that after twenty-seven ships have been withdrawn and a certain unspecified number sent in their place, there remain twenty vessels.

*peiraio\n ‘Peiraeum’ (sc. a)/kron). On the maps the promontory is marked as *spei/raion from Ptolemy and Pliny, H. N. iv. 9, 2. Ptolemy's enumeration of places on the coast of the gulf (iii. 16, § 12) is *)epi/dauros, *spei/raion a)/kron, *)aqhnai/wn limh/n, *bouke/falos limh/n, *kegxreai/. Pliny, H. N. (loc. cit.), Spiraeum promonturium, portus Anthedon et Bucephalus et Cenchreae. Steph. Byz. gives the form *peirai=os (sc. limh/n). There was another place called to\ *pei/raion in Corinth (Xen. Hell. iv. 5, 3), but in a different part. This fact and the Athenian *peiraieu/s may have caused the word to be written incorrectly. The harbour is now Frango-Porto. That Thucydides immediately calls the place a limh/n is no argument for the masculine termination, since *fa/lhron is a harbour also.

ta\ meqo/pia th=s *)epidauri/as. kai\ th=s *kopinqi/as is to be
supplied from just above. Compare the familiar omission of one of the termini after metacu/, e)n me/sw|, etc.

prosbalo/ntwn in two ways { i. kai\ tai=s nausi( kata\ qa/lassan, { ii. kai\ a)poba/ntwn (‘and also by landing’).
au)tw=n ‘of themselves,’ i.e. the Athenians. The position guards the meaning.

e)s to\ nhsi/dion. Stahl's ti is not good. The article is anticipative, the knowledge of the existence of such an island being assumed. Cf. c. 21 (init.) and note on e)/ti, c 36, § 2. The island was one of the *pe/lopos nh=soi and is now called Ovrionisi.
*parh=san ga\r kai\. kai\ is suggested by the mention of boh/qeian. ‘The Pelop. on their side had reinforcements.’
e)pi\ ta\s nau=s ‘to the support of their ships’, cf. iii. 97.
ei)/rhto . . . *)alkame/nei, ‘Alcamenes had been directed by the ephors.’ *)alkame/nh (acc. and inf. const.) is rendered almost impossible by the position of u(po\ tw=n e)fo/rwn (P-S).
w(rmhme/nwn not ‘having started,’ for this they had not done, but cf. c. 8, § 2. Add Hdt. vii. 1, ma=llon w(/rmhto strateu/esqai, ‘was ready and eager to . . .’

th
 e)n . . . katafugh/n = th
 e)s *r. katafugh
 kai\ th
 e)n au)tw=| monh/n. Cf. c. 2 (init.), th
 e)k th=s *sik. kakopragi/an.
prw=ton with a(pto/menoi, like eu)qu/s, ‘at their very first dealing with . . .’

a)poknh=sai to
 plou=n. Cf. iii. 20, a)pw/knhsan to
 ki/ndunon. The acc. after the simple o)knei=n is rare and poetical; the principle of it is the same as in ou)de/na pw/pote ki/ndunon e)ce/sthsan (Dem. 460 [10]). Cf. c. 1, § 1, cumproqumhqei=si to
 e)/kploun.

di' e)kei/nou, sc. Alcibiades. There are two possible interpretations— (a) It was better policy for Endius to carry out these measures through the agency of Alcibiades (his own ce/nos) and so reap personal glory, than to allow Agis to reap all the credit. (b) It was better for Endius that the Peloponnesians (supplying tina as subject of a)posth=sai) should gain these points through his (Endius') agency, than through that of Agis.
The former is the better, the construction being less strained. In the sense (a), Alcibiades being the actual agent, Agis would get no credit, while Endius would get more credit than any other Spartan because of his special connection with Alcibiades. This view is shown to be correct by c. 17, § 2, kai\ e(autw=| . . . kai\ tw=| a)postei/lanti *)endi/w|, w(/sper u(pe/sxeto, to\ a)gw/nisma prosqei=nai.

e)kei=nos is the proper word for emphatic reference to the speaker in opposition to some other person. Cf. ii. 11, o(/tan o(rw=sin h(ma=s ta)kei/nwn fqei/rontas; and inf. c. 45, § 4, a)ciou=si a)/llous u(pe\r th=s e)kei/nwn e)leuqeri/as kinduneu/ein. The subject to a)posth=sai is naturally *)/endion.
au)to\s sc. o( *)alkibia/dhs. Cf. c. 45, § 1, h)=n ga\r kai\ tw=| *)/agidi e)xqro/s. Alcibiades had intrigued with Agis' wife (Plut. Alc. 23).
.a)nekomi/zonto, ‘were meanwhile on their way back.’
e(kkai/deka Cf. vi. 104 and vii. 7.
th\n *leukadi/an properly ‘the territory of Leucas,’ but the name is apparently used indifferently with that of *leuka/s for the island itself. So h( *\rodi/a, etc.
fulakh\n e)/xwn tw=n . . . The article implies that these and other ships were naturally expected by the Athenians.
ai( loipai\ by partitive apposition takes up the construction begun with a)polhfqei=sai. Strictly we should have a)polhfqeisw=n kai\ kopeisw=n.

o(/sois t'. This implies a following kai\ which shall continue the idea of stealth in their approach. ‘They both arrested all those they met, and also . . . (adopted other means of concealment).’ The other means are stated in kai\ prosb. *kwru/kw| k.t.l. (instead of sailing direct to Chios).

tou= mh\ Cf. i. 4, to\ lhstiko\n kaqh/rei e)k th=s qala/sshs tou= ta\s proso/dous ma=llon i)e/nai au)tw=|, v. 27, etc. The gen. is causal. The construction is not of the commonest in classical Greek. Cf. Latin conservandae libertatis, etc.

*kwru/kw| th=s h)pei/rou the emphatic word is h)pei/rou (instead of making straight to the island of Chios). There were several places called Corycus. This one was the most southern point of the Erythraean peninsula, about 40 miles from Chios. Corycus is properly the name of the mountain
range, which ends in a promontory called *kwru/keion (Pliny, H. N. v. 31). Livy (xxx vii. 12) has ‘Corycum Teiorum promonturium tenuit.’
au)toi\ me\n . . . The de\-clause is not easy to supply. au)toi\ me\n is not opposed to the action of the discharged prisoners, but apparently to the action of the startled Chians.
keleuo/ntwn not on the same lines with cumprasso/ntwn, but gen. abs. Sub. tou/twn.

w(/ste boulh/n te k.t.l. There should be little doubt that Thucydides is responsible for all the particles in the text. The original unformulated thought was w(/ste boulh
 tuxei=n cullegome/nhn, kai\ e)n au)th=| o( *xalk. kai\ o( *)alk. toiau=ta ei)=ron w(/ste a)pe/sthsan *xi=oi. Having begun this and reached boulh
, Thucydides anticipates the consequences, for which he prepares the reader with te. The sentence should then run w(/ste boulh/n te t. c. kai\ toiau=ta ei)rei=n to
 *x. kai\ to
 *)a. w(/ste a)fi/stasqai *xi/ous. The latter part of this sentence is put in the form kai\ genome/nwn lo/gwn a)po/ te k.t.l., with an expected ending a)fi/stasqai *xi/ous [i.e. w(/ste boulh/n te t. c. kai\ (genome/nwn lo/gwn . . .) a)fi/stasqai *xi/ous]. The change of construction from an infinitive depending on w(/ste to a simple indicative assertion is in the manner of Thucydides. The te after a)/llai is the result of a similar confusion. The lo/goi are to the effect that other ships will come. The writer anticipates (by te) another assertion, as if some positive sentence were to follow; but that clause turns out to be, not something further they assert, but something further they conceal. The correspondence of te with kai\ ou) dhlwsa/ntwn is one of sound rather than sense.
cullegome/nhn Note the tense. They had arranged so that the council should be meeting in the natural course at the time when the Athenians should arrive.

a)po/ te tou= *x. kai\ *)alk. i.e. a)ro/ te tou= *x. kai\ a)ro\ tou= *)a. or a)ro\ tou= te *x. kai\ *)a. (a frequent combination as regards the single article). It is especially after prepositions that a trajection of te occurs (in all writers). Cf. Herod. i. 69, a)/neu te do/lou kai\ a)pa/ths.
kai\ au)=qis ‘and then in turn.’ au)=qis=deinde, as often.

*klazomena\s. According to Pausanias (vii. 3, 9) the Clazomenians had removed their abode to the island for fear of the Persians. oi)kou=si shows that at the time Thuc. writes they still lived on it. Cf. Xen. Hell. v. 1, 31. Alexander seems to have connected it with the mainland by a causeway.

th\n *poli/xnan It is questioned whether this is a proper or common noun. If common, the article is anticipative, as in to\ nhsi/dion, c. 11, § 1. But as a common noun the word is only late, and the termination -na_ is un-Attic. There were several places named *poli/xna; cf. ii. 85, *polixni=tai, Hdt. vi. 26, etc.

ei)/ ti de/oi k.t.l. Cf. vi. 100, pro\s th
 po/lin, ei) e)pibohqoi=en, e)xw/roun. Goodwin, M. and T., § 490. The suppressed apodosis is ‘so that they might use it . . . (in case . . .).’ P-S, Cl., etc., prefer to punctuate e)tei/xizon, ei)/ ti de/oi, sfi/sin au)toi=s k.t.l. According to this view sfi/sin au)toi=s follows a)naxw/rhsin. In any case the construction of the passage is somewhat lax. With the punctuation of the text sfi/sin au)toi=s (which is not so emphatic as at first sight appears, but=e(autoi=s, cf. vi. 63, i. 128, etc.) depends on de/oi, the const. being ei)/ ti de/oi au)toi=s pro\s a)naxw/rhsin e)k th=s nhsi=dos. Cf. Antiphon, 769 (142), ei)/ ti de/oi tw=| xorw=|. Eur. Suppl. 594, e(
 dei= mo/non moi. The laxity lies in the position of the words e)k th=s nhsi=dos. [Stahl would seek to ease (as he thinks) the construction by reading proanaxw/rhsin in apposition to *poli/xnan and dependent on e)tei/xizon. He compares i. 90, th
 *peloro/nnhson . . . i(kanh
 . . . a)naxw/phsi/n te kai\ a)fopmh/n. Far easier would be a conjecture proanaxwph=sai. The const. dei= tini with infin. is rare, but certainly Greek. Cf. Xen. Anab. iii. 4, 35, dei= e)pisa)cai to
 i(/ppon *pe/rsh| a)ndri/; Eur. Hipp. 941, etc. No such change, however, is needed.]

a)ggeli/a th=s *xi/ou. Cf. i. 61, h)=lqe de\ h( a)ggeli/a tw=n po/lewn o(/ti a)festa=sin; Soph. Aj. 221, e)dh/lwsas a)ndro\s ai)/qwnos a)ggeli/an; Hom. Od. i. 408, etc. So lo/gos, mu=qos, ba/cis tino/s.
th=s megi/sths with a qualification, c. 40, § 1, th/n megi/sthn tw=n e)n *)iwni/a| cummaxi/dwn po/lewn. In c. 6, § 4, Chios has sixty ships.

ta/ te xi/lia ta/lanta k.t.l. The accus. depends on the coming sense of kinei=n underlying the whole passage, rather than actually upon the word kinei=n after e)yhfi/santo. Thus, e)/lusan ta\s zhmi\as tw_| ei)po/nti kinei=n ta\ xi/lia ta/lanta kai\ e)yhfi\santo kinei=n au)ta/. Thc words ta\ x. ta/l. are, however, placed first for emphasis. The Greek says, ‘and the thousand talents, which during all the war they had grudged to touch, they at once under their present dismay removed the penalties laid upon the man who should propose or put to the vote the proposal, and they voted to employ (them).’ This is ungrammatical in both English and Greek, but it is an easier anacoluthon in
the synthetic form, and there should be no doubt that Thucydides wrote it. Cf. Soph. El. 709, sta/ntes d' o(/q' au)tou\s oi( tetagme/noi brabh=s | klh/rous e)/phlan kai\ kate/sthsan di/frous (=klh/rous ph/lantes kate/sthsan); Ter. Adelph. 917, tu illas abi et traduce. Cl. and Stahl follow Cobet in reading eu)qu\s li/santes . . . e)yhfi/santo, a correction which savours of the composition-class. The history of this money is given in ii. 24, kai\ xi/lia ta/lanta a)po\ tw=n e)n th=| a)kropo/lei xrhma/twn e)/docen au)toi=s e)cai/reta pohsame/nois xwri\s qe/sqai kai\ mh\ a)nalou=n, a)ll' a)po\ tw=n a)/llwn polemei=n: h)\n de/ tis ei)/ph| h)\ e)piyhfi/sh| kinei=n ta\ xrh/mata tau=ta e)s a)/llo ti, h)\n mh\ oi( pole/mioi nhi/th| stratw=| e)piple/wsi th=| po/lei kai\ de/h| a)mu/nasqai, qa/naton zhmi/an e)pe/qento.
zhmi/as sc. qa/naton (loc cit.)
ei)po/nti as r(h/twr.
e)piyhfi/santi as e)pista/ths or one of the pro/edroi.
ou)k o)li/gas coalescing, otherwise mh\

tw=n te . . . te introduces a new point; cf. ta/s te tw=n *xi/wn, § 2. kai\ nau=s plhrou=n ou)k o)li/gas is part of the clause kai\ e)yhfi/santo kinei=n ta\ x. ta/l., the object of employing the money being to provide a fleet.

ta\s . . . o)ktw\ the article does not look forward to ai(\, but is usual where a certain number is picked out and distinguished from the rest, or opposed to some other number. Cf. i. 116, tai=s me\n e(kkai/deka tw=n new=n ou)k e)xrh/santo, etc. Madvig, Synt. § 11.
*dioti/mou i. 45.
*qrasuklh=s v 19.
e(te/ras, ‘a different set. a)/llas immediately= ‘others besides.’.

e(te/ras d' a)nti\ pasw=n Stahl's e(te/ras de\ de/ka a)nti\ pasw=n is highly probable. Cf. c. 10, § 3, e(pta\ kai\ tria/konta. pasw=n cannot be otiose, but the meaning is either ‘in place of all that had gone away an equal number of others,’ i.e. twenty-seven others, were sent; or else Stahl's reading is required, ‘and to replace all these ten others were sent.’ It hardly seems that if the Athenians could afford to withdraw first eight ships and then twelve more (besides the seven of the Chians), it was necessary to send back as many as twenty-seven. It is clear
that in c. 20, § 1, the Athenians had but twenty ships at Peiraeum. At the same time we can never be sure that Thucydides narrates every change in the fleets mentioned.

o)li/gon e)pra/sseto ou)de
 Cf. ii. 8, o)li/gon e)peno/oun ou)de
 a)mfo/teroi; vii. 59, o)li/gon ou)de
 e)s ou)de
 e)peno/oun.
*sa/mon, subjugated by the Athenians after a revolt, in B.C. 439.
*te/wn The inhabitants are *th/ioi. *te/ws: *th/ios lew/s: lh/iton:. new/s: nh/ios, by quantitative metathesis from the stem *ta_v.
e)pe/plei ‘was sailing to attack.’
parh/|ei ‘was marching along the coast.’
e)canh/geto, ‘proceeded to set sail into the open.’

e)n tw=| pela/gei to be joined with w(s e(w/ra. With metewrisqei\s we should expect e)s to\ pe/lagos The sense is ‘S. got out into the open, and when lying out there took observations,’ as if mete/wros geno/menos kai\ perime/nwn.
e(w/ra imperf. ‘began to find’
polla\s predic., sub. ou)/sas. Cf. c. 8 (fin.), polu/.
e)pe/sxon, before pulling down the wall (P-S). Rather ‘before taking any action.’

oi( pezoi\ ‘the various land forces.’ This is the reading of one MS. only; the rest give oi( polloi/. The variation is difficult, since neither word can well be an error for the other. Probably the true reading is e)pe/sxon *o*u*p*o*l*u*o*i*p*e*z*o*i, i.e. e)pe/sxon ou) polu\ oi( pezoi\, ‘stopped and waited a little while.’ Cf. Hdt. i. 132, e)pisxw\n o)li/gon xro/non; Plat. Phaed. 59 E, ou) polu\n xro/non e)pisxw/n. Some qualification seems wanted.
kai\ *xalkide/a ‘waiting for Ch. as well’ is loosely put for ‘waiting so that Ch. as well might be there and take part,’ i.e. kai\ *x. parei=nai perime/nontes.
au)toi/ te To this should naturally answer kai\ barba/rwn ou) polloi/, which, however, is replaced by a verb clause introduced by de\ . . . kai\ . . .

th=s *thi/wn po/lews The genitive does not depend on tei=xos, but is most naturally partitive or relative with to\ pro\s h)/peiron Cf. c. 14, § 1, *kwru/kw| th=s h)pei/rou. ‘On the mainland
side of Teos,’ i.e. of the city (po/lews being distinguished from gh=s). Teos was situated on a promontory and could easily be walled off for defensive purposes. The genitive may also be joined a)po\ koinou= with o(\.
to\ pro\s h)/peiron P-S should not have made this agree with tei=xos. It is adverbial, like to\ pro\s du/nontos h(li/ou, Hdt. ix. 14, Aesch. Suppl. 255; to\ e)p' e)kei/nois ei)=nai, c. 48, § 6.
barba/rwn not Persians, but the non-Greek Persian subjects from Lydia and Caria.

u(/parxos A satrapy was further divided into provinces under u(/parxoi (cf. governor and governor-general). Cf. c. 31, § 2, *tamw/s, *)iwni/as u(/parxos; and c. 108, § 4, *)arsa/kou tou= *pe/rsou, *tissafe/rnous u(pa/rxou.
e)n *xi/w| katalimpa/nousin, to secure the loyalty of the Chians (Poppo).
*mi/lhton which had joined the Athenian confederacy not long after the battle of Mycale (B.C. 479). In B.C. 440 Miletus had appealed to Athens against Samos.

ta\s a)po\ th=s *p. nau=s. In c. 6, § 4, the Lacedaemonians first agree to send forty ships. In c. 7 there were thirty-nine ships of the allied contingents at Corinth, and it was decided to send these. Twenty-one are carried over the Isthmus, one is lost, and twenty are now blockaded in Peiraeum. Five ships have been prepared in Laconia and sent already.
w(/sper u(pe/sxeto v. c. 12, § 2, note.
meta\ th=s *xi/wn duna/mews i.e. with the assistance of these, and not of the nau/arxos who was to arrive.

a)posth/sas = tw=| a)posth=sai, ‘by having caused to revolt,’ the mode of getting the credit (prosqei=nai). Poppo's proposed a)posth=sai (exegetic of a)gw/nisma) is away from the mark. He compares for his infin. vii. 86, kalo\n to\ a)gw/nisma e)no/mize/n oi( ei)=nai e)pi\ toi=s a)/llois kai\ tou\s a)ntistrath/gous komi/sai, and vii. 59, e)no/mizon kalo\n a)gw/nisma sfi/sin ei)=nai . . . e(lei=n. The difference is easily appreciable. a)gw/nisma is not here a predicate, and there is no kalo/n.
to\ plei=ston tou= plou=, adverbial accus. of extent. 18 kata\ po/das = e vestigio, ‘close behind’; cf. iii. 98, iv. 126, v. 64. Polybius uses h( kata\ po/das h(me/ra=‘the very next day.’
mia=s deou/sais ei)/kosi Strombichides' eight and Thrasycles' twelve, minus one unaccounted for, probably left in Samos.
e)n *la/dh| best known as the place where the Ionians were defeated by the Persians, B.C. 495. It controlled the harbour of Miletus.
dia\ *tiss. kai\ *xal. with e)ge/neto.

e)/stw the singular, since the words kai\ po/leis are closely joined to xw/ran in the sense ‘territory, including cities.’ The terms are very degrading to the Greeks. See the improvement in c. 58, and the argument of Lichas, c. 52.

e)foi/ta ef. ‘income,’ reditus, revenue, pro/sodos. ta\ prosio/nta (Ar. Vesp. 664); prosie/nai (ii. 13). This use of foita=n is especially common in Herodotus, e.g. v. 17, ta/lanton a)rguri/ou *)aleca/ndrw| h(me/rhs e(ka/sths e)foi/ta.

kwluo/ntwn se. tau=ta (P-S). Yet, though kwlu/ein o(/pws mh\ is not found elsewhere, there is much elasticity about verbs of caution and prevention; and since skopei=n o(/pws mh\ and eu)labou=mai o(/pws mh\ are good Greek, it is quite possible for kwlu/ein to be similarly used in this isolated instance. But the construction with tau=ta understood makes a simpler structure, the first clause being less loosely attached.
tou= pole/mou tou=. If the second tou= is omitted, pro\s *)aqhnai/ous depends on kata/lusin - poei=sqai.
o)/ntwn. The forms in -wsan do not appear on Attic inscriptions till about B.C. 300. Metrical data are also against them.
de/ka e(te/ras. In c. 17, § 1, Chalcideus mans his own five ships and twenty others with Chians. A different fleet of ten is now manned.
*)/anaia on the mainland opposite (and in a way commanding) Samos. Cf. iv. 75, w(/sper ta\ *)/anaia e)pi\ th=| *samw|.

kai\ o(/ti *)amo/rghs k.t.l. kai\ should not be omitted. The chief reason for their withdrawal is no doubt ‘because Amorges is coming’; but ‘the message told them to sail back, and said that Amorges etc.’ is no unnatural way of expressing this. moreover, this may not have been the only reason.
o(/ti is more common in the sense ‘that’ than in the sense ‘because,’ and especially with a)gge/llein.
*)amo/rghs v. c. 5, § 5. As the enemy of the king and Tissaphernes, he was the enemy of the Lacedaemonians in terms of the treaty, c. 18, § 3.
*dio\s i(ero/n between Lebedos and Colophon according to Steph. Byz.
e)s th\n gh=n fqasa/ntwn. Cf.Xen. Cyr. v. 4, 9, fqa/santes ei/s po/lin tina/. The ellipsis becomes common in Hellenistic Greek.
o( pezo\s, i.e. of the Clazomenians and Erythraeans, c. 16, § 1.

met' au)tw=n Const. ‘the Chians (who had set sail with the remaining ships), assisted by the land forces, caused L. to revolt.’ This is much more natural and simple than to suppose a zeugma, with e.g. a)pa/ras or o(rmhqei\s to be supplied with pezo\s from a)nagago/menoi.

*le/bedon one of the oldest and most flourishing Ionian cities; cf. Hdt. i. 142. Its subsequent desertion (Hor. Ep. i. 11, 7) was due to its destruction by Lysimachus (Paus. vii. 3, 2). *ai)pa/s, poli/xnion *thi/wn (Strabo, p. 644).
katadiwxqei=sai to/te, ‘which had been driven in there at the time I have mentioned,’ viz. c. 10, § 3. This use of to/te is frequent in Thucydides: cf. c. 23, § 4, etc.
e)n goes with the combined notion katad. - to/te - kai\ e)formou/menai (=e)nou=sai a(/te katadiwxqei=sai k.t.l.)
i)/sw| a)riqmw=| not necessarily an exact expression; cf. ta\s h(misei/as, c. 8, § 3.
au)=qis not deinde, but ‘once more,’ as they had done in c. 10, § 2.

w(=|per e)gi/gneto k.t.l. ‘on whom was by this time devolving the general naval command.’ pa=sa, i.e. not merely of these twenty ships, but of all Peloponnesian fleets. In c. 6 Melanchridas is nau/arxos. His term has expired.
kai\ *tissafe/rnhs k.t.l. ‘T. also (came and subsequently) retired.’ kai\ looking forward to a)nexw/rhse after a)naxwrh/santos (Cl.)
e)pikaqelw\n k.t.l. In c. 16, § 3, the imperfect kaqh/|roun implies that the work was not completed. e)pi-=‘proceeding further with.’

to\ e)n th=| *te/w| tei=xos Stahl having made (c. 16, § 3) th=s *thi/wn po/lews depend on tei=xos (instead of on to\ pro\s h)/peiron) finds a difficulty. This expression, he says, could only mean ‘arcem in urbe sitam’ or ‘apud Teum,’ and neither of these suits his purpose. Yet the latter is right. The wall is a diatei/xisma across the isthmus. It is not ‘the wall of Teos’ but ‘the wall in the territory of Teos.’ Cf. iv. 5, o( strato\s e)/ti e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)/n; v. 55, e)n th=| *)epidau/rw|; vii. 1, e)n *(ime/ra|, and frequently.
w(/ste introducing the terms of a compact; cf. iv. 37, etc.
ou)k e)la/mbane ‘was making no progress in taking.’
h(, anticipatory or assumptive, or ‘the well-known.’ Cf. c. 11, § 1, to\ nhsi/dion.
e)pana/stasis toi=s dunatoi=s the verbal noun with the case of the verb. Cf. i. 73, a)ntilogi/an toi=s u(mete/rois cumma/xois; Plat. Rep. 444 B, e)pana/stasin me/rous tino\s tw=| o(/lw|.

tou= dh/mou The u(po\ of most MSS. is hardly defensible. The verbal noun seems naturally enough to be joined to u(po\ in other cases only where the sense of the noun is passive. This is true, as P-S remarks, of all the instances quoted by Classen (i. 130, a)ci/wma u(po\ . . .; ii. 65, a)rxh\ u(po\ . . .; viii. 64. fugh\ u(po\ . . .). Thus a)na/stasis tw=n dunatw=n u(po\ tou= dh/mou, ‘removal of the oligarchs by the commons,’ is normal Greek, but e)pana/stasis toi=s dunatoi=s u(po\ tou= dh/mou, ‘a rising against the oligarchs on the part of the people,’ is very questionable. See the passage quoted in last note from Plato. u(po\ could only be argued for on the ground that h( e)n *sa/mw| e)pana/stasis toi=s dunatoi=s e)ge/neto u(po\ tou= dh/mou met' *)aqhnai/wn = ‘the well-known revolt against the oligarchs was brought about by the commons working with the assistance of the Athenians,’ u(po\ being inserted because the agency is to be emphasised and distributed, and the commons being put as the agents of revolt rather than the revolters. But the order of the words is against this, nor does it improve the sense.

toi=s dunatoi=s Cf. i. 115, cunqe/menoi tw=n e)n th=| po/lei (sc. th=| *sa/mw|) toi=s dunatwta/tois, where Shilleto renders ‘the most aristocratical’; i. 24, o( dh=mos e)cedi/wce tou\s dunatou/s; iii. 27, etc. Grote, c. lxi. (note), argues strongly that the government of Samos was at this time under an exelnsive aristocracy of Geômori (‘landed proprietors’). Else why such a strong word as e)pana/stasis? Athens had apparently not interfered since
B.C. 439, and the oligarchy may have developed itself gradually. Lysander restored the oligarchy after the war was over.
e)n trisi\ nausi\. e)n has its point: ‘to the number of three ships'-crews’—‘filling three ships.’
e)s diakosi/ous . . . tinas Cf. iii. 111. tinas is a qualification like French quelques, our ‘some two hundred.’ e)s is itself qualificatory. Without e/s vii. 87, e(bdomh/konta/ tinas.

tou\s pa/ntas tw=n dunatwta/twn These words should be joined, the genitive being partitive; cf. inf. c. 75, § 3, *sami/wn pa/ntes. The superlative is correct; the most powerful were all slain, others who were less so were banished. If dunatw=n is read, tou\s pa/ntas will go with the preceding words, ‘about some two hundred in all,’ which would have little purpose, unless either a larger or a smaller number would naturally have been expected.
*)aqhnai/wn te a new and distinct point, and therefore introduced by te rather than kai\: ‘when too the Athenians had subsequently voted them autonomy.’
sfi/sin logically au)toi=s, but in the clause coming between the subject and its verb diw/|koun, and giving a reason for the action of the subject, the reflexive pronoun is not an unnatural laxity.
au)tonomi/an which they had lost in i. 117. Part of this yh/fisma has been discovered in an inscription on the acropolis.

toi=s gewmo/rois ‘the landowners,’ i.e. in a local (not the Athenian) class sense. Cf. Hdt. vii. 155, tou\s gewmo/rous kaleome/nous tw=n *surhkosi/wn e)kpeso/ntas u(po\ tou= dh/mou; Xen. Hell. ii. 2, 6 (of the Samians), sfaga\s tw=n gnwri/mwn poh/santes katei=xon th\n po/lin.

e)kdou=nai sc. ta\s qugate/ras. Cf. Plat. Rep. 362 B, gamei=n o(po/qen a)\n bou/lhtai kai\ e)kdido/nai ei)s ou(\s a)\n bou/lhtai; Polit. 310 C, kata\ du/namin gamou=si/ te para\ tou/twn kai\ ta\s e)kdidome/nas par' au(tw=n ei)s tou/tous e)kpe/mpousi pa/lin. a)gage/sqai is here substituted for gh=mai.

e)s e)kei/nous with e)kdou=nai, the order being a chiasmus. Cf. Plat. Rep. 360 E, ta/ te a)du/nata kai\ ta\ dunata\ diaisqa/netai kai\ toi=s me\n (sc. toi=s dunatoi=s) e)pixeirei=, ta\ de\ (sc. ta\ a/du/nata) e)a=|.
w(/sper h)/rcanto, c. 19 (init.).
proqumi/as ‘ab ou)de\n pendet’ (P.) a)polei/pein with genitive does not occur in positive sentences.

a)/neu te . . . Their motive is twofold. They are zealous to make as many cities as possible revolt, and at the same time they wish to strengthen their own position. This might be expressed a)posth=sai/ te ta\s po/leis kai\ w(s plei/stous labei=n tou\s cugkinduneu/sontas. But Thucydides, though he answers the te with kai\, does not answer the construction, but adds the participle boulo/menoi on the same line with a)polei/pontes.
plh/qei paro/ntes i.e. approaching the several cities in sufficient force or demonstration to work upon them.
a)posth=sai The infinitive follows the sense of ou)de\n a)polei/pontes proqumi/as (=ou)de\n h(=sson proqumou/menoi). au)toi/ te. te is again irregularly answered by kai\ o( pezo\s a(/ma parh/|ei.
w(/sper ei)/rhto viz. c. 8, § 2.
*peloponnhsi/wn landed in Chios by Chalcideus, c. 17, § 1.

*klazomenw=n te kai\ *ku/mhs i.e. along the coast via these two cities, the natural route to the Hellespont. These are the two chief cities on the way. Smyrna, which afterwards and formerly lay between them, was razed at this time, and had been so for 200 years. Of Cyme, Strabo (p. 622) says it was the largest and finest of the Aeolian towns.
peri/oikos For a perioecus in a position of honour cf. c. 6, § 4, *fru=nin k.t.l.
*mh/qumnan . . . *mutilh/nhn. For the past favourable relations of the former with Athens see iii. 2, 18, 50, vi. 85, vii. 57; and for the unfavourable treatment of the latter, iii. 50.
te/ssarsi nausi\n, though there were twenty at Cenchreae when he joined them.

w(/sper w(/rmhto ‘as he had proposed,’ implying that no accident changed his plans or prevented their execution. Cf. w(/sper e)/pleon, inf. § 3. For the meaning of the word cf c. 8, § 2, w(rmhme/nous; c. 11, § 3, w(rmhme/nwn.
pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosin In c. 19, § 2, Diomedon brings sixteen ships. Leon comes with ten more. One is left unaccounted for, as in c. 17, § 3.
h)=rxe For singular see Madvig, Gk. Synt. § 2, b.

e)s o)ye/. The same expression is generally read from a
number of MSS. in iii. 108, instead of e(/ws o)ye/ of Vat. and others. Cf. ei)s e(spe/ran h(/kein Arist. Plut. 998, e)s au)ti/ka, etc.
*pu/rran . . . *)/ereson which had previously revolted from Athens and been subdued (iii. 18, 25, 35).
w(/sper e)/pleon. Cf. w(/sper w(/rmhto, § 1, ‘sailed right into . . .’ (J.)

new=n e)kra/thsan potiti sunt (Krug.) His rule that kratei=n with gen. means in potestatem suam redigere, as opposed to the accus. use = superare will scarcely hold in view of e.g. i. 69, o( lo/gos tou= e)/rgou e)kra/tei, ‘surpassed’; Lys. 156 (53), th=s diabolh=s prosedokw=men krath/sein (‘get the better of’), etc.; and on the other hand, Aesch. Suppl. 255, kai\ pa=san ai)=an kratw= (‘hold in my power’). Yet the Thucydidean use is mostly for Kruger's view. Cf. iv. 98, ei) . . . dunhqh=nai th=s e)kei/nwn krath=sai.
punqano/menos, rather than puqo/menos, as he was told the news more than once, and gradually had it confirmed, ‘getting to know of it.’
to/te ‘on the occasion above stated,’ viz. c. 22 (fin.) Cf. c. 20, § 1, katadiwxqei=sai to/te.

kai\ o(pli/sas ‘and having equipped them (tou\s *)eresi)ous to be supplied from th
 *)/ereson) with heavy armour.’ Cf. iii. 27, o(pli/zei to
 dh=mon pro/teron yilo
 o)/nta, and inf. c. 25, § 1. Arnold remarks that under the Athenian rule there would be little use of heavy arms at Eresus.

o(pli/tas There were no necessary hoplites, properly so called, on board ships, though each trireme usually carried from seven to ten e)piba/tai (see Arnold on iii. 95). The e)piba/tai, however, are sometimes reckoned among hoplites, e g. vi. 43, o(pli/tais toi=s cu/mpasin e(kato
 kai\ pentakisxili/ois, kai\ tou/twn *)aqhnai/wn me
 au)tw=n h)=san pentako/sioi me
 kai\ xi/lioi e)k katalo/gou, e(ptako/sioi de\ qh=tes e)piba/tai tw=n new=n; and on the other hand o(pli=tai were sometimes used as e)piba/tai, cf. inf. c. 24, § 3, ei)=xon d' e)piba/tas tw=n o(plitw=n e)k katalo/gou a)nagkastou/s. Astyochus may have taken more than the usual number of fighting men, seeing that he was going to land in Lesbos.

parape/mpei of Vat. is plainly right. pare/plei of most MSS. is from the next sentence, and is of course impossible with the same word following. Trans. ‘but having caused Eresus to revolt, and having supplied it with heavy arms, he also sends by land along the coast the hoplites from his own ships (i.e. as
well as the said Eresians).’ Dobree struck out o(pli/tas, rendering ‘having caused E. to revolt, and having also armed the men from his own ships, he sends them along the coast.’ But tou\s a)po\ tw=n new=n would be too comprehensive (=‘all his crews’): either tinas or tou\s e)piba/tas would be required.
*)/antissan which had also revolted from and been reduced by Athens B. C. 428 (iii. 18, 28).

o( a)po\ tw=n *ai)ole/wn. MSS. give o( a)po\ tw=n new=n. Haase made an attempt to render this by ‘the force apart from the ships,’ but this with the article cannot be, however much a)po\ with verbs like oi)kei=n may=‘away from.’ I copy the following note written by me in the Classical Review for Dec. 1889:— ‘Astyochus has been endeavouring to secure Lesbos by means of his fleet and a small land-force. His failure is recorded in the preceding sentence. Meanwhile Eualas with the main body has set out along the mainland (c. 22, § 1) for the Hellespont by way of Cume. The return of this force is stated in the present sentence. In this view all commentators agree, but all admit that o( a)po\ tw=n new=n is unintelligible. The only meaning possible in Thucydides for these words is “the land-force which had been disembarked from the ships,” as this force had not. Jowett's discussion ends in despair. ‘The land-force in question had been first operating in Ionia, which was the seat of war. In c. 22, § 1, it leaves Ionia for the first time and marches to Cume and along that coast. From that neighbourhood it now returns, because of the failure of the simultaneous expedition to Lesbos. But Cume is the chief city of Aeolis. It is “from Aeolis” that the said army returns. Read therefore o( a)po\ *t*w*n*e*o*l*e*w*n instead of *t*w*n*n*e*w*n, i.e. o( a)po\ tw=n *ai)ole)wn (by the frequent error e for ai, due to pronunciation) with the usual pregnaney of construction.’
e)me/llhsen ‘had intended.’ The aorist for our pluperfect is regular in relative clauses.
*kegxreia=| So all MSS., as in iv. 42, though plural elsewhere. A similar vacillation of number occurs in *pla/taia and *plataiai/, *ne/wn and *ne/wnes (v. Shilleto on Dem. De F. Leg. 387).
teixizome/nhn, ‘as it was being fortified.’ though the participle in this position is often simply attributive.
*dafnou=nta unknown except from this place, and c. 31, § 2 (where it is seen to be situated inland).
oi(/ t', answered by kai\ *le/wn k.t.l., § 2.
tai=s ei)/kosi In c. 17, § 3, they are nineteen.

*pa/normon a very common geographical name. th=s *milhsi/as is a necessary addition, there being another *pa/normos in the neighbouring peninsula of Halicarnassus. For the present place cf. Hdt. i. 157, o( de\ xw=ros ou(=tos (viz. *bragxi/dai) e)sti\ th=s *milhsi/hs u(pe\r *pano/rmou lime/nos.
a)nei=lon an unusual thing (except, apparently, in these circumstances), inasmuch as the tropai=on was dedicated and, so far, inviolable.
*oi)noussw=n, five islands belonging to Chios (Hdt. i. 165). There was another group of the same name off Messenia.
*sidou)sshs . . . *pteleou= exact positions unknown.
tei/xh = castella. For the readings at this point see crit. note.

kai\ e)k th=s *le/sbou is at first sight difficult, and is bracketed by P-S after Classen. The ships, it is said, would hardly keep starting from so distant a place as Lesbos, and the preceding ta\s e)k tou= *le/sbou nau=s makes these words a kind of contradiction, the fleet having left Lesbos The latter objection is unsound. ‘Leon and D. with the Athenian ships at (e)k by construction praeg.) Lesbos’ does not imply that they brought away all the ships (nor perhaps were they likely to do so with Lesbian loyalty so uncertam). For the former, it may be pointed out that the distance is after all not more than forty miles, and that, while making the Oenussae, etc., the nearer starting-places, some of the ships might well be utilised to descend from Lesbos upon the W. side of Chios.

ei)=xon d' e)piba/tas k.t.l. Construe ‘and for e)piba/tai they had some of the hoplites who were taken from the active list and were serving nnder compulsion,’ i.e. were pressed into that branch of service. The e)piba/tai were regularly of an inferior class (qh=tes); cf. vi. 43, and note on c. 23, § 3. At this critical time the superior citizens were compelled to serve in this capacity under pain of an a)stratei/as grafh/.
e)k katalo/gou Cf. vi. 43; vii. 16, 20. The list of those liable to serve excluded the qh=tes. oi( e)n tw=| katalo/gw| are opposed to oi( e)/cw tou= k. and oi( u(pe\r to\n k.
*kardamu/lh|, on the N.E. coast of Chios. Homer (Il. ix. 150) mentions a place of the same name in Messenia.

*boli/skw| so Vat. The rest *boli/ssw|. See crit. note. Kiepert places Bolissus on the W.N.W. coast, where there is now a village called Volisso. These two landings (ten miles apart) resulted in one battle (the northern) Another landing in the south led to another battle, and a third near Chios itself to a third battle.
ta\ tau/th| sc. in the north.
*fa/nais in the S.W. A harbour and promontory. limh\n baqu/s, Strabo (p. 644); Livy, xliv. 28, Promonturium Phanae; Verg. G. ii. 98, rex ipse Phanaeus.
*leukwni/w| the modern Leuconia.
kateskeuasme/nhn ‘stocked.’ Cf. vi. 91, oi(=s h( xw/ra kateskeu/astai.

a)po\ tw=n *mhdikw=n ‘ever since the trouble with the Medes.’ The Persians had not molested Chios till after the battle of Lade (B.C. 495), but at that time they burned and ravaged the country and carried off the beautiful girls as slaves (Hdt. vi. 31, 32). Cf. i. 18, pro\ tw=n *mhdikw=n; i. 95, tou= *mhdikou= pole/mou.

eu)daimonh/santes a(/ma kai\ e)swfro/nhsan = ‘after reaching prosperity they also put restraint upon themselves.’ This reading does not imply, as P-S would make it, that the prosperity was the cause of their self-restraint. When they became prosperous there were two courses open, to break out into luxury or to check themselves from so doing. They chose the latter. Hence the tense, rather than e)swfro/noun. Cf. h(su/xasan, § 6.
e)kosmou=nto ‘ordered themselves,’ i.e. their government. Cf. c. 67, § 3, e)k tou= au)tou= ko/smou; c. 72, § 2, e)n tw=| o)ligarxikw=| ko/smw|; Hdt. i. 59, th\n po/lin kalw=s te kai\ eu)= kosme/wn.

po/nhra. Herodian (circ. 160 A.D.) is authority for the remark that oi( *)attikoi/ write proparoxytone in this sense, but oxytone in the moral sense. Cf. ‘húman’ and ‘humáne.’ So with moxqhro/s. MSS. vary.
bebai/ws ‘beyond a doubt.’

cunanaireqh/sesqai The infinitive clause is exegetic of. tau)ta/. cun-, J. says, is intensive, ‘utterly.’ P-S should not have denied this use. sun- has often the force of summariness; cf. sunte/mnein (and con-sumere, etc.) An actual parallel to the present passage occurs, Isoc. 407 D, a(/pasan th\n u(pa/rxousan eu)daimoni/an sunanei=les (‘all at once’).

th
 a(marti/an cune/gnwsan either (1) ‘they recognised their mistake,’ or (2) ‘they resolved jointly upon the mistake.’ The latter, though less common, is to be preferred. Cf. ii. 60, e)me\ to
 paraine/santa kai\ u(ma=s au)tou/s, oi(\ cune/gnwte. In later Greek oi( sunegnwko/tes=‘the conspirators.’ For the contained accus J quotes vii. 73, oi( de\ cunegi/gnwskon me
 kai\ au)toi\ ou)x h(=sson tau=ta e)kei/nou, where the neuter pronoun is of course easier.
ou(\s ai)sqo/menoi, sc. o(/ ti e)poi/oun. Cf. oi=da/ se, o(/stis ei)=. The ou(= of P-S is not called for.
h(su/xasan For aorist cf. e)swfro/nhsan, § 4. Of the two courses open they chose to check any desire for action.
tou\s ga\r pentakosi/ous. Not a specified or understood 500, but as in c. 15, § 1, ta\s . . . o)ktw/ (q.v.).
*milh/sioi, subsequently rather illogically divided by ‘partitive apposition’ (sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros) into au)toi/ te . . . kai\ oi( . . . kai\ *t. . . . kai\ au)to\s . . .

oi( meta\ *xalkide/ws the same as tou\s a)po\ tw=n e(autou= new=n o(pli/tas of c. 23, § 4; his e)piba/tai and other men. The Peloponnesian crews have been left at Chios (c. 17, § 1) and have remained there (c. 32, § 2).

ceniko
 e)pikouriko
 Herwerden, followed by P-S and others, brackets ceniko
, and similarly in iii. 109, to
 misqofo/ron o)/xlon to
 ceniko/n, where Meineke, however, would bracket misqofo/ron. It is urged that the expression is tautological, or at least pleonastic. So, therefore, in a milder form, would be iv. 52, misqwsa/menoi e)pikouriko/n (and ii. 33). InXen. Hell. vi. 1, 5, misqofo/rous e)/xw ce/nous, Dindorf and Cobet would eject misqofo/rous. In Thucyd. vi. 55 e)pikou/rois is opposed to poli/tais. Now e)pi/kouroi literally conveys only the notion of auxiliary forces, and only by suggestion that of mercenaries. In vii. 58, e)pikouri/ai has not the latter implication at all. *tissafe/rnous e)pikouriko
 might mean nothing more than an auxiliary force sent by T. The addition of ceniko
 defines the force as consisting of ce/noi (i. 121, vii. 42). If any word is to be expunged it would rather be e)pikouriko/n, for it might be claimed that all ce/noi are e)pi/kouroi. But the pleonasm is scarcely felt: ‘a certain auxiliary force of mercenaries belonging to Tissaphernes.’
katafronh/santes, ‘possessed with contempt,’ used absolutely in an adverbial way. So ii. 11, dia\ to\ katafronou=ntas a)paraskeu/ous gene/sqai. The aorist as in iv. 34.

w(s e)p' *)/iwnas Cf. v. 9, *dwrih=s me/llete *)/iwsi ma/xesqai;
vii. 5, *peloponnh/sioi/ te o)/ntes kai\ *dwrih=s, *)iw/nwn kai\ nhsiwtw=n krath/santes.
o)/xlon, a contemptuous term for the less organised soldiery, cf. iv. 126, oi( toiou=toi o)/xloi, and the context.
e)ni/kwn, a quasi-pluperfect, nikw= (cf. a)dikw=, h(/kw, etc.) being a quasi-perfect, = ‘remamed conquerors,’ victores erant. Cf. teleutw=ntes, c. 58, § 6.
to\n periteixismo\n The article implies that this proceeding would naturally follow.
tou= xwri/ou The position of the city on a point rendered the proceeding easy.

a)
 . . . prosxwrh=sai The MSS. with one exception have prosxwrh/sein. See Introduction, § 2 (iii.) Goodwin, M. and T. § 208. In iv. 69, *ni/saian perieteixizon nomi/zontes, ei e)ce/loien, qa=sson a)
 kai\ ta\ *me/gara prosxwrh=sai, but in ii. 80 almost all MSS. give nomi/zontes, ei) tau/thn prw/thn la/boien, r(a|di/ws a)
 sfi/si ta)=lla prosxwrh/sein (two MSS. omit a)
). Cf. vi. 66, and inf. c. 71, § 1, where by far the most MS. authority is for a)
 h(suxa/sein. It does not seem reasonable, in view of the almost constant variants in -sai, -sein, to retam the future, nor can a)
 well be treated as consopitum with the adverb r(a|di/was.
peri\ dei/lhn h)/dh o)yi/an. The afternoon is either prwi+/a or o)yi/a. In iv. 69 and 103 peri\ dei/lhn alone = p. d. prwi+/an. Xen. An. ii. 2, 14, a)mfi\ dei/lhn is opposed to o)ye/.
