ta\s a)po\ k.t.l. The article does not in sense go immediately with pe/nte kai\ penth/konta. Certain ships were expected from Peloponncsus and Sicily; this the article implies: the numeral states in what number the expected ships came, not the expected number.
tw=n te . . . is answered by ai(/ te e)k . . .
*sikeliwtw=n ‘belonging to the Siceliots (Sicilian Grecks),’ who are subsequently dcfined by *surakosi/wn, *selinou/ntiai.

a(\s pareskeua/zonto These thirty-three do not represent any previously specified number. In c. 3, § 2, the Peloponnesian ships to be built for the general conduct of the war were twenty-five from Lacedaemon, fifteen from Corinth, and sixty from other Peloponnesian states combined. In c. 6, § 4, the Lacedaemonians vote to send forty ships to Chios. In c. 7 it is the thirty-nine at Corinth which are to go. In c. 8, § 2, the allies met at Corinth and decided to send these thirty-nine in
two halves, and the Laconian five under Chalcideus. But circumstances would alter the actual despatch of ships, and a hard and fast forty would not be adhered to. Thus of the twenty at Peiraeum four sail with Astyochus, sixteen are left at Cenchreae, and of these six come afterwards, c. 23, § 5. Five ships of the promised forty had sailed under Chalcideus and Alcibiades. It is not for Thucydides to be constantly telling us of any change in the Peloponnesian programme. Calculation will show that ai( e)k *peloponnh/sou number now 4 + 6 + 5 + 33 = 48. Even though eight more were sent than the promised forty, Thucydides might easily speak of these ships in general as ‘those which (I have said) the P. were preparing.’

*le/ron . . . th
 pro\ *milh/tou nh=son So Vat. Nothing is known of such a name as (/eleos, which appears in most MSS., though there were several small islands about the entrance to the Latmian gulf. th
 pro\ *milh/tou is not strictly applicable to Leros in the sense in which c. 24, § 2, *oi)noussw=n tw=n pro\ *xi/ou nh/swn is correct; for Leros is nearly forty miles from Miletus, and is not so much in front of that town as of the Halicarnassean peninsula. Nevertheless, by admitting some slight ignorance or laxity on Thucydides' part, the difficulty is not felt to be great. As Arnold points ont, in c. 27, § 1, a)po\ th=s *le/rou e)pu/qeto ta\ tw=n new=n safw=s points to Leros being the island in question, and it is almost impossible that the ships can have come much closer to Miletus without being observed by the Athenians. Moreover, the Peloponnesians immediately sail up the Iasic gulf instead of going on to Miletus, and it is opposite the Iasic gulf that Leros lies. Again, Leros was a colony and dependency of Miletus (as is gathered from inscriptions and from Strabo, p. 635; cf. Hdt. v. 125), and this fact would account for the Pel. fleet choosing it for a temporary station. The Athenians get word that the Peloponnesians are ‘all but come’; this implies that they are not yet within such distance as to be visible. If Leros had been of more importance the addition of the words th
 pro\ *milh/tou nh=son would have been unnecessary. In the same case Thucydides' geography might have been more exact.
*)iasiko\n. Coins give but one *s (as in *l*a*r*i*s*a), though MSS. vary. Iasius sinus, Pliny, v. 31.

e)s *teixiou=ssan, a distance of ten miles S.E. from Miletus.
periidei=n a)poteixisqei=san Goodwin (M. and T. (old edit.) § 24, note 2) says ‘the aor. part. seems to express merely a momentary action, the time being the same that the aor.
infin. would denote if it were used in its place.’ Rather perhaps the aorist participle gives a vivid realisation or anticipation of the thing as if accomplished, while the present pictures it as being done. In a literal rendering such an expression as ‘do not neglect us having been destroyed (diafqare/ntas)’ differs much logically from ‘do not neglect us in the act of being destroyed (diafqeirome/nous)’; but the substitution of the former expression in the sense of the latter is only the result of nimble imagination. It = ‘do not let the time come when we shall have been destroyed without intervention by you.’
e)/mellon bohqh/sein, sc. by sailing round.

u(pomei/nantas Cf. iv. 30, tw=n stratiwtw=n a)nagkasqe/ntwn . . . prosi/sxontas a)ristopoiei=sqai. Herwerden and others would write u(pomei/nantes, comparing c. 104, § 4, e)peigome/nwn tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn . . . u(persxo/ntes . . . a)poklh=|sai. The objective and subjective constructions appear to be both possible Greek. See Shilleto on i. 136. u(pomei/nantas=‘that their men, their side, should, etc.’

dianaumaxei=n There are twenty Athenian ships at Lade blockading. Under Phrynichus and his colleagues forty-eight ships have come (including transports, however). On the other side fifty-five ships have jnst arrived, and a fleet of twenty-five had gone into Miletus (c. 17, § 1, cf. c. 28, § 1). The Athenians are therefore at a disadvantage.

o(/pou ga\r e)/cestin k.t.l. Jowett says ‘the simplest way of explaining this passage is to suppose that e)/cestin is forgotten in consequence of the length of the sentence and has been repeated in e)/stai.’ But this will not account for the change ei)do/tas . . . paraskeuasame/nois. Rather take from pro\s o(po/sas to a)gwni/sasqai as so-called indirect question after ei)do/tas, and understand a)gwni/sasqai with e)/cestin as well as with e)/stai Thus ei)do/tas is part of the acc. and infin. (Jelf, § 673) construction with e)/cestin, the infin. being a)gwni/sasqai implied; while paraskeuasame/nois (au)toi=s) is part of the dat. and infin. construction with e)/stai (= e)/cestai), with the infin. a)gwni/sasqai expressed. Literally ‘but where it is possible that men should (fight) at a later time, with a clear knowledge against how many ships of the enemy, and with how many of their own to meet them, they will be in a position to fight after adequate and leisurely preparation . . .’ Any slight awkwardness in this expression is to be attributed to Thucydides. Otherwise expressed it = ‘knowing how many ships they have
to meet, and how many they can manage to meet them with, if duly prepared.’ Jowett's rendering is not to be obtained from the text even with his own view of e)/stai.
o(/pou causal; cf. c. 96, § 2. o(/pou refers to this particular, and not to a general, case. Otherwise o(/pou a)\n e)ch=|.

a)gwni/sasqai After this word Vat. has o(/poi te bou/lontai. P-S reads o(po/te, the te being difficult. But o(/poi is defensible by construction praegnans, ‘shifting the scene of action to any place they choose’ (cf. poi, § 3), and te may answer to the previous thought, ‘to fight after due preparation and (shifting the scene to) anywhere they choose,’ i.e. = o(/pou e)n u(ste/rw| i(kanw=s paraskeuasame/nois, o(/poi te bou/lontai, e)/cestin a)gwni/sasqai.

tw=| ai)sxrw=| o)nei/dei Kruger and P-S eject o)nei/dei. Cl. follows and compares to\ ai)sxro/n, ii. 42, v. 105, vi. 11. The omission of o)/neidos elsewhere would not in any case be proof of its omission here. In ii. 42 to\ me
 ai)sxro
 tou= lo/gou is not far removed. Editors do not seem to have noticed that in the other instances to\ ai)sxro
 is real disgrace involved (cf. tw=| ai)sxrw=| below), while here special emphasis is laid upon the ai)sxro
 being only supposititious. Indeed o)nei/dei is said with emphasis, ‘mere reproach of disgrace.’ tw=| ai)sxrw=| ei)/cas should mean ‘yielding to the disgrace which the retreat involved’ (this is in contradiction to the next sentence): tw=| ai)sxrw=| o)nei/dei = ‘to the argument about disgrace’ (which they were urging). For ai)sxrw=| active (= ‘disgracing’) cf. Hom. Il. vi. 325, nei/kessen . . . ai)sxroi=s e)pe/essin.
nautikw=|, after u(poxwrh=sai, ‘to give way to a naval force.’ The union of the word with *)aqhnai/ous is significant: the sea was the Athenian element.

meta\ kairou= . . . meq' o(touou=n tro/pou The antithetical effort rather disarranges the sentence. ‘But there would be the deepest dishonour under any circumstances in a defeat’ (J.) kai\ emphasises o(touou=n. meta\ tro/pou instead of tro/pw| for the antithesis.

ai)/sxion For the comparative opposed to the positive ai)sxro/n cf. ii. 40, to\ pe/nesqai ou)x o(mologei=n tini ai)sxro/n, a)lla\ mh\ diafeu/gein e)/rgw| ai)/sxion. Here ai)/sxion is probably an adverb. ‘It is not disgraceful for Athenians to retire before a navy amid proper circumstances, but it will be a more disgraceful event (no matter what the circumstances) if we are defeated.’

peripi/ptein P-S and Cl. give ka)\n for kai\ in order to obtain a future sense. But Phrynichus said h( po/lis peripi/ptei by an imaginary realisation of the result. ‘Our country is entangling itself in . . .’ These words cannot be joined to cumbh/sesqai, inasmuch as mh\ mo/non (not ou)) would be required.

h(=| . . . e)nde/xesqai the oblique of h(=| e)nde/xetai. The more common construction would have been h(\n . . . prote/ran, like the accus. in i. 124, and elsewhere in Thucydides. The dat. here and Xen. Hiero, iv. 9, and Dem. (?) 859 (50).

h)\ pa/nu ge a)na/gkh| an afterthought qualification. The sense is clear but the expression lax. ‘Our country, after its mishaps, can hardly (even with secure preparation) voluntarily — or at least only under absolute compulsion — take the initiative.’ With kaq' e(kousi/an and e)nde/xetai the qualification comes in illogically, so far as its grammatical position is concerned. The obvious meaning, however, is ‘our state is hardly in a position, even after proper preparation, to take the initiative of its own accord—at any rate only absolute compulsion should drive it to such a step.’
mh\ biazome/nh| ge (‘and without the said preparation’) implied.
w(s d' e)/peise, kai\ e)/drase. Cf. c. 1 (fin.), c. 8 (fin.).

e)s . . . kate/sth Cf. c. 70, § 1, kaqista/menoi e)s th\n a)rxh/n; c. 28, § 5, e)s th\n *mi/lhton *fi/lippon kaqista=sin. ‘In all other positions of responsibility into which he was brought.’ The double ou)k goes thus, ou) — ma=llon, and ou)k e)s tou=to mo/non:
‘and quite as much in after times as on the present occasion did Phrynichus win credit for the possession of good sense,—I do not mean only as regards this matter, but in regard to all other responsible positions into which he was brought.’ The first e)s = ‘in regard to,’ while the second has this force and also another with kate/sth, and = e)s tosau=ta a)/lla e)s o(/sa kate/sth. For the fact cf. c. 68, § 3.
a)telei= th=| ni/kh|, circumstantial dative, Jelf, § 603.
kai\ pro\s o)rgh\n th=s cumfora=s equally adverbial with kata\ ta/xos. It replaces o)rgizo/menoi th=| cumfora=|.
pro\s o)rgh\n also in ii. 65, Dem. 1251, etc. For the genitive with o)rgh\ cf. Aesch. Ag. 70, a)pu/rwn i(erw=n o)rga/s, and in Latin Livy xx. i. 2, ob iram interfecti domini.
e)pikata/gontai, ‘come to land after (the Athenians have sailed).’ Cf. iii. 49, u(ste/ra au)th=s e)pikata/getai.
ta\s *xi/as nau=s In c. 17, § 3, Chalcideus and Alcibiades, with five Peloponnesian ships manned by Chians and twenty Chian ships, are pursued by the Athenians.
cugkatadiwxqei/sas. cug- belongs pleonastically to meta\, unless we prefer to take it ‘which had been pursued to port in a body.’ But cf. c. 24, § 5, meta\ pollw=n e)/mellon cugkinduneu/sein.

ta\ skeu/h a(\ e)cei/lonto the aorist for our pluperfect, as usual in relative clauses. The middle is regular in this meaning: cf. c. 90, § 5, e)cairei=sqai, and contrast e)nti/qesqai; c. 31, § 4, e)sbalo/menoi. Arnold explains ta\ skeu/h as the masts, sails, and tackling which were an impediment in fighting. He quotesXen. Hell. i. 1, 13, *)alkibia/dhs d' ei)pw\n kai\ tou/tois diw/kein au)to\n e)celome/nois ta\ mega/la i(sti/a, au)to\s e)/pleusen ei)s *pa/rion, and vi. 2, 27.
*)/iason, covering at this time a small island, which has since joined the mainland.
katei=xe ‘was in occupation.’ Intrans. Cf. iv. 32, o(/soi peri\ *pu/lon katei=xon; Xen. Hell. i. 3, 21, e)pei\ de\ pa/nth oi( pole/mioi katei=xon.
kai\ ou) prosdexome/nwn (sc. tw=n e)n *)ia/sw|). kai\ joins this to ai)fni/dioi as another reason of their success.
e)ph|ne/qhsan Cf. ii. 25, prw=tos tw=n kata\ to\n po/lemon e)ph|ne/qh e)n *spa/rth|.
*pissou/qnou . . . basile/ws, bracketed by Herwerden and P-S. Cf. c. 5, § 5.
w(/sper au)tw=| prose/tacen sc. c. 5, § 5.
palaio/plouton. Strabo (xiv. p. 658) speaks of its fisheries. For the word cf. a)rxaio/ploutos, neo/ploutos.
tou\s peri\ to\n *)amo/rghn, v. Liddell and Scott, peri\ C. I. 2. So a)mfi\. Hdt. viii. 25, oi( de\ a)mfi\ *ce/rcea (of an army).
cune/tacan sc. sfi/sin au)toi=s, from sfa=s au)tou\s above.
to\ po/lisma i.e. the material structure of h( po/lis, ‘the town.’
w(=n not dependent on e(/kaston, but the gen. of exchange or price, ‘for whom, per head . . .’ Xen. Cyr. iii. 1, 37, mhde\n au)tw=n kataqei/s.

stath=ra *dareiko\n the gold stater said to be named after Darius. Harpoeration says it was worth twenty silver drachmae Attic (= 16s. 2d.) So in Xen. An. i. 7, 18, 3000 daries = ten talents. The epithet is necessary unless the context implies the Persian coin. In iv. 52, stath=ras *fwkai/+tas. Another stater was the *kuzikhno/s.
e)s . . . kaqista=sin, ‘appoint him to Miletus,’ sc. a)/rxonta, on the analogy of kaqista/nai tina\ e)s a)rxh/n (Lys. 120 [5]).

au)tou= P-S writes au)toi\ on the ground that e)s t. *m. au)to/se or e)n th=| *m. au)tou= would be right, and any other combination wrong. au)toi\ is then their act as opposed to the appointment of Pedaritus made by the Lacedaemonians at home. But the Peloponnesians at Miletus despatch Pedaritus by land to Erythrae, while on the spot they make P. governor in Miletus. The supposed difficulty of au)tou= is removed by taking kaqista=sin e)s as a conventional phrase for to ‘put in charge of,’ implying not motion but investiture. au)tou= refers to their own position while they act, not to the position into which P. is to be placed, i.e. au/tou= belongs to o( kaqista/s, not to o( kaqista/menos. ‘There, at Miletus, they appoint to Miletus.’

katesth/sato e)s fulakh/n. Herwerden and Stahl omit e)s, and compare c. 62, § 3, *shsto\n kaqi/stato frou/rion kai\ fulakh\n tou= panto\s *(ellhspo/ntou. But for what reason is Iasus a suitable fulakh\ in the sense in which Sestos is so on the Hellespont? And could the important genitive corresponding to *(ellhspo/ntou be dispensed with? The natural sense is similar
to that of c. 1, § 3, e)s a)sfa/leian poei=sqai; Isoc. 107 (123), ei)s a)sfa/leian kaqista/nai. The middle is sufficiently defended either by the self-interest of the action, or by the meaning ‘he got it (or ‘had it’) put under garrison.’
w(/sper u(pe/sth c. 5, § 5, u(pisxnei=to trofh\n pare/cein (the rate is not specified).

e)s draxmh\n ‘to the amount of.’ So frequently with numerals. The preposition has its force. Tissaphernes pays maintenance per ship and not per man (pa/sais tai=s nausi\ die/dwken), and this amounts to (e)s), and is intended at the rate of, a drachma each man. A Greek ship's complement is 200 men (seeXen. Hell. i. 5, 5, tria/konta mna=s e(ka/sth| nhi\ tou= mhno\s dido/nai, which is stated after wards to be a triw/bolon per day per head; and cf. iii. 17, where a drachma per day is the pay of each one of the crew, with vi. 8, where sixty talents are a month's pay for sixty ships).

*)attikh\n as distinguished from the Aeginetan (*ai)ginai/a, v. 47), which was worth about half as much again. It is not stated, but implied, that the pay is daily pay. Cf. the passages quoted in the last note.

tou= de\ loipou= k.t.l. We learn later (c. 45, § 2) that Alcibiades instigated him to this course. The present place proves that the (partitive) genitive is not (as opposed to to\n loipo\n) confined to negative sentences: ‘When he paid them in the future.’

paradou=nai . . . cumple/wn; rather a harsh instance of the infinitive of purpose. Yet cf. i. 128, a)fiknei=tai tw=| me
 lo/gw| e)pi\ to
 *(ellhniko
 po/lemon, tw=| de\ e)/rgw| ta\ pro\s basile/a pra/gmata pra/ssein, where Shilleto comments on the looseness; i. 50, pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous e)tra/ponto foneu/ein ma=llon h)\ zwgrei=n; Soph. O. C. 12, manqa/nein ga h(/komen. o(/mws de\. de\ is resumptive after the parenthesis, as in vii. 33, sxedo
 ga/r ti h)/dh pa=sa h( *sikeli/a plh
 *)akraganti/nwn — ou(=toi d' ou)de\ meq' e(te/rwn h)=san — oi( d' a)/lloi k.t.l.

para\ pe/nte mna=s . . . e)di/dou tou= mhno/s A very vexed passage. The MSS. give para\ pe/nte nau=s and e)s ga\r pe/nte nau=s kai\ penth/konta tri/a (om. Vat.) ta/lanta e)di/dou tou= mhno/s. Taking the MS. reading, Jowett renders ‘for every five ships,’ and supposes a disarrangement of expression, due to a lack of clear distinction in Thucydides' mind, the words para\ pe/nte nau=s properly belonging to the next sentence. Before arriving at this view it should have been asked whether para\ pe/nte nau=s
can mean ‘for every five ships.’ There is no authority for para\ = a)na\ or kata\ in this sense. para\ pe/nte nau=s must mean either (1) ‘in alternate sets of five ships’ (which makes no manner of sense), or (2) ‘within five ships,’ i.e. within five ships more or less of a given number. Madvig, taking the second view, altered tri/a to tria/konta. This would mean, as Jowett puts it, ‘nevertheless it was agreed that more than three obols, by five ships, should be given to eaeh man. For fifty-five ships, thirty talents a month were given,’ i.e. a count of five ships was thrown in, and the payment of three obols per man was calculated on sixty ships instead of fifty-five, and the whole divided between the fifty-five crews. Thus each man would receive, by a remarkably unbusinesslike arrangement, the remarkably unmanageable sum of 33/11 obols. It is elear that, if tri/a is not altered to tria/konta, pe/nte must be read without kai\ penth/konta. Next it should be noted that the position of the words requires us to render simply ‘more than three obols was agreed upon.’ How mueh more? A little more? or somewhat more? I venture to write, in the first sentence, mna=s for nau=s, and in the second e)s ga\r pe/nte nau=s pe/nte mnw=n de/onta tri/a ta/lanta k.t.l. Translate ‘yet an agreement was made for an increase on three obols (a head) to the extent of five minae (per ship). For to five ships he offered per month three talents minus five minae,’ i.e. he gave per ship 21,000 obols = 3 obols x 200 (the crew) x 30 (the days) + 5 minae (= 3000 obols). ‘The basis of his arrangement,’ says Thucydides, ‘was two talents fifty-five minae (= 105,000 obols) per five ships.’ According to this arrangement eaeh man gets just three and a half obols instead of three, and each five ships could be paid in the very handy sum (to a Persian) of exactly 875 Daric staters. para\ pe/nte mna=s thus gives the measure of ple/on and stands in the right position for so doing. The sense ‘by the extent of five minae for each ship’ is implied in the previous die/dwke pa/sais tai=s nausi/, and by natural procedure.

w(mologh/qhsan The plural is determined by the neighbouring trei=s o)boloi\, though the true subject is ple/on h)\ trei=s o)boloi/. The expression is not equivalent to o)boloi\ plei=n: h)\ trei=s, inasmuch as the excess is only a fraction. The plurality of the obols rather than the singular of the aggregate sum determines the number of the verb.

toi=s . . . *)aqhnai/ois. Grammatically the dative depends on prosafigme/nai h)=san. Jowett's opinion that it depends on some such intended expression as e)/docen e)formei=n, with the construction subsequently changed, is disproved by
such instances as i. 72 (init.), tw=n de\ *)aqhnai/wn e)/tuxe ga\r presbei/a pro/teron e)n th=| *lakedai/moni peri\ a)/llwn parou=sa, kai\ w(s h)/|sqonto tw=n lo/gwn e)/docen au)toi=s k.t.l., where Shilleto renders ‘as there was an embassy . . . so, etc.’ Cf. i. 115, tw=n de\ *sami/wn h)=san ga/r tines oi(\ ou)x u(pe/menon a)ll' e)/fugon ei)s th\n h)/peiron. cunqe/menoi k.t.l. Nor is such syntax confined to Thucydides; cf. Hdt. ix. 109, th=| de\ kakw=s ga\r e)/dee gene/sqai, ei)=pe k.t.l. ga\r in such sentences takes the force of e)pei\, as so commonly in a)lla\ . . . ga\r: ‘During the following winter, as the Athenians had received reinforcements, they were of a mind, etc.’ (= e)pei\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois prosafigme/nai h)=san . . ., e)bou/lonto). Accepting this idiom as sufficiently common, we find the chief difficulty in the kai\ before ta\s a)po\ *xi/ou. The passage quoted from i. 72 is almost precisely similar, but Shilleto's rendering cannot disguise the fact that it is anacoluthic. Here kai\ cunagago/ntes is written as if the previous clause had run oi( *)aqhnai=oi prosafigme/nas e)/xontes k.t.l., ‘having reinforcements and having gathered . . .’ But kai\ oi)/koqen also helps and answers to kai\ ta\s a)po\ *xi/ou, the words kai\ strathgoi\ . . . *eu)kth/mwn being parenthetical (as the otherwise impossible omission of nau=s with ta\s a)po\ *xi/ou shows). The whole literally = ‘as there had arrived additional ships from home to the number of thirty-five (Charminus, etc., being in command of them), and having collected those from Chios and all the rest . . .’ [No alteration of the passage should be attempted by a critic familiar with Thucydides, but, if logical ease is desired at the expense of other considerations, it might be most natural to emend ga\r h)=san to parh=san, which would make the sentence normal by the smallest possible change.]
strathgoi\ The Athenians had no special term for admirals as distinguished from land-officers.
*strombixi/dhs If this is the same as the *s. of c. 15, § 1, and c. 17, we have not been told when or why he left the blockading forces at Lade for Athens.
ta\s a)po\ *xi/ou which had been making descents on Chios under Leon and Diomedon, c. 24, § 2.
ta\s a)/llas pa/sas e.g. from Lesbos, c. 24, § 2.

diaklhrwsa/menoi a sortitio for the division of labour or sphere of operation. Kruger compares vi. 42, tri/a me/rh nei/mantes e(\n e(ka/stw| e)klh/rwsan, and vi. 62, du/o me/rh poh/santes kai\ laxw\n e(ka/teros.
tw=n e)s *mi/lhton e)lqo/ntwn x. o(., c. 25, § 1.
laxo/ntes Cf. diaklhrwsa/menoi, sup. § 1.

oi( d' a)/lloi viz. Phrynichus, Scironides (c. 25, § 1), and Charminus (c. 30, § 1), who are all called strathgoi/. Thrasycles (c. 17, § 3), Diomedon (c. 19, § 2), and Leon (c. 23, § 1) are not directly called strathgoi/ by Thucydides. Including these, however, there would be six chief officers remaining, as against three sent to Chios. This distribution would be in fair proportion to the respective forces.

e)pi/ploun e)poiou=nto ‘proceeded to make descent upon.’ Kruger's e)pi/plous gives a different force to e)poiou=nto. [The accuracy of Thucydides in details may be gathered from his enumeration of these ships. In c. 15 there are eight ships under Strombichides and twelve under Thrasycles. In c. 19 Diomedon arrives with sixteen ships, in c. 23 Leon with ten more. In c. 25 there come forty-eight ships including transports. In c. 30 these are all collected and thirty-five more ships arrive from Athens. The total with no deductions should be 8+12+16+10+35+48 (including o(plitagwgoi/), i.e. 129. Here we find 104 ships and some transports. The difference of twenty-five is to be aceounted for by the o(plitagwgoi/, and by the number required to take back the 1500 Argives (c. 27, fin.)].
to/t', ‘as above stated,’ viz. c. 24, § 6.
dia\ th\n prodosi/an i.e. the threatened treachery (ibid.)
ta\s *peloponnhsi/wn de/ka sc. the four under himself from Erythrae (c. 24, § 6), and the six which had come from Cenchreae to Chios (c. 23, § 5). (Arnold.)
a)noiki/zesqai. So i. 7, a)nw|kisme/noi ei)si/ (‘have their towns inland’). Cf. i. 58. In c. 23, § 6, the opposite faction have retired to Daphnus: the state of things is to be reversed.

prosxwrei=n The subject is tou\s *klazomeni/ous to be understood from au)tw=n. Cf c. 23 (fin.) The order is given to the Clazomenians generally (1) that those among them who favour the Athenians shall be removed inland to Daphnus, (2) that Clazomenae shall come over to the Peloponnesians.
*tamw\s mentioned by Xenophon, An. i. 2, 21 (P-S).

prosbolh
. This of Cobet is a necessity. e)sbolh
 of MSS. ‘neither means attack nor takes the dative.’ The words ou)/sh| a)teixi/stw| might indeed make ‘an inroad,’ ‘a dash into,’ a
possible thing to do. But this use (of a city) requires parallels, and ou) duna/menos e(lei=n makes it still more unlikely. Cf. c. 35, § 3, prosbalo/ntes th=| po/lei a)teixi/stw| ou)/sh| o)li/gou ei)=lon. The second objection is still stronger, e)sba/llein e)s being the regular form of expression, and the dative not found. In iv. 25 all MSS. give pro\s th
 po/lin e)se/ballon for prose/ballon, and in ii. 79 the variants prose/ballon, e)se/ballon show, what indeed scarcely requires showing, the proneness of MSS. to confusion in regard to these prepositions.
oi)/sh| a)teixi/stw| See inf. c. 35, § 3 (note).

u(pece/keito = u(pecete/qeito, ‘had been stored away there for safe keeping.’ Cf. a)poti/qesqai, a)pokei=sqai. u(ro- implies something of secrecy. Cf. i. 137, kai\ e)c *)/argous a(\ (sc. xrh/mata) u(pece/keito; iv. 123, u(pekkomi/zei. The word is passive of u(pekti/qemai (middle); cf. i. 89, diekomi/zonto o(/qen u(pece/qento pai=das.
e)sbalo/menoi Cf. e)cei/lonto, c. 28, § 1.
au)=qis, as they had done in c. 22.
to/te, viz. c. 28, § 5.

u(ph=rxon ‘he had ready to his hand also soldiers left behind by Chalcideus to the number of 500.’ In c. 17, § 1, Chalcideus had turned the sailors of his five ships into hoplites. He thus left an average of 100 nau=tai out of each ship. The rest of the plhrw/mata he apparently took with him.

prosfe/rei . . . to
 lo/gon. lo/gous prosfe/rein is the regular Thucydidean expression (i. 57, ii. 70, iii. 4); lo/gon in iii. 109. The article is omitted here by all but Vat., but it looks back to the first sentence of this chapter: ‘he suggests to P. the above (or the said) proposal,’ which had been rejected by the Corinthians, etc. sfa=s. sfei=s would be expected, and Bekker, like Cobet, would regularly alter to the nominative, as in vi. 49, ma/list' a)
 sfa=s perigene/sqai (in orat. obl.) Cobet, Var. Lect. p. 456, adds vii. 21. How little reliance is to be placed on the evidence of MSS. is shown in Dem. De F. L. 384, where all other MSS. give sfa=s for the correct sfei=s preserved in Par. *s. Inf. c. 76, § 4, sfei=s is correctly given with the infinitive. Nevertheless it is safer, despite one's doubts, not to wholly displace this objective construction (which is good with au(to
, etc.) from good Greek writers. Though not idiomatic, it was
apparently not contrary to the genius of the language. See Shilleto on i. 136, § 5.

ta\s nau=s . . . tw=n *xi/wn Pedaritus could apparently make this refusal. He was appointed governor of Chios by the Lacedaemonians (c. 28, § 5) and had, in regard to Chios, some independence of the nanarch.
ta/s te tw=n *korinqi/wn pe/nte, ‘the Corinthian ships, which were five in number.’ These form part of the ten ships of c. 31, § 1.
*lakwnika\s i.e. three of the four ships which had come with him from Cenchreae (c. 23, § 1) were Laconian. The other may have been the Hermionian.
pro\s th\n nauarxi/an to take up his position as Lord High Admiral at the chief seat of action.
*kwru/kw|, v. c. 14, § 1.
oi( a)po\ th=s *sa/mou c. 30 (ad fin.)

kai\ au)toi\ e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera lo/fou diei/rgonto kai\ kaqwrmi/santo So the MSS. with no variation. Jowett says ‘two disparate ideas are here united by kai\ before kaqwrmi/santo. “The Athenians were only separated from the Peloponnesians by being on the other side of the hill, and” (or as we should say “when”) “they put in, and neither had been observed by the other.”’ With e(k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera lo/fou he understands o)/ntes. This does not, however, seem the most natural view. The text may be analysed thus: kai\ au)toi\ is put as if the sense e)kei=se prosbalo/ntes e)k tou= e)pi\ q. l. e)nhuli/santo were to follow; and that sense does follow in a different form, diei/rgonto kai\ kaqwrmi/santo. ‘They too . . .’ then, instead of ‘put in there,’ Thucydides, antieipating the fact of the reciprocal ignoranee of the parties, writes ‘were separated by the intervening ridge, and (so separated) came to anchor there.’ diei/rgonto, ‘were separated (and invisible while approaching from the east),’ kai\ kaqwrmi/santo, ‘and (so) came to anchor.’ In e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera lo/fou, ‘on the opposite side of the ridge,’ the article belongs to lo/fou, which word is not dependent on e)pi\ qa/tera: otherwise tou= lo/fou would be required. The nearer side of a lo/fos is o( e)pi\ ta/de lo/fos (cf. summus mons, adversum pectus, etc.), the far side is o( e)p' e)kei=na (or e)pi\ qa/tera) lo/fos. The words e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera lo/fou are to be combined with the compound diei/rgonto - kai\ - kaqwrmi/santo, ‘were separated and came to anchor on (lit. ‘from the direction
of’) the opposite side of the ridge.’ The sense stated by Dukas, kaqwrmi/santo kai\ au)toi\ e)n tw=| au)tw=| *kwru/kw| e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera u(po\ parempi/ptontos dieirgo/menoi lo/fou, is that of the text, though the grammatical construction is different.

para\ tosou=ton . . . mh\ peripesei=n. The mh\ is not essential. Cf. Isoc. 388 E, para\ mikro\n h)=lqen a)poqanei=n. Yet as compared with c. 76, § 4, par' e)la/xiston h)=lqe . . . a)fele/sqai, it may be noted that in the present place the subject desires not to do the thing which he comes very near doing, while there the subject desires to do the thing.
peripesei=n not peritsxei=n. The Athenians had thirty ships and a force of hoplites, and were at an advantage.
diapleu/sas . . . a)nazhth/santes, a reversal of the usual order of the sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros.

a(/pan . . . profasisqe/n ‘finding the whole matter had been a piece of trickery in order to get the men's deliverance from Samos,’ i.e. they had pretended to be ready to act as traitors and had thus managed to get let off. Join swthri/a| e)k th=s *sa/mou, as in vii. 70, th=s e)s th\n patri/da swthri/as (P-S).

e)k tou= *kwru/kou periple/ousa kat' *)argi=non. kat' *)argi=non might be taken with either periple/ousa or e)pitugxa/nei. The former seems the better. Translate ‘while, sailing from Corycus, they were turning the point of Arginum,’ i.e. e)k tou= *k. ple/ousa kai\ kat' *)argi=non periple/ousa. The paraple/ousa of P-S is not a good suggestion, since it is the sudden turning (peri-) which brings them upon the Chian ships. Jowett strangely renders ‘sailing round Corycus from their station on the south side of it and making for the promontory of Arginus.’ But it is clear from what follows that the Chian ships were in the waters running north and south between Chios and the mainland. The Athenian ships, coming from Corycus, sail suddenly upon them from the south-east round the promontory of Arginum.

kai\ w(/sper ei)=xon i)do/ntes e)pedi/wkon This appears the most satisfactory reading to be gathered from the discrepant MSS. ‘They joined in the pursuit just as they happened to be (situated) when they first caught sight of them’, or, ‘and when they caught sight of them, they joined in the pursuit straightway.’ The Athenian ships did not start in pursuit all together, nor in a systematic way, but as quickly as each could from the place at which, as it rounded the point, it sighted the
enemy. e)pedi/wkon is better than the simple verb; some began to pursue after others, to join in the chase.
diafqei/rontai ‘are wrecked.’
e)kpi/ptousi = e)kba/llontai, e)coke/llontai, ‘are cast ashore.’ So eicere. Cf. ii. 92, w(s h( nau=s diefqei/reto, e)/sfacen e)auto\n kai\ e)ce/pesen e)s to\n *naupakti/wn lime/na.
tw=| *mi/manti a ridge, whose greatest height is about 1100 feet, in the northern part of the Erythraean peninsula. Mentioned by Homer, Od. iii. 172.
*foinikou=nta a small bay in the gulf of Erythrae, close to the north side of that eity; Livy, xxxvi. 45.

to\n teixismo/n the anticipatory article; cf. c. 11, § 1. The reference is to the fortification in Chios (at Delphinium) mentioned inf. c. 38, § 2. Though this intended fortification has not been mentioned before, yet in c. 30, § 1 this particular force is, to operate upon Chios, and a teixismo/s of the sort at Deceleia was a natural proceeding. e)piteixismo\n would be more definite (vii. 18, i. 142). ‘They began to make preparations for their post of occupation.’

*qouri/ais. Thurii was a lately founded and very mixed colony of Magna Graecia. In vii. 33 (B.C. 413) Thurii is divided into two factions, for and against Athens. The latter faction was expelled. The position must have been subsequently reversed.

*dwrieu\s a Rhodian mentioned as Olympian victor (iii. 8). Cf. Xen. Hell. i. 5, 19, *dwrie/a o)/nta me\n *(ro/dion pa/lai de\ fuga/da e)c *)aqhnw=n kai\ *(ro/dou u(p' *)aqhnai/wn kateyhfisme/nwn au)tou= qa/naton k.t.l. He had retired to Thurii, Pausan. vi. 7, 2.,
*kni/don a city of the Dorian Hexapolis. In ii. 9, among allies of Athens at the beginning of the war are *dwrih=s *karsi\ pro/soikoi, who include *kni/dos.

a)feisth/kei u(po\ *tissafe/rnous The MSS. give a)po\, but Palmer's emendation is certain. If Cnidus had revolted from Tissaphernes, that would be precisely the reason why these ships should not go there, unless to attack it The point of h)/dh is that the place wanted no further bringing over by the Peloponnesians. They are commissioned to guard it. a)po\ for u(po\ was, in the circumstances of the quasi-passive, a natural error. Indeed, the confusion is common enough (cf. c. 107, §
1). The construction is as with teqnew/twn u(po\ (c. 38, § 3), a)ni/stasqai u(po\ (i. 8), plhga\s e)/laben u(po\ (v. 50), etc.
peri\ *trio/pion ou)/sas, i.e. cruising about it.

*trio/pion Cape Krio, the promontory north of the city (Hdt. i. 174). It is said below to be *)apo/llwnos i(ero/n. So Scylax (fourth century B.C.) calls it a)krwth/rion i(ero/n. Cf. Hdt. i. 144, tou= *triopi/ou *)apo/llwnos.
ta\s a)p' *ai)gu/ptou i.e. the ships bringing corn-supplies to Athens. Triopium is the point which they would leave to cross the Aegean after a coasting voyage from Egypt.

prosballou/sas attributive (despite its position) rather than ‘as they put in.’ Cf. c. 36, § 1, the position of diarpasqe/nta; vii. 23, ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai. This position is common in all good Greek where there is a defining participle which is itself accompanied by further specification. Madvig, Gr. Synt. § 9 a, Rem. 1.
e)/ti, anticipating the contrary state of things in c. 46, § 5.
diarpasqe/nta For the position of the attributive see on prosballou/sas, c. 35, § 2.
u(ph=n, ‘was there to their hand.’ Cf. u(ph=rxon, c. 32, § 2, and dia\ to\ u(pei=nai e)lpi/da, vi. 87.
proqu/mws . . . e)/feron the opposite of xalepw=s or bare/ws fe/rein. ‘Were zealous in the conduct of the war.’ ta\ tou= pole/mou like ta\ th=s o)rgh=s, ii. 60.
ou) pro\s sfw=n ma=llon = h(=sson pro\s sfw=n (sc. than in the interests of Tissaphernes).

e)/ti *qhrame/nous paro/ntos i.e. before he returned to Sparta. He was only sent to bring out the fleet (c. 26, § 1; c. 29, § 2), and set out to return, c. 38, § 1. The treaty is called his treaty in c. 43, § 3, and c. 52. He is here looked upon as a kind of direct representative of Sparta, with some authority apart from the nauarch.

e)poi/oun not intended for e)poiou=nto. e)poiou=nto cunqh/kas would = cuneti/qento, but e)poi/oun c. = ‘they constructed another set of agreements.’ The subsequent adoption of them is implied. In v. 76, sponda\s poh/santes pro\s tou\s *l. kai\ cummaxi/an, the
meaning is ‘bringing about,’ since it is used of a party seeking to engage the whole. So v. 32 and 38. In ii. 15, e(orth\n poiou=si, Shilleto renders ‘appoint.’
tou\s pai=das tou\s basile/ws. Artaxerxes and Cyrus (Xen. Anab. i. 1, 1).
kata/lusin, sc. tou= pole/mou.

e)n th=| basile/ws xw/ra| h)\ o(/shs a)/rxei. A comprehensive phrase, probably without real distinction, but intended to guard against a breach of the contract on the part of Persia, which might occur where an empire was extensive and adherence loose. Some outlying dependency of Persia might assail the Peloponnesians, and they wish to force the king's hand, leaving him no excuse for not assisting. Persia must either assist or declare that the attacking state is no part of its empire. Grote (c. lxi. note) supposed the former part of the expression to mean the continent of Asia, and the latter ‘as much as the satraps should find it convenient to lay hands upon of that which had belonged to Darius Hystaspes and Xerxes.’

a)fani/zetai, ‘is lost to sight’ = ‘is never seen again.’ The tense of a)pople/wn (not a)popleu/sas) should be noted. Of unexplained disappearance also iv. 80, h)fa/nisa/n te au)tou\s kai\ ou)dei\s h)/|sqeto o(/tw| tro/pw| e(/kastos diefqa/rh. In more definite circumstances Xen. Hell. i. 6, 33, *kallikrati/das e)mbalou/shs th=s new\s a)popesw\n ei)s th\n qa/lattan h)fani/sqh.
*delfi/nion. Captured by the Lacedaemonians in Xen. Hell. i. 5, 15 (B.C. 407). The modern Delfino marks the site at about seven miles north of the city of Chios.

a)/llws=‘in any case.’ te . . . kai\ give the resources of position, ‘a place both strong in any case on the land side, and also possessed of harbours.’ The second kai\ adds the further advantage of nearness. For a)/llws cf. Aesch. Cho. 680, e)pei/per a)/llws, w)= ce/n', ei)s *)/argos ki/eis.
pollai=s. In c. 24, § 3, three battles are specified, after which oi( *xi=oi ou)ke/ti e)pech=|san.
kai\ . . . teqnew/twn, kai\ . . . katexome/nhs, two reasons of a similar nature for the suspicious state of parties.
e)p' a)ttikismw=|, ‘on the ground of Atticising’; cf. feu/gein e)f' ai(/mati and similar phrases.

e)s o)li/gon katexome/nhs The scholiast explains by a)nagkazome/nhs o)ligarxei=sqai. Dobree's e)s o)li/gous (after the pattern of v. 81, e)s o)li/gous ma=llon kate/sthsan; ii. 37, dia\ to\ mh\ e)s o)li/gous a)ll' e)s ple/onas oi)kei=n; and cf. inf. c. 53, § 3, etc.) is unnecessary.

katexome/nhs = ‘being kept down,’ e)s o)li/gon, ‘till it resulted in (into the condition of) a narrow corporation’ (lit. ‘small dimensions’). th=s a)/llhs po/lews is either the ‘body politic in general’ (by a sufficiently familiar use of a)/llos), or ‘the rest of the city’ (when Tydeus and his party had been executed). The former is the better, ‘and in general public affairs being so far under domination as to result in an oligarchical government.’
dia\ tau=ta probably belongs only to au)toi\, the reason why the e)pi/kouroi are not a)cio/maxoi being their general character and not this particular jealousy of parties.
e)pi/kouroi In c. 28, § 5, to\ par' *)amo/rgou e)pikouriko\n was sent with Pedaritus.
au)toi=s, sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois. Ethic. Cf. vii. 19, etc.

e)pei\ de\ mh\ a)ntana/goien. mh\ as in ii. 15, o(po/te mh/ ti dei/seian, and inf. c. 53, § 3, o(po/te de\ mh\ fai=en, the frequentative optative (general condition) representing a set of hypothetical circumstances. ‘And whenever they refused to come out against them,’ implying that they always did so refuse. Of a)ntana/gein (though not of a)na/gesqai) Thucyd. uses either the middle (i. 117, iv. 13) or the active (as here) in this sense.
a)naxwrou=ntes Gender ad sensum, and iterative imperfect tense: for a)nexw/roun kai\ h(su/xazon.
tw=| *farnaba/zw|, v. c. 6, § 1; c. 8, § 1.
cumbou/lous. Arnold compares similar advisers sent by Sparta, ii. 85, iii. 76, v. 63 (where there are ten).
*)arkesila/ou So v. 50, *li/xas o( *)arkesila/ou. Probably this is Thucydides' genitive of *)arkesi/las (the proper Spartan form for *)arkesi/laos).
*kle/arxon to\n *(ramfi/ou Cf. c. 8, § 2.
kaqista/nai sc. nau/arxon or e)s th\n nauarxi/an.
a)po\ *male/as pela/giai, i.e. not paraple/ousai, but ‘straight across the open Aegean.’ Cf. c. 10, § 2, u(ph=gon e)s to\ pe/lagos. The distance to Melos is about sixty miles.
*mh/lw| which had come into the hands of the Athenians amid cruel circumstances (v. 116), and had been re-colonised by them.
ta\s trei=s Cf. ta\s o)ktw\, c. 15, § 1.

plei/w to
 plou=n dia\ fulakh=s pohsa/menoi Jowett renders ‘they took the precaution of going by a longer route.’ This rather represents dia\ fulakh/n. Dale has ‘having made their journey longer by taking this precaution.’ This would require tau/ths th=s fulakh=s or a different turn of expression, e.g. tau=ta fulasso/menoi. Rather, as Dukas, e)pimhku/nantes th
 o(do
 fulatto/menoi pantaxh=, ‘having made their voyage longer in a state of watchfulness.’ Cf. i. 17, di' a)sfalei/as w)/|koun; iv. 30, a)ristopoiei=sqai dia\ profulakh=s; vii. 8, ta\ kata\ to\ strato/pedon dia\ fulakh=s ma=llon e)/xwn.
*kau=non th=s *)asi/as This place did not yet, as it did later, belong to Rhodes. th=s *)asi/as implies that it was not within the Hellenic fringe. It was ‘Asiatic.’
e)pi\ ta\s . . . ‘to fetch the . . .’

tou= cumparakomisqh=nai ‘so that they might be convoyed to join them,’ or ‘so that they might be convoyed along (the coast) to Miletus.’ With the latter force of para- cf. vi. 44, parekomi/zonto th\n *)itali/an. For the construction cf. c. 14, § 1, tou= mh\ e)ca/ggeltoi gene/sqai.

kai\ mia=| ge po/lei k.t.l. kai\ is corrective, ‘and indeed . . .,’ ‘nay.’ The statement should perhaps be taken relatively, i e. most slaves in proportion to the population. Grote refers to Athenaeus vi. 265, where Theopompus (circ. 333 B.C.) is quoted as saying *xi=oi prw=toi tw=n *(ellh/nwn meta\ *qettalou\s kai\ *lakedaimoni/ous e)xrh/santo dou/lois, with the difference that *xi=oi barba/rous ke/kthntai tou\s oi)ke/tas kai\ timh\n au)tw=n kataba/llontes.
xalepwte/rws kolazo/menoi ‘being punished more severely.’ Cf. iii. 46, xalepw=s timwrei=sqai. xalepw/teron would suggest ‘with more difficulty.’

teixizome/nou . . . prosperiballome/nou. The two genitives absolute give two reasons of a slightly different nature for his immediate assistance, (1) the opportunity: Delphinium is only being fortified and is yet incomplete, so that it can be taken; (2) the danger: a wall of greater proportions is being still farther built round, after the completion of which it will be almost impossible to take the place.
th\n to/te sc. c. 33, § 1.
kai\ tou\s cumma/xous the Corinthians, Siceliots, and other contingents (c. 26, § 1).
w(/rmhto ‘was minded.’ Cf. c. 11, § 3; c. 23, § 1.
a)sfalw=s, etc., i.e. he did not wish to begin by creating a prejudice against himself in their minds.

a)fei\s to\ e)s th\n *xi/on ‘abandoning the expedition to Chios.’ We should not supply plei=n, nor indeed any Greek word. Thucydides might have written to\ th=s *xi/ou, ‘the matter of Chios’; but, as the matter was an expedition thither, e)s th\n *xi/on takes the place of the genitive.

*kw=n th
 *meropi/da, which lay directly in his way. As the scholiast says, th
 *m. is superfluous, as no other Cos is known. Cos, now Stancho (e)s ta
 *kw=). The name is a contraction of *ko/ws and is declined accordingly (*kw=, gen. § 3). Merops was a legendary king of the island.
a)tei/xiston ou)=san c. 31, § 3; c. 35, § 3.

th
 xw/ran . . . lei/an e)poei=to = e)lehla/tei th
 xw/ran. Hdt. iv. 202, tou\s loipou\s tw=n *barkai/wn lhi/hn e)ke/leuse qe/sqai. Cf. inf. c. 62, § 2, a)ndra/poda a(rpagh
 pohsa/menos. From the next words, th
 xw/ran obviously includes the inhabitants.
a)nagka/zetai u(po\ . . . parainou/ntwn, i.e. they importuned him till he could not refuse.
prospleou/sas either (1) ‘as they were sailing up,’ or (2) attributive (despite its position) as in c. 35, § 2, prosballou/sas; c. 36, § 1, diarpasqe/nta.

e)k th=s *mh/lou. They learned of the expedition from the ships which had escaped at Melos (c. 39, § 3), but they would not therefore naturally look for it about Rhodes. The fact that they did so look is explained by the following words, h)/dh ga\r h)|sqa/neto k.t.l.
peri\ th\n . . . kai\ peri\ th\n . . . The first three places form one terminus (hence also the one article only) and Lycia the other. From Chalce to the coast of Lycia is about 100 miles.
*su/mhn kai\ *xa/lkhn islands near to, and N. and W.N.W. respectively of, Rhodes. The latter was also called *xalkei/a, which fact suggests the accentuation *xalkh=n.
e)pe/plei, ‘sailed on.’ For another meaning see c. 39, § 1.
pri\n e)/kpustos gene/sqai rather represents ‘priusquam hostes cognoscerent’ than ‘priusquam cognoverunt.’
ta\ e)k tou= ou)ranou= cunne/fela o)/nta ‘the foggy state of the atmosphere.’

a)peklh/|onto, ‘they found themselves being surrounded (and cut off).’ This defeat of Charminus forms matter for a jest in Arist. Thesm. 803 (B.C. 411-410), *nausima/xhs me/n g' h(/ttwn e)sti\n *xarmi=nos: dh=la de\ ta)/rga.
*(alikarnasso/n, the chief city of Caria. It was evidently now friendly to Athens.
pa/sais, originally seventy-four in number (c. 30, § 2), but now reduced to sixty-eight through losses at Syme (c. 42, § 4).

ou)d' e)kei=noi e)p' e)kei/nous A parenthetical clause without strict grammar, for ou)d' e). e)p' e)k. w(/rmhsan or ou)d' e)kei/nwn e)p' e)kei/nous o)rmhsa/ntwn. It would be easy, but not desirable, to suggest w)s ou)d' e)kei=noi k.t.l. On e)kei=nos as the emphatic pronoun v. c. 12, § 2. ‘Nor they against them.’
ta\ skeu/h v. note on c. 28, § 1.
*lwru/mois from ta\ *lw/ruma. Livy xxx. vii. 17, 8, portus adversus Rhodum est. It is on the south side of the Carian promontory which ends in Cape Cynossema.

a(/pasai . . . ai( tw=n *p. nh=es. The history of the Peloponnesian fleet engaged on the coast of Asia Minor is as follows—five ships under Chalcideus and Alcibiades go to Chios (c. 14). [In c. 16 Chalcideus is operating with a fleet of twentythree ships from Chios and his own. In c. 17 Chalcideus mans his five Peloponnesian ships and twenty others from Chios and operates upon Miletus. These Chian ships are not to be counted.] In c. 23 Astyochus arrives with four ships, and six more Peloponnesian ships come immediately afterwards. There are thus fifteen Peloponnesian ships in those waters. In c. 26 there come to Miletus thirty-three ships from Peloponnesus and twentytwo from Sicily. In c. 33 there are thus collected at Miletus forty-eight Pelop. and twenty-two Sicilian ships. In c. 35, Hippocrates brings twelve ships to Cnidus, six of which are
captured by the Athenians. In c. 39, Antisthenes brings twenty-seven more, and in c. 42 the Peloponnesians lose three and have others disabled. All the forces under Astyochus, reckoning no Chian vessels, amount therefore to 48+22+(126) + 27 - 3 = 100. But inf. c. 44, § 2, there are ninety-four ships at Rhodes. The difference may be accounted for by disablements, or by supposing that five of the ships, being manned by Chians (c. 17), had returned to Chios. In any case the great accuracy of Thucydides is again demonstrated. Meanwhile the Athenian fleet at Samos consists of sixtyeight ships, and their other fleet, acting npon Chios, of twentyseven (three having been wrecked, c. 34). The whole naval forces of the two parties are therefore so far almost exactly equal. But there is also a Chian fleet on the Peloponnesian side. Hence in c. 52 the Lacedaemonians are said to have ‘the more’ ships, and in c. 53, § 2, ‘as many’ (ou)k e)la/ssosi).
polemh/setai the classical passive future (i. 68). Cf. timh/somai, w)felh/somai, etc.
o( *li/xas, cf. c. 39, § 2.
h)=rcan ‘had obtained empire over.’

e)nei=nai The reading of all the MSS. but one is e)nh=n. That one gives e)xrh=n. I have written Bekker's e)nei=nai in the text, though without confidence that it is correct. In meaning and construction it is open to no objection, but there seems no easy way of accounting for its corruption, least of all into e)xrh=n. e)nh=n could only be an explanatory remark of Thucydides himself, not of Lichas, and the construction would be e)/fh deino\n ei)=nai . . . (e)nh=n ga\r . . .) kai\ tou\s *lak. a)\n periqei=nai. This is approved by Classen; but it is awkward, and the explanatory remark especially, containing the opprobrious douleu/ein, is instmctively felt to be an argument of Lichas. Thucydides' comment would rather be h)=rcan ga\r nh/swn a)pa/swn k.t.l. Of itself e)nei=nai is suited to a provision in a document. Cf. Dem. 487, a)kou/ete . . . o(/ti e)ntau=q' e)/ni kai\ tou\s a)ci/ous e)/xein ta\ doqe/nta. ‘For in this provision was involved a renewal of the slavery of all the islands and of Thessaly, etc.’ I feel, however, that the MS. discrepancy, as well as geographical and historical considerations, points to *qra/|khn as the true reading; and that this suffered a common fate of proper names occurring in continuous writing (cf. Xen. Hell. i. 5, 15, where all MSS. give h)io/na for *te/wn). *q is commonly confounded with *e through shape, and AI with E through pronunciation. The passage of *q*r*e*k*h*n to *e*x*r*h*n is, therefore, not so difficult as it might seem.
‘For,’ he said, ‘by this treaty Thrace and all the islands and Thessaly, etc. (which were once reduced by Xerxes) are again in slavery.’

a)nt' e)leuqeri/as The reference is to the Lacedaemonian argument that it was Sparta's mission to free Hellas from slavery to Athens. See iv. 86 (a speech of Brasidas), and cf. inf. c. 46, § 3. In *mhdikh\n *(/ellhsi there is a strong antithesis.
e(te/ras, ‘a different set’ (not ‘a second’). The Lacedaemonian demands grow with their strength on the Asiatic coast.
th=s trofh=s ‘they did not want his maintenance-allowance on any such terms.’
di' o)rgh=s = o)rgizo/menos. Cf. dia\ fulakh=s, c. 39, § 3.

e)pikhrukeuome/nwn. Either (1) impersonal passive, ‘proposals being made to them’: cf. i. 116, e)saggelqe/ntwn o(/ti ai( nh=es ple/ousi, where, however, Shilleto should be seen, and where the passive is not the passive of a deponent (for which passives see Jelf, § 386); or (2) understand tinw=n: cf. i. 3, e)pagome/nwn (sc. tinw=n) au)tou\s e)s ta\s a)/llas po/leis; Dem. 332, ou)k a)peilou/ntwn ou)k e)paggellome/nwn ou)damw=s e)gw\ prode/dwka. The second manner is probably the better. To separate a)ndrw=n from dunatwta/twn and make it the subject of the participle (with Dobree) seems out of the question.
tw=n dunatwta/twn the leaders of the oligarchical party. Cf. c. 21.
nh=so/n te ‘the te placed as if h(gou/menoi were not to follow’ (P-S).
tre/fein ta\s nau=s so tre/fein to\ nautiko/n, Xen. Hell. iv. 8, 9.

*kami/rw|. The city of Rhodes was not built till three years later than this, and Lindus, Ialysus, and Camirus (three cities of the Dorian Hexapolis) were of almost equal importance. Hence the expression tri/polis na=sos. The exact position of Camirus was long uncertain. Kiepert's maps place it on the middle of the west coast, but in Mr. Cecil Torr's Rhodes in Ancient Times it is put considerably nearer to Ialysus. Rhodes had been obliged to contribute to Athens a contingent against Sicily (vii. 57). Dorieus, an exiled Rhodian, is now serving in the Peloponnesian fleet.
te/ssarsi kai\ e)nenh/konta see note c. 43, § 2, a(/pasai k.t.l.
kai\ e)/feugon a change of subject where there is no ambiguity.

toi=n duoi=n pole/oin ‘the two’ cities which they would have to deal with now that Camirus was in their hands; the remaining two. The article implies that the fact and the cities were well known. Hdt. (i. 144) mentions them in the order *li/ndos kai\ *)ih/luso/s te kai\ *ka/miros. Lindus is on the east coast and Ialysus on the north-west.
pela/gioi, cf. c. 39, § 3 (note).
du/o kai\ tria/konta ta/lanta, i.e. at the rate of a talent for every three ships.
a)nasth=nai, ‘changed their quarters.’ Cf. i. 87, a)nasth/tw e)s e)kei=no to\ xwri/on. Enr. Heracl 59, etc.

w(/st' a)poktei=nai, h)=n ga k.t.l. Plutarch, Alc. 24, o( d' *)=agis e)xqro\s me
 u(ph=rxen au)tw=| dia\ th
 gunai=ka kakw=s peponqw/s, h)/xqeto de\ kai\ th=| do/ch: . . . tw=n d' a)/llwn *spartiatw=n oi( dunatw/tatoi kai\ filotimo/tatoi to
 *)alk. h)/dh e)baru/nonto dia\ fqo/non. i)/sxusan ou)=n kai\ diepra/canto tou\s oi)/koqen a)/rxontas e)pistei=lai pro\s *)iwni/an, o(/pws a)poktei/nwsin au)to/n.
h)=n ga\r kai\ . . . kai\ . . . The first kai\ is placed as if merely a predicative adjective were to accompany the second kai\: ‘as if e)fai/neto were not to follow’ (P-S).
e)ka/kou ta\ pra/gmata, ‘injured their cause’; though still, as Plutarch puts it, tw=n pra/cewn pasw=n e)koinw/nei toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.

dida/skalos pa/ntwn gigno/menos i.e. gradually working himself into that position. According to Plutarch (loc. cit.) Tissaphernes, though a thorough mise/llhn, kakoh/qhs and filopo/nhros, was shrewd enough.
th/n te misqofora\n. te is answered by kai\ tou\s trihra/rxous k.t.l.
a)nti\ draxmh=s *)attikh=s v. c. 29. The present chapter clearly goes back to the time of that chapter, though nothing is said there about the influence of Alcibiades.
e)k ple/onos xro/nou than the Lacedaemonians.

triw/bolon The ordinary pay was on occasion largely
increased. In vi. 8 it is a drachma. Cf. iii. 17; Hell. i. 5, 5. For Stahl's fancy that kai\ tau=t' ou) cunexw=s has fallen out before dido/asin see note on u(polipo/ntes (inf.)

xei/rw e)/xwsi Cobet's xei=ron (Nov. Lect. p. 270) is one of those ‘corrections’ based on prepossessed notions which make that acute and tasteful scholar's work rather dangerous reading. Cf. iii. 82, ai( po/leis a)mei/nous ta\s gnw/mas e)/xousi. Because kakw=s, eu)= to\ sw=ma e)/xein are said (e.g. Plat. Gorg. 464 A), it does not follow that we are never to say kako\n, kalo\n to\ sw=ma e)/xein, any more than it follows that, because of e.g. sw/matos eu)= e)/xein, we are always to write the genitive.

h( a)sqe/neia the article (which Cobet lightly excises) is not merely the generic article with abstracts. It represents ‘the said (prejudicial) weakness,’ a previous mention of this a)sqe/neia being implied in xei/rw.

a)polei/pwsin u(polipo/ntes k.t.l. Vat. has ou)x u(polipo/ntes, and there are other traces of this reading. For the general text a)polei/pwsin a)polipo/ntes it is clear that the two compounds in a)po- cannot stand together, whereas u(polipo/ntes gives the appropriate sense of leaving in pledge. In settling the reading it must first be noticed that the sailors are said to do one of two things e)k periousi/as u(bri/zontes. The two forms of u(/bris consist in (1) debilitating indulgence, (2) desertion, through contempt of such sums as may be due to them when they leave the ships. This at least seems the most reasonable sense to extract. If we take the readings with and without ou)x, their meaning is as follows:— (1) With ou)x: ‘some of them desert their ships through not leaving behind them as a pledge (of their return) their arrears of pay.’ In this case we should have to understand that, besides giving only three obols a day, the Athenians did not pay the men regularly. This course, so far as the Athenians are concerned, has been neither stated nor implied: it has only formed part of the course recommended to Tissaphernes. Polyaen. Strateg iii. 9, 51 (quoted by Bloomfield), says that Iphicrates every month kept back a fourth part w(/sper e)ne/xuron e(ka/stou kate/xwn, i(/na mh\ li/poien to\ strato/pedon. But this would rather show that such a course was unusual, as indeed it would be likely to be among a people like the Athenians. (2) Without ou)x. In this case we can render (a) ‘desert their ships, leaving behind them as a pledge their arrears of pay,’ i.e. having been allowed holiday or furlough when their pay was in arrears (the said pay being a pledge to ensure their return) they would e)k periousi/as not mind forfeiting those
arrears, and so would not return. This would make perfect sense with the context, if only some adverb accompanied u(polipo/ntes in the meaning a)melw=s or o)ligw/rws; such an adverb, however, is not indispensable: or (b) the mh\ which precedes oi( me\n . . . oi( de\ . . . may be considered, relatively to this clause, as misplaced, i.e. as if it were i(/na oi( me\n mh\ . . . oi( de\ mh\ a)polei/pwsin, u(polipo/ntes k.t.l., ‘and others, through leaving their arrears of pay behind them, might not be induced to desert,’ i.e. mh\ a)polei/pwsi dia\ to\ u(polipei=n k.t.l. This rendering, however, is distinctly unnatural, interrupts the logical balance of the clauses, and makes the same large implication as in view (1). Further see crit. note.

e)s o(mhrei/an. e)s follows u(polipo/ntes from the sense lipo/ntes kai\ u(poqe/ntes which is involved in that participle. u(polipo/ntes implies lipo/ntes w(s u(poqh/khn. For o(mhrei/a cf. Plat. Pol. 310 E, o(mhreiw=n e)kdo/seis (concrete = ‘pledges’), and Polyb. ix. 11, 4, ei)s o(mhrei/an dou=nai.

to\n prosofeilo/menon Classen's prou)feilo/menon is not required, nor is that of Leonclave in Xen. Hell. i. 5, 7, in a similar context, where all MSS. give pros-. The meaning is ‘the wages due over and above that which is already paid’— ‘still owing.’ Cf. vii. 48, disxi/lia ta/lanta h)/dh a)nhlwke/nai kai\ e)/ti polla\ prosofei/lein (where obviously pro- is out of the question).
trihra/rxous, commanders of single ships.
strathgou\s single or joint commanders of contingents.
tw=n po/lewn the various states allied with Sparta.

e)di/dasken w(/ste . . . pei=sai, w)/ste Vat. omits the second w(/ste. Apart from the cacophony, there is no objection to either w)/ste. As regards nsage w(/ste is often joined to pei/qein, but apparently not elsewhere to dida/skein. There is possible, however, an obvious distinction; e)di/dasken w(/ste (pei=sai), ‘he tutored him till (a certain result followed),’ e)di/daske (pei=sai), ‘he recommended him to (adopt a certain course).’ The context shows that he succeeded in bribing all but the Syracusan commanders. Literally rendered the passage amounts to ‘and in regard to the trierarchs and generals of the various states Alcibiades tutored him till he worked upon them by bribery, till they gave in to him, etc.’ Of the two occurrences of w(/ste the former is perhaps the more awkward.
tau=ta viz. the reduction of the rate of payment.
ta/s te po/leis k.t.l. te introduces a new point of Alcibiades' action. deome/nas, ‘when they asked for . . .’

oi( me
 *xi=oi . . ., answered by ta\s d' a)/llas . . . a)nai/sxuntoi ei)=en . . . o)/ntes . . . a)ciou=si This is probably what Thucydides wrote, though it would be easy to read ei)=en ei) with Ba<*>er and Cobet, or ei)sin ei) with Kruger, or a)naisxuntoi=en ei) with Madvig. a)ciou=ntes would have been the true grammar, but the introduction of the clause by d' o(/mws and the intervening participle sw|zo/menoi have corrupted the construction. Less sudden changes from the participle to the finite verb occur in e.g. vii. 13 and 15. A somewhat similar instance to the present, though easier, is i. 132, mhnuth\s gi/gnetai, dei/sas . . . kai\ parapohsa/menos sfragi=da . . . lu/ei . . . (where lu/sas should have been written). ‘The Chians were shameless, being the richest of the Greeks, but they nevertheless demanded, etc.’ The change is, I think, analogous to one which is so familiar in relative sentences, e.g. Plat. Rep. 357 B, ai( h(donai\ o(/sai a)blabei=s kai\ mhde
 ei)s to
 e)/peita xro/non dia\ tau/tas gi/gnetai a)/llo h)\ xai/rein e)/xonta (for kai\ di' a(\s mhde
 k.t.l)
ei)=en . . . a)ciou=si For the change of mood cf. c. 50, § 1, gnou\s o(/ti e)/soito lo/gos kai\ o(/ti *)aqhnai=oi e)nde/contai.
e)kei/nwn emphatic for sfw=n. See c. 12, § 2 for the emphasis of e)kei=nos, and cf. c. 43, § 1.
e)s *)aqhnai/ous a)nh/loun, ‘paid money into the Athenian treasury.’

a)pe/faine . . . feido/menon . . . a)podw/sein. Cf. ii. 13, a)pe/faine d' e)/xon to\ a)/galma tessara/konta ta/lanta staqmo\n xrusi/ou a)pe/fqou kai\ periaireto\n ei)=nai a(/pan. Here feido/menon represents a fact and a)podw/sein an assertion.

komi/santa h)\ nau=s *foini/ssas, as if h)\ *(/ellhnas plei/ous were to follow. The expression, however, is varied, and strictly h)\ should in consequence have been transposed before komi/santa. We learn more of these Phoenician ships (147 in number) in c. 87. Phoenicia came into the Persian empire under Cambyses (circ. 529 B.C.) and remained more or less loosely attached till the conquest by Alexander. The Phoenician was the most important contingent at the battle of Lade (B.C. 494), and played a large part at Salamis (B.C. 480).
*(/ellhsi ple/osi i.e. not to make the Peloponnesian force on the Asiatic coast too large.

toi=s au)toi=s te gh=s k.t.l. By joining a Phoenician fleet to the Peloponnesian the enemies of Athens would sweep her fleets from the sea. The Peloponnesians would thus become masters not only of their natural element, the land (for the Lacedaemonians were held to be superior in that department), but also on the sea (where the Athenians were superior). toi=s au)toi=s, se. the Lacedaemonians. It was better policy to leave both sides (a)mfote/rous) in possession of their respective superiorities.

tou\s au)tw=| luphrou\s This reading seems necessary in place of the au)tou= or au)tou\s of MSS. Cf. vi. 18, toi=s e)kei= e)xqroi=s luphroi/. Bohme quotes as some defence of the nounuse Xen. Hell. v. 2, 33, toi=s u(mete/rois dusmene/si. One may add Aesch. Suppl. 376, a)/gos me\n ei)/h toi=s e)moi=s paligko/tois, and combinations like tui benevolentis (Plaut. Trin. 46). The possessive adjectives are, however, by no means complete evidence for the genitive, even with the same words; and the quality of the noun-adjective itself must be considered. Arnold's quotation, Xen. Mem. i. 5, 3, kakou=rgos tw=n a)/llwn, is much easier, and pole/mios, e)xqro/s, dusmenh/s tinos can hardly warrant luphro/s tinos. A just possible rendering of au)tou= = ‘there’ is in the circumstances hardly worth considering. The only objection to au)tw=| is that it appears rather unlikely to have been corrupted. See critical note.
th=s e)s gh=n . . . a)rxh=s, to avoid the cacophony of genitives (Hertlein). For the e)s of extension to, Kr. compares i. 6, tw=n pote kai\ e)s pa/ntas o(moi/wn diaithma/twn.
oi(=s = oi(=stisi (P-S). Another, though less probable, syntax is a)porei=n a)\n (tou/twn), oi(=s k t.l.

a)porei=n a)\n au)to\n sc. Tissaphernes, not the king. since the clause with basilei= e)cei=nai is dependent on e)a=n, of which the subject is Tissaphernes. So Tissaphernes is the au)to\s . . . e(autou= . . . au)tw=| . . . e)kei/nw| of the following passage.
a)nasta/s of standing up to fight. Cf. Il. xxiii. 635.

eu)tele/stera de\ ta/d' ei)=nai k.t.l. This emendation of Classen and Madvig (Adv. Crit. i. p. 28), though not certainly right, is at least an improvement upon the eu)tele/stera de\ ta\ deina\ of MSS. The MS. reading literally rendered is ‘the danger would be a cheaper one to run, to wear out, etc.,’ the infin. katatri=yai and its clause being in exegetical apposition to ta\ deina\, i.e eu)tele/stera de\ (ei)=nai) ta\ deina\, (sc.) katatri=yai k.t.l. Bnt ta\ deina\ is a curiously inappropriate expression to use of a case in which no danger is involved (cf. inf. meta\ th=s
e(autou= a)sfalei/as). There is still left, when the emendation is made, some tautology in eu)tele/stera and braxei= mori/w| th=s dapa/nhs, which, however, can be relieved by giving to eu)telh/s the not uncommon sense of fau=los, apart from a pecuniary aspect. ‘But, he said, this was a course which made less demand upon him, etc.’ The objection to the emendation lies in the a priori unlikelihood of ta/d' ei)=nai passing into ta\ deina\; and it may more probably be the case that *t*a*d*e*i*n*a should be redivided into ta/de, i(/na with katatri/yei (or -oi) to follow, i.e. ‘and that his proposed course would be an easier one, being a case in which he (T.) would wear out, etc.’ Copyists, either through negligence or because unfamiliar with this use of i(/na (cf. Antiphon, 142, 9, i(/na me\n e)ch=n au)toi=s . . . timwrh/sasqai . . . e)ntau=qa ou)dei\s oi(=o/s te e)ge/neto . . . e)le/gcai), would naturally divide *t*a*d*e*i*n*a as ta\ deina\; they would not all alike commit the same error with ta/d' ei)=nai.
au)tou\s peri\ e(autou\s Cf. vi. 18, tri/yesqai au)th\n peri\ e(auth/n.
koinwnou\s, i.e. with whom to divide sovereignty in regard to the Hellenic world.

to\n lo/gon te cumforw/taton kai\ to\ e)/rgon e)/xontas polemei=n Either (1) te joins this clause to the preceding, ‘and that they carried on war with a principle and a practice most agreeable to his interests’: Or (2) te is in an unusual place answering to kai\, while polemei=n = w(/ste polemei=n; ‘having both a principle and a practice for their warfare which were most agreeable to his interests.’ The former is the simpler and better, since the second clause is apparently not meant to give a reason for the assertion in the first.

lo/gon The Athenians really made no definite statement such as the Lacedaemonians did. The latter claimed to be liberators. Yet the Athenians may be said to have a lo/gos in so far as they often confessed to a selfish policy (see the Melian debate, v. 89 etc.) This being their lo/gos, their e)/rgon is an e)/rgon katadoulw/sews.
cumforw/taton sc. tw=| *tissafe/rnei.

cugkatadoulou=n the policy of Tissaphernes is one of katadou/lwsis. The Athenians would share (cug-) this policy or act similarly. The force of cug- is not so much of aid or union as of identity of procedure.

sfi/si te au)toi=s . . . kai\ e)kei/nw| . . . The meaning is generally taken to be ‘for they (the Athenians) would join (with the Persians) in enslaving on the one side the sea-element to themselves, on the other the Asiatic Greeks to him (Tissaphernes).’ But Alcibiades is not contemplating an offensive alliance between Athens and Persia, but only the best general policy of Persia, which would be to maintain in existence Athens rather than Sparta as the only other power with whom it must divide the sovereignty of the Greek world. ‘Of the two,’ says A., ‘the Athenians are those whose existence we should encourage; they (unlike the Lacedaemonians) will not seek to meddle with a continental power, and they will not have “a mission” like Sparta. Their policy and practice is to enslave.’ If the te (omitted by Vat.) is sound, and if e)kei/nw| is the right reading amid MS. discrepancies, the passage is somewhat brachylogic for ‘while enslaving the sea-element to themselves they would at the same time be enslaving to him (i.e. indirectly, letting him enslave) the Asiatic Greeks.’ Yet inasmuch as no adequate reason for the corruption of the grammatically obvious e)kei/nw| is forthcoming, we might suggest that Thucydides really wrote tou\s me
 ga cugkatadoulou=n a)
 sfi/sin au)toi=s (with Vat.) to\ th=s qala/sshs me/ros kai\ e)kei=non (sc. cugk. a)
) o(/soi e)n th=| basile/ws *(/ellhnes oi)kou=si: tou(s de\ . . ., i.e. ‘for whereas the Athenians would, like himself (cug-), be enslaving to themselves the seaelement, just as he would (or ‘while he would’) all the Greeks in the king's domains, on the other hand the Lacedaemonians, etc.’ The clause kai\ e)kei=non k.t.l. is in a manner parenthetical, and the sentence though grammatically less rotund (which indeed accounts for the corruptions) is rather the more Thucydidean.

to\ th=s qala/sshs me/ros either (1) ‘their share of the a)rxh/, to wit, the sea,’ or better (2) ‘the sea-element’ or ‘department.’ Cf. ii. 62, du/o merw=n tw=n e)s xrh=sin fanerw=n, gh=s kai\ qala/sshs, tou= e(te/rou u(mei=s panto\s kuriw/tatoi.

sfw=n tw=n *(ellh/nwn Alcibiades, the speaker, is a Greek. Hence sfw=n. In direct speech the words would run ou)k ei)ko/s e)sti *l. a)po\ me
 h(mw=n tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)leuqerou=n nu=n t. *)/el., a)po\ de\ u(mw=n k.t.l. Alcibiades does not identify himself with Athens (being now her enemy), nor does he in any way make tw=n *(ellh/nwn coextensive with the Athenians merely. ‘It was not likely that the L. were now freeing the Greeks from his own people, the Greeks, and yet would refuse to free them from them, the foreigner.’ By ‘from us Greeks’ Alcibiades means ‘from
Greeks like ourselves.’ He might have said simply a)po\ me
 *(ellh/nwn e)leuqerou=n *(/ellhnas, a)po\ de\ barba/rwn mh\ e)leuqerw=sai, or he might have said a)po\ me
 h(mw=n e)leuqerou=n *(/e., a)po\ de\ u(mw=n mh\ e)leuqerw=sai. Having said h(mw=n and u(mw=n, he gives the reason of the improbability by antithetically adding tw=n *(ellh/nwn (‘I mean the Greeks’) and tw=n barba/rwn (‘I mean the foreigner’). If either member of the antithesis should be omitted (which is improbable) it should be tw=n barba/rwn (with Vat.)

h)
 mh/ pote au)tou/s* ph e)ce/lwsi. It is hoped that this emendation will commend itself. The MS. reading h)
 mh/pote au)tou\s mh\ e)ce/lwsi is variously understood: (1) h)
 mh\ (‘unless’) mh\-e)ce/lwsi (‘they, the Lacedaemonians, fail to make away with’) au)tou/s (‘the Athenians’); i.e. the only supposable case in which the Lacedaemonians would not free the Asiatic Greeks from the Persian rule would be the case of their failure to crush the Athenians (the corollary being ‘do not, therefore, let them crush the Athenians’). For the two negatives editors quote Lycurg. 140, ei) mh\ nh\ *di/a mh\ tau)ta\ th=| patri/di kai\ tou/tois e)sti\ sumfe/ronta. This view contains an appreciable but a farfetched sense, and makes much too great a strain on au)tou\s in reference to the remote antecedent, the Athenians. (2) The subject of e)ce/lwsi being the Persians; h)
 mh/pote mh\ (rednndant) e)ce/lwsi (‘if they, the Persians, did not at some future time make away with’) au)tou\s (‘the Lacedaemonians’). This is simpler for au)tou\s, but a parallel can scarcely be found for the combination h)
 mh/pote mh\. Reading ph (p and m in cursive uncials being almost identical), the clause with pote is antithetical to nu=n. The sense is ‘and yet would not — unless the Persians at some time and in some way got them (the Lacedaemonians) out of the way — free the Greeks from them.’ The subject is to be drawn from the emphatic e)kei/nwn. For the thought cf. inf. § 4, tou\s *p. a)palla/cai e)k th=s xw/ras. For e)ce/lwsi cf. v. 43, i(/na *)argei/ous e)ce/lwsi kai\ au)=qis e)p' *)aqhnai/ous mo/nous i)/wsi. The exact words of Alcibiades would thus be a)po\ de\ u(mw=n, h)
 mh/ pote au)tou/s ph e)ce/lhte, mh\ e)leuqerw=sai.

e)leuqerw=sai for a)\n e)leuqerw=sai in a future sense. Thucydides does not use a)\n with ei)ko/s e)sti. Cf iii. 10, and v. 109, ou)k ei)ko\s e)s nh=son tou\s *l. h(mw=n naukrato/rwn o)/ntwn peraiwqh=nai. See Madvig, Gk. Synt § 172 R.
dienoei=to to\ ple/on, was disposed to do this rather than not: ‘was for the more part so disposed.’ Cf. iv. 27, w(rmhme/nous ti to\ ple/on th=| gnw/mh| strateu/ein.
dia\ tau=ta Editors do not appear to have remarked upon the tautology with the following words. Those who believe in extensive interpolations may eject w(s . . . parainou=nti.
prosqei\s e(auto\n *)alkibia/dh| k.t.l. ‘attached himself to A. and gave him his confidence.’ Cf. c. 50, § 3, prose/qhke . . . e)pi\ idi/ois ke/rdesi *tissafe/rnei e(auto/n; iii. 92.
a)lla\ kai\ . . ., answered by kai\ th\n a)kmh\n . . .
e)k perio/ntos opposed to e)c i)/sou. Cf. vii. 13, e)k pollh=s a)\n periousi/as mo/lis tou=to u(ph=rxe.
a)gwniei=sqai The subject is not that of h(/cein, but au)tou\s (the Pelop.) or sfei=s (‘their side’).
tw=| *tissafe/rnei, the dat. depends on a)/rista ei)=nai.

w)\n par' e)kei/nois Alcibiades was not literally with the king. Yet, residing with Tissaphernes at the local headquarters of the Persians, and being indirectly adviser to the king, he may be said to be living with ‘them.’
ka/qodon the noun of katelqei=n ( = kata/gesqai).

e)piqerapeu/wn ‘working for his own restoration over and above’ the other motive. e)pi- = insuper. Cf. c. 54, § 1, e)pelpi/zwn. The word occurs only here and in c. 84, § 5, where it has a different meaning.

ta\ me
 kai\ . . ., answered by to\ de\ ple/on kai\ . . . P-S compares i. 90 (init.), where the second kai\ is absent.
e)s . . . e)s Cobet, Nov. Lect. p. 347, would read pro\s. Though these prepositions, from their compendia, are frequently confused (cf c. 31, § 3), it would become necessary to alter a large number of passages if we accepted Cobet's diction Cf. i. 90, dhlou=ntes e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous; v. 45, h)
 e)s to
 dh=mon tou=to le/gwsin.
tou\s dunatwta/tous connoting oligarchical tendencies. Cf. c. 21, and c. 44, § 1.

tou\s belti/stous ‘all good men and true,’ Jowett. The term, like tou\s dunatwta/tous (‘the most influential’), is of course capable of the quite literal meaning ‘the best’ (in a general sense). From Alcibiades' point of view the connotation is, however, obviously ‘the most aristocratic.’ For the arrogant application of the term (cf. optimates, boni, e)sqloi/, kakoi/, deiloi/), like our English ‘the best people,’ Jowett compares Theog. 289—
nu=n de\ ta\ tw=n a)gaqw=n kaka\ gi/netai e)sqla\ kakoi=sin a)ndrw=n: h(gou=ntai d' e)ktrape/loisi no/mois.
Cf. c. 48, § 6, tou\s kalou\s ka)gaqou\s o)nomazome/nous.
e)p' o)ligarxi/a| ‘on condition of the existence of an oligarchy.’ Cf. vii. 82, ei)/ tis bou/letai, e)p' e)leuqeri/a| w(s sfa=s a)pie/nai.

ou) ponhri/a| ou)de\ dhmokrati/a| a kind of hendiadys. The latter term is explanatory of the former: ‘the villainous democracy,’ Jowett. ou)de\ joins such explanations in negative sentences as kai\ does in those which are positive. Poppo refers to Alcibiades' opinion of the democracy and its ‘injustice’ in vi. 89. Cf. vi. 92, fuga/s ei)mi th=s tw=n e)celasa/ntwn ponhri/as.

to\ de\ ple/on . . . trih/rarxoi The subject is narrowed since the beginning of the long sentence. The soldiers generally at Samos heard of Alcibiades' power, but it was only to the aristocratical party that he sent, and only the same party was striving of its own accord. The order of sense is e)peidh\ h)/|sqonto . . . oi( stratiw=tai, oi( trih/rarxoi/ te kai\ dunatw/tatoi w(/rmhnto e)s to\ katalu=sai to\n dh=mon, ta\ me\n kai\ *)a. prospe/myantos lo/gous, to\ de\ ple/on kai\ a)po\ sfw=n au)tw=n.
a)po\ sfw=n au)tw=n sua sponte. Cf. c. 6, § 1, a)f' e(autou=.
w(/rmhnto Cf. c. 11, § 3, w(rmhme/nwn, etc.

u(potei/nontos . . . poh/sein. Cf. Hdt. vii. 158, u(potei/nontos ta\ e)mpo/ria suneleuqerou=n; Dem. 625 (14), u(potei/nein u(posxe/seis; Arist. Ach. 657, ou) qwpeu/wn ou)d' u(potei/nwn misqou/s. This use, of suggesting hopes, is similar to that of u(poti/qhmi.

au)toi/ q' e(autoi=s These words go closely with e)lpi/das ei)=xon, while e)s e(autou\s is part of a phrase with peripoh/sein. Moreover, au)toi/ q' e(autoi=s is in contrast with kai\ tw=n polemi/wn . . . Thus we have no mere pleonasm: ‘they entertained great hopes both for themselves personally (to wit that they would get the control of affairs into their own hands), and also that they would overcome the enemy.’ There was in this new proposal a double chance (1) to get power for themselves, (2) to crush the Peloponnesians.

oi(/per kai\ talaipwrou=ntai ma/lista, the relative clause in the present tense to express a general truth. In point of position the clause might have been expected to come immediately after politw=n; but it is not merely descriptive or attributive, and is put after ta\ pra/gmata for the reason
that the antithesis is between powers and burdens: ‘they hoped to get the greatest powers just as they bore the greatest burdens.’ The greater burdens of the aristocrats are alluded to in the same terms, c. 63, § 4, e)sfe/rein e)k tw=n i)di/wn oi)/kwn proqu/mws xrh/mata, w(s ou)ke/ti a)/llois h)\ sfi/sin au)toi=s talaipwrou=ntas. The dunatoi\ are of course the rich, as oi( a)sqenei=s are the poor in Xen. Cyr. viii. 1, 30; Eur. Suppl. 434, etc.

peripoh/sein The active because of the reflexive expressed (e)s e(autou\s). Cf. Isaeus, 64, 6, pa/nta ei)s au(to\n periepo/hse. Without the reflexive the middle occurs in i. 9, du/namin peripohsa/menos; i. 15, i)sxu\n periepoh/santo. In other writers, however, the middle and reflexive are combined often enough, e.g. Xen. Anab. v. 6, 17.
cuni/stasan, ‘set about combining.’ For cunwmosi/ai and e(tairei=ai see c. 54, § 4, and cf. c. 81, § 2.

dia\ to\ eu)/poron th=s e)lpi/dos k.t.l., lit. ‘on account of the comfortableness of their expectations of such pay from the king’: ‘the attractive prospect of the promised payment.’ In other words, ‘the expectation of wages from the king made things look easy for them.’
tou= . . . misqou= ‘the promised pay,’ cf. xrh/mata pare/coi, § 2.
cunista/ntes ‘trying to establish.’
e)koi/nwsan See c. 8, § 1. The variant e)koinw/nhsan is just possible here in the sense ‘had held communication with,’ i.e. after they had tested the temper of the people.

ka)n sfi/sin au)toi=s Dobree's reading, accepted by nearly all editors, appears necessary: ‘among themselves and the greater part of the members of the club.’ The difficulty of accepting kai\ with the simple dat. commodi lies in the words kai\ tw=| ple/oni (tou= e(tairikou=). If they deliberated for, they would do so for the good of the league and not for that of a majority. For e)n cf. c. 63, § 4, e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s . . koinologou/menoi e)ske/yanto; c. 76, § 3, paraine/seis e)poiou=nto e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s; vi. 103, lo/gous e)/n te sfi/sin au)toi=s e)poiou=nto kai\ pro\s to\n *niki/an.

tou= e(tairikou= like to\ cummaxiko/n, to\ nautiko/n, etc. Cf. iii. 82. On the nature and purposes of e(tairei=ai v. c. 54, § 4. sfi/sin au)toi=s = the chief plotters, to\ e(tairiko/n = the main body of the cunwmosi/a.
e)/ti o)/nti, by an anticipation of his deposition (c. 54, § 3), like that in eu)po/rws e)/ti ei(=xon a(/panta, c. 36, § 1.
o(/ te *)alkibia/dhs . . .)(. . . basilei= te . . .
ko/smou Cf. c. 24, § 4, e)kosmou=nto e)xurw/teron; iv. 76, metasth=sai to\n ko/smon kai\ e)s dhmokrati/an tre/yai.

u(po\ tw=n e(tai/rwn paraklhqei\s ka/teisi Cobet (Var. Lect. p. 56) does not resist the temptation to erase paraklhqei\s for the sake of the idiom ka/teisin u(po\ (= kataxqh/setai u(po\), for which cf. c. 35, § 1, a)feisth/kei u(po\ *tissafe/rnous. We should, however, keep paraklhqei\s and still join u(po\ with ka/teisi. So far from being an interpolation, the participle is necessary. Alcibiades wants to be invited back (by the Athenians, u(po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn or th=s po/lews), thanks to the efforts of his friends; he does not wish to be merely allowed to return.
periopte/on from periora=sqai, not periora=n. periorw=mai of circumspection, iv. 73, 124; vi. 93, 103; vii. 33. For o(/pws mh\ with subjunctive aorist v. Goodwin, M. and T. § 364.
kai\ *peloponnhsi/wn i.e. as well as the Athenians; further expressed by o(moi/ws: ‘the P. also, quite as much as the Athenians.’
e)n th=| qala/ssh| o)/ntwn. e)n of the sphere of action or concern. Cf. Hdt. ii. 82, oi( e)n poih/si geno/menoi. Plat. Phaed. 59 A, e)n filosofi/a| ei)=nai; iii. 28, oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasi.
au)tou= ipsius. Such cities were Miletus, Erythrae, Cnidus.

ai(=s u(pesxh=sqai. Bohme's u(posxh/sesqai is accepted by P-S on the ground that nothing has yet been promised. This reason is searcely certain enough to be sufficient. The negotiations have been going on for some time, the Athenian army is at present in a cummaxi\s po/lis (Samos), and the leaders of the cunwmosi/a may well have been in communication with the leaders of the oligarchical parties in the allied states.

dh\ . . . o(/ti dh\ Each dh\ is ironical. Cf. c. 9, § 1 on lu/ein dh\, and with o(/ti dh\ cf. Plat. Phaedr. 268 D. Phrynichus would say ai(=s u(pesxh/meqa dh\ o)ligarxi/an, o(/ti dh\ kai\ au)toi\ ou) dhmokrathso/meqa: ‘to whom we have been so kindly promising oligarchical government for the laudable reason that we ourselves are no longer to be a democracy.’
sfa=s see note c. 32, § 3.
ou) boulh/sesqai . . . ma=llon h)\=h(=sson boulh/sesqai . . . h)\.

meq' o(pote/rou a)
 tu/xwsi tou/twn i.e. e)leuqe/rous ei)=nai meq' o(pote/rou a)
 tou/twn (e)leu/qeroi o)/ntes) tu/xwsi. Cf. iii. 43, pro\s o)rgh
 h(/ntin' a)
 tu/xhte . . . zhmiou=te. tu/xwsi has no part in the regimen of the genitives.

tou\s kalou\s ka)gaqou\s, see on tou\s belti/stous, c. 47, § 2. o)nomazome/nous, named so, but not proving themselves so.
