The construction is usually taken to be (e)/fh) au)tou\s (sc. the allies) nomi/zein tou\s kalou\s ka)gaqou\s k.t.l., the important words being put first, ‘and as for the so-called good and true men, etc.’ [For a different view of the whole passage see note on a)/kritoi (infra).]

porista\s o)/ntas kai\ e)shghta\s ‘providers and proposers’ of mischief, with an allusion to the technical use of the board of poristai/; cf. Ar. Ran 1505, whence Poppo quotes the scholiast's explanation oi( peri\ po/rou xrhma/twn ei)shgou/menoi. As those of money, so these of mischief, concoct the ways and means and propose them to the people. In vi. 89 Alcibiades says of certain such persons e)pi\ ta\ ponhro/tera e)ch=gon to\n dh=mon, oi(/per kai\ e)me\ e)ch/lasan.
tw=n kakw=n the mischief to which it was prone.
au)tou\s ipsos (the porista\s).

to\ e)p' e)kei/nois ei)=nai The variant e)kei/nous might also stand. Cf. iv. 28, to\ e)pi\ sfa=s ei)=nai; Eur. Or. 1345; Hec. 514, etc. Yet there is a difference of conception. to\ e)pi\ se\=‘as far as concerns you’; to\ e)pi\ soi\=‘as far as lies in your power.’ The former can therefore always be used for the latter, but not the latter always for the former. Thus in Soph. Ant. 889, h(mei=s ga\r a(gnoi\ tou)pi\ th/nde th\n ko/rhn, the dative could not be substituted.
kai\ a)/kritoi kai\ biaio/teron ‘not only without trial but also with less scruple’ = ‘more unfairly and frequently.’

a)/kritoi It is usual to admit that the accusative is the only grammatical case, the subject being the allies (au)tou\s). But, say Poppo, Jowett, etc., Thucydides writes ‘as if o(/ti nomi/zousi and not au)tou\s nomi/zein had preceded.’ This explanation can scarcely be called scientific or satisfactory. Poppo's vi. 21, § 2 is no parallel, nor is one readily to be found. In this rendering sfw=n = the subject peoples, and e)kei/nwn = the oppressive oligarchs. [One may venture to suggest another view of the passage tou/s te kalou\s . . . swfronisth/n, which will give to a)/kritoi a
proper syntax and otherwise afford a suitable sense. First, it should be noted that te, as usual, introduces a new point. Those which have preceded are (1) o(/ te *)alkibia/dhs . . . stasia/swsin, (2) basilei= te . . . poh/sasqai, (3) ta/s te cummaxi/das . . . e)leuqe/rous ei)=nai. The fourth argument should begin here. Second, the nominative a)/kritoi should refer to the speaker and his party. Third, the reference in a)/kritoi a)poqnh/|skein as applied to the allied states is not satisfactory. These difficulties would all disappear together if we rendered (in oratio recta) ‘and I think that the so-called good and true men will themselves (au)tou\s) cause us (sc. the generals and responsible persons) quite as much trouble as the people . . . and, if the matter lay with them, we should be put to death (on occasion) without trial and with less scruple, whereas the people is our refuge, and a check upon them.’ The arguments of Phrynichus then are—(1) Alcibiades is only seeking selfish ends, (2) the king is not likely to adopt any such policy, (3) the allies will not be attracted by the proposal, (4) the proposed government at Athens will not suit the interests of men like himself (Phrynichus). The only objection to this rendering, which the grammatical structure seems to render absolutely inevitable, lies in the following words, e)pistame/nas ta\s po/leis k.t.l., which at first sight appear to be so connected with ta\s cummaxi/das po/leis above that all intervening words must necessarily express the thought and knowledge of those po/leis. Such necessity, however, does not exist, for after the argument about the allies, followed by the argument about the interests of the generals, P. might well add ‘and I am quite certain that this is the opinion of the allied states.’ [I cannot, however, refrain from suggesting on other grounds, viz. the strong safw=s and au)to\s, and the general trend of the passage, that Thucydides wrote e)pistame/nous tou\s pollou\s. ‘And he said he had personally positive information (not eu)= but safw=s ei)de/nai) that this was the opinion of the great majority, who had learned the lesson from experience.’]

kai\ tau=ta par' au)tw=n tw=n e)/rgwn k.t.l. The order is kai\ tau=ta e)pist.-par' au)tw=n-tw=n-e)/rgwn safw=s au)to\s oi)=da, o(/ti ou(/tw nomi/zousin. By the unusual para\ for a)po\ the ‘facts’ (e)/rgwn) are personified as the teacher.
au)to\s either of immediate personal information, or as a subject to ei)de/nai in order to avoid the danger of ambiguity in that respect. The latter is less likely.

tw=n a)p' *)alk. kai\ e)n tw=| paro/nti prassome/nwn ‘of the
proposals of Alc. and the present negotiations.’ tw=n is not repeated because kai\ . . . prassome/nwn is merely exegetical.

oi( cullege/ntes tw=n e)n th=| cunwmosi/a|. It is agreed that cummaxi/a| of MSS. cannot be defended, and at least the sense is given by Haacke's cunwmosi/a|, about which the only difficulty lies in accounting for the corruption. In c. 39, § 2; c. 33, § 1; c 85, § 1, there are variant misreadings of naumaxi/a for nauarxi/a. If in such obvious instances a confusion of the kind could occur, a corresponding confusion of cummaxi/a| for cunarxi/a| is quite probable in one less obvious. oi( cullege/ntes tw=n e)n th=| cunarxi/a| is conceivable Greek for ‘such of the joint commanders as were assembled.’ The various a)/rxontes (trih/rarxoi, c. 47, § 2, and strathgoi/) who belonged to the plot were cu/narxoi and their command a cunarxi/a. Cf. oi( e)n te/lei, oi( e)n toi=s pra/gmasi. But Thucydides does not elsewhere use this rather artificial combination, and from c. 48, § 3, on the whole it appears to me probable that the corruption went one step further still, the original word being cunorki/a| ( = cunwmosi/a|) which passed through cunarxi/a| into cummaxi/a|.
oi( cullege/ntes tw=n k.t.l. not all the conspirators being present. Cf. c. 48, § 3, e)n tw=| ple/oni tou= e(tairikou=.

*pei/sandron of Acharnae, nicknamed o( o)noki/ndios (‘donkey driver’), and a favourite butt of the comedians as a fat coward. Arist. Av. 1556, Pac. 395, and cf. Xen. Symp. ii. 14. Suidas quotes a proverb *peisa/ndrou deilo/teros.
th=s tou= e)kei= dh/mou not th=s e)kei= tou= dh/mou. Part of the dh=mos has already been won over, viz. the part at Samos. The bulk of the dh=mos is left at Athens.
e)/soito . . . e)nde/contai. Cf. c. 51, § 2, w(s . . . me/llousin . . . kai\ pepusme/nos ei)/h; ii. 80, o(/ti . . . krath/sousi . . . kai\ . . . e)/soito.
pro\s th\n e)nanti/wsin ‘in view of the opposition shown in his own speech.’ pro\s gives the consideration prompting his fear. Cf. c. 39, § 2, pro\s ta\s e)pistola\s . . . u(pw/pteuon au)to/n.
pe/mpei . . kru/fa e)pistei/las, o(/ti. o(/ti depends a)po\ koinou= on pe/mpei and e)pistei/las Cf. a)poste/llei . . o(/ti inf. § 5.
e)/ti to/te o)/nta k t.l, i.e. he had not yet removed to Cnidus and thence to Rhodes, as in cc. 41 and 44.

cuggnw/mhn k.t.l ‘it is pardonable,’ he wrote, ‘for me to
devise mischief for an enemy, even though it involves the injury of my country.’

e)s xei=ras i)o/nta. Cf. Xen. Cyr. ii. 4, 15; Anab. i. 2, 26. The meaning is to ‘come to close quarters’ (comminus ire). The sense ‘putting himself in his power’ may be implied in a certain context, but forms no part of the expression. ‘Coming to close quarters’ may represent either close familiarity or close fighting. Here it is the former.
a)nelqw\n The nau/arxos leaves his fleet and makes a journey inland (a)n-).
e)s *magnhsi/an This was the Ionian Magnesia (h( u(pe\r *maia/ndrou), not the Lydian. It was about thirty miles from both Miletus and Samos. Themistocles had retired to this place (Diod xi. 57).
le/gei te answered by prose/qhke/ te . . . The clause kai\ . . . gi/gnetai is exegetical.
au)to\s mhnuth\s this is superior to au)toi=s m. in so far as with au)toi=s the clause is purely tautological, while with au)to\s there is some exegetical emphasis.
prose/qhke . . . e(auto\n Cf. c. 46, § 5, prosqei\s e(auto\n e)s pi/stin (*)alkibia/dh|).
koinou=sqai i.e. w(/ste koinou=sqai au)tw=| peri\ k.t.l, ‘to join interests with him both in this and in other matters.’

peri\ th=s misqofora=s . . . a)nqh/pteto Two MSS. omit peri\. But a)nqa/ptesqai/ tinos has a different meaning from that required here. Thus c. 97, § 3, a)nqa/ptesqai tw=n pragma/twn; Hdt. vii. 138, a)nta/ptesqai tou= pole/mou, etc, the meaning is to ‘take a hold upon,’ or ‘set about.’ Here it should be ‘to take a counter-grip,’ ‘to be tenacious on the other side’ (Hdt. iii. 137), i.e. to ‘resist.’ With this peri\ seems no less than necessary. Lit. ‘he was less tenacious in resisting in the matter of the incomplete payment of his troops also.’ a)nqh/pteto like a)ntei=xe, a)nte/teine, etc., with no object expressed, = a)nqi/stato.
malakwte/rws Cf. c. 29, § 2, malako\s h)=n peri\ tou= misqou=. In c. 45, § 3, Hermocrates is the only general who does resist.
pe/mpei gra/mmata . . . oi(=a k.t.l. = e)piste/llei oi(=a . . . kai\ a)ciw=n as if (le/gwn).

oi(=a de/drake kai\ a)ciw=n . . . kai\ pa/nu, with e)n tw=| meg. kind. w)\n. It is difficult to understand why some editors join kai\ pa/nu to qorubou/menos in
an unparalleled position. kai\ is simply connective (though kai\ pa/nu is of course a recognised combination, e.g. ii. 11, 51), while pa/nu intensifies the following superlative; ‘and being in the very greatest danger.’ For the position of pa/nu cf. Plat. Euthyd. 305 C, pa/nu para\ polloi=s; 305 E, pa/nu e)c ei)ko/tos lo/gou.
kalw=s i.e. as should have been expected, — in a becoming and honourable manner.
o(/ti The second o(/it = w(s after a)poste/llei, while the first =dio/ti with memfo/menos.
au)toi=s the Peloponnesians.
pra/ceie the subject is Phrynichus, not Astyochus. au)ta\ pra/ceie, sc. betray the fleet. The suppressed protasis is ‘if they were willing.’
di' e)kei/nous sc. the Peloponnesians. More emphasis is required than au)tou\s would give. It was for their sakes and not his own that he had brought himself into danger.

au)to
 diafqarh=nai ipsum: ‘rather than lose his own life.’ The antithesis of the pronoun is not e)kei/nous above, but lies in the sense implied, viz. tou=to kai\ a)/llo pa=n bla/yai th
 po/lin ma=llon h)\ au)to
 diafqarh=nai u(po\ tw=n e)xqi/stwn. The nominative au)to\s would be incorrect here, since au)to
 diafqarh=nai does not depend on the verb of saying, but is part of a clause dependent on a)nepi/fqonon ei)/h.
a)dikou=nta, ‘not acting straightforwardly.’ Cf. ou) kalw=s e)kru/fqh, c. 50, § 5. Plut. Alcib. 25 has it e)lelh/qei d' a)/ra (sc. o( *fru/nixos) prodo/ths prodo/th| dialego/menos.
e)ca/ggelos with its ordinary sense of betraying a secret to those not in it. Cf. e)caggeli/a, Xen. Cyr. ii. 4, 23; e)cagge/llein, ibid. vi. 1, 42.
me/llousin . . . pepusme/nos ei)/h Cf. c. 50, § 1.

ku/rios h)=n pra/sswn For the participle cf. v. 34, w)/ste mh/te a)/rxein mh/te priame/nous ti h)\ pwlou=ntas kuri/ous ei)=nai. One should not accept Reiske's alteration of Eur. Suppl. 1190, ou(=tos ku/rios, tu/rannos w)\n, | pa/shs u(pe\r gh=s *danaidw=n o(rkwmotw=n to -ei)=n. Lit. ‘and he was within his powers in so acting on his own authority.’ au)to\s = mo/nos = without waiting for sanction. tau=ta, sc. the measures he proposed.
e)k tou= toiou/tou, i.e. in consequence of Phrynichus' trickery and advice.
kai\ w(\s ‘already, as it was’ = ‘in any case.’ Cf. c. 56, § 3; c. 87, § 3 (kai\ ga\r w(\s au)toi=s ou)de\n e)/melle xrh/sesqai), and elsewhere. So ou)d' w(\s (i. 132), mhd' w(\s (i. 74).
me/llousa sc. teixisqh/sesqai.
e)pistolai\ the plural used of one letter. Cf. i. 132.

ta\ a)po\ tw=n polemi/wn, ‘the plans of the enemy.’ The construction is with proeidw\s, au)ta\ being understood with a)natiqe/nai. Cf. ii. 64, ou) dikai/ws, ei) mh\ kai\ o(/tan para\ lo/gon ti eu)= pra/chte, e)moi\ a)naqh/sete (sc. au)to/).
*)alkibia/dhs me\n, resumed at the end of the chapter kai\ o( me\n *)a., and answered by oi( de\ meta\ tou= *p.
pareskeu/aze with a personal object, iii. 36, pareskeu/asan tou\s e)n te/lei . . . kai) e)/peisan r(a=|on . . .
o(/pws e)/stai The verbs are verbs of striving (=e)/prassen). Goodwin, M. and T. § 339.
ple/osi nausi\ For the relative strength of the fleets see note on c. 43, § 2, a(/pasai k.t.l. The enumeration here must include the Chian contingent. Cf. c. 53, § 2, ou)k e)la/ssous.
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn=h)\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi by comparatio compendiaria. Madvig, Synt. § 90, R. 1.
peisqh=nai ‘to follow the advice’ of Alcibiades if he possibly could.

th\n e)n th=| *kni/dw| diafora\n c. 43, § 3, where Lichas objects to the existing terms and the parties separate in indignation: ‘the opposition which the Peloponnesians raised at Cnidus to the treaty of Theramenes’ (Jowett).
h)/|sqeto not=e)pu/qeto, but with diafora\n = ‘when he had seen how far he was at variance with the Peloponnesians.’

h)/dh ga\r k.t.l.—i.e. h)/dh ga\r e)gege/nhto (‘for it had taken place before the time of which we are now speaking’) e)n th=| *(ro/dw| o)/ntwn au)tw=n kata\ tou=ton to\n kairo/n (‘inasmuch as the Pelop were in Rhodes at the date before us’). h)/dh is doubtless felt with o)/ntwn as well as with e)gege/nhto. After narrating the progress of the Pelop affairs up to their inactivity in Rhodes, Thucydides in c. 45 returns to the part which had been ‘for some time back’ played by Alcibiades. During Alcibiades'
intrigues, while the Pelop. were at Miletus, Phrynichus acted as in c. 50. Afterwards the quarrel at Cnidus took place; the Pelop. went to Rhodes, and the persuasions of Alcibiades are still working upon Tissaphernes, who is now greatly affected by the quarrel above-mentioned.
to\n tou= *)alk. lo/gon viz. in c. 46, § 3.
e)phlh/qeusen transitive and causative: cf. c. 1, § 1, on e)ph/lpisan.
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn. Dobree should not have struck this out. It draws attention to the Athenian side as opposed to Tissaphernes and his relations with the Peloponnesians.
kefalaiou=ntes e)k pollw=n Cf. vi. 91, polla\ parei\s ta\ me/gista kefalaiw/sw.

*eu)molpidw=n, the priestly clan which provided the hierophants of the Eleusinian mysteries, and the e)chghtai\ of laws touching a)se/beia. They had some (though rather indefinite) judicial powers in cases of impiety, Dem. Androt. 601, Lys. 104 (10). The *kh/rukes were the other great priestly house, who actually slew the victims (Athen. xiv. 79), and are generally mentioned in association with the Eumolpidae (e.g. Pausan. i. 38).

peri\ tw=n mustikw=n Alcibiades had been charged with taking part in the mutilation of the Hermae, and with caricaturing the mysteries at a carousal. Plut. Alc. 19, e)/legon de\ *qeo/dwron me/n tina dra=n ta\ tou= kh/rukos, *pouluti/wna de\ ta\ tou= da|dou/xou, ta\ de\ tou= i(erofa/ntou to\n *)alkibia/dhn. Alcibiades was therefore charged with to\ a)sebei=n peri\ tw\ qew/. The actual terms of the ei)saggeli/a are given in Plut. Alc 22, ending with para\ ta\ no/mima kai\ ta\ kaqesthko/ta u(po/ te *eu)molpidw=n kai\ *khru/kwn kai\ tw=n i(ere/wn tw=n e)c *)eleusi=nos.
marturome/nwn kai\ e)piqeiazo/ntwn per deos obtestantibus. Cf. ii. 75, tosau=ta e)piqeia/sas. mh\ kata/gein depends on the combined sense of the participles, which are words of dissuading.
parelqw\n sc. e)pi\ to\ bh=ma.
pro\s . . . sxetliasmo\n ‘in the face of much indignant complaint.’

para/gwn ‘producens in medium,’ P-S. The causative of parelqei=n: cf. para/gein e)s me/son, Hdt. iii. 129. Used of a witness, Dem. 285 (170). Cf. iii. 68, e(/na e(/kaston paragago/ntes kai\ e)rwtw=ntes . . . o(po/te mh\ fai=en k.t.l.; v. 46, etc.
ou)k e)la/ssous Cf. ple/osi nausi\, c. 52.
a)ntiprw/|rous ‘facing them,’ i.e. in a condition and spirit ready for action.
o(po/te . . . mh\, see c. 38, § 5, e)pei\ de\ mh\ a)ntana/goien.

e)ntau=qa h)/dh In view of the following safw=s and the sense generally, this is somewhat better than dh\. He had not ventured to speak clearly before, but only to hint at some change. Now (iam) he dares to go so far as to openly propose oligarchy. Cf. iv. 35, w(s de\ e/ne/dosan, e)ntau=qa h)/dh k.t.l. Inf. c. 67, § 3, e)ntau=qa dh\ lamprw=s e)le/geto h)/dh, shows that dh\ in itself was not felt to be strong in this sense.
tou=to the desired alliance.

ei) mh\ politeu/some/n te answered by *)alkibia/dhn te kata/comen, the intervening kai\ . . . poh/somen kai\ mh\ bouleu/somen being parts of the former line of policy. Says Peisander, ‘we must form a wiser government, and we must bring back Alcibiades.’ The former item he explains or expands by the clauses with kai\. Thus ei) mh\ (1) politeu/some/n te . . . kai\ . . . poh/somen . . . kai\ mh\-bouleu/somen . . . (2) *)alk. te kata/comen.
swfrone/steron connoting oligarchy. Cf. c. 64, § 5; iii. 82, etc.
e)s o)li/gous poh/somen Cf. c. 38, § 3, th=s po/lews e)s o)li/gon katexome/nhs; ii. 37, dia\ to\ mh\ e)s o)li/gous oi)kei=n; v. 81, ta\ e)n *sikuw=ni e)s o)li/gous ma=llon kate/sthsan.
mh\ to\ ple/on peri\ . . . h)\ peri\ ‘not so much about . . . as about . . .’
e)pelpi/zwn, ‘hoping besides’ Cf. e)piqerapeu/wn, c. 47, § 1. The verb has a causal sense in c. 1, § 1, but one similar to this in Eur. Hipp. 1011.
kai\ is to be expressed by emphasis on the verb ‘that they could change.’

metabalei=tai The subject is perhaps o( dh=mos, though Dukas says h( o)ligarxi/a dhlono/ti. Cf. metaqe/sqai, c. 53, § 3; metaballome/nous, c. 90, § 1; i. 71, etc. A people is said metaba/llein to\ e)/qos (i. 123) or th\n politei/an (Aristot. Pol. iv. 5, 2), or, without the object, metaba/llesqai.
pra/ssein. The object is ta\ pro\s to\n *tissafe/rnh, which is at the same time the subject of e(/cein.

o(/ph| a)
 . . . dokoi/h . . . e(/cein The direct narration would have o(/ph| a)
 u(mi=n dokh=| a)/rista e(/cein. According to rule this should in indirect narration after a past tense either become o(/ph| dokoi/h or remain o(/ph| a)
 dokh=|. The rule, however, by a confusion has its exceptions, if MSS. are to be trusted: see Goodwin, M. and T. § 702, and § 692, and the quotations there. The present instance, owing to the discrepant readings and the facility of corruption either way, must be put down as doubtful; vii. 48, e)c w(=n a)/n tis eu)= le/gwn, diaba/lloi, where all MSS. agree, is a case somewhat easier than this. Inf. c. 68, § 1, kra/twtos e)nqumhqh=nai geno/menos kai\ a(\ [a)
] gnoi/h ei)pei=n, there is considerable evidence for the omission of a)
 (see note there) and an easy explanation of its appearance. In the present instance Thucyd. may the more easily have been led to write a)
 from a confusion between o(/ph| dokoi/h a)/rista a)
 e)/xein (put in the usual idiomatic order o(/ph| a)
 dokoi/h a)/rista e)/xein) and o(/ph| dokoi/h a)/rista e(/cein, which is its equivalent. [These instances of a)
 with relative and optative are of course to be distinguished from those in which a)
 belongs to the verb and forms an apodosis, e.g. vii. 50, diabouleu/sasqai o(/pws a)
 pro/teron kinhqei/h.]
*diome/donta kai\ *le/onta. Cf. c. 23, § 1. It appears that they had returned to Athens.
o( me\n *pei/sandros, answered by o( de\ *le/wn k.t.l., c. 55, § 1.

ta\s cunwmosi/as k.t.l. Cf. Livy, ix. 26, coitiones honorum adipiscendorum causa factae (called also factiones, sodalitates). Grote has a full note on the subject in Hist. G. pt. ii. c. lxii These caucuses and clubs are alluded to in Plat. Rep. 365 D, e)pi\ to\ lanqa/nein cunwmosi/as te kai\ e(tairei/as suna/comen, by which biaso/meqa w(s pleonektou=ntes mh\ dido/nai di/khn. Cf. Plat. Theaet. 173 D, spoudai\ e(taireiw=n e)p' a)rxa/s. They are said here to be intended ‘to control lawsuits and offices.’ An oath of such a cunwmosi/a is given in Aristot. Pol. v. 7, 19, as tw=| dh/mw| kako/nous e)/somai kai\ bouleu/sw o(/ ti a)\n e)/xw kako/n.
e)pi\ toi=s parou=sin ‘to suit the present exigcncies.’
diame/llesqai impersonal passive: ‘so that there should be no delay.’
a)neilkusme/nas. Cf. c. 44, § 4.
ma=llon h)\ e)k th=s *kw= In c. 44, § 3, the Athenians had been making their descents e)k th=s *xa/lkhs kai\ e)k th=s *kw=. Cf. c. 60, § 3.
to\ tei=xos, c. 38, § 2.
bohqh/sein For the future see on c. 2, § 1, cumproqumhqe/ntes a)palla/cesqai.
to\ . . . e)pikouriko/n, sc. to\ par' *)amo/rgou of c. 28, § 5, and cf. c. 38, § 3
th=s o(mologi/as, ‘the desired (or expected) agreement.’

e)dida/sketo, viz. c. 46, § 2. e)dedi/dakto might seem more apposite, and the translators say ‘had been taught.’ But Tissaphernes is still under the influence of Alcibiades, and though A. wishes him to favour the Athenian side rather than the Lacedaemonian, yet he recommends him to wear out the Greeks upon each other (c. 46). The imperfect is therefore sound, ‘according to the lesson he was learning from him.’

ei)=dos Cf. ii. 41, e)pi\ plei=sta ei)/dh; vi. 77, o(rw=ntes au)tou\s e)pi\ tou=to to\ ei)=dos trepome/nous. There was perhaps originally a metaphor from metamorphoses such as those of the gods, Proteus, etc.
to\ au)to\, sc. mh\ cumbh=nai.

au)to\s me
 dia\ to\ de/os, o( d' *)alkibia/dhs . . . e)bou/leto an easily intelligible laxity of expression. au/to\s me
 dia\ to\ de/os, o( d' *)alkibia/dhs dia\ to\ bou/lesqai k.t.l would be the sequence suggested by au)to\s me
 . . ., though even this of course would be a loose extension of the appositive construction (sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros). There is, in fact, a confusion of two ways of speaking, viz. (1) dokou=si/ moi o(/ te *tiss. kai\ o( *)alk. to\ au)to\ boulhqh=nai, o( me
 *t. dia\ to\ de/os, o( de\ *)a. dia\ to\ bou/lesqai k.t.l., and (2) dokei= de/ moi o( *tiss. to\ au)to\ boulhqh=nai, au)to\s me
 dia\ to\ de/os (au)to\ boulo/menos), tou= d' *)alk. . . . boulome/nou. . . .

cumbhsei/onta The MS. reading cumbasei/onta is erroneously formed. diabasei/w is the reading in Dio C. 40, 32, but diabhsei/w in Agathias, 39 D. Inf. c. 79, § 3, naumaxhsei/ontes (cf. polemhsei/w). This class of desiderative verbs is regularly formed on the sigmatic future stem (drasei/w, apallacei/w) The only defence of cumbasei/w would be that correct forms in as (gelasei/w, e)lasei/w) may have prompted incorrect analogous forms, and especially where nouns like cu/mbasis, dia/basis previously existed.

e)bou/leto k.t.l. e)bou/leto dokei=n belongs to all that follows,
but with the subject of dokei=n divided: i.e. e)bou/leto dokei=n (au)to\s) mh\ a)du/natos ei)=nai pei=sai, a)lla\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous mh\ i(kana\ dido/nai tw=| *tiss. k.t.l ‘he wanted it to seem, not that he was powerless . . ., but that the Athenians, etc.’

w)/ste to\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn . . . ai)/tion gene/sqai, ‘so that the Athenian side (or position) became responsible’ (sc. for the failure of the negotiations). Cf. iii. 59, to\ th=s cumfora=s; vii. 61, to\ th=s tu/xhs. Without to\ we must render less well ‘so that it (the failure) became the fault of the Athenians.’

nh/sous te . . . kai\ a)/lla What these other demands were we do not know. a)/lla seems somewhat bald, but is relieved by the following oi(=s ou)k e)nantioume/nwn k.t.l., ‘he demanded that all Ionia should be given up, and then the adjacent islands, as well as making other demands which the Athenians did not oppose, etc.’ The variant kai\ ta)=lla would apparently mean ‘and everything else (which appertained to Ionia and its adjacent islands)’: cf. c. 37, § 5, e)n th=| basile/ws xw/ra| h)\ o(/shs basileu\s a)/rxei, with the same vagueness. See crit. note.

th
 e(autou= gh=n The e(autw=n of some inferior MSS. is allowable for sfw=n on the ground of emphasis. But e(autw=n would imply a ridiculous demand. On the other hand it might seem a small request to make that the Persians should be allowed to use any fleet they wished along their own shore. Yet in reality the concession would be great. For the Persian king to keep as large a fleet as he chose sailing where he chose off the coast of Ionia in the Aegean, was to endanger every outlying part of the Athenian empire. Unfortunately the evidence with regard to existing agreements between Persia and Athens is contradictory and obscure. Historians are at variance as to the existence of the so-called ‘Peace of Callias’ (wrongly called ‘of Cimon’) of B.C. 445. Thucydides says nothing of the convention, but, as Grote points out (Hist. pt. ii. c. xlv.), it is clear from Thucydides himself that since the supposed date of the ‘Peace of Callias’ such a state of things had existed between Athens and Persia as would correspond to the supposed terms of the treaty. That there was an embassy of Callias to Susa is seen from Hdt. vii. 151. It is its results which are uncertain One cannot, however, suppose that all the statements of the Attic orators relating to the ‘Peace of Callias’ are based upon either imposture or mere mistake. Dem. De F. Leg. 428 has *kalli/an to
 *(ipponi/kou tau/thn th
 u(po\ pa/ntwn qruloume/nhn ei)rh/nhn presbeu/santa, i(/ppou me
 dro/mon h(me/ras pezh=| mh\ katabai/nein e)pi\ th
 qa/lattan basile/a, e)nto\s de\ *xelidoni/wn kai\ *kuane/wn ploi/w| makrw=| mh\ plei=n k.t.l.
Plutarch, Cim. 487 [13. 5], refers the convention to Cimon, but quotes Callisthenes (circ. B.C. 350) as saying that there was really no such agreement, but that merely de facto the king did keep his fleet within these limits. For the present passage we may point out (what seems to have been forgotten) that the reality of the existence of such a treaty is not here involved. It will be quite enough to suppose that in their negotiations, if not in any convention, with Persia the Athenians claimed that the king should not use a fleet on the Ionian coast. If Callias had demanded this, Tissaphernes would now seek to settle the matter before concluding an alliance. We cannot reject the consensus of ancient statement that this restriction upon the Persian navy was at least a condition insisted upon by Athens. We should not try to emend Thucydides from our preconceptions as to the ‘Peace of Callias,’ but rather correct our preconceptions of the ‘Peace of Callias’ from the hint of Thucydides. There is, however, no statement in any writer that the king was not allowed to build a fleet. Hence nau=s poei=sqai kai\ paraplei=n is correctly taken as =nau=s pohsa/menon paraplei=n. Cf. c. 15, § 1, ta\ xi/lia ta/lanta e)/lusan ta\s zhmi/as kai\ e)yhfi/santo kinei=n.

ou)ke/ti ti a)ll' a)/pora nomi/santes, i.e. ou)ke/ti ti (a)/llo) a)ll' a)/pora nomi/santes, ‘no longer thinking anything (else) but that the matter (ta\ pra/gmata) was an impracticable one.’ a)/llo is not indispensable in this idiom, cf. Soph. O. T. 1331, e)/paisen ou)/tis (sc. a)/llos) a)ll' e)gw/, though it is commonly expressed. A different way of expressing the same sense would be ou)ke/ti ti a)/ll' h)\ a)/pora nomi/santes (where a)/llo is not to be confounded with a)lla\). An alternative rendering ou)ke/ti ti (pra/ssousin), a)ll' a)/pora nomi/santes . . . komi/zontai would be difficult to support by a parallel.

e)kpepolemw=sqai. This is distinctly preferable to e)kpepolemh=sqai. The sense is ‘to be in a state of complete hostility.’ Cf. vi. 77, e)kpolemou=n pro\s a)llh/lous. The forms in -e/w are apt to eneroach on verbs of this class, which are regularly formed in -o/w (so also -a/w in e.g. e)kkwfa/w, e)kkwfo/w). In the present, polemei=sqai (i. 37), ‘to have war made upon one,’ and polemou=sqai (i. 36), ‘to be made an object of war,’ may of course be used for each other without much distinction, and hence in iii. 82 (polemoume/nwn) and iv. 20 (polemou=ntai) it is doubtful to which form the verbs should be referred. But the perf. e)kpepolemh=sqai should mean ‘to have had war decisively
made upon one,’ while e)kpepolemw=sqai is a present-perfect, ‘to have been made a complete enemy of,’ i.e. ‘to be in a state of complete hostility.’ The latter is required here. Cf. e)polemw/qh (i. 57), polemw/sesqe au)tou/s (v. 98).
w(/sper e)bou/leto, ‘consistently with his policy of . . ’
e)panisou=n Cf.c. 87, § 4, a)nisw/sews e(/neka.
metapemya/menos ou)=n. ou)=n is resumptive of the remark beginning pa/ntwn ou)=n, though after a shorter interval than usual. Cf. vii. 6
tri/tw| kai\ deka/tw|. Darius Nothus therefore began to reign in B.C. 424-423.

*)alecippi/da The actual Doric genitive is used in the treaty. Alexippidas was the ephor eponymus. Cf. Paus. iii. 11, 2, e)/foroi pare/xontai to\n e)pw/numon kaqa\ dh\ kai\ *)aqhnai/ois tw=n kaloume/nwn e)nne/a e)pw/numo/s e)stin ei(=s a)/rxwn. So in Xen. Hellenica regularly, e.g. e)pi\ e)fo/rou me\n o)/ntos e)n *spa/rth| *eu)arxi/ppou, a)/rxontos d' e)n *)aqh/nais *eu)kth/monos (i. 2, 1) etc.

e)n *maia/ndrou pedi/w|: in Caria: iii. 19, e)k *muou=ntos a)naba\s dia\ tou= *maia/ndrou pedi/ou me/xri tou= *sandi/ou lo/fou. Strabo XIV. p. 648, XV. p. 691. The Maeander empties itself opposite Miletus. Magnesia, the seat of the satrap (cap. 50, § 3), is in the district. In c. 57, § 1, Tissaphernes went down to Caunus, and this compact is made on his return, and includes all the Persians in contact with Grecian affairs.

*(ierame/nh k.t.l. Hieramenes is mentioned in Xen. Hell. ii. 1, 9 as brother-in-law of Darius. His function in Asia Minor is unknown. Like Theramenes acting for Sparta (cc. 36, 38, 43), he may not have been an actual governor of a district concerned, but only present as one of the plenipotentiaries of the king. The ‘sons of Pharnaces’ include Pharnabazus, the satrap of Dascyhtis (c. 6, § 1), but Pharnabazus appears not to have been present in person at the signing of this treaty. The contracting parties on the Persian side were Tissaphernes for the satrapy of ta\ ka/tw, the sons of Pharnaces representing Pharnabazus of the satrapy of Dascylitis, and Hieramenes probably directly representing the king. The compact is with plenipotentiaries, and the treaty does not begin cunqh=kai pro\s basile/a as in cc. 18 and 37.

o(/sh th=s *)asi/as e)sti/, a most important amendment
of the terms of c. 37, § 2, o(po/sh xw/ra kai\ po/leis basile/ws ei)si\ *darei/ou h)\ tou= patro\s h)=san h)\ tw=n progo/nwn, to which Lichas had so naturally objected (c. 43, § 3). The Hellenic states, however, are still surrendered according to the Persian point of view, though perhaps not according to the Lacedaemonian.
kata\ ta\ cugkei/mena, i.e. ‘the terms at present existing,’ c. 29, § 2. § 6.

*lakedaimoni/ous de\, . . . e)f' e(autoi=s ei)=nai. The words e)f' e(autoi=s ei)=nai are an afterthought. In the acc. and inf. construction of the treaty *lakedaimoni/ous de\ tre/fein, h)\n bou/lwntai is intended. ‘The Laced. shall, if they so wish, maintain their own fleet.’ But Thucydides, or the author of the treaty, joins tre/fein closely with h)\n bou/lwntai, and supplies the infinitive by e)f' e(autoi=s ei)=nai, leaving *lakedaimoni/ous without structure. ‘The Laced. shall, if they choose to maintain their own fleet, have the right to do so’; but for this e.g. e)a=sqai would be required in strict grammar.
e)ph\n a form occurring in Thucydides only in two treaties, here and v. 47. It is, however, sufficiently common Attic.
teleutw=ntos a quasi-perfect like nikw=n, a)dikw=n etc.

h)
 de\ . . . katalu/ein . . . katalu/esqai, sc. to
 po/lemon. Both active and middle are used of ending a war and coming to terms. katalu/ein (v. 23, in a treaty), katalu/ein to
 po/lemon (v. 47, a treaty), but katalu/ointo (iv. 18), katalelume/nous to
 e)kei= po/lemon (vi. 36). In the present passage, in view of the sudden change, katalu/esqai should probably be taken as impersonal passive.

gou=n, ‘at all events.’ The translation ‘he wanted to appear to be preparing’ is incorrect. dh=los ei)=nai is not ‘to appear,’ nor does gou=n qualify that term, but rather belongs to paraskeuazo/menos. ‘He wanted it to be seen that he was preparing’ — though he might defer the actual performance as he chose.

*)wrwpo\n. The possession of this town had long been and continued to be a bone of contention between Athens and Boeotia. The Oropians are *)aqhnai/wn u(ph/kooi in ii. 23 (B.C. 431). In iv. 96 (B.C. 424) the Athenians managed to hold the place after their defeat by the Boeotians, and to leave a garrison there.
*)eretriw=n Eretria was the second town in Euboea, Chalcis being the chief. In c. 95, § 3, Eretria is said to be 60 stadia from Oropus.

e)pi\ th=| *)eretri/a| Cf. iv. 75, mh\ w(/sper ta\ *)/anaia e)pi\ th=| *sa/mw| ge/nhtai. This gives the reason of the action of the Eretrians in the matter. If they revolted, Oropus would be dangerous to them.

to\ xwri/on k.t l. Const. a)du/nata h)=n to\ xwri/ou (subj.) mh\ ou) mega/la bla/ptein, sc. ei) a)postai=en. *)aqhnai/wn e)xo/ntwn= ei) *)aqhnai=oi e)/xoien. It might seem tempting to read mega/l' a)\n bla/ptein, but the expression ‘impossible for the place not to injure’ in the sense ‘impossible that the place should not injure’ is as good Greek as English.
w(/rmhnto, ‘were bent upon.’ Cf. w(rmhme/nwn, c. 11, § 3.
a)po\ th=s *xa/lkhs, v. c. 55, § 1.

e(w/rwn . . oi(=o/n* te/ tina MSS. have oi)=o/n te ei)=nai. Kruger, P - S, and editors generally eject ei)=nai, on the ground that the regular construction with o(ra=n is with the participle, while the infinitive is never found. Cf. Liddell and Scott, o(ra=n II. c. In ii. 45, o(rw= me/gan to
 a)gw=na has the predicative adjective without either participle or infinitive. If ei)=nai is omitted, however, the participle o)
 must be read, since e(w/rwn oi(=o/n te alone cannot be paralleled. It is true that ai)sqa/nesqai occurs in rare instances with the infinitive, e g. vi. 59, ai)sqanome/nous au)tou/s . . . du/nasqai, and v. 4, ai)sqo/menos ou)k a)
 pei/qein. It should, however, be noticed (1) that in each of these Thucydidean instances there is some reason for avoiding the participle, (2) that ai)sqa/nesqai is akin to a)kou/w and punqa/nesqai (which also take infin. occasionally), while o(ra/w is akin to oi)=da (which does not take infinitive). Similarly parts of gignw/skw may here and there take infinitive in the sense of ‘resolving that’ (akin to ai)sqa/nesqai, etc.), but e)/gnwka = oi)=da can only take a participle. Cf. Shilleto on i. 43. I read therefore e(w/rwn ou)ke/ti . . . oi(=o/n te/ tina, which is analogous to o(rw= me/gan to
 a)gw=na of ii. 45, and which arose from a confusion of OIONTETINA with OIONTEINAI. ‘They saw that it was no longer possible for one (i.e. themselves) to proceed to Chios without a naval battle.’
*derkuli/das te, answered by kai\ oi( *xi=oi.
*)/abudon on the Asiatic side at the narrowest part of the Hellespont.
ei)si\ de\ sc. oi( *)abudhnoi/
*le/onta te . . . kai\ nau=s dw/deka.

*)antisqe/nei e)piba/ths k.t.l. In c. 39, § 1, Antisthenes brought twenty-seven ships from the Peloponnese for Pharnabazus. These ships had (c. 42, § 5) united with the general Pelop. fleet, gone with it to Cnidus and thence to Rhodes. The meaning of e)piba/ths has been much discussed. Kruger supposes it to signify an inferior officer, or deputy, like e)pistoleu/s, For this there is no sort of authority. Throughout Thucydides e)piba/ths = miles classiarius, while elsewhere a frequent meaning is ‘passenger’ or ‘supercargo.’ From the expression *le/ontos mi/a below he seeins to have had one ship placed under his command by the nauarch or else to have equipped one himself. If e)piba/ths here, as usually, = miles classiarius, it need not necessarily denote a common marine, but rather an officer of marines, and for such a person to be appointed trierarch need cause no surprise. In Xen. Hell i. 3, 17, Hegesandridas is in command of ships e)piba/ths w)\n *minda/rou, and inf. c. 73, § 4, Thrasyllus o(pliteu/wn is connected with Thrasybulus trihrarxw=n and becomes, with him, one of the strathgoi/ (c. 76, § 2) ‘Leon, a Spartan who came out with the expedition of Antisthenes, (not as a trierarch or strathgo/s but) in the marine service.’ e)piba/ths might also be a distinguished Spartan, carried on board the ship of Antisthenes over and above the ship's company. But this is not the Thucydidean sense of the word elsewhere.
tou=ton resumptive of *le/onta. Cf. iv. 44, toi=s d' h(mi/sesi tw=n *korinqi/wn, oi(\ . . ., tou/tois ou) kata/dhlos h( ma/xh h)=n.

ai(\ e)/tuxon fu/lakes k.t.l. On the composition of the Peloponnesian fleet at this time, see c. 43, § 2, and c. 44, § 2. In c. 35, § 1, ten ships came from Thurii under Dorieus, and these are the only ships of Thurii which are mentioned. We do not know which particular six ships were captured off Triopium, but at least four of them must have been Thurian. Here we find five. These and the Syracusan vessels have been counted in the ninety-four ships at Rhodes in c. 44, § 2. Either they should not have been so counted, or else nine or ten ships had left Rhodes without any mention of the fact by Thucydides.
*le/ontos mi/a presumably a Laconian ship.

ta\s du/o kai\ tria/konta. In c. 30, § 2, the Athenians sail to Chios with thirty ships and some transports, and in c. 34 they lose three by shipwreck. Either the transports count as five, or else there is an addition from some source not stated.
The former seems to be the case from c. 62, § 2, nausi\n . . . w)=n kai\ stratiw/tides h)=san.
e)nauma/xhsan sc. oi( *xi=oi kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi.

ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes. sxo/ntes of Vat. is less good. The present is ‘like nikw=ntes’ (P-S) and is regular. Cf. iv. 25, e)n th=| naumaxi/a| . . . ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes . . . parekomi/sqhsan, where all MSS. agree. So i. 105, etc.
eu)qu\s should probably be joined with the participle, ‘immediately that D arrived.’ The position of the word, however, is somewhat against this.
parecelqo/ntos ‘having completed (e)c-) his march along the coast.’.
e)n tw=| *(ellhspo/ntw|. e)n as Poppo observes, because ‘the Hellespont’ is the name of a district.
*la/myakos a colony from Phocaea and Miletus (Strabo, p. 589), about twenty miles from Abydus. The city had been attached to Atheus since B.C. 479.
a(rpagh\n pohsa/menos. Cf. c. 41, § 2, th\n xw/ran . . lei/an e)poei=to.
*shsto\n, about four miles from Abydus obliquely across the Hellespont. It was regarded by the Athenians as the key of the strait (Arist. Rhet. iii. 10, § 7).

h(/n pote *mh=doi ei(=xon The to/te of most other MSS. than Vat. will hardly stand. Though to/te is often used of a matter previously mentioned, ‘at the time above stated’ (cf. c. 20, § 1), it cannot be referred so far back as to i. 89 (*shsto\n e)polio/rkoun *mh/dwn e)xo/ntwn), which is the last reference to the possession by the Medes. A rendering ‘on the well-known occasion’ would be far-fetched. For the fact cf. Hdt. ix. 115.

oi( e)n th=| *milh/tw| kai\ o( *)astu/oxos puqo/menos . . . e)qa/rshse, the verb agreeing with the nearer or more important subject. Cf. c. 81 (init.), oi( de\ proestw=tes e)n th=| *sa/mw| kai\ ma/lista *qrasu/boulos . . . e)/peisen . . kai\ pleu/sas k.t.l. Similarly to\n *strombixi/dhn kai\ ta\s nau=s (= e)/xonta ta\s nau=s) a)pelhluqo/ta, with which cf. iv. 112, *brasi/das me\n ou)=n kai\ to\ plh=qos . . . e)tra/peto boulo/menos k.t.l. The writer considers Strombichides alone: what he does is what his forces do.
komi/zei, sc. e)s *mi/lhton.
a)ntanh/gonto v. c. 38, § 5, a)ntana/goien.
u(po\ ga\r k.t.l. ga\r gives the reason of the ‘mutual suspicions among the Athenian forces’ in the last sentence.

katele/luto. katelu/eto has been generally, but unfortunately, accepted as a correction. The difficulties which seem to exhibit themselves prima facie with the pluperfect are (1) that the subversion of the democracy was not yet completed at Athens, (2) that if it had been completed the suspicions would be over and the real state of things manifest, (3) that u(po\ tou=ton to\n xro/non reads strangely with the pluperfect, (4) that the words e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais do not at first sight seem sufficiently relevant to the suspicions at Samos. The first three objections, it is thought, are removed by reading katelu/eto, and the fourth also, by the consideration that the forces at Samos would be mutually suspicious because of the negotiations proceeding between their leaders and Athens, and because they did not know what to expect next. But all this is founded on a misconception, the fact being that the passage beginning e)peidh\ ga\r is retrospective and explanatory of katele/luto. Beginning with these words and continuing through cc. 64-71, Thucydides goes back to recite the progress of the conspiracy. He has to deal with the story of two matters, the progress of the war and the progress of the revolution. In cc. 53-54, Peisander and other deputies go to Athens, propose a change of government, and are sent to Asia to work with Alcibiades and Tissaphernes. In c. 56, § 5, they break off these negotiations and withdraw to Samos. At the present passage Thucydides takes up the tale of what they had done subsequently (but previously to the operations of the war described since c. 56). The events nariated in the first section of the present chapter took place in the spring of the year following that in which Peisander's deputation had come to Samos (c. 61, init.) Before the opening of c. 63 all that is related in the following chapters 63-71 (of the progress of affairs at Athens) had taken place. katele/luto is therefore necessary, and, being a quasi-imperfect, is joined with u(po\ tou=ton to\n xro/non, to which kai\ e)/ti pro/teron is corrective. ‘For about this time or earlier still the subversion of the democracy at Athens was complete.’ This naturally caused a suspicious state of feeling at Samos.
ta/ t' e)n au)tw=| tw=| strateu/mati answered by kai\ au)tw=n tw=n *sami/wn. ‘The army’ is opposed to the people on which it was quartered.
bebaio/teron kate/labon ‘got a firmer grasp of.’ Dukas compares i. 9, o(/rkois kateilhmme/nous. Cf. Plut. Pericl. 33, pa/nta fulakai=s katalabw/n.

prou)tre/yanto k.t.l. For the readings of the following passage see crit. notes. dunatwta/tous is preferable to the positive, since the reference is to those who had the most influence among the new Samian democracy. In c. 21 the new democracy slays 200 dunatw/tatoi of the oligarchy, and reduces the landowners generally to the weakest and worst of positions. Here the dunatw/tatoi are simply the most influential persons among the party now in power. This is further shown by the clause beginning with kai/per.

kai/per e)panasta/ntas au)tou\s a)llh/lois ‘though they (the new order of dunatw/tatoi) had themselves (au)tou\s = ipsos) risen in revolt against one another’ a)llh/lois is illogical, but one should not be tempted to emend to e.g. a)/llois. It was against the previous oligarchs that this party had ‘revolted’ (c. 21), but ‘among themselves,’ ‘in their own case,’ the Samians (generally) had just experienced the contrary democratic revolution, and the two notions are confused. Properly, of course, e)panasth=nai could not be used with a)llh/lois at all, since the word is only applicable to one party, the oppressed. There is a confusion of the two notions (1) kai/per e)panasta/ntas au)tou\s pro/teron, i(/na mh\ o)l., and (2) kai/per tw=n *sami/wn au)tw=n a)llh/lois e)nantiwqe/ntwn k.t.l.
ka)n sfi/sin au)toi=s. Cf. c. 48, § 3.
e)ske/yanto . . . e)a=n a brachylogy for skeya/menoi e)/gnwsan e)a=n. e)a=n = ‘to let him go.’
ou) bou/letai sc. cumbh=nai, or some such word.
ou)k e)pith/deion being untrustworthy and grasping.
au)tou\s . . . kinduneu/ontas o(ra=n the objective construction. Cf. sfa=s, c. 32, § 3; boulome/nwn . . u(pomei/nantas dianaumaxei=n, c. 27, § 1.
a)neqh/setai ‘be let go,’ like a rope or something at which they had been stretching. ta\ pra/gmata, sc. of the revolution.
a)nte/xein ta\ tou= pole/mou is an accus. of closer definition. a)nte/xein intrans. ‘hold out.’ Cf. c. 86, § 7, kai\ ta)=lla e)ke/leuon a)nte/xein.
talaipwrou=ntas Cf. c. 48, § 1.
parakeleusa/menoi, sc. e)n e(autoi=s (iv. 25) or a)llh/lois (Xen. An. iv. 2, 11).
a)/rxein, further exegesis of h(|rhme/non after e)s ta\ e)pi\ *qra/|khs h(|rhme/non, i.e. = w)/ste a)/rxein.

*qa/son, which was connected with Thrace by position and by early possessions there (i. 100, iv. 107). Thasos had been an original member of the confederacy of Delos, but had subsequently quarrelled with and been reduced by Athens after a two years' siege (B.C. 463). Cf. i. 100, 101.
th\n po/lin e)tei/xizon. See i. 101, tei=xos kaqelo/ntes after the above siege.

th=s me\n met' *)aqhnai/wn a)ristokrati/as k.t.l. There is emphasis on met' *)aqhnai/wn, and a)ristokrati/as is opposed to e)leuqeri/an. Some time ago they might have thought it something to obtain such a concession from Athens, but they no longer valued ‘an aristocratical constitution attached to Athens,’ when they were daily expecting something better from Lacedaemon, viz. entire independence. There is a purposed jingle in prosdeo/menoi . . . prosdexo/menoi.

fugh\ in a collective sense = fuga/des tine\s. Cf. Xen. Hell. v. 2, 9, kata/gein e)bou/lonto th\n fugh/n; Aesch. Suppl 76, ta=sde fuga=s ei)/ tis e)/sti khdemw/n; Aeschin. De F. u(po\ is joined to the verbal noun from its sense of tine\s e)kbeblhme/noi. Cf. c. 35, § 1, a)feisth/kei u(po\ *tissafe/rnous. feu/gein u(po\ is common.
ma/lista a(\ = ‘as nearly as possible what . . .’

th\n po/lin te o)rqou=sqai their state was gaining its independence of Athens, kai\ to\n . . . dh=mon katalelu/sqai, and their own oligarchical party was established in power. Thus in external and internal relations alike their policy was suited.

o)rqou=sqai not w)rqw=sqai, as the liberation is not yet complete. The state was ‘coming right.’ There is a metaphor from a ship righting itself. Cf. Soph. Antig. 162, a)/ndres, ta\ me\n dh\ po/leos a)sfalw=s qeoi\ | pollw=| sa/lw| sei/santes w)/rqwsan pa/lin The present tense has in other places (e.g. ii. 60, po/lin . . . o)rqoume/nhn) the sense of ‘proceeding on the right (or prosperous) lines.’

swfrosu/nhn labou=sai. Cf. c. 53, § 3, ei) mh\ politeu/somen swfrone/steron. For this oligarchical catchword Arnold quotes iii. 82, a)ristokrati/as sw/fronos protimh/sei, and contrasts it with the a)kolasi/a ascribed to democracies (Hdt. iii. 81). Thucydides certainly appears to sympathise with the
aristocratical view. swfrosu/nhn labou=sai=swfronisqei=sai: cf. i. 91, u(/yos lamba/nei and other combinations with labei=n.

a)/deian tw=n prassome/nwn i.e. the oligarchical parties, being established, could act without being regarded by a ruling dh=mos as conspirators. Previously their negotiations with Sparta might cause them banishment or other punishment, in which the Athenians would assist.

th=s a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn u(pou/lou eu)nomi/as ou) protimh/santes This reading is derived from Dionysius (De iis quae Thucydidi propria sunt, c. xi. p. 800), who in his time must have had much more trustworthy MSS. than ours. The view of Jowett that ‘the reading in Dionysius is probably a slip of the memory,’ is scarcely tenable in view of the fact that Dionysius quotes the passage and comments on its construction with great particularity. He says that the customary grammar would be to write the feminine protimh/sasai, and the accus. th\n u(/poulon eu)nomi/an instead of the genitive. It is scarcely to be supposed that Dionysius would comment thus on grammatical peculiarities which existed only in his own imagination. Poppo points out that Dionysius is wrong in taking the genitive to be a kind of solecism, since, as a matter of fact, ou) protimh/santes is rightly explained by the scholiast ou) fronti/santes ‘not caring about,’ in which sense the genitive is regular with protima/w. Poppo compares Aesch. Ag. 1672, mh\ protimh/sh|s matai/wn tw=nd' u(lagma/twn; Eur. Alc. 761, etc. The accus. th\n . . . u(/poulon au)tonomi/an of the MSS. is itself a correction made by some one labouring under the same error as Dionysius. Vat., however, has by some accident retained th=s, as also a)po\ (while the other MSS. have u(po\). Another indication of the truth of Dionysius' reading appears in eu)nomi/as. It is fortunate that the genuine word has thus survived, since the Athenians did not offer their u)ph/kooi independence (au)tonomi/an), even while they turned their governments into oligarchies. ‘The states made for downright freedom, caring nothing for the hollow and deceitful “good government” offered by the Athenians.’ What the Athenians offered was what they called eu)nomi/a (from the oligarchical point of view), a term in keeping with swfrosu/nhn above. Indeed the words eu)nomi/an a)po\ tw=n *)aq. answer precisely to th=s met' *)aq. a)ristokrati/as of § 3. Yet such eu)nomi/a coming from Athens was insufficient and of precarious tenure: the old sore might soon break out again. The metaphor of u(/poulos is common in Greek. Cf. Plat. Gorg. 518 E, oi)dei= kai\ u(/poulo/s e)stin h( po/lis.
The purpose of the proposal is that when the payment for attendance at the boule, ecclesia, and dicasteria ceases, the poorer citizens may practically be prohibited from taking part in public affairs. ‘Payment of members’ should cease. Dukas well refers to Aristot. Pol. vi. 4, 6.
meqekte/on tw=n pragma/twn Arnold quotes Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 18; where under the Thirty a nominal 3000 are chosen— tou\s meqe/contas dh\ tw=n pragma/twn.

h)=n de\ tou=to eu)prepe\s k.t.l., ‘now this was (only) a specious pretence, intended for the mass, etc.’ The 5000 were to be mythical. The omission of e.g. mo/non with eu)prepe\s might seem to leave the clause somewhat bald; but Thucyd. makes eu)prepe\s in itself carry sufficient emphasis of ‘pretence.’ Cf. vii. 57, a)na/gkh| me\n e)k tou= eu)prepou=s, boulh/sei de\ kata\ e)/xqos k.t.l. So in iii. 82, met' o)no/matos eu)prepou=s, in a large measure eu)prepou=s = yeudou=s. ‘Now this was a pretence, intended, etc.’

e)pei\ e(/cein ge. e)pei\ . . . ge might perhaps be taken together: cf. vi. 18, e)peidh/ ge kai\ cunwmo/samen (where, however, there is no separation). But in vii. 30, e)pei\ e)/n ge th=| a)/llh| a)naxwrh/sei k.t.l., the particle ge is best taken as throwing emphasis on th=| a)/llh|. So here ge is best combined with e(/cein: ‘those who were endeavouring to change the government meant to have the government.’
me/ntoi i.e. despite the oligarchical proceedings, the ecclesia and boule still met.

h( a)po\ tou= kua/mou. Cf.c. 69, § 4, e)pe/sthsan toi=s a)po\ tou= kua/mou bouleutai=s. The ‘bean’ was used in drawing lots. See Plut. Pericl. c. 27, where the drawer of a white bean has the advantage. Ar. Av. 1022, kua/mw| laxw/n; Hdt. vi. 109, o\ tw=| kua/mw| laxw\n polemarxe/ein; Xen. Mem. i. 2, 9, a)/rxontas a)po\ kua/mou kaqista/nai. This is the same as h( boulh\ oi( pentako/sioi. Andoc. i. 96 quotes from a law oi( pentako/sioi laxo/ntes tw=| kua/mw|. Cf. kuameu/ein. The definition is necessary to distinguish this popular council from h( boulh\ h( e)c *)arei/ou pa/gou. The boulh\ of 500 and the dh=mos form the democratic body politic: cf. e)/doce th=| boulh=| kai\ tw=| dh/mw|.

e)bouleu/onto. e)bou/leuon of some MSS. would be the vox propria if it expressed only the function of a boulh/. Here both the dh=mos and the boulh\ ‘deliberate,’ and though either active or middle may be used in that sense, the latter is the more usual, and has here the greater support.

prou)/skepto The MSS. give prou)ske/pteto. In point of
mere tense either would stand, ‘it had been previously considered,’ or ‘it used to be previously considered.’ But (1) whereas deponent verbs not unfrequently use the perfect and pluperfect in a passive sense, they rarely use the present and imperfect in such a way, and only in a few recognised verbs, e.g. bia/zomai, w)nou=mai, e)rga/zomai (very rarely); (2) ske/ptomai, e)skepto/mhn are scarcely Attic for skope/w, e)sko/poun. Veitch quotes Plato, Lach. 185 B, and Alc. (2) 140 as the only instances of the present tense before Aristotle, and no instance of the imperfect till Lucian. These two considerations combined are decisive.

a)nte/lege/ te ou)dei\s . . . dediw\s k.t.l., as if instead of ou)dei\s he had said, ‘a man refrained from opposing, because he feared . . .’ So in Latin ‘nemo contradicebat, sed (quisque) timebat,’ etc.
ei)/ tis kai\ a)ntei/poi ‘when anybody did oppose.’
e)teqnh/kei ‘he was a dead man.’

dikai/wsis lit. ‘a doing of justice’ in regard to him. The scholiast explains by ko/lasis h)\ ei)s di/khn a)pagwgh/, the former of which is, of course, what the sense amounts to. In i. 141 dikai/wsis is a ‘claim’ of right. But dikai/wma = ‘penalty,’ Plat. Legg. 864 E, and dikaiou=n = ‘punish,’ Hdt. i. 100. So iii. 40, dikaiw/sesqe u(ma=s au)tou/s.

ple/on h)\ o(/son e)tu/gxanen o)\n. Cf. c. 87, § 5, e)/fh au)ta\s e)la/ssous h)\ o(/sas basileu\s e)/tace cullegh=nai. ‘Imagining the conspiracy to be much more extensive than it actually (e)tu/gxanen) was.’ The o(\ h)=n of most MSS. is clumsy, but can be construed, ‘imagining the conspiracy to be much more extensive than the amount which (o(/son) the actual one (o(\ h)=n) really (e)tu/gxanen) was.’

kai\ e)ceurei=n au)toi\ a)du/natoi o)/ntes . . . e)cairei=n The MSS. mostly have kai\ e)ceurei=n au)to\ (or au)toi\) a)du/natoi o)/ntes dia\ to\ me/geqos th=s po/lews kai\ dia\ th\n a)llh/lwn a)gnwsi/an ou)k ei)=xon au)to\ (or au)toi\) e)ceurei=n. Some inferior MSS. omit the last two words. We may take one of two views, either (1) that the last words au)toi\ (or au)to\) e)ceurei=n are a gloss to explain ou)k ei)=xon, or (2) that au)toi\ (or au)to\) e)ceurei=n is a corruption of some other words. The omission of the last two words in some MSS. is no proof that they have no right in the text, since they may well have been critically expelled as a dittography. If we take the first view and eject au)to\ e)ceurei=n, we must still further eject a)du/natoi o)/ntes, in order to make any sense or construction of ou)k ei)=xon, unless we take the unlikely course of
giving to the second kai\ the sense of etiam, ‘while unable to find it out because of the size of the city, they were also unable to do so because of their not knowing one another.’ No one is likely to maintain this correction and rendering. If we take the second view, au)to\ e)ceurei=n is an error for some words to eomplete the sense beginning ‘and being unable to find it out because of the greatness of the city and their not knowing each other, they could not——.’ The context seems to require ‘put it down,’ or ‘deal with it.’ In the Classical Review for December 1889, I suggested the emendation au)to\ e)cairei=n, which I am now more strongly convinced is right. ‘Being unable on their side (au)toi\) to discover it . . . they could not make an end of it.’ For e)cairei=n cf. c. 46, § 3, h)\n mh/pote au)tou\s e)ce/lwsi; Xen. Hell. ii. 2, 19, mh\ spe/ndesqai *)aqhnai/ois a)ll' e)cairei=n, and frequently.
th\n a)llh/lwn a)gnwsi/an Jowett quotes Aristot. Pol. vii. 4, 7, and his remark that for political purposes a)nagkai=on gnwri/zein a)llh/lous, poi=oi/ tine/s ei)si, tou\s poli/tas.

w(/ste a)mu/nasqai e)pibouleu/santa. There is some dispute as to whether e)pibouleu/santa is subject or object of a)mu/nasqai. The absence of the article is an objection to the latter view, though e)pibouleu/santa as = e)pib. tina\ is not impossible. The former seems the better: ‘so as to contrive a plot and avenge oneself.’ e)pibouleu/santa, sc. met' au)tou=, to be supplied from the tini to whom one complains. Thucyd. might have said ‘it was impossible for a man in his indignation to bewail himself to a friend, so as to get his help in a scheme of revenge.’ The latter clause is differently, but no less intelligibly, expressed.

h)\ a)gnw=ta a)\n hu(=ren, w(=| e)rei=, k.t.l. Constr. hu(=ren ga\r a)\n h)\ a)gnw=ta (in a noun sense. ‘a stranger’), w(=| e)rei= (‘to speak to’), h)\ a)/piston (adj ) gnw/rimon (a noun, ‘acquaintance’).
hu(=ren a)\n sc. ei) proswlofu/rato.

w(=| e)rei= The indic. fut. is regularly kept after secondary tenses in sentences like these. Goodwin, M. and T. § 565. Cf Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 2, e)/doce tw=| dh/mw| tria/konta a)/ndras e(le/sqai, oi(\ tou\s patri/ous no/mous cuggra/yousi, kaq' ou(\s politeu/sousi.

w(s mete/xonta/ tina accus. absol. with w(s. Cf. i. 134, w(s a)/gos au)toi=s o)/n; vi. 24, w(s ou)de\n a)\n sfalei=san mega/lhn du/namin; vii. 25, w(s diapepolemhso/menon; Soph. O. T. 100; Jelf, § 703.
ou(=toi the unexpected adherents of the league.

be/baion th\n a)pisti/an tw=| dh/mw| pro\s e(auto\n katasth/santes ‘by chuching the peoples distrust towards itself.’ Arnold remarks that the sentence shows a lack of finish in a)/piston and a)pisti/an. Stahl would eject kai\ to\ a)/piston . . . e)po/hsan. It would also be easy to regard be/baion . . . katasth/santes as an interpolation of some commentator who thought plei=sta . . . w)fe/lhsan obscure. The trend of the passage is thus: the commons are suspicious of one another; the reason is explained in e)nh=san ga\r k.t.l., because there were people in the league whom one would never have thought capable of favouring oligarchy. These persons, once thought so sure, naturally made men suspicious of the general run of people (pro\s tou\s pollou\s), whose leanings were not so well known or so much relied on. tw=n o)li/gwn next comes with antithesis to tou\s pollou\s, at least in sound: ‘and they were of great service in securing the safety of the few.’ But instead of merely adding the word ‘thereby’ or ‘accordingly,’ he explains again how they were of such service, viz. ‘by making a settled matter of the distrustfulness of the demos towards itself.’ This could have been expressed by e.g. kai\ ou(/tw plei=sta k t.l. or kai\ dia\ tau=ta plei=sta k.t.l. The only palliation, but a considerable one, of the tautology lies in the sense of the word dh/mw|, which must be distinguished here from toi=s polloi=s. It is the assembly or people viewed politically which was prevented from making any stand or taking any action. Reduced to its lowest terms the sentence = ‘by making men generally distrust each other, they assisted the safety of the oligarchs, because they secured inertness on the part of the democratic body politic.’ It would be easy to suggest a)nelpisti/an if any change were really necessary.
ou)=n resumptive after the explanatory note beginning c. 65, § 2, kai\ ga\r *)androkle/a k.t.l.

cuggrafe/as cf. Isoc. Areop. 151, ei) peri\ tou/twn e)ke/leuon u(ma=s e(le/sqai sune/drous h)\ suggrafe/as, di' w(=n o( dh=mos katelu/qh to\ pro/teron, ei)ko/tws a)
 ei)=xon th
 ai)ti/an tau/thn. Harpocration (in voc. suggrafei=s) h)=san de\ oi( me
 pa/ntes suggrafei=s tria/konta oi( to/te ai(reqe/ntes kaqa\ fhsi
 *)androti/wn te kai\ o( *filo/xoros, e(ka/teros e)n th=| *)atqi/di. o( de\ *qoukudi/dhs tw=n de/ka e)mnhmo/neuse mo/non tw=n probou/lwn. Suidas (pro/bouloi) agrees with this, pro\s toi=s ou)=si de/ka h(|re/qhsan a)/lloi ei)/kosi ei)shghso/menoi ta\ dokou=nta th=| politei/a|. There is, however, little likelihood that the pro/bouloi of c. 1, § 3, are either the same as, or bodily included
in, the cuggrafh=s, and it is generally agreed that Harpocration, and after him Suidas, has confounded these cuggrafh=s with the thirty tyrants of seven years later, who are enumerated in Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 2. e)/doce tw=| dh/mw| tria/konta a)/ndras e\le/sqai, oi(\ tou\s patri/ous no/mous cuggra/yousi, kaq' ou(\s politeu/sousi k.t.l.
gnw/mhn e)senegkei=n Cf. v. 38, ou)ke/ti e)sh/negkan peri\ *)argei/wn e)s ta\s boula/s.

cugkaqi=san. For cune/klh|san of MSS. Herwerden's conjecture is cuneka/lesan; but this, as Stahl observes, would hardly have been corrupted into so much more difficult a word. Jowett prefers cune/lecan, a variant not largely supported and probably a gloss. cune/klh|san is explained by Arnold as referring to the place of assembly being railed in. P-S quotes Ovid, Fast. i. 53, est quoque quo populum ius est includere saeptis, which is in no way apposite to the Athenian assembly. Unless the meaning be that the smallness of the space and the extra distance were intended to result in a small and ‘packed’ assembly, there seems to be no point in cune/klh|san. Nor is ‘to shut up together’ a natural or explicit term in the sense ‘to confine to a small space and so reduce the number.’ It does not appear, either, that the ground at Colonus was likely to be less spacious than the Pnyx or other meeting-places. They do not (as Jowett renders) ‘meet in the temple of Poseidon’; but they meet at ‘Colonus, which was a sacred precinct of Poseidon.’ Curtius (Hist. Gr. iii. p. 438) supposes an enclosure made for the occasion, but for this cune/klh|san passes the limits of reasonable brachylogy. The reading offered in the text supposes a corruption from c*u*n*e*k*a*q*i*c*a*n toc*u*n*e*k*l*e*i*c*a*n, both suneka/qisan and sune/kleisan being the common forms of the later Greek for cugkaqi=san and cune/klh|san respectively. kaqi/zw is common of convening or holding an assembly or court of law. Cf. o( dh=mos a)/nw kaqh=to. sugkaqi/zw occurs in the middle, Xen. Hell. v. 2, 35, e)pei\ de\ sunekaqi/zeto to\ dikasth/rion. Cf. Dem. 1434, sugkaqezo/menos e(/kastos (of persons in the assembly).

to\n *kolwno/n the Colonus par excellence. This *kolwno/s (of Soph. Oed. Col.) is distinguished by the epithet *(/ippios from the Colonus inside the city, which was called *)agorai=os or *mi/sqios. On the topography of the place see Jebb on Soph. Oed. Col. (Introduction), who seeks to defend cune/klh|san, but agrees that i(ero\n is not the ‘temple.’
*)aqhnai/wn as if he were about to proceed o(/stis a)\n bou/lhtai gnw/mhn ei)pei=n. This construction takes a different shape, and *)aqhnai/wn is left to depend for its apparent grammar on tis.

a)natei\ ei)pei=n Sauppe's conjecture for the a)neipei=n and a)natre/pein of MSS. accounts for the discrepancy. a)neipei=n is to ‘proclaim,’ and a)natre/pein is clearly out of the question. A slight tautology in a)natei\ and the following sentence is not out of place in formal resolutions.
gra/yhtai parano/mwn See Smith's Dict. Antiq. (the article on parano/mwn grafh/ by C. R. Kennedy and H. Hager), and Wayte's Introd. to Demosth. Androt. and Timocrates.
e)ntau=qa dh\ . . . e)le/geto h)/dh v. cap. 53, § 3, on e)ntau=qa h)/dh.
ko/smou cf. c. 24, § 4, e)kosmou=nto; c. 72, § 2, o)ligarxikw=| ko/smw|.
misqoforei=n v. c. 65, § 3.
kai\ . . . de\ ‘and . . . furthermore’: i. 132, ii. 36, vi. 71, vii. 56, kai\ h)=n de\ a)/cios o( a)gw/n; Xen. Hell. v. 2, 37, oi)/ te a)/lloi kai\ h( tw=n *qhbai/wn de\ op/lis.

o(/tw| tro/pw| kate/sth e)s k.t.l. a free use of the so-called indirect question: ‘devised the whole matter, how it was brought to this result.’ Properly a mixture of the notions cune/qhken, o(/tw| tro/pw| katasth/setai e)s tou=to, ‘devised by what way the matter should be brought, etc.,’ and cune/qhke to\ pra=gma, w(=| tro/pw| kate/sth e)s tou=to, i.e. ‘he contrived the matter, as to the way in which it was brought to this issue.’ o(/tw| can scarcely = w(=| in classical Attic prose. The only instance in Thucydides where o(/stis apparently = o(\s is in vi. 3, bwmo/n, o(/stis nu=n e)/cw th=s po/lew/s e)stin, a passage where other peculiarities occur (see Wolfflin in Classen), and which is by no means decisive for the equivalence (v. P-S ad loc.)

*)antifw=n of Rhamnus, the earliest of the ten orators of the ‘canon,’ and the first logogra/fos. He was as unpopular with the comic poets as with the dh=mos. Thucydides is said to have been his pupil, but this statement, resting on a secondhand remark of the Pseudo-Plutarch (Vit. Orat.) and others, is of dubious truth. The authenticity of some of the extant orations of Antiphon (fifteen fonikoi\ lo/goi) is questioned. On his style and works see Jebb's Attic Orators.

a)reth=| not in the moral sense of ‘virtue,’ but = ‘ability, force of character and faithfulness to party ties’ (Jowett). So ii. 37 a citizen at Athens ou)k a)po\ me/rous to\ ple/on e)s ta\ koina\ h)\ a)p' a)reth=s protima=tai. In ii. 40 a)reth/ = ‘kindliness.’

u(/steros There is little to choose between this and the deu/teros of Vat. Both words are variously constructed, e.g. c. 41, § 1, u(/stera pro\s . . ., but i. 91, ou)deno\s u(/steroi. So deu/teros pro\s . . ., Soph. Frag. 325; deu/teros ou)deno/s, Hdt. i. 23; but polu\ deute/ra meta\ . . ., Thuc. ii. 97.

a(\ [a)\n] gnoi/h M. Cf. c. 54, § 2, o(/ph| [a)\n] au)toi=s dokoi/h a)/rista e(/cein. The present instance cannot be defended even on the ground which is possible there. For the general expression cf. ii. 60, o( ga\r gnou\s kai\ mh\ safw=s dida/cas e)n i)/sw| kai\ ei) mh\ e)nequmh/qh.
a)gw=na ‘arena,’ Jowett. The reference is particularly to judicial procedure.

deino/thtos that sort of cleverness which can ‘make the worse appear the better reason,’ sophistry. Cf. iii. 37, mh\ deino/thti kai\ cune/sews a)gw=ni e)pairome/nous para\ do/can tw=| u(mete/rw| plh/qei parainei=n.

kai\ e)n dikasthri/w| kai\ e)n dh/mw| i.e., says P.S, in ordinary di/kai which went straight to the courts, and also in cases of probolh\ and ei)saggeli/a before the ecclesia. But a)gwnizome/nous e)n dh/mw| has a much more general reference, being used of other contests than those of litigation. A person wishing to speak (‘contend a point’) in the assembly on a yh/fisma might seek the help of Antiphon beforehand, or one who sought political honours and position (tou= dh/mou proesta/nai) might do the same. Cf Xen. Mem. iii. 7, 4, ou) tau)to/n e)stin, e)/fh, i)di/a| te diale/gesqai kai\ e)n tw=| plh/qei a)gwni/zesqai (where Charmides has been encouraged to seek political distinction).
w)felei=n sc. as logogra/fos.

kai\ au)to/s te. Most editors read de\ for te. The Herodotean te in the sense of ‘too’ is claimed here by Classen and Jowett as well as in i. 9, where MSS. give kai\ nautikw=| te (one omitting te), and in vi. 44, kai\ pro/s te tou\s *(rhgi/nous (where 3 MSS. omit te). See Jowett's lengthy argument and citations on i. 9. The correction ge would perhaps be nearer than de\, if any correction were required. But Jowett's sufficient vindication of kai\ . . . te is hardly called for here, since te is the particle connecting the sentences and kai\ merely emphasises au)to\s, thus, te (‘and’) kai\ au)to\s (‘in his own case’).

e)peidh\ ta\ k.t.l. There is great confusion of reading at this point. Most of the best MSS. give e)peidh\ mete/sth h( dhmokrati/a kai\ e)s a)gw=nas kate/sth meta\ (ta\ for meta\ one inferior MS.) tw=n tetrakosi/wn e)n u(ste/rw| metapeso/nta u(po\ tou= dh/mou e)kakou=to. The rest mostly have e)peidh\ ta\ tw=n tetrakosi/wn
k.t.l., which is, of course, entirely easy. There is yet another variant e)peidh\ meta\ tw=n tetrakosi/wn metapeso/nta k.t.l. The divergence is not easy to explain. We might with P-S assume that mete/sth h( dhmokrati/a is a gloss on ta\ . . . metapeso/nta u(po\ tou= dh/mou, and we might perhaps further suppose ei)s a)gw=nas kate/sth to be a gloss on e)kakou=to; but, on the other hand, the omission of the words from mete/sth to meta\ may be due to the eye of the copyist passing from the former to the latter, while the omission of ta\ after meta\ may be accidental. For readings proposed, see crit. note. The reading of the best MSS. is plainly untranslatable, and its tautology is quite unendurable. The tautology might be lessened somewhat and a tolerable construction made by reading o(/te ta\ for meta\, i.e. e)peidh\ mete/sth h( dhmokrati/a kai\ e)s a)gw=nas kate/sth (sc. *)antifw=n), o(/te ta\ tw=n tetrakosi/wn e)n u(ste/rw| metapeso/nta u(po\ tou= dh/mou e)kakou=to (‘at the time when, etc.’) If there is any truth in this conjecture, it might next be supposed that the vulgate e)peidh\ . . . kate/sth, o(/te ta\ . . . e)kakou=to arose from conflation of a genuine reading and its gloss, i.e. either o(/te ta\ . . . e)kakou=to is a gloss on e)peidh\ . . . kate/sth or vice versa. From the fact that some MSS. give e)peidh\ ta\ tw=n k.t.l., and from the quality of the expressions, I am induced to prefer the reading given in the text, though o(/te and not e)peidh\ may, according to the theory offered, be what Thucydides wrote. The question is one which scarcely admits of settlement. Fortunately the general meaning is in no way affected. [Keeping the whole suggested reading e)peidh\ mete/sth . . . o(/te ta\ . . . e)kakou=to, we might render ‘after the democracy had come about again and Antiphon was arraigned, at the time when the acts of the 400 (which had subsequently been overturned by the people) were meeting with punishment.’ In this case mete/sth h( dhmokrati/a = ‘the democracy came about through a change,’ not (as P-S seems to suppose) ‘the democracy was overthrown.’ Cf. Plat. Rep. 553 E, e)c h(=s metabolh=s o)ligarxi/a mete/sth (‘came about’). e)s a)gw=nas kate/sth would refer to his several arraignments on the several charges.] On the return to democracy and the subsequent arraignments see Grote, Hist. Gr. pt. ii. c. lxii. (vol. vii. pp. 315-329).
metapeso/nta ‘reversed.’ As a quasi-passive (of metaba/llein) it is joined with u(po\ tou= dh/mou, though these words are felt a)po\ koinou= with e)kakou=to.
di/khn a/pol. acc. of closer definition or extent of action, analogous to di/khn diw/kein, e(lei=n etc. tina.

a)pologhsa/menos in the lost speech peri\ metasta/sews.
This encomium is quoted by Cic. Brut. xii. 47, Antiphontem Rhamnusium . . . quo neminem umquam melius ullam oravisse capitis causam cum se ipse defenderet, se audiente, locuples auctor scripsit Thucydides (a sufficiently inexact statement).

diafero/ntws proqumo/taton. P-S quotes Plato, Prot. 349 D, a)ndreiota/tous diafero/ntws. The genitive belongs rather to diafero/ntws than to the superlative. Homer, Herodotus, etc., similarly use ma/lista with superlative.
u(p' o)ligarxi/as katelqei=n cf. c. 35, § 1, a)feisth/kei u(po\ *tissafe/rnous.

*qhrame/nhs. For his subsequent history see cc, 89-98, Xen. Hell. i. 1, 12; 6, 35; ii. 2, 3. He was afterwards one of the thirty tyrants. His shiftiness earned him the name of *ko/qornos, the boot that fits either foot (Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 31, 47; Poll. vii. 91, dia\ to\n peri\ th\n politei/an a)mfoterismo/n).

tou= *(/agnwnos according to the scholiast on Arist. Ran. 541 (cf. 970) he was a Cean adopted by Hagnon. Cf. Plut. Nic. 2. Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 30 has ou(=tos e)c a)rxh=s timw/menos u(po\ tou= dh/mou kata\ to\n pate/ra *(/agnwna propete/statos e)ge/neto th\n dhmokrati/an metasth=sai ei)s tou\s tetrakosi/ous kai\ e)prw/teuen e)n e)kei/nois.
prw=tos ‘a leading man.’
a)p' ‘proceeding from.’

e)p' e)/tei e(katostw=| ma/lista The expulsion of the tyrants took place in the year B.C. 510. This is B.C. 411. e)p' is rejected by many editors, nor as a mere expression of ‘time at which’ can it be paralleled from Attic prose, though that use can be met with in Epic verse, e.g. e)p' h)/mati tw=|de, Il. xiii. 234; e)f' h(me/rh| h(d' e)pi\ nukti/, Hes. Op. 102. Here e)pi\ rather = ‘after.’ ‘After the lapse of about a hundred years since. . . .’
kai\ ou) mo/non mh\ k.t.l. mh\ depends on the infinitive pau=sai e)leuqeri/as, while ou) mo/non belongs to xalepo\n h)=n (Cl.)
u(pe\r h(/misu The leadership of Athens gradually tightened into command from B.C. 479.

div2.p:
a)lla\. a(/ma of Wilamowitz is attractive, since there is no real opposition between ou)deno\s a)nteipo/ntos and kurw/sasa. Speakers may argue against a plan, and it may none the less be passed. Nevertheless such an expression as ‘no opposition having been raised, but the assembly having
passed the measure,’ is natural enough in the form ou)deno\s de\ a)nteipo/ntos a)lla\ th=s e)kklhsi/as kurwsa/shs tau=ta k.t.l., and the same sense may (though less smoothly) be expressed by h( e)kklhsi/a ou)deno\s a)nteipo/ntos a)lla\ kurw/sasa tau=ta, where the genitive absolute and the nominative participle are co-ordinate extensions of the predicate.
h)=san d'. de\ should not be omitted, as it introduces a parenthetical note (‘but first I ought to say . . . ’); after which ou)=n (§ 2) resumes the promised explanation (toiw=|de tro/pw|).

e)f o(/plois The order of the words is oi( me
 e)pi\ tei/xei (h)=san), oi( d' e)n ta/cei (h)=san) e)f' o(/plois k.t.l., ‘some were on the walls, others were at their posts standing by their arms because of the enemy at Deceleia.’ The citizens would be drafted into companies; these companies would have certain posts; a citizen who was with his company at its post awaiting orders was e)n ta/cei. He would not be actually waiting in arms, but standing by his arms, ready to seize them on occasion. He is therefore e)n ta/cei e)f' o(/plois. e)f' o(/plois is to be distinguished from e)n o(/plois. Jowett takes e)f' o(/plois = ‘on duty,’ and construes tw=n e)n *dekelei/a| pol. e(/neka h)=san e)f' o(/plois oi( me
 e)pi\ tei/xei, oi( d' e)n ta/cei. But cf. vii. 28, pro\s ga th=| e)pa/lcei th
 me
 h(me/ran kata\ diadoxh
 oi( *)aqhnai=oi fula/ssontes, th
 de\ nu/kta kai\ cu/mpantes plh
 tw=n i(ppe/wn, oi( me
 e)f' o(/plois poiou/menoi, oi( d' e)pi\ tou= tei/xous, . e)talaipwrou=nto. P-S rather strangely construes oi( d' e)n ta/cei (qui autem in acie militabant) e)f' o(/plois (h)=san) (in stationibus erant).

div3.p: a)pelqei=n sc. home from their posts at the change of guard; cf. kata\ diadoxh\n in vii. 28 (just quoted). Those in the league were to wait about, not close by the arms (which would cause suspioion), but at some little distance (a)/pwqen), near enough to seize them if necessary.

*)/andrioi kai\ *th/nioi k.t.l. All these peoples are mentioned among the allies of Athens in vii. 57. The contingents here mentioned had been brought by Peisander (e)p' au)to\ tou=to h(/kontes), v. c. 65, § 1.

tw=n e)poi/kwn See ii. 27. The Athenians drove out the Aeginetans (B.C. 431), kai\ th\n *ai)/ginan a)sfale/steron e)fai/neto au(tw=n pe/myantas e)poi/kous e)/xein: kai\ e)ce/pemyan u(/steron ou) pollw=| e)s au)th\n tou\s oi)kh/toras. Lysander restored the Aeginetans in
B.C. 404. Krüger and P-S eject the relative clause as a gloss, and certainly either tw=n e)poi/kwn or oi)kh/sontas would seem to be interpolated. But inasmuch as the actual number of Carystians is mentioned, while in the text *ai)ginhtw=n depends but vaguely on the notion of tines (suggested from the more definite *karusti/wn triako/sioi), it seems very probable that oi)kh/sontas conceals a numeral, e.g. o)gdoh/konta.
oi( ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato\n. The article is explained by the relative clause oi(=s e)xrw=nto k.t.l..

*(/ellhnes. No satisfactory explanation of this word is forthcoming. Though absent from several of the best MSS., it cannot be lightly omitted without some account of its appearance in all the rest. Jowett says ‘as distinguished from slaves or Scythian bowmen.’ Grote (pt ii. c. lxii.) calls them ‘a band of Grecian youths, got together from different cities,’ an account which is highly improbable. ‘They were probably young oligarchs, the jeunesse dorée of Athens’ (Jowett and Classen). Arnold, P-S, Cl. think they were members of the aristocratic clubs; and, indeed, no other conclusion can well be come to. In c. 92, § 6, tw=n i(ppe/wn neani/skoi assist the oligarchical party. Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 23, paraggei/lantes toi=s neani/skois oi(\ e)do/koun au(toi=s qrasu/tatoi ei)=nai cifi/dia u(po\ ma/lhs e)/xontas paragene/sqai refers to the same class of persons. In c. 65, § 2, it is custa/ntes tine\s tw=n newte/rwn (a somewhat less definite word) who kill Androcles. [It would be easy to suggest eu)genei=s, but so simple a word was not likely to be corrupted into one so incomprehensible. The sense required is that of ‘patrician’ youths, the eu)patri/dai; and, unlikely as it may seem at first, it is quite possible that Thucydides wrote *gele/ontes, which word, being unknown to the copyist, took the corrupt shape *(/ellhnes The *gele/ontes were the most aristocratic of the four old Attic tribes. Hdt. (v. 66) tells how Cleisthenes abolished the old tribal division of *gele/ontes, *ai)gikorei=s, *)argadei=s and *(/oplhtes, and substituted a local division into ten tribes. The object of this measure was to break up old ties of clanship in favour of democracy. The etymological value of the four titles is not very distinct, but is sufficiently so to enable us to infer the equivalence with another classification, viz. of *eu)patri/dai = *gele/ontes, *gew/moroi = *ai)gikorei=s + *)argadei=s, *dhmiourgoi/ = *(/oplhtes. The *gele/ontes are regularly mentioned first, as in Eur. Ion 1580, *gele/wn me\n e)/stai prw=tos k.t.l. On the whole question of these tribes and of the Eupatrids see Grote, H. G. vol. iii. c. x. It may be urged that, these tribes having been politically and nominally abolished in B.C. 509, there would be no such
thing as *gele/ontes neani/skoi at the date of the 400. But (1) the consciousness of clan connection did as a matter of fact survive very strongly at Athens, (2) this distinction of four tribes or castes occurred in other Ionian communities as a regular thing, (3) the passage in Euripides shows that the tradition was still kept alive in his day.]
toi=s a)po\ tou= kua/mou cf. c. 66, § 1.
to\n misqo\n a drachma per day (Bockh, Publ. Ec. Ath. i. 327).

e)/feron de\ k.t.l. ‘they themselves brought them their pay for all the remainder of their term of office, and gave it to them as they left the room,’ i.e. they paid it out of their own pockets (au)toi\).
u(pech=lqe ‘had come out, giving way to them (u(po-).’ Cf. u(peksth=nai etc.

oi( de\ tetrako/sioi. de\ in apodosis is common in Thucydides. The nearest parallel to the present place is iii. 98, me/xri me\n ou)=n oi( toco/tai ei)=xo/n te ta\ be/lh au)toi=s kai\ oi(=oi/ te h)=san xrh=sqai, oi( de\ a)ntei=xon.

pruta/neis a)peklh/rwsan They proceeded in the constitutional way so far. In the regular boulh/ the ten tribes took the prutanei/a in turn, and lots were cast for the order. Of the fifty pruta/neis for thirty-five days, there were five bodies of ten pro/edroi for seven days each, and of these there was an e)pista/ths for each day. The casting of lots for pruta/neis here in all probability includes the subdivisions pro/edroi, e)pista/ths. pruta/neis is the general term.

o(/sa pro\s tou\s qeou\s Cf. c. 92, § 9, o(/son kai\ a)po\ boh=s e(/neka w)rgi/zeto toi=s o(pli/tais; iv. 48, o(/sa ge kata\ to\n po/lemon to/nde; vii. 11, o(/sa ge kata\ gh=n; Dem. 272, o(/son kaq' e(/na a)/ndra. Cf. quantum ad. Either the indicative or the ‘restrictive’ infinitive may be supplied.
eu)xai=s kai\ qusi/ais i.e. they performed the ei)sith/ria (ei)shlu/sia in Corp. Inscr. 3173) in honour of Zeus *boulai=os and Athena *boulai/a.
polu\ metalla/cantes . . dioikh/sews ‘having changed (things) greatly from the democratic system.’ polu\ is adverbial. Less well ‘having changed a great part of . . .,’ which would rather be polla\.
plh\n frequently = plh\n o(/ti, e.g. Hdt. vii. 32.

ta\ de\ a)/lla k.t.l. The ta/ te a)/lla of Classen (followed by P-S) is undesirable. Thucydides began as if he would proceed metalla/cantes . . . kata\ kra/tos e)/nemon th
 po/lin. But after dioikh/sews he inserts a qualification ‘only they did not set about recalling the exiles, because of Alcibiades,’ after which he continues ‘yet in other respects, etc.,’ as if the parenthetic qualification had been a main sentence without plh
. That is to say, kata\ kra/tos e)/nemon th
 po/lin would be grammatically sufficient and correct, as also would be tou\s me
 feu/gontas ou) . . . e(/neka, ta\ de\ a)/lla k.t.l. Cf. vii. 33, sxedo
 ga/r ti pa=sa h( *sikeli/a, plh
 *)akraganti/nwn, (ou(=toi d' ou)de\ meq' e(te/rwn h)=san), oi( d' a)/lloi . . . e)boh/qoun.
a)/ndras te ... pro/s te *)=agin.
e)pith/deioi u(pecaireqh=nai cf. Andoc. 34 (37), e)pith/deios o)strakisqh=nai. The active infin. would have the same sense, i. 138, a)/cios qauma/sai. Jelf, § 667.

metesth/santo ‘had them removed’ = ‘banished them.’ Aeschin. Ctes. 129, tou\s me\n e)nagei=s kai\ tw=n pepragme/nwn ai)ti/ous metesth/santo, tou\s de\ di' eu)se/beian fugo/ntas kath/gagon. In i. 79, metasthsa/menoi pa/ntas = ‘had strangers removed.’ metasth=sai (act.) is frequent of banishment. Haacke's notion ‘brought them over to their side’ is away from the mark. The proceedings are kata\ kra/tos.
