ei)ko\s ei)=nai k.t.l. a brachylogy for ei)ko\s ei)=nai ma=llon cugxwrei=n, a(/te sfi/si kai\ ou)ke/ti tw=| a)pi/stw| dh/mw| a)\n cugxwrou=nta: ‘and that it was only reasonable that he should be more ready to make terms, masmuch as he would be making terms with them and no longer with the fickle democracy.’

o( de\ nomi/zwn . . . tara/ssesqai au)tou/s. Jowett states the general opinion that the confusion and tautology of this passage ‘may reasonably lead to the inference that this portion of the work has not received the last corrections from the author's hand.’ P-S with justice observes ‘sed hic non desideramus scriptoris diligentiam, sed sanum dicendi genus.’ Literally rendered the passage = ‘but Agis, thinking that the state (or government, c. 66, § 1) was not in a settled condition, and that the democratic body would not surrender its ancient liberty in so ready a manner (sc. to the oligarchs), and (further) thinking that, if it were to see a large Lacedaemonian force, it would not remain quiet, nay, not altogether believing that, as it was, they (sc. the Athemans) were no longer in a troublous state,’ etc. The last clause may also be rendered ‘nay, not
altogether believing that, as it was, they (sc. the oligarchs) were no longer afraid (sc. of the democracy still triumphing).’ If we make all due allowance for the fact that the subject of the first h(suxa/zein is th
 po/lin, and that of the second to
 dh=mon, and if we give whatever weight it may deserve to Jowett's rather weak defence of h(suxa/zein . . . ou)k a)
 h(suxa/zein on the ground of ‘the want of another word,’ the tautology is still too flagrant to be endurable, even by those who accept the ‘revision’ theory of Thucydidean composition. Nor is this the only objection. (1) According to Thucydides' manner ei(/ te introduces a new point in a distinct way, and for that new point we must look in the words that follow. (2) In reference to the words ei(/ te stratia
 pollh
 i)/doi sfw=n, it must be noted that he immediately after sends for stratia
 pollh
, and makes the Athenians see such a force. Why is this done? Because, says Thucydides, he hoped that he could frighten them (taraxqe/ntas) into submitting more readily to the terms the Lacedaemonians chose (ma=llon a)
 xeirwqh=nai sfi/sin, h(=| bou/lontai). [It is manifestly wrong to render (with Jowett) taraxqe/ntas as ‘distracted by civil strife,’ or ‘in the prevailing state of anarchy.’ For this tarassome/nous or tetaragme/nous would be required.] The thought is plainly, ‘Agis did not readily listen to the proposals of the oligarcns, because he thought they had no such assured position as to conclude terms with him, and he thought too that, by bringing up a large force against Athens, he was much more likely to obtain satisfactory terms.’ The latter part of this thought has suffered in the Greek text. Most editors have assumed corruption in the case of the first h(suxa/zein. Dobree (followed by P-S) ejected th
 po/lin ou)x h(suxa/zein and read ou)/t' eu)qu\s, making ou)/te answer to ei(/ te. Interpolation of the kind implied seems highly improbable. It would be more reasonable to suspect the second verb. If the next clause ou)d' e)n tw=| paro/nti . . . tara/ssesqai au)tou/s be rightly rendered, ‘nay, not altogether believing that, as it was, they (sc. the negotiating oligarchs) were no longer afraid,’ and if the context be carefully examined, it will appear that the rough English of the passage (when sound) should read ‘but Agis, thinking that the state was not in a settled condition, and that the democracy would not surrender its ancient liberty in so ready a manner, and thinking too that the sight of a large Lacedaemonian force would make it more ready to come to terms, nay, not altogether believing that, even as it was, they were no longer alarmed, was not at all responsive to those who had come from the 400, but sent for a large additional force from the Peloponnese, and not long afterwards he made a descent in person with the garrison from Deceleia, in conjunction with
the new arrivals, to the very walls of Athens, in the hope that the Athenians would be so alarmed as to submit themselves more readily on any terms to the Lacedaemonians, or that, in consequence of the confusion which would in all probability arise from both inside and outside, he might even be certain of capturing without any trouble at least the long walls, which would be left undefended.’ Agis thinks (1) that the internal feuds are not at an end, (2) that with a large force he could get better terms by frightening the Athenians, whom he already suspects (e)n tw=| paro/nti) of being frightened at him. The words ou)k a)
 h(suxa/zein seem, therefore, to disguise the sense ‘would be the more ready to come to terms,’ which Thucydides would most characteristically express by e.g. ou)k a)
 h(=sson with cugxwrh=sai or its equivalent. cugxwrh=sai, however, or cugxwrei=n would hardly have been thus corrupted. A rarer verb might suffer such a fate, and I venture to think that Thucyd. wrote ou)k a)
 h(=sson cugxa/zein, which, written, as usual, with merely an accent to represent the syllable -on, would easily pass into ou)k a)
 h(suxa/zein. sugxa/zein is given by Hesychius = sugxwrei=n. proxa/zein, though lost from literature, is quoted by Hesychius and Photius = proxwrei=n. So paraxa/zw = paraxwrw=. Xenophon (Anab. iv. 1, 16) has a)naxa/zontes = a)naxwrou=ntes, and a)naxa/zesqai = a)naxwrei=n (Cyr. vii. 1, 34). In Anab. iv. 8, 18, diaxa/zontas is a certain restoration of Schneider for dixa/zontas. diaxa/sasqai occurs Cyr. vii. 1, 31. The rarity of xa/zw and its compounds outside poetry will account for the corruption here. Such rare words would probably occur more frequently in a sound text of Thucydides, who gives us such rarities as dei=ma, prosferh/s, o(maixmi/a, kataspe/rxein, ei(rkth/, a)po/dasmos.
th\n po/lin ou)x h(suxa/zein i.e. that the new government was not permanently established.
eu)qu\s ou(/tw cf. r(a|di/ws ou(/tw, a(plw=s ou(/tws, ou(twsi\ me\n a)kou=sai, sic temere, etc.
i)/doi sc. h( po/lis, though to\n dh=mon is nearer in position.
sfw=n sc. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn.
ou)d' e)n tw=| paro/nti k.t.l. i.e. even with his present forces they were frightened at him. With tara/ssesqai of ‘alarm,’ cf. taraxqe/ntas (inf.), and Ar. Eq. 66, Aesch. Cho. 289, etc.
pa/nu ti cf. ma=llo/n ti, sxedo/n ti, etc.
ou) pisteu/wn mh\ ou)ke/ti cf. c. 60, § 1, a)du/nata h)=n mh\ ou) mega/la bla/ptein.

ou)ke/ti The oligarchs opened up negotiations with him as if they were established in power and were prepared to treat on equal terms. Agis suspects that their assurance is assumed, and that they have not yet got over their alarm at the outlook, viz. of the danger from the enemy outside made greater by the insecurity of their position inside. This alarm is described in c. 1.
au)tou\s either the negotiating oligarchs or the Athenians generally; preferably the former.
meta\ tw=n e)lqo/ntwn sc. e)k *peloponnh/sou.
xeirwqh=nai explained by Dukas as e)ndw)sein kai( ei/rh/nhn de/cesqai, and this sense is required by h(=| bou/lontai.

h)\ kai\ au)toboei\ a)
 k.t.l. If tw=n ga is retained, with punctuation at qo/rubon, we must repeat xeirwqh=nai in a different sense (= ai(reqh=nai): i.e. ‘hoping that either through being thrown into alarm the Athenians would the more easily be made to submit on the terms the Lacedaemonians desired, or else might be (overpowered) at the first onset through, etc.’ In this case ga implies that the capture of the long walls meant the capture of Athens, which, in fact, was far from being the case (cf. iv. 69). The reading of other MSS. th=s tw=n does away with this objection, as well as with the objection to repeating xeirwqh=nai in a different sense; it has, however, little support as compared with tw=n ga, and looks like a piece of early ‘editing.’ There is some objection also to th=s being separated so far from its noun. Baner suggested tw=n gou=n, but tw=n g' a)
 accounts better for the corruption. a)
 helps the sentence along, e)lpi/sas . . . au)toboei\ a)
 . . . tw=n g' a)
 . . . ou)k a)
 a(martei=n. a)
 is thrice expressed in ii. 41, le/gw kaq' e(/kaston dokei=n a)/n moi to
 au)to
 a)/ndra par' h(mw=n e)pi\ plei=st' a)
 ei)/dh kai\ meta\ xari/twn ma/list' a)
 eu)trape/lws to\ sw=ma au)/tarkes pare/xesqai. It is twice expressed in shorter sentences, e.g. i. 76, a)/llous g' a)
 ou)=n oi)o/meqa ta\ h(me/tera labo/ntas dei=cai a)
 ma/lista ei)/ ti metria/zomen. In the present passage a)
 recurs in the usual positions, viz. with the adverb (au)toboei\), with the restrictive particle (ge), and with the verb. Cf. Soph. Antig. 69, ou)/t' a)
, ei) qe/lois e)/ti pra/ssein, e)mou= g' a)
 h(de/ws drw/|hs me/ta.

dia\ th\n kat' au)ta\ e)rhmi/an The Athenians would, he thought, be defending the walls proper of the city or drawn away by internal confusion. ta\ makra\ tei/xh are the walls to the Peiraeus, of which the one called to\ e)/cwqen or to\ bo/reion was guarded.
prose/meice . . . e)ggu\s. Cf. iv. 93, e)peidh\ prose/meicen e)ggu\s tou= strateu/matos au)tw=n.
ta\ e)/ndoqen k.t.l. i.e. there was no sign of mutiny.

tw=n o(plitw=n kai\ yilw=n k t.l. The one article collects these various infantry contingents as against the cavalry. yiloi\ properly include toco/tai, and kai\ tocotw=n = ‘including bowmen.’ P-S compares iv. 36.
ou(/tw dh\ gnou\s ‘having found out (the state of things = his mistake).’ Cf. c. 75, § 1, didaxqe/ntes, ‘having been taught (better).’

oi( pra/ssontes not, as Jowett, ‘the promoters of the change,’ but = oi( ta\ th=s po/lews pra/gmata pr. (= oi( tw=n pragma/twn mete/xontes). Dem. 240 (45) and Aristot. Pol. vii. 2, 4, combine politeu/esqai kai\ pra/ttein.
kai\ th
 u(pero/rion a)sxoli/an. kai\ might be explanatory, but as opposed to stratei/as the reference may be to such other business as takes men abroad, e.g. commerce and service as mariners, etc.
e)s ou)de
 pra=gma k.t.l. lit. ‘the Athenians had never yet come to debate any matter of such dimensions that in dealing with it 5000 had assembled,’ which is another way of saying that ‘no matter, even the greatest in their history, had ever drawn together 5000 persons.’ (ou(/tw me/ga) . . . e)n w)=| . . . = w(/ste e)n au)tw=|. Cf. Ar. Ach. 736; Eur. Alc. 194; Hdt. iv. 28, dusxei/meros au(/th h( xw/rh ou(/tw dh/ ti e)sti
, e)/nqa . . . The statement must perhaps be taken cum grano, though it is apparently a fact that the number was generally less than 5000, and at least the assertion must have borne the appearance of truth. It is argued that 6000 votes were required for ostracism like that of Hyperbolus. But ostracism was a matter of voting and not of deliberation. Though 6000 persons were required to vote on the fixed day, the number of those attending the previous e)kklhsi/a (which decided whether such a vote should be taken) was not specified. The word bouleu/sontas is of importance.
a)/lla t' e)pistei/lantes k.t.l. either e)pistei/lante/s te ei)pei=n a)/lla ta\ pre/ponta, or join ta\ pre/pont' ei)pei=n, ‘and giving them further instructions, (viz.) what was suitable to say.’
kata/stasin sc. e)s a)rxh/n. Cf c. 70, § 1, kaqista/menoi e)s th\n a)rxh/n.
mh\ . . . ou)/t' au)to\s . . . sfa=s te i.e. ‘would neither itself abide by . . . nor suffer them to keep it.’ In the antithesis sfa=s is put first for emphasis. mh\ after sfa=s is redundant.
nautiko\s o)/xlos a specially democratic element in the state. Cf. c. 73, § 5, and c. 84, § 3.

a)rcame/nou tou= kakou= ‘that the mischief might begin there and . . .’ tou= kakou=, the feared (or possible) mischief. The expression appears to have been proverbial. Cf. a)rxe/kakos, Il. v. 63; a)rxh\ kakw=n, Hdt. v. 97; ou) smikrw=n kakw=n h)=rcen, Soph. Tr. 871.
e)n ga\r explaining o(/per e)ge/neto, not the fear of the oligarchs (dei/santes). The events at Samos were not yet known at Athens.

e)newteri/zeto h)/dh ta\ peri\ th
 o)ligarxi/an ‘a reaction had set in against the oligarchical movement’ (J.) The passive as in iv. 41, mh\ sfi/si ti newterisqh=| tw=n kata\ th
 xw/ran, corresponding to the active of i. 115, newteri/sai boulo/menoi th
 politei/an.

o(/nper = u)f' o(/nper. Cf. c. 76, § 4, e)k tou= au)tou= xwri/ou a)munei=sqai ou(=per pro/teron; i. 1, e)k de\ tekmhri/wn w(=n . . . pisteu=sai cune/bh (which, however, might be a case of attraction for oi(=s). Xen. Symp. iv. 1, e)n tw=| xro/nw| w(=| u(mw=n a)kou/w etc.
to/te viz. c. 21. On this use of to/te see c. 20, § 1.

o)/ntes dh=mos Jowett says ‘the popular party,’ and P-S ‘qui plebeii, ex plebe erant.’ But why not the more obvious sense ‘who were (since that time) a democracy’? kai\ o)/ntes dh=mos expresses the consequence of e)panasta/ntes. In the meaning sought by J. and P-S, Thucydides would rather have written e.g. oi( e)k tou= dh/mou to/te e)panasta/ntes.
e)ge/nonto e)s triakosi/ous cunwmo/tai ‘became conspirators to (about) the number of 300’ Cf. c. 21, e)s diakosi/ous tina/s. In § 6 they are called oi( triako/sioi simply.
o)/nti by attraction for ou)=si.

*(upe/rbolo/n te, answered by toi=s te ple/osin k.t.l. The clause kai\ a)/lla . . . toiau=ta cune/pracan, which might seem to answer to te, is only an amplification of the first member. The Samians first kill Hyperbolus and join the
Athenians in other deeds of violence: second, they prepare to attack the popular party.

*(upe/rbolon the famous demagogue, a luxnopw/lhs (Ar. Eq. 739) and butt of Aristophanes (Ach. 846, Eq. 1304, Vesp. 1007, Nub. 550-560, Pac. 681, Thesm. 839, etc.), as also of Cratinus, Eupolis and Plato Comicus. Aristophanes (Eq. 1304) also calls him moxqhro/s. Cf. Plut. Nic. 11, dia\ moxqhri/an. His political influence is attested from B.C. 425. He was probably ostracised in B.C. 416. Plutarch (Aristid. 7, Nic. 11, Alcib. 13) says that he brought ostracism on himself in attempting to bring it on Nicias or Alcibiades.

ou) dia\ duna/mews kai\ a)ciw/matos fo/bon on the purpose of ostracism cf. Aristot. Pol. v. 2, 4, . . . di' u(peroxh
 de\, o(/tan tis h)=| th=| duna/mei mei/zwn h)\ kata\ th
 po/lin kai\ th
 du/namin tou= politeu/matos: gi/nesqai ga ei)/wqen e)k tw=n toiou/twn monarxi/a h)\ dunastei/a: dio\ e)niaxou= ei)w/qasin o)straki/zein, oi)=on e)n *)/argei kai\ *)aqh/nhsin. Grote, H. G. pt. ii e. xxxi. Athens had ostracised Themistocles (i. 135), Aristides, Thucydides son of Melesias, and Cimon. The case of Hyperbolus brought the institution into contempt. Plutarch (Nic. 11) quotes Plato Comicus for the lines— kai/toi pe/praxe (sc. *(upe/rbolos) tw=n tro/pwn me
 a)/cia, au)tou= de\ kai\ tw=n stigma/twn a)na/cia: ou) ga toiou/twn ei(/nek' o)/strax' hu(re/qh. Plut. adds kai\ to\ pe/ras ou)dei\s e)/ti to\ para/pan e)cwstraki/sqh meta\ *(upe/rbolon.
meta\ *xarmi/nou te . . . kai/ tinwn k.t.l. i.e. aided and abetted by them.
e(no\s tw=n strathgw=n v. c. 30, § 1; c. 41, § 3; c. 42, § 2.
pi/stin dido/ntes au)toi=s Jowett's ‘to whom they pledged their faith’ misses the point. Rather by this act of assassination they give a guarantee of their earnestness.
toi=s ple/osin the Samian democracy.
tw=n te strathgw=n answered by kai\ *qrasubou/lw| k t.l, kai\ *qrasu/llw| . . . kai\ a)/llois being subordinate to the first kai\.
*qrasubou/lw| the same who afterwards kath/gage th\n fugh\n and overthrew the thirty tyrants.
*qrasu/llw| afterwards one of the six generals of the battle of Arginusae who were condemned by the Athenians.

o(pliteu/onti The scholiast explains a)nti\ tou= o(plitikou= a)/rxonti, but the Greek does not imply this. For promotion see on e)piba/ths c. 61, § 2. The following relative clause shows why these individuals are chosen out, and a private soldier in the Athenian army may very well have shown a special opposition to the oligarchical proceedings. The modern distinction of class and culture in such cases did not exist.
ou)k h)ci/oun k.t.l. Constr. ou)k h)ci/oun au)tou\s perii+dei=n sfa=s (the Samians), etc.
diafqare/ntas see on perudei=n a)poteixisqei=san, c. 26, § 3.
*)aqhnai/ois The dat. also Xen. Cyr. vi 1, 16. a)llo/trios with dat. Isoc. 306 C. This regimen is due to the sense of hostility, though the genitive of separation is more proper to the word.
cune/meinen For this tense in a relative clause instead of pluperfect v. Goodwin, M. and T. § 58.

tw=n te stratiwtw=n . . . kai\ tou\s *para/lous. The soldiers are distinguished from the sailors by te . . . kai\, and the words ou)x h(/kista do not imply that the *pa/raloi are part of the soldiery. ‘They begged both each one of the soldiers, and also, in a special degree, the Paraloi, etc.’ The *pa/raloi or *parali=tai are the crew of the state-galley *pa/ralos.
*)aqhnai/ous kai\ e)leuqe/rous i.e. not dou=loi nor even me/toikoi.
pa/ntas rowers (zugi=tai, qrani=tai, qalami=tai) as well as marines and officers.

e)n th=| nhi+\ ple/ontas Constr. literally ‘the Paraloi, men who sailed in their ship as a crew of Athenians and freemen one and all.’ Not=tou\s e)n th=| n pl., but=‘forming a crew of nothing but Athenians and freemen.’
kai\ mh\ parou/sh| ‘even before it came,’ i.e. at the mere suggestion.
au)toi=s sc. the Samian democratic party.
tria/konta/ tinas. Cf. c. 21, e)s diakosi/ous tina/s.

e)p' au)th=s either (1) simply ‘on board it’: cf. vi. 61, o( *)alkibia/dhs e)pi\ ploi/ou e)peraiw/qh, or (2) ‘in command of it’: cf. Hdt. v. 109, e)p' ou(= e)ta/xqhmen, and such phrases as o( e)pi\ th=s dioikh/sews. Add e.g. iv. 11, nau/arxos de\ au)tw=n e)pe/plei
*qrasumhli/das. But Chaereas seems not to have been a ‘Paralus’ himself, but only to have been sent with the ship to aid the mission. Otherwise a)/ndra *)aqhnai=on would be useless after c. 73, § 5. Moreover, if he had been in charge, his escape (dialaqw/n pws) would have been unlikely.
a)/ndra *)aqhnai=on i.e. not a Samian.

e)s th\n meta/stasin the reaction from oligarchy which was taking place, ‘the (attempted) revolution.’ Chaereas is one of those alluded to above (c. 73, § 4), oi(\ e)do/koun ma/lista e)nantiou=sqai toi=s cunestw=sin.
a)paggelou=nta with *xaire/an only. Cf. c. 63, § 1 for similar constructions.
tw=n me\n *para/lwn k.t.l. The clause which properly answers to this is o( de\ *xaire/as k.t.l. Another clause with de\ intervenes, but that de\ is merely connective.

e)s a)/llhn stratiw=tin nau=n. a)/llhn is appositive: ‘into another vessel, one which was a troop-ship’ Cf. ii. 31, xwri\s de\ o( a)/llos o(/milos yilw=n ou)k o)li/gos, ‘and, besides these, the light-armed as well.’ By being placed in a troop-ship they would be secured from rising. These *pa/raloi appear again c. 86, § 9.
au)tw=n ipsorum, by position: sc. tw=n stratiwtw=n.
dianoou=ntai with change of subject. Cf. c. 44, § 2, e)cefo/bhsan tou\s pollou\s kai\ e)/feugon.
ei)/rcein For the fut. with dianoou=ntai sce note on c. 2, § 1, cumproqumhqe/ntes a)palla/cesqai.
teqnh/kwsi the perfect of the immediately realised consequence. Cf. c. 66, § 2, e)teqnh/kei.
e)pikatayeudo/menos. e)pi- of addition. Cf. e)piqerapeu/wn, c. 47, § 1.

e)pi\ . . . w(/rmhsan ba/llein i.e. w(/rmhsan e)pi\ tou\s . . . (w(/ste) ba/llein (au)tou/s). Cf. c. 84, § 3, w(/rmhsan e)pi\ to\n *)astu/oxon w(/ste ba/llein. Liddell and Scott wrongly join w(/rmhsan ba/llein (intrans.).
kai\ e)/ti the other reading kai\ e)pi\ repeats e)pi\ unnecessarily. kai\ e)/ti = ‘and furthermore.’

u(po\ tw=n dia\ me/sou ‘by the moderate party’ is the usual
translation. It would be better to say ‘the neutral parties.’ Cf. iii. 82, ta\ de\ me/sa tw=n politw=n u(p' a)mfote/rwn h)\ o(/ti ou) cunhgwni/zonto h)\ fqo/nw| tou= periei=nai diefqei/ronto. P-S comparesXen Hell. v. 4, 25, oi( me\n ou)=n tou= *kleombro/tou fi/loi, a(/te e(tai=roi o)/ntes tw=| *sfodri/a|, a)polutikw=s au)tou= ei)=xon, to\n d' *)aghsi/laon kai\ tou\s e)kei/nou fi/lous e)fobou=nto, kai\ tou\s dia\ me/sou de/.

mh\ . . . a)pole/swsi Either (1) mh\ gives the purpose of e)pau/santo, while didaxqe/ntes stands alone (like gnou\s, c. 71, § 2), ‘having been taught better’; or (2) didaxqe/ntes and kwluqe/ntes together amount to the sense of being rendered cautious ( = eu)labei=s geno/menoi), and mh\ is dependent on that notion according to the principle stated by Goodwin, M. and T. § 354, and § 365. P-S renders ‘edocti eo consilio ne . . . perderent.’ The position would rather make for the latter view; the usual construction of kwlu/ein and dida/skein (mh\ with infin.) for the former.

w(/rkwsan pa/ntas . . . o(/rkous. For the double accus cf. Ar. Lys. 187, ti/n' o(/rkon o(rkw/seis poq' h(ma=s; The second accus. is limited to the etymologically cognate terms. In iv. 74, o(rkw/santes pi/stesi mega/lais mhde\n mnhsikakh/sein.
o(monoh/sein i.e. mh\ stasia/sein.

pole/mioi/ t' e)/sesqai the nomin. as if pa/ntes w)/mosan had preceded instead of w(/rkwsan pa/ntas. Similarly ou)de
 for mhde
 is a laxity not to be defended by any subtlety. In direct narration the oath would be pole/mioi/ t' e)so/meqa kai\ ou)de
 e)pikhrukeuso/meqa, and Thucydides retains ou)de
 as if after an ordinary verb of saying.

cunekoinw/santo lit. ‘the soldiers made common cause with the Samians in all their interests and in the issue of the risk they ran.’ The argument is—they thought that the Samians and themselves were in the same straits: both alike had nowhere to turn beyond themselves: they could not yield to the 400, and they could not yield to the enemy. Accordingly they made common cause. Jowett takes pra/gmata as ‘troubles.’ Rather it is ‘interests.’
oi( me\n the Athenians in Samos.
oi( de\ the oligarchs at Athens.
a)nagka/zontes i.e. attempting to do so. Cf. c. 48, § 3, cunista/ntes.
e)po/hsan see on e)poi/oun, c. 36, § 2. Not ‘held’ an assembly, but ‘got together.’
e)/pausan sc. th=s a)rxh=s.

e)xo/ntwn sfw=n. e)/xontes (sfei=s) would be the normal construction, i.e. subjective rather than circumstantial. But cf. ii. 83, e)peidh\ a)ntiparaple/ontas e(w/rwn au)tou\s para\ gh=n sfw=n komizome/nwn; iii. 13, bohqhsa/ntwn de\ u(mw=n . . . proslh/yesqe; vii. 48, xrhma/twn ga\r a)pori/a| au)tou\s e)ktruxw/sein a)/llws te kai\ . . . qalassokratou/ntwn.
ta/s te a)/llas k.t.l. answered by kai\ dunatw/teroi k.t l., the sentence from po/lin te . . . to kai\ pro/teron being an cxplanatory parenthesis.
ta\ xrh/mata i.e. to\n fo/ron. o(moi/ws . . . kai\ ei) . . . k.t.l., ‘in the same way as if they had their headquarters at Athens.’
par' e)la/xiston dh\ ‘within exceedingly little of . . .’ For the phrase cf. c. 33, § 3.
o(/te e)pole/mhsen viz. in B.C. 440 (i. 115). For the comparative naval successes see i. 116, 117.
ou(=per i.e. e)c ou(=per, v. c. 73, § 1.
sfei=s grammatically unnecessary, but added to emphasise the contrast.
kai\ di' e(autou/s te. For kai\ . . . te sec Jowett's note on i. 9, and the remark on c. 68, § 2.
prokaqhme/nous Cf. Xen. Hell. v. 2, 4, toi=s h(mi/sesi tw=n stratiwtw=n prokaqhme/nois tw=n tafreuo/ntwn; Hdt. viii. 36, etc pro- expresses protection.
au)tou\s sc. tou\s e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais. They (the speakers) had kept the Peloponnesians from blockading the port of Athens. kai\ with pro/teron. kratei=n is imperfect.

(oi(\) kai\ nu=n . . . katasth/sontai The MS. reading kai\ . . . katasth/sontai, with sudden change to the finite verb (as if o(/ti had preceded), is not tolerable in a passage where every other clause is put consistently in the infinitive. Dobree's katasth/sesqai is obvious, but would not have suffered this corruption. Classen's katasth=nai (which seems meant for kaqesta/nai) is open to the same objection. Haase, P-S and others suppose a lacuna, P-S giving kai\ nu=n e)/ti ma=llon, e)pei\ e)s k.t.l. Something less drastic is desirable, and correction must start with the considerations that (1) katasth/sontai is likely to be genuine, in which case the clause must be relative
and introduced by some relative pronoun or adverb, which was accidentally lost for some not too recondite reason; (2) the genitive boulome/nwn (sc. tw=n e)n th=| po/lei) makes it most probable that the subject of katasth/sontai is not ‘the party at Athens’ but either ‘those in Samos’ or else ‘the several parties.’ The likelihood that the subject is the speakers is increased by the clause w(/ste au)toi\ dunatw/teroi ei)=nai k.t.l. [The scholiast says e)n tou/tw| duna/mews au)toi\ kaqesta=sin, w(/ste k.t.l., which would seem to imply a reading kaqesta/nai, but which certainly shows his view as to the subject of the verb.] The easiest correction satisfying these conditions is to insert oi(\, which fell out accidentally after the -*o*u of e)/splou, and whose loss was facilitated by the apparent co-ordination of kai\ pro/teron . . . kai\ nu=n. Compare the total loss of ou) after *xi/ou c. 101, § 1, and at the same time confusions like that of oi(/per and ou(=per inf. § 6. oi(\ refers to the emphatic word in the previous clause, viz. e(autou/s.
kai\ dunatw/teroi ‘that they would actually be better able’: i.e. not merely as well off, but even better.
braxu/ te/ ti, te introducing a new point.
a)polwleke/nai sc. sfei=s.

oi(/ ge a brachylogy for ou)de\n a)polwleke/nai (a)polwleko/tes tou/tous) ge, oi(\ . . . When it is said that in such condensations the relative = e)pei\ e)kei=noi, the strict analysis of the expression should not be lost sight of. Cf. ii. 44, xalepo\n oi)=da pei/qein o)/n, w(=n kai\ polla/kis e(/cete u(pomnh/mata; iv. 26, a)qumi/an te plei/sthn o( xro/nos parei=xe para\ lo/gon e)pigigno/menos, ou(\s w)/|onto h(merw=n o)li/gwn e)kpoliorkh/sein.
mh/te preferred to ou)/te because oi(/ ge is descriptive.
a)ll' au)toi\ . . . stratiw=tai a lax semi-parenthesis, constructed, however, as if it were part of the relative sentence, oi(/ ge being treated as = e)pei/ ge.

ou(=per e(/neka k.t.l. either (1) ‘which is the reason why a state exercises control over camps,’ or (2) (as Grote) ‘which is the great superiority of a city over a camp.’ The former is the better in point of sense, while the latter would rather have required di' o(/per or w(=|per.
kai\ e)n tou/tois ‘even in these matters,’ sc e)n oi)=s e)bou/leuon.
au)toi\ de\ sw/|zein k.t.l. ‘whereas they themselves were upholding them, and would endeavour to compel the oligarchs also to uphold them.’

w(/ste ou)de\ tou/tous . . . xei/rous ei)=nai lit. ‘so that these too, who could give good advice, were not worse among them (than at Athens).’ Jowett neatly renders ‘our advisers in the camp then are at least as good as theirs in the city.’ a)\n with bouleu/oien forms an apodosis.

w(/ste ou)de\ Cf. v. 40, w(/ste ou)de\ pro\s *)aqhnai/ous e)/ti sfi/sin ei)=nai cummaxi/an poh/sasqai. See Shilleto, Appendix B to Dem. De Falsa Leg. ou) in such sentences represents ou) with indic. in the direct narration (here ou)k ei)si\ . . . )
kai\ ta\ tou= pole/mou k.t.l. Jowett points out the favourite opposition of lo/gos and e)/rgon implied in kai\.

oi( de/ka presbeutai/ These words are probably rightly rejected by Herwerden. They are unnecessary to the sense, and pre/sbeis is the correct plural. presbeutai/ occurs only here and in c. 86, § 1 (where it is equally unnecessary), except for Andoc. 28, 36, presbeuta\s u(ma=s h(mei=s oi( pre/sbeis poiou=men, where the reason of its presence is obvious. In inscriptions presbeutai/ does not appear till the third century B.C.
u(po/ te *)astuo/xou kai\ *t. The position of te is the usual one in such combinations. See c. 54, § 2, ta/ te pro\s to\n *tiss. kai\ *)alkibia/dhn.

tou= me\n ou)k k.t.l. as if tou= de\ *tissafe/rnous ou) komi/zontos were to follow. But to\n d' au)= *tissafe/rnh, dependent on diebo/wn, takes its place, the construction meanwhile having been interrupted by the clause a)lla\ . . . diatribh=nai, which has reverted to dependence on the verb of complaining.
pro/teron sc. c. 30 (fin.), 38 (fin.), 44 (fin.), 60, § 3.
au)toi/ te . . . kai\ to\ nautiko\n ‘on the one hand they themselves . . . on the other the Athenian fleet . . .’

ou)de/pw e)n tw=| au)tw=| ei)sin ‘are not yet united.’ pw is an anticipation of the fact first mentioned in c. 79, § 3, prosede/xonto kai\ to\n *strombixi/dhn k.t.l. Cf. the similar anticipation with e)/ti noted in c. 36, § 1. Strombichides with twenty-four Athenian ships had sailed to Abydos (c. 62, § 2), and other ships were left in Chios.

a)lla\ . . . me/nontes k.t.l. a)lla\ answers to ou)k (e)qe/lontos) but the clause reverts to the infin. after diebo/wn, i.e. a)lla\ (diebo/wn) me/nontes (sfei=s) kinduneu/sein k.t.l. ‘No,’ they said, ‘while we wait for the Phoenician fleet, we shall most likely be worn out.’
ta\s . . . *foini/ssas see c. 59.

a)/llws o)/noma kai\ ou)k e)/rgon either in apposition to nau=s or to the whole notion ‘waiting for the Ph. ships.’ a)/llws = ‘merely.’ Cf. Dem. De F Leg. 348, o)/xlos a)/llws kai\ baskani/a katefai/neto; Eur. Tro. 476, ou)k a)riqmo\n a)/llws; Soph. Phil. 947, ei)/dwlon a)/llws, and frequently.
diatribh=nai Cf. c. 46, § 2, katatri=yai; c. 56, § 2, tri/bein a)mfote/rous; c. 87, § 3, i(/na diatri/bh| a)pelqw\n ta\ tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn.

komi/zein . . . kai\ o(/ti . . . kakoi= one might have looked for komi/zein . . . kai\, o(/ti ou) . . . di/dwsi, kakou=n. The reverse change from the constr. with o(/ti to the infin. is common. P-S quotes as a parallel for the present passage v. 65, tou\s strathgou\s e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon . . . tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous a)feqh=nai . . . kai\ o(/ti . . . ou)dei\s e)pidiw/kei.
do/can . . . w(/ste . . . Cf. c. 45, § 3, e)di/dasken w(/ste . . . pei=sai w(/ste cugxwrh=sai; c. 81, § 1, th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs e)xo/menos . . . w(/ste . . . So yhfi/zesqai w(/ste frequently.

a)po\ cuno/dou lit. ‘as a result of a council meeting.’ Cf. c. 97, § 2, a)f' w(=n (e)kklhsiw=n) nomoqe/tas e)yhfi/santo; i. 97, a)po\ koinw=n cuno/dwn bouleuo/ntwn. The use of a)po\ in e.g. c. 99, a)po\ paragge/lmatos ai)fnidi/ou a)/ras, is akin.

dw/deka kai\ e(kato\n the ninety-four ships of c. 44, § 2, had been reinforced by others from Chios (c. 63, § 2). It is not possible, however, to keep an exact tally of every ship in the narrative of Thucydides.

*muka/lhs Mycale was the scene of the defeat of the Persians in B.C. 479 (i. 89). The name belongs to the range which ends in Cape Trogilium. According to Steph. Byz. and Scylax there was a town of the name, and something more definite than the range seems to be required here.
ai(\ e)/tuxon k.t.l. This territory belonged to Samos. Glauce is placed by Kiepert at the south and near the point of Cape Trogilium.
o)li/gon about a mile.
pro\s th\n *muka/lhn ‘looking towards M.’
tw=| plh/qei with i(kanoi\, ‘strong enough in point of numbers.’
e)k th=s *milh/tou i.e. they had got previous information from Miletus. Cf. c. 41, § 4, e)pu/qonto oi( e)n th=| *sa/mw| e)k th=s *mh/lou to\n e)pi/ploun au)tw=n.
naumaxhsei/ontas see cumbhsei/onta, c. 56, § 3.

e)p' *)abu/dou. The genitive is brachylogic, tho sense being e)p' *)abu/dou (a)postalei/sais kai\ e)kei=se) a)fikome/nais. The reference is to c. 62, § 2, whence the easier reading e)p' *)/abudon seems to be taken. For the position of the attributive participle cf. c. 35, § 2, and c. 36, § 1.

o)ktw\ kai\ e(kato\n. P-S wishes to read ps' for ph', i.e. 106 instead of 108, on the ground that Strombichides would only bring twenty-four ships (c. 62, § 2). But why may he not have taken others from Delphinium on his way?

a(qro/ais tai=s nausi\n either (1) the ships of the Athenians, the dative depending on a)cio/maxoi or a)ntanh/gonto, and the thought being a(/te h)/dh a(qro/ais ou)/sais, or (2) the ships of the Peloponnesians, the dat. being instrumental and the thought kai/per a(qro/ais ou)/sais. For the former it may be argued that kai/per is the more difficult to supply, and that there is a reference to the previous willingness of the Peloponnesians to fight o(/te ai( nh=es tw=n *)aqhnai/wn ou)de/pw e)n tw=| au)tw=| ei)si/n (c. 78). For the latter, the instrumental sense would answer to c. 79, § 2, ou) nomi/santes tw=| plh/qei diakinduneu=sai i(kanoi\ ei)=nai, and e)kei/nwn would seem to be required with nausi\n unless the ships were those of the Peloponnesians.
w(/sper . . . proseta/xqh sec c. 8, § 2; c. 39, § 2.
to\ *buza/ntion a colony of Megara. It had previously revolted from Athens (B.C. 440) along with Samos and had been induced (i. 117).

kai\ ai( me
 tw=n *p. k.t.l. To the general sentence belonging to ai( me
 . . . nh=es there should correspond a sentence of the shape oi( de\ e)n th=| *sa/mw| *)aqhnai=oi k.t l, which is differently expressed in § 4. For the rest, the present sentence might have been expected to run (1) ai( me
 . . . nh=es au(=tai e)xeima/sqhsan, kai\ ai( me
 *dh/lou labo/menai . . . pa/lin h)=lqon e)s *mi/lhton, ai( de\ . . . diaswqei=sai *buza/ntion a)fista=si, or (2) ai( me
 . . . nh=es xeimasqei=sai, ai( me
 . . . labo/menai . . . h)=lqon, ai( de\ . . . a)fista=si, by the scheme of partitive apposition. To write e)xeima/sqhsan would bring us nearer to the former, and to omit kai\ before ai( me
 *dh/lou would bring us nearer the latter. The
former correction is in no way likely, the latter is not out of the question in the combination —*q*e*i*c*a*i*a*i—. Nevertheless neither of these changes removes the difficulty that the only finite verb after ai( me
 *dh/lou k.t.l. is a)fista=si, and that the ships which returned to Miletus are grammatically said to ‘bring about the revolt of Byzantium.’ It is best to treat the text as an anacoluthon by confusion of the two constructions given above, with the further fault that the disarranging parenthesis *kle/arxos . . . h)=rxen causes ai( me
 . . . e)lqou=sai to be left without a verb. xeimasqei=sai, like e)lqou=sai, is nomin. pendens.
*dh/lou labo/menai gen. of the means of safety grasped. Cf. iii. 24, labo/menai tw=n o)rw=n diafeu/gousi. So a)ntilabe/sqai. Delos is about 120 miles W. of Miletus.
au)=qis either ‘subsequently’ or ‘(he started) again.’
h)=rxen as a(rmosth/s (Xen. Hell. i. 3, 15). In Xen. loc. cit. Helixus is met with as general of the Megarians under Clearchus.
o)ktw\ there are eight in c. 107, § 1. The number diaswqei=sai is ten. It would be futile to inquire into the doings of individual ships.

ai)ei/ te . . . e)xo/menos as if kai\ te/los . . . pei/sas with finite verb kath=ge were to follow, i.e. ‘Thrasybulus, who both clung to the same view . . . and also at last induced the soldiery to accept it . . . proceeded to bring back Alcibiades.’ With pei/sas the sentence would be correct, except that kai\ before *yhfisame/nwn would be better omitted. But instead of pei/sas the finite verb e)/peisen is wrongly written, the intervening e)peidh\ . . . *)alkibia/dhn having diverted the construction. Though the sentence begins with a plural subject, the singular construction proceeds in agreement with *qrasu/boulos alone, as the chief spirit in whom the doings of the rest are summed up. Cf. c. 63, § 1, oi( e)n th=| *milh/tw| kai\ o( *)astu/oxos puqo/menos . . . to\n *strombixi/dhn kai\ ta\s nau=s a)pelhluqo/ta e)qa/rshse.
th=s au)th=s sc. as that stated in c. 76, § 7. For the phrase cf. i. 140, th=s me\n gnw/mhs ai)ei\ th=s au)th=s e)/xomai mh\ ei)/kein *peloponnhsi/ois.
e)peidh\ mete/sthse k.t.l. ‘after he had effected the revolution’ (to democracy).
w(/ste see on do/can w(/ste, c. 79, § 1.

e)p' e)kklhsi/as a phrase not elsewhere found in the classical period, though it occurs in later Greek. It is analogous to the genitive with e)pi\ (= coram) in e.g. e)pi\ martu/rwn, e)pi\ pa/ntwn (e)cele/gxein) etc., or to that in the sense ‘on the occasion of’; v. Lidd. and Scott, e)pi\ A. III. 3.
au)toi=s instead of sfi/si. Cf. c. 76, § 3, au)tw=n a)fe/sthke.

metasth/seien sc. o( *)alkibia/dhs. The optat. is used rather than metasth/sei, the notion being ‘thinking their only safety lay in the chance of Alcibiades making Tissaphernes change sides from the Peloponnesians to them.’
th/n te i)di/an cumfora\n as opposed to the affairs of the state—kai\ peri\ tw=n politikw=n.
th=s fugh=s gen. of definition.

tw=n te mello/ntwn The te is placed as if some antithesis with the present was to be expressed; but as e)lpi/das can only refer to the future, and as the antithesis is not expressed in the expected form, the position of te is scarcely logical. ‘He brought them into great hopes both as regards the future, and also assured them of his great influence, etc.’ Either tw=n te mello/ntwn e)s e)lpi/das k.t.l. or e)s e)lpi/das te au)tou\s tw=n mello/ntwn k.t.l. would have been normal. Such antithesis as there is appears in the clause kai\ u(perba/llwn k.t.l.
foboi=nto au)to\n not au(to\n. Cf. au)toi=s sup. § 1.
ai( cunwmosi/ai which were now determined to do without him, c. 63, § 4, and c. 70, § 1.

diaba/llointo of reciprocal ill-will; ‘might be drawn into as bad terms as possible with Tissaphernes.’ Cf. c. 83, § 1; c. 109, § 1; Plat. Phaedo 68 A, and the active in Plat. Symp. 222 C, e)me\ kai\ *)aga/qwna diaba/llein.

e)kpi/ptoien = e)kba/llointo. a)po\ (before tw=n), found in some good MSS., is inferior Greek. e)kba/llein and e)kpi/ptein take either the simple gen. or gen. with e)k, but not properly a)po/. Yet cf. Eur. Phoen. 1193, e)/qnh|skon, e)ce/pipton a)ntu/gwn a)/po.
d' ou)=n resuming the notion e)mega/lune th\n e(autou= du/namin after the explanatory i(/na . . . e)kpi/ptoien.

ta/de what follows. me/gista e)pikompw=n. me/gista is predicative: ‘boastfully
exaggerating them to the utmost.’ Otherwise ‘making very great boasts about the matter,’ the two words standing more by themselves.

e)cargurw=sai Cf. Hdt. vi. 86, e)/doce/ moi ta\ h(mi/sea pa/shs th=s ou)si/hs e)cargurw/santa qe/sqai para\ se/; Dem. De Pac. 59, th
 ou)si/an e)carguri/sas. For the notion cf. Xen. Hell. i. 5, 3, e)a
 de\ kai\ tau=ta (e)kli/ph|) kai\ to
 qro/non katako/yein e)f' ou(= e)ka/qhto, o)/nta a)rgurou=n kai\ xrusou=n. Our expression ‘to sell his shirt off his back’ is paralleled in Xen. Anab. vii. 5, 5.
e)n *)aspe/ndw| on the Eurymedon in Pamphylia. The town itself was about seven miles from the mouth of the river.
kai\ ou) *peloponnhsi/ois. ou) though following h)= mh\n, is the proper negative, being joined to one word in emphatic antithesis to a preceding positive (komiei=n te' *)aqhnai/ois).

ei) sw=s au)to\s katelqw\n au)tw=| a)nade/caito ‘if he himself (Alc.), being safely restored, were to become surety to him (Tissaphernes).’ This reading best reconciles the discrepancies of MSS., and makes an entirely satisfactory sense. sw=s is a word of Thucydides (iii. 34).

a)nade/casqai is a legal term of ‘going bail,’ Theophr. Char. xxvi. (quoted by P-S). The dat. commodi au)tw=| is obviously natural, and is paralleled by Polyb. xi. 25, 9. au)toi=s of several good MSS. could only be unsatisfactorily taken as ethic dat. with katelqw\n. If au)toi=s as a variant on au)tw=| has any significance, it may point to au)tou\s, a)nade/casqai/ tina being Greek for ‘to go bail for’ a person. Cf. Polyb. v. 16, 8. Probably, however, it is merely a mistaken emendation.
a)neti/qesan ‘entrusted to him,’ or ‘were for entrusting to him.’ Cf. Arist. Nub. 1452— tauti\ di' u(ma=s, w)= *nefe/lai, pe/ponq' e)gw\ u(mi=n a)naqei\s a(/panta ta)ma\ pra/gmata.

dia\ to\ au)ti/ka k.t.l. see crit. note. The ordinary reading is kata\ to\ au)ti/ka k.t.l. As an expression of time kata\ to\ au)ti/ka is not found, and in any case would be hardly appropriate with e(toi=moi h)/dh. dia\ to\ au)ti/ka is of course impossible in such a meaning. If kata\ were sound it would have to be regarded as governing to\ . . katafronei=n in the sense of dia\, by a rare use akin to such expressions as kat' e)/xqos, ai)ti/an kaq' h(/ntina, etc., while the variant dia\ would be its interpretation. The MSS. go on to read tou/s te (or with little support to/te) paro/ntas. ge of P-S makes excellent sense, and if kai\ before
plei=n is rendered as = etiam, the sentence becomes normal by joining dia\ (or kata\) with the following articular infinitive. The general sense is ‘their present enemies were not enough for them, and they were eager actually to sail against Athens.’
kai\ pa/nu ‘altogether’ (pronounced with emphasis). Cf. ii. 11, w(/ste xrh\ kai\ pa/nu e)lpi/zein; vi. 10, etc.
i(/na dh\. For the tone implied in dh\ cf. c. 9, § 1.
e)ndei/knusqai ‘show off.’
tw=| *tissafe/rnei . . . e)kei/nois instrumental cases. He frightened each party with the other.
punqano/menoi ‘getting to know of.’
kai\ pro/teron to be joined. kai\ is not connective. The distrust had existed before. See c. 78 and the general dissatisfaction in c. 45.
diebe/blhnto the pluperfect, is a quasi-imperfect, of a state (=e)xqrw=s die/keinto). For the sense cf. diaba/llointo, c. 81, § 2.
ga\r going back to the reason of their ‘earlier distrust.’

kata\ to
 e)pi\ k.t.l. This correction of Göller and Dobree for kai\ of MSS. has the merit of restoring grammar with the slightest possible change. An interchange of kai\ and kata\ is among the commonest errors. If kai\ were sound, it would have to be supposed that Thucydides had meant to proceed in some such way as cunhne/xqh kai\ to
 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pi/ploun . . . e)s mi=sos ma=llon e)/ti e)sbeblhke/nai to
 *tissafe/rnh k.t.l., i.e. ‘for it happened that the descent of the Athenians upon Miletus (when they had refused to come out and fight them) had also helped to bring Tissaphernes (who had in consequence become much more remiss in paying their wages) more and more into the hatred in which he was already previously held by them.’ kai\ could have stood if some transitive verb had taken the place of e)pidedwke/nai (which is only intransitive in the sense of increasing; cf. vi. 60, etc.) The easy correction kata\ can hardly be resisted. The literal sense becomes ‘it happened to them that, when at the time of the Athenian descent on Miletus they had refused to go out against them and fight, Tissaphernes, having become much more remiss in the matter of paying wages, had advanced farther in the hatred in which, even previously to these
events, he was held by them on account of Alcibiades.’ This is still confused enough in arrangement, but none the less Thucydidean. The force of kai\ before e)s to\ misei=sqai, which is not at first apparent, may be found by comparison with e.g. c. 1, § 4, kai\ w(s e)/docen au)toi=s kai\ e)poi/oun tau=ta, where kai\ may be called consequential. Thus cunhne/xqh . . . *tissafe/rnh . . . a)rrwsto/teron geno/menon, kai\ e)s to\ misei=sqai . . . e)pidedwke/nai, ‘it happened that Tissaphernes, having become remiss, had (as a consequence) also, etc.’
kata\ to\n e)pi/ploun sc. c. 79, § 6.
a)rrwsto/teron similarly a)rrwsti/a| = a)proqumi/a| (sec. Suidam) in in. 15.
e)s . . . e)pidedwke/nai Cf. vi. 60, e)pedi/dosan . . . e)s to\ a)griw/teron; Hdt. ii. 13, e)pididw=| e)s u(/yos.
dia\ to\n *)alkibia/dhn with misei=sqai. See c. 45, § 2, for the injury done by Alcibiades' persuasions in the matter of the pay of the Peloponnesians.
oi(=a/per. Cf. c. 84, § 3, oi(=a dh\ nau=tai.

kai/ tines kai\ tw=n a)/llwn k.t.l. i.e. the respectable part of the sailors and rowers, who were of inferior standing to the soldiery. Hence a)nqrw/pwn rather than a)ndrw=n. Jowett's ‘some men of position’ takes a different view.

kai\ ou) mo/non to\ stratiwtiko/n objected to by Kruger and P-S as a redundancy, and for a fancied suspiciousness in the use of stratiwtiko/n. The latter objection is nought, in view of the frequency of to\ nautiko/n, to\ cummaxiko/n, to\ o(plitiko/n, etc. The former is partly met by the consideration that Thucydides is strongly emphasising a certain fact.
ou)/te . . . te without the usual contrast. The second member is an amplification of the notion of the first.
to/ te dido/menon k.t.l. sc. lamba/noien.
a)palla/cetai o(/qen k.t.l. i.e. e)kei=se (or e)s toiou=ton to/pon) o(/qen, ‘to some place from which they could get maintenance.’
e(/cei Cf. c. 86, § 7.

e)pife/ronta o)rga\s = ‘morigerantem.’ xarizo/menon kai\ sugxwrou=nta, Schol. In i. 140 o)rgh=| = ‘mood,’ though determined by the context. Cf. iii. 82, pro\s ta\ paro/nta ta\s o)rga\s tw=n pollw=n o(moioi=; Pind. P. ii. 141, a)lwpe/kwn o)rgai=s i)/keloi.
di' i)/dia ke/rdh Cf. c. 50, § 3, e)pi\ i)di/ois ke/rdesi.
cunhne/xqh . . . qo/rubos. Cf. Plat. Polit. 270 C, metabola\s sumferome/nas.
peri\ to\n *)astu/oxon Liddell and Scott, peri\ C. I. 5.
ga\r epexegetic, like nam, enim, introducing the narrative.

*surakosi/wn kai\ *qouri/wn Twenty Syracusan ships came in c. 26, § 1, and one in c. 35, § 1. Ten Thurian ships under Dorieus arrived in c. 35, § 1. Of these some were lost (c. 35, § 3). Five appear again in c. 61, § 2.

o(/sw| ma/lista kai\ e)leu/qeroi answered by tosou/tw| kai\ qrasu/tata. o(/sw| kai\ e)leuqerw/tatoi is resolved into o(/sw| kai\ ma/lista e)leu/qeroi, and, the emphasis being upon their ‘freedom,’ kai\ is put before that word rather than before ma/lista.

to\ plh=qos in partitive apposition to oi( nau=tai, as oi( plei=stoi might have been in a similar sentence. Cf. i. 126, oi( *)aqhnai=oi a)ph=lqon oi( polloi/. Plato, Phaedr. 275 B, has w(s e)pi\ to\ plh=qos. The accus. of closer definition, as in po/soi to\ plh=qos (Hdt. iv. 2, etc.), has no place here. to\ plh=qos=‘the majority,’ i. 20, 125.

tw=| ge *dwriei= k.t.l. ‘and in the case of Dorieus, he even went so far as to raise his stick against him.’ The treatment of Dorieus is specially remarkable, hence ge. Concerning Dorieus see c. 35, § 1.

th
 bakthri/an The carrying of a stick was a peculiarity of Lacedaemonian generals. Commentators quote Plut. Themist. 11 (of Eurybiades), e)parame/nou de\ th
 bakthri/an w(s pata/contos o( *qemistoklh=s e)/fh: pa/tacon me/n, a)/kouson de/; Xen. Anab. ii. 3, 11, (of Clearchus), e)n me
 th=| a)ristera=| xeiri\ to\ do/ru e)/xwn, e)n de\ th=| decia=| bakthri/an. Add Xen. Hell. vi. 2, 19 (of Mnasippus), to
 me/n tina bakthri/a|, to
 de\ tw=| stu/raki e)pa/tacen.

oi)=a dh\ nau=tai. The ellipse is not of o)/ntes, but rather of some general verb-sense, e.g. poiou=sin or poei=n filou=sin, ‘as is usual with sailors,’ ‘in sailor fashion.’ The turbulence of sailors was proverbial, cf. c. 72, § 2. Eur. Hec. 607, a)ko/lastos o)/xlos nautikh/ t' a)narxi/a.

e)krage/ntes Cf. Hdt. vi. 129, katei=xe e(wuto/n, ou) boulo/menos e)kragh=nai e)s au)to/n; id. viii. 74. Lucian (Calum. 23) has the active with cog. acc. e)krhgnu/nai o)rgh/n. The reading e)gkrago/ntes
is less forcible, though otherwise appropriate. Cf. Arist. Plut. 427, ou) ga\r a)\n tosoutoni\ e)ne/krages h(mi=n mhde\n h)dikhme/nh.
ou) me/ntoi . . . ge in opposition to what was expected. ‘However, he escaped stoning . . .’

to\ e)n th=| *milh/tw| . . . frou/rion. In terms of the treaty of c. 58 Miletus now belongs to the Persian empire. Cf. inf. § 5, tou\s a)/llous tou\s e)n th=| basile/ws. The Milesians are thus practically in revolt.
au)tou= sc. tou= *tissafe/rnous, not tou= frouri/ou, in which case au)tou= would be otiose after e)no/ntas.
*li/xas who had been so firm in his demands, c. 43, § 3.
au)toi=s viz. with these proceedings.

kai\ douleu/ein answered by kai\ e)piqerapeu/ein. douleu/ein is a strong term, but applicable to the present subjection of the Milesians, who are no longer a free Greek state. Cf. c. 46, § 3, cugkatadoulou=n e)kei/nw| (sc. to Tissaphernes) o(/soi e)n th=| basile/ws *(/ellhnes oi)kou=sin.
e)piqerapeu/ein, ‘furthermore to court his favour.’ e)pi- has the sense of ultro. The same word has a different meaning in c. 47, § 1.
u(/steron with a)poqano/nta (= e)pei\ u(/steron a)pe/qanen). as the position shows.
au)toi=s the Peloponnesians.
pro/s te to\n *)astu/oxon kai\ to\n *t. Cf. c. 78, § 1, u(po/ te *)astuo/xou kai\ *tissafe/rnous.
*mi/ndaros slain next year (B.C. 410) at Cyzicus in a battle with the Athenians, Xen. Hell. i. 1, 18.
e)ph=lqe so e)pelqei=n of taking command, c. 20, § 1.

di/glwsson like the Carian Mus sent by Mardonius in Hdt. viii. 133-135, and the interpreter Pigres in Xen. Anab. i. 2, 17. The epithet implies that both languages were spoken naturally and equally well. Cf. iv. 109, oi)kou=ntai cummi/ktois e)/qnesi barba/rwn diglw/sswn.

tou\s *mig. poreuome/nous i.e. an embassy from them.
Jowett compares i. 31, where a whole people is similarly identified with its representatives. poreuome/nous = ‘were on their way.’
ma/lista with e)pi\ kataboh=| k.t.l., ‘chiefly to decry himself.’
*(ermokra/th who had all along resisted Tissaphernes. Cf. c. 45, § 3.
e)/xqra de\ pro\s au)to\n (sc. to\n *(ermokra/th) h)=n au)tw=| (sc. tw=| *tissafe/rnei), since Tissaphernes is the subject of the passage.
ta\ teleutai=a anticipating the events of the next year.

fugo/ntos e)k *surakousw=n a good instance of this sense of feu/gein, ‘having been declared an exile from Syracuse.’ Cf. Xen. Hell, i. 1, 27, h)gge/lqh (410 B. C.) toi=s tw=n *surakosi/wn strathgoi=s oi)/koqen o(/ti feu/goien u(po\ tou= dh/mou. The reason was a political victory of the opposite faction. Hermocrates afterwards established himself in Sicily and carried on a war against Syracuse.
kai\ oi( k.t.l. rather than oi( de\, as this sentence properly forms a continuation of c. 85, thus, o( d' *)alkibia/dhs diebebh/kei . . . kai\ oi( e)k th=s *dh/lou . . . a)fiknou=ntai.
to/te viz. c. 72, § 1.

a)nadida/contas The force of a)na- is often inappreciable in such compounds. In Plat. Rep. 381 E a)napeiqo/menai simply = peiqo/menai. In 1. 32, iii. 97, the sense of getting one to change one's mind (meliora docere, alia probare) can still be extracted. The present envoys were sent dida/contes (c. 72, § 1). In the interval a meta/stasis has occurred, and a change of mind has now to be worked. They come i(/na dida/skwsi, they find there is need a)nadida/skein.
a)poktei/nein e)bo/wn i.e. e)bo/wn “a)po/kteine.” Cf. inf. § 8, ei)pw\n . . . parei=nai. The verb is treated as a verb of command.
katalu/ontas ‘trying to put down the democracy,’ by addressing the assembly in this way.
h(suxa/santes for tense cf. c. 24, § 4.
ou)/t' e)pi\ . . . ou)q' i(/na, contrasting the internal and external ruin of the state (Cl.) These two form the denial; the affirmation begins with tw=n te . . .

gi/gnoito the present tense, is used because the general revolution to oligarchy (h( meta/stasis) is not yet complete or assured, the consent of the army in Samos being required; the optative because the reason alleged may or may not be true. e)cei=nai ga\r. a)\n should not be supplied The possibility actually occurred. Their own words would be e)ch=n ga\r, o(/te e)se/balon (sc. oi( pole/mioi, in c. 71, § 1) h)/dh h(mw=n (sc. tw=n tetrakosi/wn) a)rxo/ntwn k.t.l.

tw=n te pentakisxili/wn . . . meqe/cousin either (1) pa/ntes tw=n pentakisxili/wn meqe/cousi tw=n pragma/twn (c. 65, § 3) or th=s politei/as; cf. c. 72, § 1, pentakisxi/lioi/ te o(/ti ei)=en kai\ ou) tetrako/sioi mo/non oi( pra/ssontes: or (2) pa/ntes meqe/cousi tw=n pentakisxili/wn, ‘all should have a share in the 5000,’ i.e. all shall share their functions in turn. Against the latter it may be urged that the statement was contrary to their orders (c. 72, § 1), and contrary to the principle involved; nor does it appear natural Greek. c. 93, § 2 seems to settle the matter, le/gontes tou/s te pentakisxili/ous kai\ e)k tou/twn e)n me/rei, h(=| a)\n toi=s pentakisxili/ois dokh=|, tou\s tetrakosi/ous e)/sesqai. The partitive genitive with pa/ntes as in c. 21.
kako\n e)/xousin ou)de\n said of oi( pa/sxontes as kaka\ pare/xein is said of oi( poiou=ntes. Cf. po/non e)/xein (ii. 76), ai)ti/an e)/xein, etc.
e)pi\ toi=s sfete/rois au)tw=n ‘in possession of their own belongings.’
e(/kastoi the plural for each man's set of oi)kei=oi.

prw=ton. prw=tos the common reading, should perhaps mean ‘in an eminent degree,’ with the sense of c. 68, § 4, e)n toi=s cugkatalu/ousi to\n dh=mon prw=tos h)=n. prw=ton cannot be taken in the sense of ‘for the first time,’ since Alcibiades had done good to his country before (vi. 16), and, as Jowett points out. Thucydides does not elsewhere summarily condemn his conduct. Nor is the combination prw=ton kai\ ou)deno\s e)/lasson natural with that sense. It does not appear to have been noticed also that the salutary prevention exercised by Alcibiades in c. 82, § 2, was on an earlier occasion than this. At the assembly at which he was restored he had prevented the rash undertaking (c. 82, § 2). He had since gone to meet Tissaphernes (c. 82, § 3), and it was not till he had returned (c. 85, § 4) that the envoys of the 400 came and the project of attacking Athens was mooted again. prw=ton must therefore be taken with w)felh=sai in the same construction as polu\,
ple/on, me/ga w)felh=sai, ‘he did capital service.’ The words kai\ ou)deno\s e)/lasson are epexegetical. Cf. vii. 44, me/giston de\ kai\ ou)x h(/kista e)/blayen, which forms an exact parallel. Cf. also vii. 27, e)n toi=s prw=ton e)ka/kwse ta) pra/gmata.
w(rmhme/nwn of eagerness. Cf. c. 11, § 3.
e)pi\ sfa=s au)tou\s i.e. e)p' *)aqhnai/ous or th\n e(autw=n po/lin.
e)n w(=| Cf. iii, 84, vi. 55: ‘when, in such a case.’

safe/stata . . . ei)=xon Dobree's safe/stat' a)
 naturally suggests itself. On omission of a)
 see Goodwin, M. and T. § 49, 2, whose statement would not include an instance like the present. Jelf, § 858. Constructions like kalo
 h)=n, u(ph=rxe, e)boulo/mhn, e)kindu/neuse (iii. 74) without a)
 should not be quoted as parallel to this. ‘He ran a risk,’ ‘it was within possibility,’ etc., are often quite interchangeable with ‘he would have run a risk,’ ‘it would have been possible,’ etc. safe/stata ei)=xon is rather to be defended on the ground of vivid realisation, like Horace's ‘sustulerat . . . nisi levasset.’ Cf. vi. 55, kai\ ou)x w(s a)delfo\s new/teros w)
 h)po/rhsen, e)n w(=| ou) pro/teron cunexw=s w(milh/kei th=| a)rxh=|. Plut. Alc. 26 has toi=s polemi/ois eu)qu\s e)/xein u(ph=rxen *)iwni/an k.t.l..
kwluth\s gene/sqai grammatically dependent on dokei=, but actually a statement of fact.
i)di/a| ‘individually.’

th
 boulh
 . . . tou\s pentakosi/ous i.e. th
 a)po\ tou= kua/mou. Never th
 b. tw=n pentakosi/wn.
ei) de\ e)s eu)te/leian k.t.l. with reference to the measure proposed in c. 65, § 3, and passed c. 67, § 3, that only oi( strateuo/menoi should misqoforei=n.
ta)=lla a)nte/xein see c. 63, § 4.
pro\s me\n ga\r sfa=s au)tou\s k.t.l. ‘for as to their relations with each other (=pro\s a)llh/lous) . . . there was great hope of their ultimately (kai\) coming to terms.’
sw|zome/nhs ‘so long as it was being kept in safety.’ See on o)rqou=sqai c. 64, § 4.
to\ e(/teron ‘the one division or the other,’ the democratic body at Samos or the oligarchic Athenians at home.
o(/tw| ‘with whom to be reconciled,’ not instrumental.
*)argei/wn. The Argives have taken no part since the previous year (c. 27, § 6).

tw=| e)n th=| *sa/mw| tw=n *)aqhnai/wn dh/mw| The full title implies formal recognition. The Athenians in Samos are considered by the Argives to represent the proper democratic government with which to treat.
w(/ste bohqei=n Cf. c. 45, § 3 for w(/ste. Lit. ‘making favourable propositions with a view to assisting them.’
e)paine/sas perhaps with the notion (frequent with e)painw=) of ‘thanks’ for assistance which is declined, at least for the present.
to/te sc. c. 74, § 2.
th=| . . . nhi\ the one mentioned c. 74, § 2.

[pemptou\s]. The reading here is very uncertain. The weight of authority is for pe/mpousi, which makes no construction. pemptou\s, on the other hand, is a formation which should have an adjectival, not a verbal, meaning (i.e. not = pemfqe/ntas or pempome/nous). lekto/s, plekto/s, e)klekto/s, etc., are similarly formed, but have an adjectival force. No word of sending is wanted, and therefore a gloss might be suspected (though cf. c. 89, § 1, oi( a)po\ tw=n tetrakosi/wn pemfqe/ntes pre/sbeis, where, however, there is more excuse for its appearance, v. loc.) More probably both pe/mpousi and pemptou\s are misreadings. It appears from c. 89, § 2, that only a part of the oligarchy were concerned in the negotiations with Sparta, and that there was some secrecy about the proceedings. It is not impossible that as tw=n tetrakosi/wn has occurred just before and as tetrakosi/wn would be written u<*>, the true reading may have been a)p' au)tw=n u(pope/mptous and not a)po\ tw=n u<*>pemptou\s. In such case au)tw=n would refer to the before-mentioned tetrakosi/wn, and u(pope/mptous, ‘secret,’ would have its adjectival value. Cf. u(pope/mpein, iv. 46. In Xen. Anab. iii. 3, 4 u(po/pemptos is now read for u(/poptos.
*laispodi/an mentioned in vi. 105.
*)aristofw=nta The name was not uncommon, and there are no data for identifying him with the orator of the deme Azenia.

*melhsi/an Grote seeks to identify him with the Melesias in the Laches of Plato, conjecturing that he was the son of Thucydides o( *melhsi/ou the opponent of Pericles.
[oi(\]. Though this word may possibly be due to an anacoluthon, as if a genitive clause had preceded instead of the relative oi(\ e)ta/xqhsan k.t.l., it seems more probably an interpolation.
tou\s pre/sbeis viz. those of the Argives, mentioned above.
w(s e)do/kei dh/ ‘as he would have them believe.’ dh\ is ironical, as in c. 9, § 1. His real object, according to Thucydides, was tribh=s e(/neka kai\ a)nokwxh=s (inf. § 4).
th=| stratia=| sc. tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn; dat. commodi.
*tamw\n an Egyptian (Xen. Anab. i. 4, 2) of Memphis (Diod. Sic. xiv. 19. 5). He appears in the Anabasis as commander of the fleet of Cyrus.
u(/parxon Cf. c. 16, § 3.

oi( me\n ga\r sc. le/gousin, to be supplied from ei)ka/zetai. P-S compares Diog. Laert. vi. 76, peri\ de\ tou= qana/tou dia/foroi le/gontai lo/goi: oi( me\n ga\r boo\s po/da fago/nta . . . teleuth=sai: oi( de\ k.t.l., and Tac. Ann. i. 9, at apud prudentes vita eius varie extollebatur arguebaturve: hi pietate erga parentem . . . ad arma civilia actum, etc.
diatri/bh| cf. diatribh=nai, c. 78 and note.

proagagw\n having brought them so far on their way as to Aspendus, i.e. so as to make them look upon the war as a reality and be the more glad to be released. The following kai\ ga\r w(\s k.t.l. carries out this notion, ‘for in any case he did not mean to use them’; he only brought them thus far for this purpose.

e)kxrhmati/saito a)fei/s ‘to make money by selling the crews their discharges,’ Jowett. This is the natural interpretation. With the change of mood (after diatri/bh|) cf. the reverse change, vi. 96, o(/pws tw=n te *)epipolw=n ei)=en fu/lakes kai\ . . . taxu\ cunestw=tes paragi/gnwntai. Explanations of such variations are frequently far-drawn. In all probability they do not spring from any conscious desire for variety, but from the spontaueous flexibility of a mind to which either form might be the first to offer itself in the circumstances.
kai\ w(\s see c. 51, § 2.
a)/lloi d', w(s With the oi( me\n and oi( de\ preceding no w(s or o(ti has been expressed after the implied le/gousin. w(s here reminds the reader that Thucydides is quoting opinions.

kataboh=s e(/neka k.t.l. ‘because of his being decried . . .,’ ‘because of the complaint which was being carried to Lacedaemon concerning him’ (viz. c. 85, § 2). Stahl renders ‘ut fama rei Lacedaemonem perveniret,’ and adds ‘kataboh\ hic non criminationem significat.’ But from the nature of its composition kataboh\ cannot be used in a favourable nor even in a neuter sense. Cf. c. 85, § 2. Stahl is led into the error by a desire to make tou= le/gesqai stand in apposition to kataboh=s, and dependent on e(/neka. But tou= le/gesqai is more naturally taken as the causal construction of the articular infinitive. Cf. tou= mh\ e)ca/ggeltoi gene/sqai, c. 14, § 1.

tou= le/gesqai Jowett prefers to\ le/gesqai and trcats it as the ‘accusative of the remoter object’ (or ‘more precise definition,’ Poppo) = ‘touching its being said.’ He compares ii. 87, ou)xi\ dikai/an e)/xei te/kmarsin to\ e)kfobh=sai (where, however, auother rendering is no less probable). There is considerable freedom in the accusatival use of the infinitive with the article. See Jowett on ii. 87, Jelf § 670, and, as an instance of a class, ii. 53, to\ me\n prostalaipwrei=n tw=| do/canti kalw=| ou)dei\s pro/qumos h)=n. The present case, however, lacks a true analogue, and, in the discrepancy of MSS., tou= is perhaps to be preferred. ‘In respect to its being said’ does not follow the leading verbal notion here so naturally as in other instances adduced.

e)moi\ me/ntoi dokei = safe/staton to/d' ei)=nai, k.t.l. The MSS. omit to/d', and editors appear to find no difficulty in the construction. Yet the use of the infinitive after safe/staton ei)=nai, instead of the regular w(s or o(/ti, is surely remarkable enough to deserve some comment. dh=lo/n, fanero/n, safe/s e)sti are not joined with infinitive; and to express his meaning Thucydides had the choice of two constructions, (1) dokei= dhlo/tatos ei)=nai . . . ou)k a)gagw
, or (2) dokei= safe/staton ei)=nai, w(s . . . ou)k h)/gagen. I have added to/d' as the easiest correction. In the emended construction the infinitive clause does not depend on safe/staton ei)=nai, but is exegetical of to/de. ‘This usage (sc. of tou=to and to/de),’ says Jelf (§ 657, 2), ‘is very common before infinitives, generally without the article.’ He quotes Plat. Apol. 38 C, a)po\ tou= au)toma/tou a)
 u(mi=n tou=to e)ge/neto, e)me\ teqna/nai dh/; Od. 1, 82, ei) me
 dh\ nu=n tou=to fi/lon maka/ressi qeoi=sin, nosth=sai *)odush=a. Moreover to/de improves the sense. Thucydides has said (§ 2) that it is not easy to tell Tissaphernes' intention. ‘But in my own opinion the greatest certainty seems to be this, that, etc.’
a)nokwxh=s (e(/neka), ‘ut res suspeusas teneret,’ Portus.
fqora=s i.e. i(/na fqei/roi ta\ pra/gmata au)tw=n (c. 78).
a)nisw/sews i.e. i(/na e)panisoi/h au)tou\s pro\s a)llh/lous (c. 57, § 2).
prosqe/menos Cf. c. 50, § 3, prose/qhke . . . e(auto\n *tissafe/rnei.

e)pei/, ei)/ge e)boulh/qh, diapolemh=sai a)
† e)pifanei\s k.t.l. For the MS. readings see crit. note. They are manifestly untranslatable, since e)pei\, ei)/ ge e)boulh/qh diapolemh=sai, perifane\s dh/pou (sc. e)sti
 o(/ti e)du/nato a)
 ou(/tw poei=n) is quite out of reasonable question. Dobree added a)
 and construed e)pei\, ei)/ ge e)boulh/qh, diapolemh=sai a)
 perifane/s (e)sti) k.t.l., ‘for, if he had chosen, it is beyond all doubt clear that he could have carried the war to an end.’ P-S objects to the redundancy in the last clause. It may be further objected that the infinitive with perifane/s e)sti is bad Greek, diapolemh/sas a)
 perifanh/s e)sti being required, or else the construction with o(/ti. Again, e)ndoiastw=s is not the opposite of safw=s but of proqu/mws (Hdt. vii. 174), and e)ndoia/zw has the sense of indecisiveness of action, rather than that of uncertainty of belief. Reiske's conjecture e)pifanei\s gives the structure e)pei\, ei)/ ge e)boulh/qh, diapolemh=sai a)
 (sc. dokei=) e)pifanei\s (‘cum supervenisset’) k.t.l. The emendation is ingenious and may be adopted provisionally. Nevertheless it leaves dh/pou awkwardly placed, makes a great strain upon dokei= (which is at some distance, and becomes personal after being impersonal), and does not seem altogether a natural way of expressing the fact that, if he had chosen to bring round all his forces, he could have ended the war. With Reiske's reading ou)k e)ndoiastw=s ( = proqu/mws) must be joined to e)pifanei/s. The sense is given by Plutarch (Alcib. § 26), ou) ga h)=n a)/dhlon, o(/ti toi=s e(te/rois du/namis tosau/th prosgenome/nh tou\s e(te/rous a)fh|rei=to komidh=| to\ kra/tos th=s qala/tths, which passage might seem to show that e)pifane\s is sound.
tw=| nautikw=| instrumental.
a)nqw/rmoun sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.
e)la/ssous h)\ o(/sas. Cf. c. 66, § 3, polu\ ple/on h(gou/menoi ei(=nai h)\ o(/son e)tu/gxanen o)/n. According to Diod. Sic. (xiii. 38) the king had required 300 ships.
o( de\ k.t.l. ‘but as a matter of fact, he (Tissaphernes) . . .’
xa/rin a)\n . . . e)/sxen ‘would have obtained all the more gratitude.’
e)n tou/tw| ‘in such case’; not = e)pi\ tou/tw|

a)p' e)lasso/nwn generally rendered ‘at less expense.’ This makes a tautology in the sentence, since a)p' e)lasso/nwn would merely repeat the notion of ou)/t' a)nalw/sas polla\. Rather ‘with smaller resources,’ a)po\ expressing the stock upon which one draws. Tissaphernes would gam more favour in the king's eyes (1) because of the slight expenditure, (2) for his skill in obtaining the same results with less means. The king's admiration would be all the greater. This use of a)po\ soon passes, of course, into the sense of ‘cost at which . . .,’ as in Ar. Eq. 538, o(\s a)po\ smikra=s dapa/nhs u(ma=s a)risti/zwn a)pe/pempen; Plut. 377, e)gw/ soi tou=t' a)po\ smikrou= pa/nu | e)qe/lw diapra=cai.
d' ou)=n resumptive. Cf. ou)=n, c. 57, § 2.
w(s e)pi\, ‘with the intention of fetching . . .’
h)\ ga\r au)to\s k.t.l. Plut. Alc. 26 puts it h)\ metasth/sein pro\s au)tou\s h)\ diapra/cesqai mhde\ pro\s e)kei/nous komisqh=nai.
e)s th\n . . . fili/an . . . diaba/llein. e)s gives the ground of the expected disaffection. Cf. v. 75, e)piferome/nhn ai)ti/an e)s malaki/an; Xen. Anab. ii. 6, 30, me/mfesqai ei)s fili/an.
o( me\n answered by oi( d' e)k th=s *sa/mou, c. 89. me\n implies that Thucydides is about to leave Alcibiades for affairs elsewhere.

th=s *fash/lidos kai\ *kau/nou Phaselis (in Lycia) is beyond Caunus, some forty miles westward of Aspendus, on the Pamphylian Gulf. It was a town of importance in trade (ii. 69). Thucydides mentions the main destination first (cf. i. 116, e)pi\ *kau/nou kai\ *kari/as), and then adds, as worth mentioning, kai\ *kau/nou, as Caunus lay in the way. For similar reversal of order, though without the same reason, cf. iii. 29, prosmei/cantes a)p' au)th=s (sc. th=s *dh/lou) th=| *)ika/rw| kai\ *muko/nw|. In c. 108, § 1, the return voyage is a)po\ th=s *kau/nou kai\ *fash/lidos, where Thucydides looks at the two places in combination and mentions them in order from the western point of view The single article in each case combines the two places into one geographical notion.

a)/nw practically = ‘eastward.’ The part of Asia Minor on the Aegean Sea is called ta\ ka/tw, the parts farther east are ta\ a)/nw. The king of Peisia comes down to the Grecian sea, a Greek goes upward into the king's territory by land, or parallel to such direction by way of the king's waters.
e)k th=s *sa/mou ‘returning from Samos,’ where they were in c. 86.
ka)kei/nois )( kai\ *peloponnhsi/wn.

tou\s pollou\s tw=n metexo/ntwn Thucydides does not distinguish clearly between the 400 and the oligarchical party generally. Grote (pt. ii. c. lxii.) says, ‘there began to arise, even in the bosom of the Four Hundred, an opposition minority affecting popular sentiment.’ The 400 are specially dealt with in c. 92, § 6. Here tou\s pollou\s k.t.l. cannot refer to such a minority, but belongs to the wider oligarchical party.
cuni/stanto i.e. they began to do so now, after receiving the report.
ta\ pra/gmata ‘the state of affairs.’

tw=n pa/nu strathgw=n On pa/nu in such combination see note c. 1, § 1, toi=s pa/nu tw=n stratiwtw=n . . . diapefeugo/si. strathgw=n, however, gives general offence. If tw=n e)n th=| o)lig. kai\ e)n a)rxai=s o)/ntwn is a partitive genitive dependent on strathgw=n, ‘the very generals among those who were in the oligarchy and in offices’ is an awkward expression where tw=n pa/nu strathgw=n would be quite sufficient. And if this objection counts for nothing, a potent obstacle lies in the word strathgw=n itself. Aristocrates, for instance, is not a strathgo\s, but a taxiarch (c. 92, § 4). If, however, these words are in attributive construction with tw=n strathgw=n, what is the point of the addition kai\ e)n a)rxai=s o)/ntwn, seeing that strathgoi\ must necessarily be ‘in office’? And, again, one of the two instances quoted is not a strathgo\s at all. The text might just possibly be taken tw=n pa/nu strathgw=n tw=n e)n th=| o)ligarxi/a| kai\ (tw=n) e)n a)rxai=s o)/ntwn, i.e. ‘some of the oligarchical generals themselves and of other officers.’ The first tw=n would in that case belong equally to pa/nu strathgw=n and to e)n a)rxai=s o)/ntwn. But it is hard to believe that the omission of the important article is likely. The two phrases with e)n after tw=n can scarcely be dissociated. The mere expulsion of strathgw=n (P-S, Cl., etc.) is not sufficient, as the word has none of the look of an interpolation in the context. It would be easier to amend to tw=n pa/nu krati/stwn k.t.l., ‘of the very foremost of those in the oligarchy and in office.’ Cf. v. 8, *lhmni/wn kai\ *)imbri/wn to\ kra/tiston; Xen. Hell. vii. 1, 42, tou\s krati/stous=‘the most aristocratic.’ Of h and is Cobet (Nov. Lect. p. 745) says, ‘notum est *h et *i*s, h et is, sexcenties inter se permutari,’ and he gives such instances as nomh/mata for nomi/smata, e)mbro/ntistos for e)mbro/nthtos, etc. The remaining corruptions are palaeographically easy; or the whole may come under Introd. § 2 (ii.)
*qhrame/nh v. c. 68, § 4.

*)aristokra/th to\n *skelli/ou His name is played upon by Aristophanes (Av. 126)— *ep. a)ristokratei=sqai dh=los ei(= zhtw=n. *e*u. e)gw/; h(/kista: kai\ to\n *skelli/ou bdelu/ttomai. Cf. Plat. Gorg. 472 A. Aristocrates became a strathgo\s under Alcibiades B.C. 407 (Xen. Hell. i. 4, 21), and was one of the six put to death after Arginusae (Xen. Hell. i. 7, 2 sqq.)
mete/sxon not metei=xon, but, when the oligarchy was being established, they got an active share in the government.

e)n toi=s prw/tois This reading of Vat. and e)n prw/tois of the other MSS. do not justify the change to e)n toi=s prw=toi of Bekker and many subsequent editors, who have been led perhaps more by a fancy for the idiom than by any more solid reason. A comparison of instances and reasonable presumption tend to show that e)n toi=s prw=toi = primi omnium, while e)n toi=s prw/tois = ‘inter primos.’ The latter is obviously the meaning here. Theramenes was ‘among the first’ (cf. c. 68, § 4). In vii. 19 ou(=toi me\n ou)=n e)n toi=s prw/tois o(rmh/santes all MSS. agree in prw/tois, and there also Bekker, P - S, etc., write prw=toi, though the meaning is inter primos. In iii. 17 all agree in e)n toi=s plei=stai. In i. 6, e)n toi=s prw/tois de\ *)aqhnai=oi to\n si/dhron kate/qento, the evidence is in favour of prw/tois. There can hardly be finality to this question, since it may always be urged that e)n toi=s prw=toi would naturally be corrupted to prw/tois, and that therefore the evidence of MSS. is weakened. On the other hand it scarcely seems good criticism, because of the existence of the idiom e)n toi=s with the nominative, to alter the natural expression e)n toi=s with dative every time it occurs. Inf. c. 90. § 1, e)n toi=s ma/lista, and vii. 71, e)n toi=s xalepw/tata are clear instances of the idiom. [e)n toi=s prw=toi mete/sxon is variously analysed into (1) e)n toi=s (mete/xousi) prw=toi mete/sxon, (2) e)n toi=s (prw/tois) prw=toi mete/sxon, and (3) prw=toi e)n toi=s (neut. demonstrative) The last is the only explanation which commends itself to one's linguistic feeling. It regards the idiom as a survival of something logically correct.]

spoudh=| pa/nu ‘in very earnest.’ Their fear of Alcibiades was very real, as is shown by § 4, safe/stata d' au)tou\s e)ph=re k.t.l. The order of thought is a little confused for fobou/menoi to/ te stra/teuma, w(s e)/fasan, kai\ to
 *)alkibia/dhn spoudh=| pa/nu, or fobou/menoi, w(s e)/fasan, to/ te stra/teuma kai\ to
 *)alkibia/dhn
(o(
 kai\ spoudh=| pa/nu e)fobou=nto). ‘They said they were afraid of the army and of Alcibiades (and of him they were afraid in real earnest).’

tou/s te e)s th
 *lakedai/mona k.t.l. The discrepancy of reading in this passage will be seen from the crit. note. No satisfactory solution has yet been given of the textual difficulties. The underlying sense is perhaps not certain enough to enable any conjecture to appear convmcing. Taking the average reading of MSS. as printed in the text, it is clear that te after tou/s has no place in the sense, that presbeuome/nous is used in the wholly unwarranted meaning of presbeu/ontas, and that ou) to\ a)palla/cein, as accus. of ‘remoter object’ or ‘closer definition’ (see note c. 87, § 3, to\ le/gesqai), depends upon nothing. Jowett thinks that with e)/pempon omitted, ou) to\ a)palla/cein may depend by a laxity on fobou/menoi d', w(s e)/fasan. as if it were a verb of saying, influencing the remainder of the sentence. He ultimately inclines, however, to Poppo's ou)/toi. which still leaves the infinitives a)palla/cein and xrh=nai without government by any verb which can be reasonably supplied. Again, the statement about their sending envoys to Lacedaemon is contrary to the facts, inasmuch as it is the other faction of the party who are engaged in these proceedings (cf. c. 90, § 1). Jowett seeks to force the sense ‘they joined in sending the ambassadors.’ This, he admits, is unnatural for e)/pempon, and it still makes presbeu/omai = presbeu/w. For fear one should quote e.g. v. 39, h)=lqon presbeuo/menoi, it may be pointed out that there the negotiating people is identified with or summed up in its ambassadors (cf. note on c. 85, § 2, poreuome)nous). The usual resource is to omit e)/pempon and to read ou)/toi a)pallacei/ein (conjectured by Abresch from the scholiast's o(/ti a)pallaktikw=s e)/xousi), supplying e)/legon from the general sense. This arrangement gives in a maimed form the sense ‘but fearing, as they said, not only the army in Samos and Alcibiades (whom they feared in real earnest), but also those who were sending envoys to Lacedaemon (lest they might do the state some injury without an understanding with the majority), they urged, not indeed that they wanted to get rid of too narrow an oligarchy, but that they ought, etc.’ The meaning of the latter portion of the passage seems to be that, while their real motive was a desire to get rid of too narrow a cliquism among themselves (through which they did not enjoy an equal influence in affairs), they did not say this, but they said — the same thing in an equally open way. The desire to be rid of too close a body is precisely what they did advance. And whence did e)/pempon get into the text?
The scholiast says h( de\ dia/noia: oi( peri\ to
 *qhrame/nh a)/rxontes to/te th=s o)ligarxi/as kai\ metasxo/ntes au)th=s e)n prw/tois, o)rego/menoi de\ dhmokrati/as e)/legon ou)x o(/ti a)pallaktikw=s e)/xousi th=s o)ligarxi/as (o(/per h)=n a)lhqe/s), a)ll: o(/ti fobou=ntai tou\s e)n *sa/mw| kai\ *)alkibia/dhn kai\ tou\s a)pio/ntas ei)s *lakedai/mona pre/sbeis, mh/ ti ou(=toi kako
 e)rga/swntai th
 po/lin o)ligarxi/as genome/nhs. h)/dh ou)=n h)ci/oun tou\s pentakisxili/ous kaqista/nai. But tou= a)/gan e)s o)li/gous e)lqei=n is not equivalent to th=s o)ligarxi/as, and Thucydides states clearly enough what their motives really were in §§ 3 and 4. For the rest, the scholiast's rendering is not to be obtained from our text and probably only represents the best dia/noia which he could suspect in his own text. The corruption is probably very deep, and one may venture to think that what Thucydides wrote was something like fobou/menoi d', w(s e)/fasan, to/ t' e)n *sa/mw| stra/teuma kai\ to
 *)alkibia/dhn spoudh=| pa/nu, ou(/s te e)s th
 *lakedai/mona presbeuome/nous u(pe/blepon, mh/ ti a)/neu tw=n pleo/nwn kako
 dra/swsi th
 po/lin, ou) to\ < a(/pan e)/legon > a)pallacei/ein tou= e)s o)li/gous oi)kei=n, a)lla\ k.t.l., ‘fearing . . . the army in Samos and Alcibiades . . . and those persons whose negotiations with Lacedaemon they looked upon with suspicion for fear they should do the country an injury, they said, not indeed that, they were anxious to be rid of oligarchy altogether, but that, etc.’ The exact words used by Thucydides can hardly be conjectured with certainty, but the meaning evidently is that, while they objected to extreme narrowness in the oligarchy, they did not object to the general principle of to\ e)s o)li/gous oi)kei=n.

a)/neu tw=n pleo/nwn ‘invita maiore civium parte,’ P - S; ‘without the consent of the majority of the oligarchy,’ Jowett. The latter is preferable. There is no talk here of the general body of citizens, and that the presbeuo/menoi were a minority of the oligarchical party itself is clear from sup. § 1 (tou\s pollou\s) and c. 90, § 1.
e)s o)li/gous e)lqei=n P-S quotes Aristot. Pol. ii. 6, 10, dio/per ei)s o)li/gous h(=ken h( xw/ra. Cf. note on c. 38, § 3, e)s o)li/gon katexome/nhs.
a)podeiknu/nai = creare.
i)saite/ran ‘on a more equal basis.’ Cf. Aeschin. Tim. 25, i)/sh kai\ e)/nnomos politei/a; Xen. Hell. vii. i, 45, w(s th=s politei/as e)some/nhs e)n toi=s i)/sois kai\ o(moi/ois.

h)=n de\ tou=to me
 sxh=ma k.t.l. ‘now in this they offered a constitutional semblance, so far as their language
went.’ sxh=ma approaches, but is not identical with, pro/sxhma, ‘pretence,’ a word used by Thuc. i. 96, iii. 82, v. 30. Cf. Hdt. iv. 167, pro/sxhma tou= lo/gou; Plat. (?) Epin. 989 C, ou) sxh/masin a)ll' a)lhqei/a|. The force of politiko
 may be seen from e.g. iii. 82, i)sonomi/a politikh/; Aristot. Pol. v. 5, 2, politikwte/ra e)ge/neto h( o)ligarxi/a; Dem. 151, ou)k i)/sws ou)de\ politikw=s. For tou= lo/gou cf. c. 91, § 3, diabolh\ mo/non tou= lo/gou. Others take sxh=ma politiko
 as = sxh=ma politei/as (Plat. Pol. 291 D), or sxh=ma po/lews (vi. 89), giving a much less natural force to the adjective and the genitive lo/gou.

tw=| toiou/tw| prose/keinto, e)n w(=|per k.t.l. ‘were in that kind of temperament, the prevalence of which is particularly ruinous,’ cf. proskei=sqai oi)/nw|, Hdt. i. 133, or ‘applied themselves to the said course — conduct which is exactly that in which, etc.’

e)k de\ dhmokrati/as k.t.l. Much difficulty has been made concerning this passage, the difference of opinion turning on the rendering of a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn. See Grote's long note in pt. ii. c. lxii. of Hist. Greece. One vexed point ought never to have been raised. a)po\ is not u(po\, and e)lassou/menos a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn cannot be the same as e)lassou/menos tw=n o(moi/wn (masc.), which is the normal Greek for ‘distanced by his equals.’ Looking at the desired sense and construction at the same time, and at the order of the words, which naturally joins a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn to e)lassou/menos, one can hardly imagine another rendering than ‘but when election proceeds from a democracy, a man acquiesces more easily in the result, consoling himself that, though he fails, the start was not fair and level (i.e. a start on one's merits),’ which means that when a number of persons become an oligarchy, if a man does not get the first place, he is annoyed; all start alike, and leadership should naturally fall to merit and importance: but in a democracy the start is different; if two men are pitted against each other, the influencing causes of election will not be intrinsic superiority, but other reasons; a man feels that he has not been beaten on his merits, and he passes the matter over. An election on one's merits is a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn: but when other causes, such as move a populace, affect the choice, the start is ou)k a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn. a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn is neuter also in i. 141. Cf. v. 101, a)po\ tou= i)/sou; v. 89, a)po\ th=s i)/shs a)na/gkhs; i. 77, to\ me\n ga\r a)po\ tou= i)/sou dokei= pleonektei=sqai, to\ d' a)po\ tou= krei/ssonos katanagka/zesqai.
h)gwni/zeto Each made it a sort of prize to struggle for. See on a)gwnizome/nous, c. 68, § 1.
prw=tos sc. in rank.
prosta/ths tou= dh/mou Cf. iii. 75, oi( tou= dh/mou prosta/tai; iv. 46, etc. The title is not official (cf. ‘leader of the opposition’). The prosta/tai are merely champions of the popular interests.

tw=| toiou/tw| ei)/dei either (1) politei/as, cf. iii. 62, kai/toi ske/yasqe e)n oi)/w| ei)/dei e(ka/teroi h(mw=n tou=to e)/pracan and context; or (2) in a wider sense of ei)=dos, ‘such a course,’ cf. c. 56, § 2, tre/petai e)pi\ toio/nde ei)=dos and note. The scholiast explains by katasta/sei. The sense of toiou/tw| is to be gathered from the latter part of the preceding chapter.
kai\ proestw=tes i.e. who had most influence among that faction.
