o(\s kai\ . . . dihne/xqh viz. cc. 48-51. pote\ cannot, of course, be sound with to/te. Editors therefore for the most part bracket pote\ (which is omitted by several MSS.) They do not, however, notice a greater difficulty in the tense of strathgh/sas. The aorist should refer to an action past with reference to the time of the leading verb, i.e. the time indicated in strathgh/sas should be previous to that intended in dihne/xqh. The present instance belongs to no class of exceptions. Greek would require either o( kai\ strathgh/sas e)n th=| *s. pote\ kai\ tw=| *)al. (to/te) dienexqei/s, or o(\s kai\ strathgw=n . . . pote\ . . . dihne/xqh. The words strathgh/sas . . . pote\ are probably an interpolation, in explanation of the brief Thucydidean o(\s kai\ tw=| *)alkibia/dh| to/te dihne/xqh. See also crit. note. o(\s kai\=‘the same who . . .’

*)ari/starxos Xen. (Hell. i. 7, 28), writing of B.C. 406, shows that, before that date, A. had been brought to trial for his share in these proceedings, and for the treachery mentioned inf. c. 98, § 1.
e)n toi=s ma/lista k.t.l. v. c. 89, § 2, on e)n toi=s prw/tois. The order is e)nanti/os e)n toi=s ma/lista kai\ e)k plei/stou, the words e)n toi=s belonging to both superlatives.
*pei/sandros see cc. 49, 53.
*)antifw=n see c. 68, § 1.
oi( dunatw/tatoi Cf cc. 21 and 47, § 2, for the sense ‘most aristocratic,’ and c. 63, § 3, for the sense ‘most influential.’
pro/tero/n te )( pollw=| te ma=llon . . .
kai\ e)peidh\ is merely connective to e)pei\. pre/sbeis te . . . kai\ . . . e)poiou=nto belongs to the first part of the proceedings.
sfw=n with a)pe/sth.
pre/sbeis a)pe/stellon see c. 71, § 3; c. 86, § 9.
th\n o(mologi/an which they had been pressing for (c. 71, § 3). For the accus. with prou)qumou=nto cf. c. 1, § 1.
to\ e)n th=| *)hetiwnei/a| The article is anticipatory. Cf. to\ nhsi/dion, c. 11, § 1.
tou\s pollou\s ‘people generally,’ outside the 400, as the following kai\ sfw=n shows.
ta\ au)tou= at Athens.
o(/stis kai\ o(pwsou=n a)nekto/s sc. e)sti. kai\ emphasises o(pwsou=n. Lit. ‘in every way, i.e. whatever way was in any possible degree tolerable.’

kai\ nausi\ kai\ pezw=| de/cwntai. The dative is circumstantial, and is a noticeable instance of the possible extension of a case-use. kai\ nausi\ kai\ pezw=| e)lqei=n would be normal; the substitution of de/casqai causes an extension which would hardly be allowed by a priori notions of syntax.

xhlh\ ‘a mole,’ resembling a ‘claw.’ Cf. i. 63, parh=lqe para\ th\n xhlh\n dia\ th=s qala/sshs; vii. 53, etc. Two moles ran out from the north and south sides of the harbour, nearly meeting in the middle of the channel, and leaving a passage for only two or three triremes abreast. The harbour was thus made into what was called a klh|sto/s limh/n (vii. 38). Eetioneia was the northern mole. There was a natural promontory which was very helpful in forming the klh=|qron, but the xhlh/ in question was a further projection from it and was of artificial work. Xen. Hell. ii. 3, 46, faneroi\ e)ge/nonto e)pi\ tw=| xw/mati e)/ruma teixi/zontes, ei)s o(\ e)bou/lonto tou\s polemi/ous deca/menoi k.t.l. Various late and mediaeval authorities (Harpocration, Suidas, etc.) call Eetioneia an a)/kra, and the name may have belonged to a portion of the natural promontory as well as to the xw=ma, or the xhlh/ itself may be loosely spoken of as an a)/kra.

cu\n tw=| pro/teron k.t.l. ‘with the help of,’ or ‘in connection with . . .’ The ‘landward’ wall is the main outer wall of the town of Peiraens, on the northern side of the harbour. It defended the port from an attack on the landward side.
e)s au)to\ sc. to\ tei=xos, to be supplied from the sense.

tou= ge e)/splou Jowett says ‘a handful of men could protect at any rate the entrance to the harbour, if not the approach from the city.’ The force of ge may rather be ‘they had control of the (important point, viz. the) entrance of the harbour, if nothing else.’ ge thus implies that the control is satisfactory.

e)p' au)to\n ga\r k.t.l. i.e. ‘for both the old landward wall and also the inner new one, which was being built inside against the sea, came to an end exactly at the fort (one of a pair), which was at the mouth of the harbour, the said harbour being narrow.’ The description is rather clumsy, probably because Thucydides was himself so well acquainted with the locality. Arnold has rightly explained that the pu/rgos was at the end of the xhlh/; from this pu/rgos ran the mole to the natural promontory, whence the masonry continued inland as the outer wall of Peiraeus. The oligarchs built another wall inside the heads, at an angle to this, running from the same pu/rgos by the shore of the harbour. The object of the second wall was to prevent a landing upon Eetioneia from the harbour of Peiraeus itself. Having carried this wall sufficiently far, they carried a third side of the triangle across to the old landward wall (hence sup. e)teixi/zeto cu\n tw=| pro/teron k.t.l.), and in doing so they cut off inside the triangle the stoa/ mentioned below. Thus they have a small triangular space walled in, containing the Eetioneia and the stoa/, a space which is a castle (tei=xos) easily defended by a handful of men.
to\n e(/teron because there was another on the opposite mole.
teixizo/menon For position of the attributive participle cf. c. 35, § 2; c. 36, § 1, etc.
pro\s qa/lassan. qa/lassan is used rather than to\n lime/na for antithesis to pro\s h)/peiron. The new castle could be attacked by ‘land’ or by ‘sea.’

diw|kodo/mhsan i.e. they cut it off from the town and enclosed it by a wall. Cf. iv. 69, a)rca/menoi d' a)po\ tou= tei/xous o ei)=xon kai\ dioikodomh/santes to\ pro\s *megare/as, and the uses of diastauro/w, diateixi/zw.

stoa/n generally, though wrongly, identified with the makra\ stoa/ of Paus. i. 1, 3, e)/nqa kaqe/sthken a)gora\ toi=s e)pi\ qala/sshs, and the stoa\ a)lfito/pwlis of Ar. Eccl. 686, built by Pericles. Cf. Ar. Ach. 548, stoa=s stenaxou/shs siti/wn metroume/nwn.
dieqro/ei Cf. diebo/wn, c. 78.

toi=s cu/mpasi (1) Taken by Haacke, P-S, etc., as meaning ‘no agreement for the whole Athenian people (though the Lacedaemonians were willing to make terms with the oligarchs).’ This must mean ‘no agreement which the whole body of the people would be likely to accept.’ But the envoys had not sought to obtain terms for any one but the oligarchy. ou)de
 pra/cantes implies failure in their mission. (2) Bauer, Dukas, etc., take it as = o(/lws, omnino, joining it with the negative: ‘nothing at all.’ The separation from ou)de
 is apparently too great for this, and the expression is hardly classical Greek. In Demosth. De Cor. 239 (39), toi=s me
 ga o(/lois ou)de
 me/trio/n moi dokei=te poiei=n, the words are part of a spurious letter of Philip. toi=s pa=sin of ii. 64, v. 28, vii. 50, stands on a different footing. A third rendering may be suggested, viz. ‘on the whole question’: lit. ‘having effected nothing leading to an agreement upon (for) the whole situation.’

w(=n h)=san k.t.l. ‘among which were included some Italian ships from Tarentum and Locri and some Sicilian vessels.’ Tarentum was a colony of Sparta. During the Sicilian expedition its attitude had been merely negative, though naturally it was unfriendly to Athens (vi. 44, 104). *lokroi\ *)epizefu/rioi was a Locrian colony with a Lacedaemonian element. Its previous relations with Athens had been hostile (iii. 99, vi. 44, vii. 1, etc.).

e)pi\ *la=| Las, though called by Livy (xxxviii. 30) vicus maritimus, was ten stadia from the sea according to Pausan. iii. 24, 5. Hence e)pi\ rather than e)n. The town was about five miles S W. of Gythium.

diafqare/ntas The nominative might have been looked for. On the objective construction see c. 48, § 5, u(pesxh=sqai sfa=s. The present instance is easier, inasmuch as the subject to lh/sein is gathered from the impersonal tis: ‘they, the said negligent persons, etc.’

h)=|n de/ ti kai\ toiou=ton k.t.l. ‘now there really was something of the kind on the part of those who were accused, and it was not altogether (or ‘by no means’ ou) pa/nu) a mere calumny for the sake of making a point.’
kathgori/an e)xo/ntwn is the passive of kathgorou/ntwn, the personal use of the passive kathgorei=sqai being very rare. Cf. kako\n e)/xousi, c. 86, § 3; ai)ti/an e)/xein (iv. 114), etc.

ma/lista me\n . . . ei) de\ mh\ . . . e)ceirgo/menoi de\ kai\ tou/tou
The alternatives should be clearly distinguished. e)bou/lonto o)ligarxou/menoi runs throughout: ‘preserving their oligarchy they desired (1) ma/lista me\n kai\ tw=n cumma/xwn a)/rxein, ‘if possible, to rule not only Athens but also the allies’; (2) ei) de\ mh\, au)tonomei=sqai ta\s nau=s . . . e)/xontes, ‘or, as the second best terms, to be left in possession of the fleet and walls of Athens in independence of the Lacedaemonians’; (3) e)ceirgo/menoi k.t.l., ‘if they were debarred from this too, to admit the enemy, and give up the fleet and walls, if only they might secure their personal safety.’

mh\ ou)=n u(po\ tou= dh/mou ge k.t.l. ‘at any rate not to be themselves the first to meet with destruction at the hands of the restored democracy.’ ge of one MS. and the scholiast is certainly right. For ou)=n . . . ge cf. Soph. Ant. 84, a)ll' ou)=n promhnu/sh|s ge tou=to mhdeni/; El. 233; Hdt. iii. 140, ei) kai\ smikra/, a)ll' w)=n i)/sh ge h( xa/ris.

kai\ o(pwsou=n ‘in any way whatever,’ cf. c. 90, § 2. Most editors prefer to make kai\ connective, and construe cumbh=nai e)/xein ta\ th=s po/lews a)/neu teixw=n kai\ new=n kai\ o(pwsou=n. Render ‘actually to introduce the enemy, and, giving up ships and walls, make any manner of terms as to the fate of the country.’ ta\ th=s po/lews e)/xein is apparently always taken in the sense of ta\ pra/gmata e)/xein, i.e. make terms enabling them to hold the government. But in the last resource all that the oligarchs will seek is their personal safety, and the government may go to the Lacedaemonians. ta\ th=s po/lews can hardly be used for ‘the government,’ unless e.g. pra/ssein stands in place of e)/xein. The more natural rendering surely is cumbh=nai (w(/ste) ta\ th=s po/lews (‘the condition of the state’) e)/xein kai\ o(pwsou=n.
e)pesagwga\s tw=n polemi/wn ‘ways of letting in the enemy.’
ou)=n resumptive. The words h)=n de/ ti kai\ toiou=ton . . . e)cergasa/menoi were a parenthetical comment. ta\ lego/mena, sc. by Theramenes above.
e)k th=s presbei/as sc. of c. 90, § 2.
plhgei\s . . . pata/cas the proper aorists act. and pass. of tu/ptw = ferire. Rutherford, New Phryn. clii.; Cobet, Var. Lect. 335 sqq.

peripo/lwn ‘militia,’ serving only in Attica on patrol and garrison duty. In vi. 45 peripo/lia are explained by the
scholiast as ta\ e)n th=| xw/ra| frou/ria. Cf. iv. 67; Aeschin. De F. Leg. 167, e)k pai/dwn a)pallagei\s peri/polos th=s xw/ras tau/ths e)geno/mhn du/' e)/th (i.e. from eighteen to twenty years of age). Plutarch (Alc. 25) calls the assassin Hermon, obviously from a confusion with *(/ermwn tis tw=n peripo/lwn, inf. § 5. Lycurgus (contr. Leocr. 164 ([112]) says Phrynichus was killed by night para\ th\n krh/nhn th\n e)n toi=s oi)su/ois by ‘Apollodorus and Thrasybulus.’ According to Lysias 137 (71) Thrasybulus of Calydon and Apollodorus of Megara killed him as he was taking a walk. There is no need to attempt a harmony of these stories. The account of Thucydides should be the more trustworthy. ‘It may well be,’ says Arnold, ‘that some zealous friends of the democracy laid claim to a merit with which really they had no concern.’

e)n th=| a)gora=| plhqou/sh| The statement of place e)n th=| a)gora=| is combined with the statement of time a)gora=s plhqou/shs (Xen. Mem. i. 1, 10), or peri\ a)gora
 plh/qousan (Anab. ii. 1, 7). Hence the article. ‘in the agora at the time when it is full.’ The time is the latter part of the forenoon, the day being divided into prwi/:, peri\ a)gora
 plh/qousan, meshmbri/a, dei/lh (Kuhner on Xen. Anab. i. 8, 1). Plato, Gorg. 469 D, has ei) e)gw\ e)n a)gora=| plhqou/sh| labw
 e)gxeiri/dion k.t.l.

a)pelqw\n of which P-S seems to miss the point, is necessary to the sense. ou) polu\ a)po\ tou= bouleuthri/ou would be a mere statement of place, ‘not far from the senate-house’; the added a)pelqw\n signifies that Phrynichus had just left that house, and had not got far from it when the blow was struck. He may have been just reporting the result of his embassy.
ou)deno\s gegenhme/nou a)p' au)tou= newte/rou ‘no signal action having been taken in consequence.’ au)tou= is neuter and refers to the event just named. Cf. a)p' au)tou=, c. 99.
kai\ o( *qhrame/nhs k.t.l. ‘Theramenes on his part also . . .’ Action having begun, Th. is moved to something practical.
h)=|san e)pi\ ta\ pra/gmata Cf. § 4, kai\ e)/rgw| h)/dh h(/ptonto tw=n pragma/twn.
o(rmisa/menoi . . . katededramh/kesan i.e. they had established themselves at Epidaurus, ravaged Aegina from that station, and returned to Epidaurus (hence pa/lin o(rmei=n inf.).
*ai)/ginan For its present relations see note on *ai)ginhtw=n, c. 69, § 3.
katakolpi/sai ‘came up the gulf (the Saronic).’ Their natural course to Euboea was E.N.E. across by Sunium.
prosgenome/nwn ‘having resulted (upon the matter).’ Cf. Soph. O. C. 1198, gnw/sei kakou= qumou= teleuth\n w(s kakh\ prosgi)gnetai. The genitive is absolute, not dependent on te/los.
h(/ptonto Theramenes and his party.
oi( ga\r . . . ga\r introduces the narrative (name).
oi)kodomou=ntes For position of the participle see c. 35, § 2; c. 36, § 1, etc.

taciarxw=n A taxiarch is properly the commander of a ta/cis, the infantry supplied by a tribe. Hence the following fulh/n. Cf. Aeschin. De F. Leg. 169, *temeni/dou tou= th=s *pandioni/dos tacia/rxou. On iv. 4 Arnold contends that the term is used more widely of regimental officers. This looser use is borne out by the mention here of the fact that Aristocrates was in charge ‘of his own tribe,’ a remark which intimates that tacia/rxos is here used in its strict sense. The reading fulakh\n would not be impossible in the meaning ‘having his own watch (of the day),’ i e. being in command for a part of the day. But the context is against this.
*)alecikle/a afterwards sentenced to death for his share in the oligarchical treason (Lycurg. Leocr. 134).
tou\s e(tai/rous the aristocratic clubs. Cf. tou= e(tairikou=, c. 48, § 3; ta\s cunwmosi/as, c. 54, § 4.
to\ sti=fos. to\ rlh=qos is the body contemplated numerically, to\ sti=fos the same body contemplated as an array for action. See crit. note.
cugkaqh/menoi. Cf. * cugkaqi=san, c. 67, § 2.

boulome/nois tau=t' h)=n. tau=ta can scarcely bear directly the far-off implication of the scholiast dhladh\ o)ligarxei=sqai. Rather it = ‘this side of the matter,’ i.e. ‘the present conduct of the 400.’

e)s ta\ o(/pla i)e/nai lit. ‘to go to the arms’ (where they were stacked). Cf. c. 69, § 1, e)p' au)toi=s toi=s o(/plois, and inf. § 8, e)pi\ ta\ o(/pla ferome/nous. ta\ o(/pla becomes = the arsenal or magazine, just as ta\ o)/ya, oi( i)xqu=s, etc., = the fishmarket, etc.
cunafairhso/menos sc. to\n *)alecikle/a

e(/na tw=n strathgw=n, o(\s h)=n k.t.l. o(/stis of most MSS. would give a reason for the special selection. Of a definite person o(/stis is common in Herodotus, but the proper distinction must be maintained in Attic prose. As for vi. 3, bwmo
 o(/stis nu=n e)/cw th=s po/lew/s e)stin, see commentators in loc. As in later times o(/stis and o(\s were used indiscriminately, it may be that o(/stis is due to nothing better than a copyist's error. Nevertheless as paralamba/nein strathlgo
 o(/stis o(mognw/mwn e)/stai is Greek, so Thucydides may possibly have written paralabw
 strathgo
 o(/stis o(mognw/mwn h)=n, the statement of purpose in the choice being expressed in an unusual way.
*)ari/starxos see c. 90, § 1.
tw=n i(ppe/wn neani/skoi see c. 69, § 4. The i(pph=s belong to the second highest class in the state and are therefore of aristocratical leanings.

*qoukudi/dou . . . po/lews i.e ‘the proxenus of Athens at Pharsalus,’ not of Pharsalus at Athens, since the proxenus of one state in another must be a citizen of the latter. th=s po/lews, moreover, naturally refers to Athens.

e)fedreuo/ntwn e)/ti. e)ggu\s of most MSS is easier, but not on that account the more probable. In iv. 71 e)ggu\s e)fedreuo/ntwn occurs. e)/it = insuper: ‘with the enemy still to be reckoned with’ by the victor of the two parties.
sfw=n au)tw=n = a)llh/lwn, but with stronger reflexiveness for antithesis to polemi/wn. Cf. c. 86, § 7, pro\s sfa=s au)tou\s . . . cumbh=nai.

o(/son kai\ a)po\ boh=s e(/neka ‘so far as shouting went.’ A conflation of o(/son a)po\ boh=s and boh=s e(/neka, evidently well established: cf. Xen. Hell. ii. 4, 31, prose/ballen o(/son a)po\ boh=s e(/neken. Cf. similar pleonasms in Soph. Phil. 554, a(\ toi=sin *)argei/oisin a)mfi\ sou= 'neka | bouleu/mat' e)sti/, and Plat. Legg. 701 D, ti/nos dh\ xa/rin e(/neka. Haacke compares the German usage ‘von Rechts wegen.’
kai\ is an untranslatable part of the phrase, emphasising its qualificatory nature.
kai\ oi( e)nanti/oi sc. tw=| *qhrame/nei.

tw=| a)lhqei= See crit. note. The common reading tw=| plh/qei leaves e)xale/painon weak, and may be due to the notion that e)nanti/oi would naturally be followed by a dative. P-S, reading tw=| a)lhqei=, take it strangely as the case after e)xale/painon, ‘rei veritatem aegre ferebant.’ This makes a far-fetched sense,
and tw=| a)lhqei= should naturally suggest an antithesis to o(/son a)po\ boh=s e(/neka. tw=| a)lhqei= = re vera does not apparently occur elsewhere, but is natural and quite analogous to tw=| o)/nti. The accus. to\ a)lhqe\s occurs vi. 33, pro/fasin me\n . . . to\ de\ a)lhqe/s. Cf. Isoc. iii. 33, tw=| me/n lo/gw| . . . th=| de\ a)lhqei/a|. If Thucydides is fond of such usages as to\ a)sfale\s = a)sfa/leia, he may well use tw=| a)lhqei= = a)lhqei/a|.
. o(mo/se e)xw/roun, a metaphor from conflict at close quarters. Cf. ii. 62, i)e/nai toi=s e)xqroi=s o(mo/se.
kai\ ei) . . . ei)=nai sc. dokei=.

. e)pekru/ptonto . . . tw=| o)no/mati mh\ . . . o)noma/zein, i.e. w(/ste mh\ o)noma/zein. For the construction cf. ii. 53, a(\ pro/teron a)pekru/pteto mh\ kaq' h(donh\n poei=n. Render literally, ‘for they nevertheless as yet hid (themselves i.e.) their purpose under the name of the 5000, so as not (i.e. not daring) to use flatly the terms “whoever wishes the people to rule,”’ o)noma/zein rather than le/gein because the point lies in the express name dh=mon as opposed to tou\s pentakisxili/ous.
w)=si ‘exist,’ sc. oi( pentakisxi/lioi.

kai\ pro/s tina ei)pw/n tis k.t.l. ‘and for fear that, if a man were to say anything to another, he might in ignorance make a mistake,’ i e. the man to whom he was suggesting a democratical revolution might turn out to be himself one of the 5000.

a)/ntikrus † a)
 dh=mon h(gou/menoi If the reading is sound there is a very peculiar confusion of a)/ntikrus dh=mon h(gou/menoi and a)/ntikrus a)
 ei)=nai dh=mon h(gou/menoi. a)
 may possibly be an error for dh\ (*a*n and *d*h Cobet, Nov. Lect. p. 539), or less easily for au)=, ‘democracy once again.’ For a)/ntikrus with noun cf. ou)de)n h)\ a)/ntikrus doulei/a (i. 122). To simply omit a)
 with Kruger, P-S, etc., is scarcely criticism, and yet a)
 cannot be allowed, in default of something parallel, to stand without ei)=nai or some similar verb.
o(/mws kai\ teqorubhme/noi i.e. kai\ teq., o(/mws. Cf. vii. 75. kai\=‘though at the same time . . .’ The perfect as in pefo/bhmai, teqau/maka, pefro/ntika, etc.
cune/labon in the relative clause = pluperfect, as usual. Cf. cune/meinen, c. 73, § 4.

to\ pro\s th=| *mounixi/a| *dionusiako\n qe/atron Munichia was the citadel of Peiraeus, elevated about 300 feet. Hence
pro\s. The theatre of Dionysus was on the N.W. slope of this hill. An assembly in this place is spoken of in Lys. c. Agorat. 464, 479 (*mounixi/asin e)n tw=| qea/trw|), and the ecclesia ‘in the Peiraeus’ of Dem. De F. Leg. 379 was no doubt held in the same theatre. On meetings away from the Pnyx see c. 67, § 2.

e)ceklhsi/asan So one MS. only, the rest giving e)cekklhsi/asan, obviously misled by the double k in e)kklhsi/a. For the position of the augment in these pseudo-compound verbs (e)gkwmia/zw, e)nekwmi/asa) see Rutherford, New Phryn. Art. xx. The use may have varied at different periods. There is MS. authority in the same author for both imperf. e)kklhsia/zete (Lys. 126) and e)ceklhsi/aze (Lys. 136). We can never feel quite sure that the scribes have preserved a genuine form when they give e.g. e)kklhsi/azon (imperf.) The participle e)cekklhsia/sas (Aristot. Oecon. ii. 13) is due to false analogy with the finite verb.
do/can au)toi=s sc. xwrei=n e)s to\ a)/stu.

e)n tw| *)anaki/w| the temple of the Dioscuri (*)/anakes). Moeris says *)/anakes kai\ *)ana/kion *)attikw=s, *dio/skoroi kai\ *diosko/reion *(ellhnikw=s. Cf. Corp. Inscr. 489, swth/roin a)na/koin te *dioskou/roin. Cic. Nat. D. iii. 21, § 53, *dio/skouroi etiam apud Graecos multis modis nominantur: primi tres qui appellantur Anactes Athenis (where see Mayor's note). The Anacium was at a short distance to the N.W. of the Acropolis.
e)/peiqon ‘tried to persuade.’
e)pieikei=s ‘reasonable.’
parakate/xein lit. ‘keep down along with (themselves).’
diafqei/rein The sense of e)/peiqon is continued over the parenthetical clause le/gontes . . . e(/sesqai.
a)nw=sai The metaphor may be either from ‘launching,’ cf. Hom. Od. xv. 533, a)nw/santes (sc. th\n nau=n) ple/on, or from thrusting back a creature seeking refuge.
to\ pa=n plh=qos ‘the body as a whole.’
e)fobei=to ma/lista peri\ k.t.l. ‘began to find its chief fears centring on the general safety of the state,’ i.e. instead of on internal dissensions. Cf. to\ nautiko/n, to\ cummaxiko/n, etc.
poh=sai not poh/sasqai, but ‘that an assembly should be summoned (or arranged).’ See c. 36, § 2.

*dionusi/w| sc. i(erw=|. The orthography (not -ei/w|) is shown
by the metre in Arist. Frag. 187, ti/s a(\n fra/seie pou= 'sti to\ *dionu/sion.
e)ph=lqen sc. the fixed day. Cf. e)fh=ke, c. 67, § 2.
au)to\ tou=to . . . to\ pa/lai lego/menon k.t.l. ‘began to think that this was exactly what Theramenes had been telling them for some time’ (c. 91, § 2, and c. 92, § 3).
katapeptwke/nai sc. to\ tei=xos. A quasi-passive ( = katabeblh=sqai).

ta/xa me/n ti kai\ . . . ei)ko\s de\ kai\ . . .‘whereas, on the one hand, there may perhaps really have been some agreement . . . yet, on the other, in all probability . . .’ The repeated kai\ makes a concession to both views, while me\n . . . de\ qualify the former view.

a)po\ cugkeime/nou lo/gou. lo/gou though not absolutely necessary to the sense, is natural enough. For the shape of the expression cf. a)po\ paragge/lmatos (c. 99), a)po\ cunqh/matos (iv. 67), a)po\ proeirhme/nou tino/s (iv. 130).
a)ne/xein ‘waited.’ So ii. 18, vii. 48.

oi( d' au)= *)aqhnai=oi. Bekker emends to oi( d' ou)n, resuming the narrative after the parenthesis o( de\ *)aghsandri/das . . . a)ne/xein. But au)= is justified by the contrast between the expectation of Agesandridas and the actual event. He expected to find the Athenians severed by faction; they prove to be of one mind as to the external enemy.

w(s tou= i)di/ou pole/mou mei/zono/s * tou a)po\ tw=n polemi/wn k.t.l. For the readings of MSS. see crit, note. The common reading mei/zonos h)\ a)po\ must be rendered ‘inasmuch as their own war (i.e. the struggle among themselves), a more serious war than was threatened by the enemy (i.e. the Lacedaemonians), was not far off, but actually at the harbour’ But, apart from the peculiarities of the expression, their ‘own war’ was at this moment no more at the harbour than it had been some time before. They go to the harbour because of the enemy's appearance. On the other hand, if h)\ is omitted, the rendering is ‘inasmuch as a war with the (common) enemy, of more serious import than their domestic feud, was not far off, but at the harbour's mouth.’ The reasons why the Athenians flocked down to the Peiraeus are according to these two readings respectively—(1) to prevent treachery at the harbour, (2) to resist the common enemy.
Inasmuch as the presence of tou= in some MSS. must be explained, and since the latter of the above two renderings is much the more probable, I venture to read tou and construe w(s a)po\ tw=n polemi/wn ou)x e)ka\s o)/ntos (pole/mou) tou mei/zonos tou= i)di/ou pole/mou: ‘inasmuch as a more serious war than their domestic war was threatening them close by from the enemy.’ For the one genitive depending on the other cf. i. 136, u(p' e)kei/nou pollw=| a)sqeneste/rou (‘by one mueh weaker than he’).
ta\s parou/sas i.e. already in the water.
kaqei=lkon sc. e)k tw=n newsoi/kwn.
peribalou=sai. Cf, Hdt. vi. 44, e)k de\ *)aka/nqou o(rmeo/menoi to\n *)/aqwn perie/ballon.
*qorikou= . . . *prasiw=n Thoricus and Prasiae are the two seaside towns nearest to Sunium after the cape is rounded. Thoricus, seven miles from Sunium, was a place of some importance.
*)wrwpo/n which was now in the hands of the Boeotians, c. 60, § 1.

a)cugkroth/tois lit. ‘not welded together,’ i.e. not trained to work together. Cf. Dem. 520, sugkrotei=n kai\ dida/skein to\n xoro/n; Xen. Hell. vi. 2, 12, ou) fau=lon h(gou/menos ei)=nai e)pi\ sugkekrothme/nas nau=s ei)kh=| peripleu=sai.

a)pokeklh|me/nhs th=s *)attikh=s ‘now that Attica was shut off from them,’ viz. through the occupation of Deceleia by the enemy. In vii. 27-28 the Athenians th=s xw/ras a)pa/shs e)ste/rhnto, and h( tw=n e)pithdei/wn parakomidh\ is e)k th=s *eu)boi/as. The city itself tw=n pa/ntwn e)paktw=n e)dei=to kai\ a)nti\ tou= po/lis ei)=nai frou/rion kate/sth. This will explain why Euboea was ‘all in all’ to them.
*qumoxa/rh The same general proceeds to the Hellespont in Xen. Hell. i. 1, 1.

e)n *eu)boi/a| ou)/sais. The reading of half a dozen good MSS., e)s *eu)/boian ou)/sais is indefensible. ei)=nai e)s is not equivalent to parei=nai e)s. In Hdt. i. 21, a)po/stolos e)s th
 *mi/lhton h)=n (which has been weakly quoted), the verbal adj. decides the construction (=a)pestalme/nos e)s th
 *m. h)=n), and the same is the case with Hdt. v. 108, prosdo/kimon e)s th
 *ku/pron ei)=nai. The reading e)s *eu)/boian is either a mere slip due to the
illusion that the words belonged to a)fikome/nwn, or else ou)/sais is an error for e.g. (e)lq)ou/sais or (h(k)ou/sais.

qala/sshs me/tron ‘the distance by which it is separated is about sixty stadia of sea.’ The intervening distance is measured over and consists of sea. Cf. ii. 86, die/xeton de\ a)p' a)llh/lwn stadi/ous ma/lista e(pta\ th=s qala/sshs.
e)pwlei=to ‘was on sale.’ See on c. 90, § 5.
plhroume/nwn probably neuter. Cf. e)saggelqe/ntwn, i. 116. ‘The manning of the ships proceeding slowly.’ tw=n new=n could scarcely be supplied.
o(/pws tu/xoien optative by assimilation, regular in dependent clauses. Goodwin, M. and T., § 563.
dia\ toiau/ths dh\ paraskeuh=s ‘after only this amount of preparation.’

u(pe\r tou= lime/nos ‘in front of the harbour.’ u(pe\r implying that they moved out, and, in the Greek idea, up, only so far. Cf. i. 112, pleu/santes u(pe\r *salami=nos . . . e)nauma/xhsan; i. 137, a)posaleu/sas u(pe\r tou= stratope/dou. Putting out to sea is to go upwards, a)na/gesqai, mete/wros gi/gnesqai )( kata/gesqai.

oi( de\ . . . perigi/gnontai k.t.l. ‘others get into the fortification in Eretria which the Athenians held in their own hands, and so escape, as do all the ships which reach Chalcis.’ perigi/gnontai thus has oi( for subject, and is regularly' constructed. Editors generally prefer to read oi(\ de\, understanding katafeu/gousi from the previous sentence.
*xalki/da some fifteen miles farther up the channel.

*eu)/boia/n te a)posth/santes . . . kai\ ta)=lla . . . kaqi/stanto. For the anacoluthon of te with participle answered by kai\ with finite verb (as if a)pe/sthsan had been written) see c. 81, § 1, ai)ei/ te . . . e)xo/menos . . . kai\ te/los e)/peise. Cl. and P-S suppose a lacuna of e.g. e)/sxon after a)posth/santes.

plh\n *)wreou= in the extreme north of the island, formerly called Histiaea (vii. 57). 2000 Athenian cleruchs had been settled in the place by Pericles after the Euboean revolt of B.C. 445 (i. 114). Hence au)toi\ ei)=xon.

h)=lqe i.e. the report of it. Cf. Dem. Ol. iii. 5, w(s ga\r h)gge/lqh *fi/lippos a)sqenw=n h)\ teqnew/s, (h)=lqe ga\r a)mfo/tera),
k.t.l. In i. 61 more correctly h)=lqe . . . h( a)ggeli/a. So iii. 33.

megi/sth tw=n pri\n an idiom almost too common to notice. Cf. a)ciologw/taton tw=n progegenhme/nwn (i. 1). megi/sthn tw=n pro\ au)th=s (i. 10), me/giston dh\ tw=n pri\n ki/ndunon (vi. 13). Tac. Agr. 36 [34]. ceterorum Britannorum fugacissimi.
o(/pou causal. Cf. c. 27, § 2.

a)/dhlon o)\n cf. i. 2. Thucydides prefers the neuter impersonal absolute participle singular in the accusative, and places it here with the genitive absolute of other genders. In vii. 68, nomi/swmen . . . nomimw/taton ei)=nai . . . a(/ma d' e)kgenhso/menon, the participle should be taken as in the absolute construction.

e)c h(=s plei/w h)\ th=s *)attikh=s w)felou=nto the second preposition omitted as in c. 73, § 1, u(p' au)to
 to
 xro/non tou=ton, o(/nper k.t.l. Cf. ii. 44; vii. 47, w)felimw/teron pro\s tou\s e)n th=| xw/ra| sfw=n e)piteixi/zontas to
 po/lemon poei=sqai h)\ *surakosi/ous. For the fact cf. c. 95, § 2.
di' e)gguta/tou ‘with the closest imminence.’

sfw=n with *peiraia = . The order is absolutely against joining sfw=n with pole/mioi, and the sense so gained is of no value. sfw=n to\n *peiraia= = ‘their own Peiraeus’: the matter is coming home to them. The genitive is the same as in the common forms th=s *)attikh=s e)s *oi)no/hn (ii. 18), etc. Lobeck's eu)qu\ is a natural suggestion, but not needed.

kai\ ta\ me/xri *eu)boi/as. Vat. has *boiwti/as by an error of general resemblance, and some editors accept it under a misappre hension. No trouble would have been caused by the text if the inclusive force of me/xri had been remembered, ‘up to and embracing Euboea.’ Cf. c. 43, § 3. Plat. Menex. 239 E, *darei=os pezh=| me
 me/xri *skuqw=n th
 a)rxh
 w(ri/sato. Boeotia had always limited the Athenian empire on that side, so that ta\ me/xri *boiwti/as would mean nothing, whereas ‘everything up to and including Euboea’ means that even the Athenian possessions right up to Attica itself would be lost.

dia/foroi o)/ntes . . . oi( me\n . . . oi( de\ . . . w)fe/loun. The subject of w)fe/loun is neither grammatically nor kata\ su/nesin the Lacedaemonians, but ‘the parties.’ Instead of saying ‘the difference between the methods of the two parties was of much service to the Athenians,’ Thucydides, putting the matter personally, the concrete for the abstract (cf. dh=loi o)/ntes, etc.), says, ‘for being widely different in their methods . . .
they were of the greatest service.’ This is entirely Greek. For its preference of the personal construction cf. vi. 33, ou)/te ga\r bla/ptein h(ma=s plei/w oi(=oi/ te e)/sontai h)\ pa/sxein, ou)/q' o(/ti mega/lw| sto/lw| e)pe/rxontai a)nwfelei=s.
o)cei=s . . . bradei=s Thucydides is fond of comparing the morale of the two peoples. Cf. i. 70, iv. 55, etc.
o(moio/tropoi geno/menoi k.t.l. Arnold refers to vii. 21 and 55.
d' ou)=n ‘however,’ the statement of what might have been and the comparison of methods have been a digression.
o(/mws sc. kai/per e)kpeplhgme/noi (c. 96, § 1).

p.lemma: mi/an me\n . . . )( e)gi/gnonto de\ kai\ a)/llai . . .

div3.p: to/te prw=ton ‘then for the first time,’ i.e. this was the first recognition of the Pnyx as once more the true seat of assembly (cf. *dh=mos *pukni/ths). The last assembly which had formally met had been held at Colonus (c. 67, § 2). One which had been appointed, but not held, was to have met in the theatre of Dionysus (c. 93, § 3). The oligarchs would naturally prefer that the old tradition should be broken through as far as possible.

ou(=per ei)w/qesan sc. e)kklhsia/zein, to be understood from e)kklhsi/an cune/legon. P-S writes oi(=per, understanding culle/gein and requiring exact balance to e)s th\n *pu/kna. In ii. 86, ou(=per . . . prosebebohqh/kei, all MSS agree, and ou(=per may be retained from the sense parh=n bebohqhkw/s.

ei)=nai de\ au)tw=n o(po/soi kai\ o(/pla pare/xontai In English we should reverse the position of kai\: ‘all who supply a hoplite's outfit shall also be members of the 5000.’ The qualification for membership was to consist in supplying, at one's own expense, the outfit of a hoplite. Inasmuch as the number of such persons was not defined, we must suppose ‘the 5000’ to be used loosely as a convenient name for a body politic excluding the lowest classes. The assembly must, however, have calculated that those who could supply an outfit of heavy arms would come to some number not very remote from 5000. Arnold supposes that the acting 5000 would be drawn from such a body ‘by lot, by election, or by rotation.’ This does not appear very practicable, and it strains the words of Thucydides. Commentators seem to compare with the number 5000 the whole number of hoplites e)k katalo/gou, who were at one time
13,000, and they naturally find the discrepaney great. But if Thucydides had meant ‘every hoplite’ he would have said e g. ei)=nai de\ au)tw=n pa/ntas tou\s o(pli/tas. It seems evident that only a portion of the ‘roll’ actually supplied themselves with the outfit.

misqo\n fe/rein the true Attic, not fe/resqai (Cobet, Nov. Lect. p. 568). The reference is to misqo\n bouleutiko/n, e)kklhsiastiko/n, dikastiko/n. See c. 65, § 3. The design is still to secure respectability rather than economy.

mhdemia=| a)rxh=| Jowett's ‘for any office’ would correspond rather to the genitive mhdemia=s a)rxh=s, which P-S writes. The dative is modal or instrumental ‘by serving in any office.’ The comprehensiveness of the term a)rxh\ is seen from Aristot. Pol. iii. 1, 4, tw=n a)rxw=n ai( me/n ei)si dih|rhme/nai kata\ xro/non . . . o( d' a)o/ristos, oi)=on o) dikasth\s kai\ e)kklhsiasth/s.
ei) de\ mh\ by this time a mere compound = ‘otherwise.’ Cf. i. 28, po/lemon de\ ou)k ei)/wn poei=n: ei) de\ mh\ k.t.l., ii. 5, etc.

e)pa/raton e)poh/santo As the middle shows, e)pa/raton is neuter: ‘made it an accursed thing.’ It is usually rendered as if masculine (which would require e)po/hsan). Cf. i. 118, to/te d' ou)ke/ti a)na/sxeton e)poiou=nto; i. 102, deino\n pohsa/menoi.
puknai\ ‘frequent.’
a)f' w(=n Cf. c. 79, § 1, a)po\ cuno/dou.

nomoqe/tas in the recognised sense of the term, a committee of Heliasts for the revision of the laws. The Athenians are returning to the old constitution and reappointing the old officers. Arnold, however (see Grote, pt. ii. c. lxii. note), fancies these nomoqe/tai to be a special board of cuggrafh=s. But the words kai\ ta)=lla and the whole context are against this.
to\n prw=ton xro/non ‘during the first period’ of these new measures. On the extent of its continuance see Jowett's note at this place.

e)pi/ g' e)mou= is to be joined with ou)x h(/kista ( = ma/lista) and this again with eu)= politeu/santes, ‘this, during its first days, was the best government that the Athenians ever secured in my time.’ Thucydides plainly belonged to the ‘middle’ party (iii, 82).
politeu/santes For the tense cf. c. 24, § 4, eu)daimonh/santes a(/ma kai\ e)swfro/nhsan.

h(/ te e)s k.t.l. Vat. has h(/ ge. P-S reads h(/de. If te is
sound, Thucydides begins as if another clause to which metri/a would apply were to follow e)ge/neto. The following clause, however, is not of that nature. Nevertheless the present irregularly placed te followed by kai\ does not appear unlike Thucydides.
a)nh/negke The intransitive use is more common (of recovery from sickness, etc.) See L. and S. a)nafe/rein, II 6, b.
tw=n pragma/twn i.e. tou= pole/mou (P-S).

toco/tas tina\s tou\s barbarwta/tous. The toco/tai in question are the police or city-guard of Athens, slaves, mostly drawn from Scythia (hence ba/rbaroi). See Boeckh, Oecon. i. 276-278. Their full number at this time, according to Aeschines, De F. Leg 335, was about 1200. In Aristoph. Ach. 54, the crier calling for the police says oi( toco/tai!

*oi)no/hn Cf. ii. 18, h( ga\r *oi)no/h ou)=sa e)n meqori/ois th=s *)attikh=s kai\ *boiwti/as e)tetei/xisto, kai\ au)tw=| frouri/w| oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)xrw=nto o(po/te po/lemos katala/boi. The town was on the direct road from Athens to Thebes and Delphi.
e)n meqori/ois th=s *boiwti/as sc. kai\ th=s *)attikh=s. Cf. c. 10, § 3, pro\s ta\ meqo/ria th=s *)epidauri/as.

dia\ cumfora
 . . . diafqora=s ‘a mishap consisting in the destruction, etc.’ Cf. c. 81, § 2, th
 cumfora
 th=s fugh=s; i. 33, h( cuntuxi/a th=s h(mete/ras xrei/as. Some Corinthians returning from Deceleia had been annihilated by a sally from Oenoe.
e)qelonthdo\n i e. independently of the general orders of the war as directed by Agis.
cumbeba/sqai impers. Cf. iii. 67, iv. 23, etc.
kai\ oi( e)n th=| *milh/tw| ‘the P. in Miletus, on their side also,’ as opposed to the new Peloponnesian force which had subjugated Euboea.

oi( . . . *peloponnh/sioi not followed by any verb, but resumed by ou(/tw dh\ o( *mi/ndaros. Cf. iv. 73, oi( ga\r *megarh=s . . . ou(/tw dh\ tw=| *brasi/da| oi( tw=n feugo/ntwn fi/loi k.t.l., with about as much intervening matter as here.

w(s trofh/n te . . . kai\ ai( *f. nh=es . . . o(/ te *fi/lippos . . . *farna/bazo/s te The first te looks forward to kai\ ai( nh=es and these combined form one member of a co-ordination, of which the second and third te supply the two other elements.
In kai\ a)/llos *(ippokra/ths the kai\ does not answer to a te, but joins *(ippokra/ths to *fi/lippos.
tw=n . . to/te . . . prostaxqe/ntwn Cf. c. 87, § 3, where this duty is given to Tamos.
ai( *foi/nissai nh=es ou)de\ o( *tissafe/rnhs h(=kon The single negative as in Aesch. Ag. 532, *pa/ris ga\r ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis; Cho. 294; Pind. P. vi. 48, and elsewhere not rarely.

te/ws usually translated incorrectly as if = pw, ‘not yet,’ but it should be taken with *tissafe/rnhs alone: ‘the Phoenician ships had put in no appearance, nor had Tissaphernes done so in the meantime’ (i.e. pending their arrival).
o( cumpemfqei\s Cf. c. 87, § 6.
kai\ w)\n gives the reason of his ability to speak on the subject. He was a Spartan and was moreover at Phaselis (and so could know).
kai\ au)to\s ‘on his side too,’ i.e. as much as Tissaphernes.
ple/on ti sxh/sein a)p' au)tou==pleonekth/sein e)k tou/tou tou = pra/gmatos (Aemilius Portus). For a)p' au)tou = cf. c. 92, § 2.
a)po\ paragge/lmatos Cf. ii. 90, a)po\ shmei/ou e(no\s e)pistre/yantes. ai)fnidi/ou is explained by o(/pws la/qoi k.t.l.

trisi\ kai\ e(bdomh/konta In c. 79, § 1, the Peloponnesian ships number 112. In c. 80, § 3, ten of them reach the Hellespont. In the sentence following the present we are told that sixteen others had gone on in the same summer. There should thus be eighty-six accounted for. Diodorus (xiii. 38) states that Dorieus had been sent with thirteen ships to Rhodes to suppress a threatened revolution. This would leave the seventy-three mentioned here. (In Xen. Hell. i. 1, 2, Dorieus brings fourteen ships from Rhodes to the Hellespont.) Thucydides, however, says nothing of these thirteen ships. We have had occasion to remark before (c. 79) that we cannot expect Thucydides to give an account of the fate of every ship in either the Peloponnesian or the Athenian fleet. He states that, as a fact, seventy-three ships left Miletus. He does not (as commentators seem to suppose) arrive at this number by a computation, but states it on the word of his authorities for the particular event. There may have been occasional errors of copying in the case of numbers written compendiously, but such errors were surprisingly infrequent. See, however, c. 104, § 2.
th=s *xersonh/sou which had been largely eolonised by Athenians.
*)/ikaron the nearest large island, west of, and near to, Samos.
*qra/sullos v. c. 76, § 2.

au)to\n kaqe/cein au)tou= either intrans. (cf. c. 28, § 2, e)n h)=| *)amo/rghs katei=xe) or trans., of which the passive occurs in ii. 86, e)n w)=| oi( *)aqhnai=oi peri\ *krh/thn katei/xonto. The latter makes the better sense. Thrasyllus knew that Mindarus wished to get to the Hellespont: he might hope to keep him in Chios, but he would not naturally expect him to stay there of his own accord.
e)n th=| *le/sbw| For this place as an a)formh\ against Chios cf. c. 24, § 2, kai\ e)k th=s *le/sbou o(rmw/menoi.
paraskeua/zein e)ke/leuen sc. tou\s *mhqumnai/ous, otherwise paraskeua/zesqai would be used. Cf. iii. 49, paraskeuasa/ntwn tw=n *mutilhnai/wn th=| nhi+\ oi)=non kai\ a)/lfita.
*)/eresos th=s *le/sbou should be joined. th=s *le/sbou a)feisth/kei (‘from the rest of Lesbos’), though not impossible, is not probable: the revolt is from the Athenians.
ou)x oi( a)dunatw/tatoi litotes; ‘some of the most important.’

prosetairistou\s = in societatem adscitos. prosetairi/zomai is found in middle and passive sense. The political notion of e(tairei/a (cf. tou= e(tairikou=, c. 48, § 3; tou\s e(tai/rous, c. 92, § 4) lies under the word here.
cu/mpasin circumstantial, and to be joined with prose/balon.
kata\ to\ cuggene\s See note on cumprasso/ntwn tw=n *boiwtw=n, c. 5, § 2. In iii. 2 the Boeotians are stated to be cuggenei=s of the Mytilenians (as *ai)olh=s, according to the scholiast).
proelqo/ntas i.e. who left Mytilene in time to anticipate them.
au)=qis = deinde: c. 14, § 2, etc.
e)/cw They were first defeated in an attempt at capturing the city, and then in a pitched battle in the open.
dia\ tou= o)/rous Ordymnos rather than Lepetymnos (see Kiepert's Atlas von Hellas).
u(sterh/sas sc. too late to prevent the exiles from securing Eresus.
tine\s du/o. tine\s does not qualify the number, but denotes the casual presence, of these ships, ‘a couple of ships.’

kai\ ai( *mhqumnai=ai ‘(all) the Methymnaean ships’— ‘the fleet of M.’ This rendering does away with the objection of P-S that the ships had not been ‘previously mentioned.’ Dobree, followed by P-S, wrote *mhqumnai=ai pe/nte. to harmonise the numbers, and feeling that e' might easily drop out after -aiai (ai being pronounced like e). One might perhaps rather suppose that e' before *mhqumnai=ai became ai( in Vat., and was lost from the rest. See crit. note. Thrasyllus with fifty-five ships is joined by Thrasybulus with five. To these add the two from the Hellespont, and, of the whole sixty-seven, five must be Methymnaean.

tw=| strateu/mati instrumental, ‘by the forces on board them.’ a)f' w(=n, however, should not be joined closely with tw=| strateu/mati, but taken with the whole clause: ‘(working) from on board these ships, by means of the forces in them, etc.’

duoi=n h(me/rain. MSS. have dusi
 h(me/rais. But dusi
 is a form unknown in Attic until Roman times (Meisterhans, Gr. Att. Ins. p. 124), and is expressly condemned by Phrynichus (Rutherford, New Phryn. Art. clxxxv.) The correction to duoi=n being made, h(me/rain must be written (New Phryn. ibid.) Jowett renders ‘having spent two days in provisioning,’ as if he read du/o h(me/ras. The accusative would be used if the provisioning took the whole time; the genitive implies that it was done ‘at times within’ two days. So P - S renders intra duos dies, comparing v. 14, w)/|onto o)li/gwn e)tw=n kaqairh/sein th
 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn du/namin. Jelf, § 523, 2. The genitive is really partitive. We cannot render ‘provisioning themselves for two days' voyage,’ because of the following th=| tri/th|.
labo/ntes the masc. because o( *mi/ndaros kai\ ai( nh=es is regarded as = oi( *peloponnh/sioi.

tessarakosta\s a coin of unknown value,—a)rxai=a nomi/smata e)pixw/ria is all the scholiast can say. Obviously it was 1/40 of some standard sum, perhaps a stater, in which case 1/40 =
3 obols. Arnold quotes e(/ktas *fwkai+/das from an inscription in Boeckh's ‘Economy.’

ou) pela/giai. ou) was added by Haacke. The meaning plainly is that they did not sail in the straightest course to the Hellespont, which would be W.N.W. through the open sea, but they chose to hug the coast of Asia Minor keeping Lesbos on the left. By proceeding pela/giai they would pass not far from Eresus. a)lla\, moreover, requires a preceding negative. Grote has a long and vehement note (pt. ii. c. lxiii.) in which he tries to show that the text is sound, and that Mindarus sailed from Chios southwards round the island, going up its western side and round the north, in order to avoid the scouts whom he supposes to be watching the channel. The note is, however, based on an illusion. pela/giai cannot mean what he would have it mean, viz. ‘sailing on the sea-side of the island.’ It can only be opposed to coasting. Yet even with Grote's fanciful and tortuous view, the ships would still paraplei=n and not plei=n pela/giai. Moreover, Thucydides distinctly says that their reason for sailing as they did was ‘to avoid falling in with the ships at Eresus.’ The scouts, again, are posted on the mainland opposite Lesbos (c. 100, § 2). If they had been opposite Chios they would at least have seen Mindarus' departure from that city.
th=s *fwkai+/dos gen. part. with what follows.

*karteri/ois Pliny, v. 38 [138], says, Carteria iuxta Smyrnam insula, which is incorrect as to position but may be true as to the insula. The plural points to a group. The nearest point of [the Phocaeid] to Chios by sea is some fortyfive miles distant. The Arginusae islands may be reckoned at some twenty-five miles farther.

u(peraiwrou=ntai. All MSS. but one inferior copy give the meaningless peraiou=ntai; that copy has deipnopoiou=ntes, and from this reading and the coenavere of Valla editors mostly read deipnopoiou=ntai. But, as Classen pertinently asks, ‘wie erklart sich diese sonderbare Erscheinung?’ deipnopoiou=ntai cannot have become peraiou=ntai by any comprehensible error. A glance at the map will show the disproportion between the distances accomplished on the first and second day, and also how small a voyage (25 miles) was effected between the a)/riston of this day and the following night. It is evident that some stay was made at Arginusae, and naturally so, inasmuch as the fleet wished to pass between Mytilene and the mainland when it was dark. The word of which peraiou=ntai is a corruption was presumably a similar but uncommon word. Taking these
considerations together, one may feel justified in inserting in the text u(peraiwrou=ntai, ‘they lie at anchor off.’ Cf. Hdt. vi. 116, oi( de\ ba/rbaroi th=|si nhusi\ u(peraiwrhqe/ntes *falh/rou, tou=to ga\r h(=n e)pi/neion to/te tw=n *)aqhnalwn, u(pe\r tou/tou a)nokwxeu/santes ta\s ne/as a)pe/pleon o)pi/sw e)s th\n *)asi/hn. The Arginusae islands are at the limit of the territory of Cyme, and ‘when the Peloponnesians have coasted along this territory’ they stop till dead of night (parapleu/santes th\n *kumai/an u(peraiwrou=ntai k.t.l.) They do not now put into the mainland (which from this point was dependent on Mytilene), but lie off it at Arginusae.

th=s h)pei/rou has caused some difficulty. P - S brackets it. Others take it that *)arginou=ssai, like *su/bota (i. 47, 50), comprehended a part of the mainland in the immediate vicinity of the islands, so that *)arginou/ssais th=s h)pei/rou = ‘the mainland portion of Arginusae.’ This is possible; but with the reading u(peraiwrou=ntai the genitive is directly governed by that verb, and the whole = ‘they lie at anchor off the mainland’ (and not actually on its shore), e)n tw=| a)ntipe/ras th=s *mutilh/nhs means not ‘on the mainland opposite M.’ but ‘across the water from M.’
e)/ti pollh=s nukto\s i.e. ‘while there was still much of the night left,’ or ‘while the night was still deep,’ ‘long before dawn,’ = multa nocte. Cf. Polyb. v. 8, 3, pollh=s w)/ras.
e)s *(armatou=nta Though not otherwise known, the place was evidently ‘directly opposite Methymna,’ and must have been about fifty miles sailing from Arginusae.
*lekto\n (neut.), the S. W. promontory of Troas and end of the Ida range.

*(amacito\n The atlases (after Strabo, xiii. 1, § 47) place this town south of Larisa. But Xenophon (Hell. iii. 1, 13) has the same order as Thucydides, po/leis prose/laben e)piqalattidi/as *la/risa/n te kai\ *(amacito\n kai\ *kolwna/s, and their authority should perhaps be preferred.
*(roi/teion some seven miles up the Hellespont from Sigeum. As Classen points out, h)/dh belongs to tou= *)ellhspo/ntou.

e)n th=| *shstw=| k.t.l. In c. 62, § 3 Sestos was made the Athenian station to guard the Hellespont. Strombichides had brought back to Samos all the twenty-four ships with
which he had gone to Sestos (c. 79, § 5). The ships named here must therefore be those sent in c. 80, § 4.

oi( fruktwroi\ The article assumes that they naturally existed. For the rest cf. iii. 22, o(/pws a)safh= ta\ shmei=a th=s fruktwri/as toi=s polemi/ois h)=; iii. 80, e)fruktwrh/qhsan au)toi=s e)ch/konta nh=es prosple/ousai.
u(pomei/cantes th=| *xersonh/sw| ‘having got close up under the shore of the Chersonese.’ The word is a(/p. ei)r. in this sense (e)ggi/santes schol.), but cf. prosmei=cai, cummei=cai.
e)p' *)elaiou=ntos some twenty miles down the coast, at the S. point of the Chersonese.

e)kpleu=sai e)s th\n eu)ruxwri/an ta\s tw=n polemi/wn nau=s A combination of the notions e)kpleu=sai e)s th\n eu)ruxwri/an and u(pekfugei=n (ii. 90) ta\s tw=n *p. nau=s. The peculiar construction e)kpleu=sai ta\s nau=s is made the easier by the intervening words, but in any case the accus. is sufficiently paralleled by the more or less rare accus. with e)kbai/nein, e)ci/stamai, e)ce/rxomai, e)kqrw/skw, e)kkli/nw, e)kporeu/omai. Cf. iii. 34, u(pecelqo/ntes tou/tous; ii. 88, mhde/na o)/xlon u(poxwrei=n.
ta\s me\n e)n *)abu/dw| e(kkai/deka. Cf. c. 99 (ad fin.).

proeirhme/nhs fulakh=s k.t.l. The scholiast explains kai/toi proeirhme/nou toi=s e)n th=| *)abu/dw| u(po\ tou= fili/ou e)pi/plou, tou/testin u(po\ tou= sto/lou tou= meta\ *minda/rou, o(/pws parafula/ttwsi tou\s *)aqhnai/ous k.t.l. According to Jowett ‘proeirhme/nhs fulakh=s really explains not why the Athemans escaped the notice of the sixteen ships, but why it is necessary for the writer to tell us so.’ But why should the e)piple/ontes *peloponnh/sioi need to send this message, and how should they know of the whereabouts of these ships better than their friends at Abydos? Moreover the scholiast's kai/toi is not to be gathered from Thucydides. All commentators find the dative construction of the agent very harsh here, and it is unexampled in Thucydides with the verb proeirh=sqai—naturally enough, since the dative would be ambiguous (cf. e.g. cedendum est nobis) with this particular verb. Rather the words mean ‘they escaped the notice of the ships at Abydos, who had given warning to their approaching friends to keep a watch for them in ease of their trying to sail out.’ By this it would be implied that they had shifted the responsibility, and were not troubling so much about the matter themselves. This sense, it is true, is rather awkwardly and incompletely expressed, and P - S therefore supposes a lacuna after e)/laqon to be filled with e.g. a)mele/steron
throu/sas. It does not seem, however, that this brachylogy is more obscure than others in Thucydides, and, in default of MS. discrepancy, it appears best to retain the text with an explanation which satisfies the requirements of the grammar and, apart from a certain characteristic ellipsis of expression, the requirements of the sense. Grote's account of the passage (pt. ii. c. lxiii.) may well be called by P-S ‘contorta,’ and scarcely deserves serious consideration.

tw=| fili/w| e)pi/plw| ‘the friendly armada = toi=s e)piple/ousi fi/lois. Goeller compares ii. 90, mh\ diafu/goien ple/onta to
 e)pi/ploun sfw=n oi( *)aqhnai=oi. * oi( de\ meta\ k.t.l. All MSS. give ta\s de\ . . . poiou/menoi, and all but Vat. and another give pa=sai. See crit. note. With these readings katido/ntes and poiou/menoi would be nominatives pendent, or unpleasantly constructed in apposition with the feminine pa=sai. Such a structure seems impossible. Reiske therefore read pa/sais, and is followed by P - S and others. Next th
 di/wcin poiou/menoi referring to the Athenians would have to be rendered as by Valla e vestigio fugae se mandaverunt. But di/wcin cannot = fugh/n, and di/wcin poiou/menoi can only = diw/kontes. To substitute diw/kontes will be to show the absurdity of this rendering. Cf. e/n th=| diw/cei, c. 103, § 2. The article too is untenable in such a meaning. Dobree's emendation is poioume/nou (with *mivda/rou), Haacke's poioume/nwn, and Classen's poioume/nas (which is easiest in point of construction, but quite unlikely to have been corrupted into the text). By keeping poiou/menoi, reading pa/sas from Vat., and assuming that oi( de\ became ta\s de\ through the antithesis of ta\s me
 and the idea that katido/ntes referred to the Athenians, we obtain the sense ‘but Mindarus and his party, catching sight of them at daybreak and immediately giving chase, fail to get before them all,’ but only succeed in cutting off four. katido/ntes is perhaps rather better used of the enemy who catch sight of what was intended to be unseen, than of the Athenians who are seeking to hide. th
 di/wcin, implying that the pursuit was a matter of course. poiou/menoi in the present tense because the whole = diw/kontes.

*)/imbrou The nearest point of this island is about fifteen miles from Elaius; the town itself was about twenty-three. Lemnos is forty miles distant. These islands were the surest of the Athenian dependencies.

para\ to\n *)elaiou=nta. para\ need not be suspected. There
are four ships at distances apart sailing along by Elaius, and the capturing includes motion in pursuit. Cf. Xen. Hell. i. 2, 9, pro\s tou\s para\ to\ e)/los e)tra/ponto. In vi. 57 all MSS. but one (inferior) give perie/tuxon tw=| *(ippa/rxw| para\ to\ *lewko/rion kalou/menon. If peri/, which the one MS. gives there, is right, it need not therefore be substituted here with Dobree. This use of para\ with acc. is common in Herodotus.
to\ i(ero\n tou= *prwtesila/ou. Cf. Hdt. vii. 33; ix. 116, 120; Paus. i. 34 § 2; Strabo xiii. 1. 31. It was of some splendour.
e(\c kai\ o)gdoh/konta. There were sixteen from Abydos, Mindaius had seventy-three (c. 99), of which two were taken by the Athenians (inf. § 2), and one is not accounted for.

yeusqe/ntes tw=n skopw=n ‘disappointed in their scouts,’ i e. their scouts had failed to inform them. Cf. Plat. Menex. 245 C, tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn e)yeu/sqh. The gen. follows yeu/desqai as it does a)marta/nein, a)pata=sqai, etc. The exact nature of the mistake will depend on the nature of the expectation. Cf. iv. 108, e)yeusme/noi th=s tw=n *)aqhnai/wn duna/mews; Soph. Aj. 807, e)/gnwka fwto\s h)pathme/nh.
du/o. Diodorus (xiii. 39, quoted by Krüger) says trei=s, which would make the account of Peloponnesian ships exactly tally. But that is no argument for altering Thucydides.
to/te viz. c. 102, § 3.

h(me/ra| u(/steron ‘sic Latine anno post non addito uno dici solet. Cf. h(me/ran, iv. 114, 2’ (P-S). Add Dem. De F. Leg. 379, ei) ga\r e)n h(me/ra| po/lin h)/|rei, du/o kai\ ei)/kosi/n ei)sin a)riqmw=|.
e)k th=s *)/imbrou also those from Lemnos (c. 102, § 2). See e(\c kai\ e(bdomh/konta, c. 104, § 2.
e)pi\ ke/rws ‘in column,’ longo agmine, as opposed to e)pi\ fa/laggos (Xen. Hell. vi. 2, 30), quadrato agmine.

a)rca/menoi a)po\ *)ida/kou me/xri *)arrianw=n. Nothing is known of Idacus or Arrhiani, nor are the genders of the words certain. The context (a)rca/menoi, etc.) seems to imply that Arrhiani is farther up the Hellespont than Idacus. me/xri with pare/teinan, not a)rca/menoi.
nh=es by apposition.

e(\c kai\ e(bdomh/konta The seventy-six are made up of the fifty-five ships of Thrasyllus (c. 100, § 1), five of Thrasybulus (ibid § 4), the two which had been returning to Athens (ibid. § 5), and the escaped fourteen out of the eighteen ships of c. 102, § 2.

*darda/nou probably the origin of the name Dardanelles. The town is frequently named (e.g. Hdt. vi. 43). The line therefore extended some seventy stadia, or about eight miles, giving from ten to eleven ships to the mile.

e(\c kai\ o)gdoh/konta This is the total number given above (c. 103, § 1). The MSS. mostly give o)ktw\ kai\ e(ch/konta by a transposition, but two good copies have o)ktw\ kai\ o)gdoh/konta. Inf. § 5 it is said of the Athenians in the middle of the line that they were inferior in numbers, and the remark applies generally.
ai( a)/rista ple/ousai. This left wing is lower down the Hellespont, and the best ships are there to prevent the ontward escape of the Athenians. See inf. § 4.
w(s e(/kastoi dieta/canto = ‘had their several posts of command at intervals.’

u(persxo/ntes. The frame of the sentence is e)peigome/nwn . . . kata\ me\n to\ decio\n . . . a)poklh=|sai . . . kata\ de\ to\ me/son e)cw=sai k.t.l. As if e)bou/lonto had been written instead of the genitive absolute, the nominative u(persxo/ntes appears. Thus e)bou/lonto a)poklh=|sai au)tou\s u(persxo/ntes (= tw=| u(persxei=n) is regular (cf. v. 50). For this boulome/nwn (in the shape e)peigome/nwn . . . u(persxo/ntes is substituted. The passage v. 41 quoted by Arnold is not analogous.
a)ntepech=gon ‘extended their line in that direction to prevent them.’ Cf. c. 105, § 3, pausa/menoi th=s e)pecagwgh=s tou= ke/rws.
peri/egignonto tw=| plw=| i.e. got before them.

*kuno\s sh=ma where tradition placed the tomb of Hecuba. Eur. Hec. 1265, ku/wn genh/sei pu/rs' e)/xousa de/rgmata; 1271, 1273, tu/mbw| d' o)/noma sw=| keklh/setai kuno\s talai/nhs sh=ma, nauti/lois te/kmar. But the name must have had a less romantic origin. There is a Cynossema also in Caria: cf. *kuno\s ou)ra/, *kuno\s kefalai/.
e)pece/bhsan ‘landed to follow up their victory’. (J.)
a)fane/s . . . h)=n sc. what was going on, ‘the state of things.’

th
 a)/kran to\ *kuno\s sh=ma Cf. i. 47, th=| *leuki/mmh tw=| a)krwthri/w|; iv. 46, th
 *nisai/an to
 lime/na; iv. 70, u(po\ tw=| o)/rei th=| *geranei/a|. The name is repeated for clearness' sake.

dia\ to\ krath/santes . . . diw/kontes It seems necessary to admit this anomaly into Thucydidean syntax. dia\ to\ diw/kontes (= diw/kein by a confusion) krath/santes (‘when victorious’) is akin to iv. 63, dia\ to\ h)/dh foberou\s paro/ntas *)aqhnai/ous, and v. 7, ou) boulo/menos au)tou\s dia\ to\ e)n tw=| au)tw=| kaqhme/nous baru/nesqai.
sfw=n = e(autw=n.

gno/ntes de\ . . . ta\s e)pi\ sfi/si nau=s e)pexoi/sas. . h)mu/nanto. This sentence has been variously taken: (1) gno/ntes ta\s e)pi\ sfi/si nau=s e)pexou/sas, ‘discovering that the ships opposed to them were pausing.’ To this, though it gives a good order and construction, it was naturally objected by Arnold that there was nothing to make this left Peloponnesian wing pause in its attack. The Pelop. centre is indeed partly disorganised, but it is victorious, and the left wing has its own battle to fight. (2) gno/ntes is taken alone as = gno/ntes to\ gigno/menon (cf. gnou\s, c. 12, § 1), while ta\s nau=s depends on h)mu/nanto. For e)pexou/sas in the sense of ‘opposition to’ Classen compares Hdt. vi. 49, doke/ontas e)pi\ sfi/si e/pe/xontas tou\s *ai)ginh/tas k.t.l. With e)pi\ sfi/sin, ‘over against them,’ e)pe/xein may stand in the senses of (1) ‘extending,’ cf. i. 48, ii. 77; (2) ‘attending,’ as in e)pe(xein to\n nou=n; (3) ‘bearing down,’ cf. Hdt. ix. 59, e)pei=xe e)pi\ *lakedaimoni/ois. The last is the meaning here. For the position of the attributive participle see c. 35, § 2; c. 36, § 1.
th=s e)pecagwgh=s Cf. c. 104, § 4, a)ntepech=gon.

u(polamba/nontes peplanhme/nas ‘catching them up in their disorganised state.’ The scholiast has deca/menoi (reading u(polabo/ntes), which gives an inferior sense. ‘Intercepted,’ Jowett. u(polamba/nein is used poetically and in Herodotus and Xenophon of sudden evils. Cf. Xen. Hell. iii. 5, 20, dusxwri/a u(pela/mbanen au)tou/s. In i. 68, iv. 28, u(polabei=n is to ‘catch up’ or seize suddenly or stealthily.
peplanhme/nas For the perfect of a state or condition cf. teqorubhme/noi, c. 93, § 1
nau=s me\n o)li/gas . . . th\n me/ntoi ‘though . . yet . . .’.
braxei/as k.t.l. = ‘gave them but a short distance to cover before reaching shelter.’
ta\ kata\ braxu\ sfa/lmata ‘their slight reverses in detail,’ lit. ‘which had happened a little at a time,’ viz. in c. 42, § 4, at Syme; in c. 95, § 7, at Eretria; and in c. 102, § 2, at Elaius.
ou(= to\ *kuno\s sh=ma presumably the same as the *(eka/bhs mnhmei=on, Diod. xiii. 40.
a)ne/lpiston note the position: ‘never having expected to hear of this good fortune.’

p.lemma: e)pi/ te tai=s . . . e)perrw/sqhsan, kai\ e)no/misan . . .

div3.p: dunata\ not impersonal, but in agreement with ta\ pra/gmata. Cf. iii. 86, ei) sfi/si dunata\ ei)/h ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a| pra/gmata u(poxei/ria gene/sqai.

a)po\ spoudh=s. All MSS. give u(po\, upon which no commentator has remarked. Thucydides has kata\ spoudh/n, i. 93, ii. 90; meta\ spoudh=s and dia\ spoudh=s are also natural expressions; but there is no parallel to this use of u(po\. Such expressions as u(p' o)rgh=s, u(f' h(donh=s, u(po\ de/ous are only used where the o)rgh/, h(donh/, de/os is the cause or motive of the action. In c. 35. § 1, all MSS. wrongly give a)po\ for u(po\. If the contrary emendation is made here, we get the well-authenticated a)po\ spoudh=s = spoudh=| or spoudai/was = ‘they worked with a will.’ Cf. a)po\ tou= perifanou=s = perifanw=s (i. 35), a)po\ a)ntipa/lou paraskeuh=s (i. 99). Hom. Il. vii. 359, ei) d' e)teo\n dh\ tou=ton a)po\ spoudh=s a)goreu/eis.
oi( e)n th=| *shstw=| Thucydides has omitted to tell us that they had established themselves there after the battle. It was, however, the natural thing to do.
a)festhkui=an i.e. h(\ a)festhkui=a e)tu/gxane. Diod. xiii. 40, au(/th ga\r pro\ th=s naumaxi/as h)=n a)festhkui=a pro\s *farna/bazon kai\ *kle/arxon.

*(arpa/gion called by Strabo (p. 587) *(arpagei=a, and placed by him e)n th=| meqori/a| th=s *kuzikhnh=s kai\ th=s *priaphnh=s. The name is supposed to refer to the rape of Ganymede. The places are so near together that they are mentioned without regard to order of geographical position.
ta\s . . . o)ktw\ Cf. c. 80, § 4.

a)ne/pracan The compound implies a debt (which is here
an indemnity). Cf. ii. 95, a)napra/ssein u(po/sxesin; Xen. Anab. vii. 6, 40, misqo\n a)napra/ttein.
e)pi\ to\n *)elaiou=nta. Again Thucyd. has omitted to say that the captured ships had been deposited there.
ta\s e)kei=qen nau=s v. c. 95. This fleet was wrecked off Mt. Athos (Diod. xiii. 41). But Hippocrates was saved, as appears from Xen. Hell. i. 1, 23.
tai=s trisi\ kai\ de/ka named in c. 88. See the same place for the order *kau/nou kai\ *fash/lidos.
*peloponnhsi/ois dat. incommodi with the general sense.
*(alikarnasse/as . . . *kw=n. In c. 42, § 4, and c. 41, § 2 respectively these places are found to be on the Athenian side.
a)nazeu/cas ‘shifting his quarters,’ ‘breaking up camp.’ The word occurs several times in Herodotus. Cf. Xen. Anab. iii. 4, 37, e)poreu/onto kai\ au)toi\ a)nazeu/cantes.
*)anta/ndrioi k.t.l. Despite what follows, the Persians managed to keep the town (Xen. Hell. i. 1, 25).
dia\ th=s *)/idhs tou= o)/rous Cf. c. 105, § 2, th\n a)/kran to\ *kuno\s sh=ma. The march would be some forty-five miles, and over a range of about 1000 ft. in height.

*dhli/ous k.t.l. In v. 1 the Athenians *dhli/ous a)ne/sthsan e)k *dh/lou, h(ghsa/menoi . . . ou) kaqarou\s o)/ntas i(erw=sqai . . . kai\ oi) *dh/lioi *)atramu/tion *farna/kou do/ntos au)toi=s e)n th=| *)asi/a| w)/|khsan.
e)/xqran prospohsa/menos a)/dhlon ‘professing to have a quarrel which he did not wish to declare openly’ (J.).

a)/lla e)piba/llontos ‘and inasmuch as he was moreover laying upon them burdens, etc.’ a)/lla is used as in the well-known idiom, Aeschin. 23, prosoflw
 ou) th
 e)pwbeli/an mo/non a)lla\ kai\ a)/llhn u)/brin. Cf. ii. 14, e)sekomi/zonto pai=das kai\ gunai=kas kai\ th
 a)/llhn kataskeuh/n.

ai)sqo/menos . . . to\ e)/rgon. Jowett's ‘perceived that this new injury was the work of the Peloponnesians' would require *peloponnhsi/wn o)\n e)/rgon. Rather ‘learning of this act on the part of the Peloponnesians in addition to . . .’ Though
the Peloponnesians did not initiate this revolt, they had assisted it with their hoplites.
to\ e)n *milh/tw| c. 84, § 4.
*kni/dw| which had joined him in c. 35, § 1.
e)cepeptw/kesan = e)cebe/blhnto. Cf. e)kba/llousi, c. 108, § 5.
diabeblh=sqai see c. 83, § 1.

o(/pws me/myhtai/ te k.t.l. This reading is much to be preferred to me/myhtai/ ti, which is probably an attempt at assisting the genitive. ti is away from the mark. It was not ‘some part,’ but the whole matter, about which he found fault. The causal genitive as in Il. i. 93; Eur. Hipp. 1402, etc.; Jelf, § 490. kai\ ta\s diabola\s . . . † a)pologh/shtai. diabola\s a)pologei=sqai for pro\s diabola\s a)p. is an unparalleled expression. The cognate accusatives di/khn a)pologei=sqai and tau=ta a)pologei=sqai are obviously not analogous, and should not have been adduced here by Classen. Some eight MSS. add a)pw/shtai after diabola\s, and that word may of course have fallen out in the rest, though it is easier to explain its insertion. If it be inserted, however, there is a disagreeable sound as well as an unpleasant tautology in the sentence. Omitting a)pw/shtai, it is open to us to suspect either (1) that pro\s has fallen out before ta\s (unless kai\ pro\s diabola\s ta\s peri\ should be read), or (2) that a)pologh/shtai is an error for some verb of similar shape. Cobet, Var. Lect. p. 368, reads a)polu/setai (the subj. a)polu/shtai is necessary), comparing c. 87, § 1, and v. 75, and adding that in Hdt. viii. 59 one MS. gives a)pologou/menos for a)poluo/menos. With this reading, which makes excellent construction and sense, kai\ peri\ tw=n new=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn=kai\ peri\ tw=n new=n kai\ peri\ tw=n a)/llwn. tw=n a)/llwn refers to the failure of wages and supplies (c. 99, etc.) The only objections to a)polu/shtai are (1) that it was not a word altogether likely to be corrupted in all texts, (2) that it does not account for a)pw/shtai. I am inclined to think that Thucydides wrote the rare a)pela/shtai (from a)pelau/nw), which is on the one hand glossed by a)pw/shtai and on the other replaced by a better known word a)pologh/shtai.

th=| *)arte/midi Commentators are in doubt whether this proceeding signifies piety or policy. The Artemis of Ephesus was a Hellenised ‘Hittite’ divinity, originally, at least, more oriental than Greek. Grote understands that the object was ‘to conciliate the Ionic Greeks.’ As we do not know how
Thucydides would have continued, we cannot tell that this statement was to be left thus baldly.
[o(/tan o( meta\ tou=to k.t.l.], this sentence, omitted by one MS., is not Thucydidean even in expression, and is obviously a tag to end off an incomplete chapter.
The history is continued in the Hellenica of Xenophon.
